('15', 0, 1, 2, 40) 1. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('15', 0, 2, 3, 72) AHMEDABAD, May 21 [1915]
('15', 0, 3, 4, 97) MY DEAR FRIEND, Here am I now hoping to settle down.
('15', 0, 3, 5, 150) The boys are at the Gurukul, Hardwar, I have wired for them and they may be here any day.
('15', 0, 3, 6, 240) Two cottages have been placed at my disposal.
('15', 0, 3, 7, 286) They are isolated from this big city.
('15', 0, 3, 8, 324) There are 3 acres of ground attached to them.
('15', 0, 3, 9, 370) Living there I shall conduct the Institution 1 along our lines and shall search for an agricultural plot.
('15', 0, 3, 10, 476) I pleaded for admission to the Society after Mr. Gokhale’s death as I knew that such was his wish.
('15', 0, 3, 11, 575) 2 Of course, my admission could not mean any alteration of my views.
('15', 0, 3, 12, 644) They are too firmly fixed to be altered.
('15', 0, 3, 13, 685) I find here nothing but confirmation.
('15', 0, 3, 14, 723) I am passing through a curious phase.
('15', 0, 3, 15, 761) I see around me on the surface nothing but hypocrisy, humbug and degradation and yet underneath it I trace a divinity I missed there as elsewhere.
('15', 0, 3, 16, 908) This is my India.
('15', 0, 3, 17, 926) It may be my blind love or ignorance or a picture of my own imagination.
('15', 0, 3, 18, 999) Anyway it gives me peace and happiness.
('15', 0, 3, 19, 1039) It fills me with hope and confidence without which no man could work.
('15', 0, 3, 20, 1109) I wonder if you will stick to your carpentry and restaurant keeping.
('15', 0, 3, 21, 1178) Both are good education.
('15', 0, 3, 22, 1203) Your diary does not even give me an idea of your monthly expenses.
('15', 0, 3, 23, 1270) Does Polak continue to give you satisfaction by way of letters?
('15', 0, 3, 24, 1334) Do you do any reading at all?
('15', 0, 3, 25, 1364) Have the rosary and Imitation of Christ disappeared from your view entirely?
('15', 0, 3, 26, 1441) With love,
('15', 0, 4, 27, 1452) OLD FRIEND
('15', 0, 5, 28, 1463) From the original: Gandhi Kallenbach Correspondence.
('15', 0, 5, 29, 1516) Courtesy: National Archives of India
('15', 0, 6, 30, 1553) 1 The Kochrab Ashram which was established on May 20, 1915 on the outskirts of Ahmedabad 2 Vide An Autobiography, Part V, Ch. VI.
('15', 1, 0, 1, 1683) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('15', 1, 3, 4, 1800) UMIYASHANKER, I have your letter.

('15', 1, 3, 6, 1895) I have no personal relation with Hussain Tyobji so that I could write to him.
('15', 1, 3, 7, 1973) However, Chhabildas should apply immediately, or you may do so on his behalf.
('15', 1, 3, 8, 2051) may mention my name and say that I know him well and will be ready to give a guarantee [on his behalf].
('15', 1, 3, 9, 2155) If he then inquires of me, I shall be able to say something.
('15', 1, 3, 10, 2216) Have you done anything about what you were to send me concerning Chhotu?
('15', 1, 4, 11, 2289) Blessings from
('15', 1, 5, 12, 2304) MOHANDAS

('15', 1, 7, 14, 2393) 3. LETTER TO KUNVARJI V. MEHTA
('15', 1, 8, 15, 2424) AHMEDABAD, May 25, 1915
('15', 1, 9, 16, 2448) BHAISHRI KUNVARJI, I do not see the least possibility of my being able to attend the conference this time.
('15', 1, 9, 17, 2555) I feel there is need for me to stay here at present.
('15', 1, 9, 18, 2608) I find I have been away from the students too long and should not therefore leave at once.
('15', 1, 9, 19, 2699) I must therefore look for another occasion to visit Surat.
('15', 1, 10, 20, 2758) Vandemataram from
('15', 1, 11, 21, 2776) MOHANDAS GANDHI

('15', 2, 1, 2, 2942) 4. LETTER TO G. A. NATESAN
('15', 2, 2, 3, 2969) AHMEDABAD, May 28, 1915
('15', 2, 3, 4, 2993) DEAR MR. NATESAN, I have your letter enclosing cheque for Rs. 3,000 for which please find receipt herewith.
('15', 2, 3, 5, 3101) I notice that the Bangalore ‘talk’ has been much misrepresented and that Mrs. Besant has done me no justice whatsoever.
('15', 2, 3, 6, 3221) I saw the ‘talk’ only the day before yesterday and it is a parody of what I actually said.
('15', 2, 3, 7, 3312) I never sent Mrs. Besant any explanation for publication I now hear that she has published what purports to be an explanation from me.
('15', 2, 3, 8, 3447) Could you please send me the copies if you have seen them.
('15', 2, 4, 9, 3506) Yours sincerely,
('15', 2, 5, 10, 3523) M. K. GANDHI
('15', 2, 6, 11, 3536) From a photostat of the original in Gandhiji’s hand: G.N. 2229
('15', 2, 7, 12, 3599) 5. LETTER TO G. B. VEERASWAMY
('15', 2, 8, 13, 3629) AHMEDABAD, May 30, 1915
('15', 2, 9, 14, 3653) DEAR MR. VEERASWAMI, You may come here at any time you like and you will stay if we mutually agree.
('15', 2, 9, 15, 3753) 1 now nothing is obligatory.
('15', 2, 9, 16, 3782) English books are stocked here in a large quantity and newspapers are also received.
('15', 2, 9, 17, 3867) Those who are in the Institution 2 do write letters and stamps or post cards are provided for them.
('15', 2, 9, 18, 3967) The rest can be discussed personally if you decide to come.
('15', 2, 9, 19, 4027) Servants of India Society may not admit you as you are only a matriculate.
('15', 2, 10, 20, 4102) Yours truly,

('15', 3, 1, 2, 4262) 6. LETTER TO P. G. BALASUNDARA SASTRI
('15', 3, 2, 3, 4300) AHMEDABAD, June 1, 1915
('15', 3, 3, 4, 4324) DEAR SIR, Mr. Natesan 1 has sent me your letters addressed to him and to me.
('15', 3, 3, 5, 4401) I thank you for both.
('15', 3, 3, 6, 4423) Your son 2 has been in correspondence with me.
('15', 3, 3, 7, 4470) His last letter stated that he was driven away by you.
('15', 3, 3, 8, 4525) I therefore wrote to him yesterday saying that in that case he was free to come to me.
('15', 3, 3, 9, 4612) His ultimate aim seems to be to join the Servants of India Society.
('15', 3, 3, 10, 4680) If your boy comes here and is found to be not of mature age so far as I am concerned he will be certainly sent back to you.
('15', 3, 3, 11, 4804) I take no boysunder age without the consent of their parents.
('15', 3, 3, 12, 4866) You may therefore fully depend upon my co operation with you.
('15', 3, 4, 13, 4928) Yours faithfully,
('15', 3, 5, 14, 4946) M. K. GANDHI MR. P. G. BALASUNDARA SASTRI GOVINDAPURAM VILLAGE ADUTURAI POST THANJAVUR DISTRICT, MADRAS PRESIDENCY
('15', 3, 6, 15, 5061) From a photostat C.W. 11016. Courtesy: Balachandran
('15', 3, 7, 16, 5113) 7. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('15', 3, 8, 17, 5145) AHMEDABAD, June 4 [1915] 1
('15', 3, 9, 18, 5172) MY DEAR FRIEND,
('15', 3, 10, 19, 5188) I feel like crying out to you ‘Do come and help me!’ Mrs, Gandhi is again down with her swellings.
('15', 3, 10, 20, 5287) She has lost all power of resistance.
('15', 3, 10, 21, 5325) She weeps like a child, is ever angry with me as if I was the party responsible for her swellings.
('15', 3, 10, 22, 5424) I am over head and ears in work.
('15', 3, 10, 23, 5457) This institution costs me much trouble.
('15', 3, 10, 24, 5497) I wish I had the time to
('15', 3, 11, 25, 5522) 1 G. A. Natesan 2 G. B. Veeraswamy 3 From the contents
('15', 4, 0, 1, 5577) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 5
('15', 4, 1, 2, 5617) describe to you the troubles I am passing through.
('15', 4, 1, 3, 5668) I am not dejected but I feel lonely.
('15', 4, 1, 4, 5705) You know what I mean.
('15', 4, 1, 5, 5727) Heaven knows what will happen.
('15', 4, 1, 6, 5758) There are so many sick people on the Farm.
('15', 4, 1, 7, 5801) I want hours of solitude and have not a minute of it.
('15', 4, 1, 8, 5855) Do ‘buck up’ and prepare for the struggle of the spirit when you are able to come here.
('15', 4, 1, 9, 5943) I know nothing about some honour 1 that has been conferred upon me.
('15', 4, 1, 10, 6011) I have just received a letter of congratulations.
('15', 4, 1, 11, 6061) More in my next.
('15', 4, 1, 12, 6078) With love,
('15', 4, 2, 13, 6089) OLD FRIEND

('15', 4, 4, 16, 6190) 8. LETTER TO MAGANLAL GANDHI
('15', 4, 5, 17, 6219) Vaishakh Vad 7 [June 4, 1915]
('15', 4, 6, 18, 6249) MAGANLAL, I have your letter.
('15', 4, 6, 19, 6279) I see that you are rather upset.
('15', 4, 6, 20, 6312) The fault, I am sure, is mine.
('15', 4, 6, 21, 6343) In attempting to ride too many horses at a time, I am in danger of falling off all of them.
('15', 4, 6, 22, 6435) I have not quite, for my enthusiasm proceeds from an eager desire for service.
('15', 4, 6, 23, 6514) I may not, however, be able to hold on long if I continue to go the way I am doing, forgetting all about service.
('15', 4, 6, 24, 6628) Be patient.
('15', 4, 6, 25, 6640) I intend to send you all, on suitable occasions, to different places, so that you may see things for yourselves.
('15', 4, 6, 26, 6753) Everything will depend on what help we get and how many we can have with us here.
('15', 4, 6, 27, 6835) I am perfectly confident of this, at any rate, that I shall satisfy the aspirations of you all; meanwhile, I do feel that the life you have all led so far has not been in vain, that, on the contrary, you have learnt much.
('15', 4, 6, 28, 7057) I am not unaware that you have not attained to a state of perfect non attachment, for I have not attained it myself and I know that you are yet to reach even my level.
('15', 4, 6, 29, 7225) If we stop making noise about the vows, we shall “not find ourselves in unhappy situations as we occasionally do.
('15', 4, 6, 30, 7339) And now one question.
('15', 4, 6, 31, 7361) Explain to me what you mean by “not having attained to a state of perfect non attachment”.
('15', 4, 6, 32, 7452) I can explain [how that is so with me].
('15', 4, 6, 33, 7492) For example, I observe brahmacharya, but not in all its subtle aspects.
('15', 4, 6, 34, 7564) I cannot say that my
('15', 4, 7, 35, 7585) 1 The Kaisar i Hind Gold Medal; vide the following item.
('15', 5, 0, 1, 7642) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 5, 1, 2, 7682) mind or eyes are never disturbed.
('15', 5, 1, 3, 7716) 2. I maintain truthfulness, but I cannot say that I am never guilty of exaggeration, consciously or unconsciously.
('15', 5, 1, 4, 7831) To say what I like saying and not to say anything which I do like saying casts a shadow on the vow of truthfulness.
('15', 5, 1, 5, 7947) 3. I make untiring efforts to control the palate but I observe that I extract the utmost pleasure from the five articles [I permit myself in a day].
('15', 5, 1, 6, 8096) But I do want to keep these and other vows inviolate and make progress in them day by day, and I am quite confident that 1 shall succeed.
('15', 5, 1, 7, 8234) I feel that I am not likely now to depart from a literal observance.
('15', 5, 2, 8, 8303) From the Gujarati original in Gandhiji’s hand: C.W. 5685. Courtesy: Radhabehn Choudhri
('15', 5, 3, 9, 8390) 9. LETTER TO RANCHHODLAL PATWARI
('15', 5, 4, 10, 8423) AHMEDABAD, Vaishakh Vad 8 [June 5, 1915] 2
('15', 5, 5, 11, 8466) RESPECTED SHRI RANCHHODBHAI,
('15', 5, 6, 12, 8495) Having been very busy with various affairs, I could not write earlier.
('15', 5, 6, 13, 8566) Those at Hardwar were expected to arrive any day and so I could not go to Gondal nor could I stay on [at Rajkot].
('15', 5, 6, 14, 8680) I have taken up residence in two bungalows here.
('15', 5, 6, 15, 8729) Efforts [for acquiring land] will now be taken up.
('15', 5, 6, 16, 8780) Boarding expenses have to be found by me.
('15', 5, 6, 17, 8822) Utensils.
('15', 5, 6, 18, 8832) tools, etc., have been supplied by Ahmedabad.
('15', 5, 6, 19, 8878) Things have not made as much progress as we would have liked, for the various articles take a long time in arriving.
('15', 5, 6, 20, 8995) Could you send from there someone to teach [us] how to operate an indigenous loom?
('15', 5, 6, 21, 9078) Could you secure me such a loom and some sample of handloom cloth woven on it?
('15', 5, 6, 22, 9157) Do you know any teacher, a man of character, who can teach Sanskrit and Gujarati?
('15', 5, 6, 23, 9239) We may pay him.
('15', 5, 6, 24, 9255) We shall be satisfied if we get one for a short period.
('15', 5, 7, 25, 9311) 1 The letter is incomplete.
('15', 5, 7, 26, 9339) 2 From the references to the arrival from Hardwar of Maganlal Gandhi’s party at Ahmedabad and the draft constitution of the Ashram in the letter, it appears to have been written in 1915.

('15', 6, 1, 4, 9683) I am sending three copies.
('15', 6, 1, 5, 9710) If you require more, ask for them.

('15', 6, 1, 7, 9773) Or, would you like to suggest a different one altogether?

('15', 6, 11, 24, 10423) 11. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('15', 6, 12, 25, 10456) AHMEDABAD, June 7, 1915
('15', 6, 13, 26, 10480) MY DEAR FRIEND, I am writing this early in the week as I may not be able at all to write at a later time.
('15', 6, 13, 27, 10586) Mrs. Gandhi is again very bad with her swelling and has almost become a child.
('15', 6, 13, 28, 10665) She has no restraint on herself.
('15', 6, 13, 29, 10698) Then I have to go to Poona and attend to several other things.
('15', 6, 13, 30, 10761) Distraction is very great.
('15', 6, 13, 31, 10788) And I am hardly able to give you long letters.
('15', 6, 14, 32, 10835) 1 Vide “Draft Constitution for the Ashram”, before 20 5 1915 2 This appears to have been written in 1915, for Gandhiji left Ahmedabad for Poona on June 10, 1915, and returned from there on June 16. Vide “Diary for 1915”.
('15', 7, 0, 1, 11056) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 7, 1, 2, 11096) I do not fear your internment.
('15', 7, 1, 3, 11127) You will simply enjoy it.
('15', 7, 1, 4, 11153) You will be able to make the best of it.
('15', 7, 1, 5, 11194) I understand that the Kaisar i Hind Gold Medal has been awarded to me.
('15', 7, 1, 6, 11265) I have no official intimation as yet.
('15', 7, 1, 7, 11303) My difficulties here are of a different type altogether and some of them most trying.
('15', 7, 1, 8, 11389) When I have greater leisure, I shall describe them to you.
('15', 7, 1, 9, 11448) For the time being, if I do not give you long letters, you will know that my whole time is given to organizing the Institution and looking after pat[ients].
('15', 7, 1, 10, 11605) I do wish you w[ould] try to take up the course we had jointly devised.
('15', 7, 1, 11, 11677) 1 Where is Imitation of Christ?
('15', 7, 1, 12, 11709) What about the rosary?
('15', 7, 1, 13, 11732) What about the Song Celestial?
('15', 7, 1, 14, 11763) And why not Gujarati?
('15', 7, 1, 15, 11785) With love,
('15', 7, 2, 16, 11796) Yours, OLD FRIEND

('15', 8, 1, 2, 12675) 13. LETTER TO RANCHHODLAL PATWARI
('15', 8, 2, 3, 12709) AHMEDABAD Vaishakh Vad 12 [June 9, 1915] 1
('15', 8, 3, 4, 12752) RESPECTED SHRI RANCHHODBHAI,
('15', 8, 4, 5, 12781) I have your letter.
('15', 8, 4, 6, 12801) Thanks for your criticism.
('15', 8, 4, 7, 12828) The portion concerning parents is written with the best intentions but I shall make changes in it all the same.
('15', 8, 4, 8, 12940) As for the other points, instead of carrying on a discussion in letters, I hope to have a full talk about them when we meet.
('15', 8, 4, 9, 13065) I will sacrifice this life itself to uphold the sanatana dharma as I understand it.
('15', 8, 5, 10, 13149) I want coarse cloth as well as fine hand woven cloth.
('15', 8, 5, 11, 13203) I shall be glad, therefore, if you send it from there as well as from Palanpur.
('15', 8, 5, 12, 13283) Please send the loom and the man who will teach how to operate it, as soon as they can possibly arrive.
('15', 8, 6, 13, 13387) Respectful greetings from
('15', 8, 7, 14, 13413) MOHANDAS

('15', 9, 5, 6, 14382) 15. LETTER TO RANCHHODLAL PATWARI
('15', 9, 6, 7, 14416) AHMEDABAD, Vaishakh Vad 13 [June 10, 1915] 1
('15', 9, 7, 8, 14461) RESPECTED SHRI RANCHHODBHAI, I wrote to you yesterday in the midst of many preoccupations.
('15', 9, 7, 9, 14552) I think some of your questions I should answer right now.
('15', 9, 7, 10, 14610) I have a little time on hand today and, since I leave for Poona in the evening, I set down a few things this very moment.
('15', 9, 7, 11, 14732) There need be no congratulations on [the award of] the Kaiseri Hind medal.
('15', 9, 7, 12, 14807) 2 One may get it and also lose it.
('15', 9, 7, 13, 14842) I do want a medal, but of a different kind altogether.
('15', 9, 7, 14, 14897) There is no knowing when I shall get it, if ever.
('15', 9, 7, 15, 14947) The English article which is sold as flour is often no flour but a mixture of other things.
('15', 9, 7, 16, 15039) There is fraud in [the sale of] this article.
('15', 9, 7, 17, 15085) The retailer, being a third party, may not perhaps be involved in it.
('15', 9, 7, 18, 15155) Handloom cloth is only an example.
('15', 9, 7, 19, 15190) The vow of swadeshi implies that every article should be swadeshi.
('15', 9, 7, 20, 15257) Kindly permit me to say that the observance of this vow has a subtle moral bearing.
('15', 9, 7, 21, 15341) Arithmetic will certainly include oral sums and Indian accountancy.
('15', 9, 7, 22, 15409) It cannot be that Gujaratis will never look outside Gujarat.
('15', 9, 7, 23, 15470) They will go everywhere in India.
('15', 9, 7, 24, 15504) They are to serve the nation.
('15', 9, 7, 25, 15534) If they do not know the languages of Madras, they can have no contact with the people there.
('15', 9, 7, 26, 15627) As for English, it can be of service only to those who know English.
('15', 9, 7, 27, 15696) Shankar 3 had learnt all the languages of India.
('15', 9, 7, 28, 15745) Vallabh 4, who belonged to the land of the Dravids, had learnt Gujarati.
('15', 9, 8, 29, 15818) 1 This was written on the next day after “Letter to Ranchhodlal Patwari”, 9 6 1915. 2 Gandhiji was awarded this medal on June 26 at Poona.
('15', 9, 8, 30, 15957) 3 8th century philosopher 4 15th century philosopher
('15', 10, 0, 1, 16010) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 11
('15', 10, 1, 2, 16051) There are at present hundreds of Gujaratis in Madras who know Tamil.
('15', 10, 1, 3, 16120) [In] Europe, people in the various countries know four or five European languages.
('15', 10, 1, 4, 16203) It is very easy to acquire such proficiency in languages.
('15', 10, 1, 5, 16261) The time wasted over English will, if saved, be sufficient for the purpose of these other languages.
('15', 10, 1, 6, 16362) Pupils are to receive education which will incline them to do nothing but national service when their studies are over.
('15', 10, 1, 7, 16482) If, on growing up, they leave the Ashram, the education will have failed to that extent.
('15', 10, 1, 8, 16571) Should any occasion of the kind arise, the student will be free [to follow his inclination].
('15', 10, 1, 9, 16664) It is not the aim, however, that the students should return to their parents and get lost in the sea of practical affairs.
('15', 10, 1, 10, 16787) I have had bitter experience that, when provision is made for exceptional circumstances, parents conveniently fall ill.
('15', 10, 1, 11, 16907) While they are still in the stage of brahmacharya, students must not go to attend marriages.
('15', 10, 1, 12, 17000) They are to be surrounded with a new kind of atmosphere and I always feel that, if there is frequent breaking away from this, building of character is impossible.
('15', 10, 1, 13, 17163) As for dress, a single uniform is prescribed for the present, it being necessary to do this for several reasons.
('15', 10, 1, 14, 17276) I think I have given very deep thought to the subject of milk.
('15', 10, 1, 15, 17339) It is a legacy of our non vegetarian past.
('15', 10, 1, 16, 17382) It is objectionable from so many points of view that it ought to be avoided altogether.
('15', 10, 1, 17, 17470) Quite a number of boys have gone through the experiment for several years and I have observed no ill effects on their health.
('15', 10, 1, 18, 17596) More [about this] when we meet.
('15', 10, 1, 19, 17628) I shall try to respect people’s sentiments in every way I can without compromising the aims of the Ashram.
('15', 10, 1, 20, 17735) We have secured four teachers.
('15', 10, 1, 21, 17766) One of them will stay with us.
('15', 10, 1, 22, 17797) Others live in the neighbourhood and come over daily for teaching.
('15', 10, 1, 23, 17864) If a teacher is not a man of character, he will be of no use to us.
('15', 10, 2, 24, 17932) Respectful greetings from
('15', 10, 3, 25, 17958) MOHANDAS For washing clothes, I use for the present an Indian soap which is free from fat.
('15', 10, 3, 26, 18049) I am looking out for a substitute.

('15', 12, 5, 7, 20117) 18. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('15', 12, 6, 8, 20150) AHMEDABAD, June 15 [1915] 1
('15', 12, 7, 9, 20178) MY DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('15', 12, 7, 10, 20214) The omission of your dairy altogether is, I feel, a retrogression.
('15', 12, 7, 11, 20281) It was a good measure of discipline.
('15', 12, 7, 12, 20318) Your diary gave me an insight into yourself for that particular week as nothing else could.
('15', 12, 7, 13, 20410) Do please therefore resume your diary if you can.
('15', 12, 7, 14, 20460) This has been a sad week.
('15', 12, 7, 15, 20486) Bombay has so weighed me down that I am in a most melancholy mood.
('15', 12, 7, 16, 20553) If I had to live in Bombay for one year, I would die.
('15', 12, 7, 17, 20607) I am glad just now you are not with me.
('15', 12, 7, 18, 20647) I go about barefoot.
('15', 12, 7, 19, 20668) There is hardly a road clean enough to make you feel safe about your tread.
('15', 12, 7, 20, 20744) This has not got on my nerves so much hitherto because I have not had the opportunity of walking much.
('15', 12, 7, 21, 20847) And the closets!
('15', 12, 7, 22, 20864) I know you would vomit eternally if you merely looked at them.
('15', 12, 7, 23, 20927) Now what is the duty of a reformer in this position?
('15', 12, 7, 24, 20980) Can the city life be mended?
('15', 12, 7, 25, 21009) If not, can he by working in a city perpetuate the life?
('15', 12, 7, 26, 21066) Suppose he succeeded in getting clean roads and clean closets, not by any means an easy task, what will he have gained?
('15', 12, 7, 27, 21186) How is he to deal with the filth within?
('15', 12, 7, 28, 21227) How will he regulate the morality of the people?
('15', 12, 7, 29, 21276) These are awful questions and I have to answer them, you have to answer them.
('15', 12, 7, 30, 21354) The enclosed is a partial or complete answer.
('15', 12, 7, 31, 21400) Read it carefully and criticize freely and fully.
('15', 12, 7, 32, 21450) 2 I will send you more copies later.
('15', 12, 7, 33, 21487) I have a limited number by me here.
('15', 12, 7, 34, 21523) The life at Ahmedabad is good.
('15', 12, 7, 35, 21554) There you would be perfectly at home.
('15', 12, 7, 36, 21592) The boys are making progress.

('15', 13, 4, 17, 22440) 19. LETTER TO J. B. PETIT 1
('15', 13, 5, 18, 22468) AHMEDABAD, June [16] 2, 1915
('15', 13, 6, 19, 22497) DEAR MR. PETIT,
('15', 13, 7, 20, 22513) I beg to submit herewith an account of the income and expenditure as up to the 31st January 1915 in connection with the passive resistance movement in South Africa.
('15', 13, 7, 21, 22678) Publication of the account has been delayed beyond my desire and expectation.
('15', 13, 7, 22, 22756) It was Mr. Gokhale’s intention that the accounts should be published along with a statement about the disposal of the balance in hand.
('15', 13, 7, 23, 22891) As he was the prime mover in India and remained in closest touch with the movement to the end, I never did anything without consultation with him, and through him with your Committee.
('15', 13, 7, 24, 23075) It was his intention that before the accounts were finally published, I should confer with your Committee.
('15', 13, 7, 25, 23182) The cruel hand of Death having removed him from us, the matter of publication has been further delayed, and it is only now that it has become possible to submit the accounts to the public.
('15', 13, 8, 26, 23371) 1 This was sent to the addressee, Jehangir Bomanji Petit, who was Secretary of the South African Indian Fund, as a draft.
('15', 13, 8, 27, 23493) It was eventually printed and made public on October 31, 1915, with additions and alterations indicated in footnotes.
('15', 13, 8, 28, 23611) 2 Vide “Diary for 1915”.
('15', 14, 0, 1, 23636) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 15
('15', 14, 1, 2, 23677) The income includes not only the monies received through you but includes also those received from Madras, Rangoon, London and various parts of Africa, Passive Resistance School, etc.
('15', 14, 1, 3, 23861) Thus, of the £27,324.0.7, £8,424.0.7 were monies other than those received through you.
('15', 14, 1, 4, 23949) As to expenditure, there are some items which require explanation.
('15', 14, 1, 5, 24016) Relief which takes up nearly £3,000/ means assistance given to Passive Resisters or their families, and it is a recurring item.
('15', 14, 1, 6, 24144) There are widows of Passive Resisters who died during the struggle without leaving anything for those left behind them.
('15', 14, 1, 7, 24264) There are children of Passive Resisters and Passive Resisters themselves who require support.
('15', 14, 1, 8, 24358) 1 Farm upkeep and improvements mean expenses in connection with the Phoenix Settlement which became the Passive Resistance Farm after the transference to Phoenix of Passive Resisters from Tolstoy Farm belonging to Mr. Kallenbach.
('15', 14, 1, 9, 24588) Phoenix Settlement consists of 100 acres of land originally bought by me for locating the printing works of Indian Opinion.
('15', 14, 1, 10, 24712) Though the legal title vested in me for some years, I never made personal use of the property.
('15', 14, 1, 11, 24807) During the struggle, however, I divested myself of the legal title and it is now held by Trustees for public purposes defined in a registered Trust deed.
('15', 14, 2, 12, 24961) This property is still being used for housing Passive Resisters or their families.
('15', 14, 2, 13, 25044) Settlers who are living on the land receive no wages but take out of the income from Indian Opinion, and other sources just enough for their maintenance.
('15', 14, 2, 14, 25198) The journal has never been and can never become an entirely self supporting proposition.
('15', 14, 2, 15, 25287) The English portion of it is mainly of an educative character for the European public amongst whom it is distributed gratis.
('15', 14, 2, 16, 25412) It was a powerful weapon in the armoury of Passive Resistance and continues to be the only recorder of accurately sifted facts about our countrymen in South Africa and of Passive Resistance movement.
('15', 14, 2, 17, 25612) It is in no sense a commercial enterprise.
('15', 14, 2, 18, 25655) This settlement will still need assistance.
('15', 14, 3, 19, 25699) The third item is Valiama Hall.
('15', 14, 3, 20, 25731) This is an institution founded in the memory of the late Valiama, a girl of 17 who died shortly after her discharge from prison of fever contracted therein.
('15', 14, 3, 21, 25888) Its use will be

('15', 16, 1, 2, 29004) the now famous Asiatic Registration Bill in the year 1906, but as year after year the struggle rolled on with temporary settlements, it included many other things besides the Asiatic Registration Act, and covered the whole of South Africa till at the time of the settlement the points in Passive Resistance were as follows: 1
('15', 16, 2, 3, 29330) (1) Repeal of the Asiatic Act.
('15', 16, 2, 4, 29361) (2) Removal of the racial or colour disqualification as to immigration from the Union legislation.
('15', 16, 2, 5, 29460) (3) Removal of the legal disabilities of Indian wives.
('15', 16, 2, 6, 29515) (4) Removal of the annual Poll Tax of £3, which was payable by ex indentured Indians, their wives and grown up children.
('15', 16, 2, 7, 29636) (5) Just administration of existing laws with due regard to vested rights.
('15', 16, 2, 8, 29711) All these points are covered by the settlement of the last year which are considered 2 to be a complete vindication of Passive Resistance and I venture to state that if more has not been gained, more was not and could not be asked 3 for as an item in Passive Resistance, for a Passive Resister has to frame his minimum as well as his maximum and he dare not ask for more nor can he be satisfied with less.
('15', 16, 2, 9, 30117) But I do not wish to be understood to mean that nothing further remains to be done in South Africa, or that everything has been gained.
('15', 16, 2, 10, 30253) We have only fought for removal of legal disabilities as to immigration, but administratively it tells more heavily upon us than other nations.
('15', 16, 2, 11, 30397) In accepting administrative inequality, we have given due regard to existing conditions and prejudices.
('15', 16, 2, 12, 30501) 4 We fought to keep the theory of the British Constitution intact so that practice may some day approach the theory as near as possible.
('15', 16, 2, 13, 30638) There are still certain laws in South Africa, for instance, the Law 3 of 1885, Trade Licence Laws of the Cape and Natal which continue to cause worry.

('15', 17, 0, 1, 31365) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 17, 1, 2, 31406) Administration of the Immigration Law is not all it should be.
('15', 17, 1, 3, 31469) For these, however, Passive Resistance [is not] applied and is at present inapplicable, its application being confined to grievances which are generally felt in a community and are known to hurt its self respect or conscience.
('15', 17, 1, 4, 31696) Any of our 1 grievances referred to by me may any day advance to that stage.
('15', 17, 1, 5, 31773) Till then only the ordinary remedies of petition, etc., can be and are at present being applied 2. Letters received from South Africa show that difficulties are being experienced in some cases acutely by our countrymen and if not much has been heard of them in India just now, it is because of the extraordinary self restraint of our countrymen in South Africa during the crisis that has overtaken the Empire.
('15', 17, 1, 6, 32183) This struggle has defined principles and removed disabilities which were in the shape of a national insult.
('15', 17, 1, 7, 32291) The larger question of the treatment of British Indians who came there 3 from outside can only be dealt with here 4 and for the question of the local disabilities still unredressed, your Committee will have to exercise a ceaseless watch and assist as heretofore the efforts of our countrymen in South Africa.
('15', 17, 1, 8, 32600) I feel that I ought to place on record my strong conviction, based upon close personal observation extending over a period of twenty years, that the system of indentured emigration is an evil which cannot be mended but can only be ended.
('15', 17, 1, 9, 32838) No matter how humane the employers may be, it does not lend itself to the moral well being of the men affected by it.
('15', 17, 1, 10, 32956) I therefore feel that your Committee should lose no time in approaching the Government of India with a view to securing entire abolition of the system for every part of the Empire.
('15', 17, 1, 11, 33137) Before closing, I am bound to mention that the struggle would not have ended so soon and even as satisfactorily as it did, but for the generous support rendered by the Motherland under the leadership of the great and saintly patriot whose death we all mourn and but for the very sympathetic and firm attitude taken by the noble man who at present occupies the Viceregal chair.

('15', 20, 5, 8, 36353) 21. LETTER TO KHUSHALCHAND GANDHI
('15', 20, 6, 9, 36387) AHMEDABAD,
('15', 20, 7, 10, 36398) Jeth Sud 11 [June 23, 1915] 1
('15', 20, 8, 11, 36428) BHAISHRI KHUSHALJIVAN GANDHI, For some time, 1 have been thinking about Chi.
('15', 20, 8, 12, 36505) Narandas.
('15', 20, 8, 13, 36515) That ultimately he is to live with me is his own desire as also yours and mine.
('15', 20, 8, 14, 36595) My only purpose in employing Narandas in a job is that thereby he should earn something and contribute to your expenses.
('15', 20, 8, 15, 36716) I feel that you should fix the figure of your needs, and that I should meet them and that you should then free Narandas.
('15', 20, 8, 16, 36837) The Ashram needs one or two persons.
('15', 20, 8, 17, 36874) If Narandas comes, the need will be met.
('15', 20, 8, 18, 36915) I am looking for someone whom I can engage as a paid assistant.
('15', 20, 8, 19, 36979) Why should I then not give the opportunity to Narandas?
('15', 20, 8, 20, 37035) Maganlal and Manilal are kept fully occupied with the teaching of Sanskrit and they are quite engrossed in it.
('15', 20, 8, 21, 37146) This being so, we are short of teachers.
('15', 20, 8, 22, 37187) On myself also, I have placed an excessive burden, with the result that I have to leave undone some other things which require my attention.
('15', 20, 8, 23, 37328) Hence, if Narandas joins me, I will be saved from many difficulties.

('15', 22, 5, 9, 40001) 23. LETTER TO GENERAL TRAFFIC MANAGER, G. I. P. RAILWAY
('15', 22, 6, 10, 40057) [AHMEDABAD, June 28, 1915] 1
('15', 22, 7, 11, 40086) THE GENERAL TRAFFIC MANAGER G. I. P. RAILWAY BOMBAY
('15', 22, 8, 12, 40138) SIR, I travelled on the 27th instant from Poona to Bombay on 3rd class return ticket, taking the 16.45 train last Saturday from Kirkee.
('15', 22, 8, 13, 40274) As my ticket was only as far as Dadar and as I wished to go as far as Victoria Terminus, I informed an official that I was travelling beyond my destination.
('15', 22, 8, 14, 40431) I attempted to give the information at Dadar but succeeded in giving it only at Parel.
('15', 22, 8, 15, 40518) The official, who I subsequently learnt was a brakesman, told me to inform the bada 2 Guard.
('15', 22, 8, 16, 40611) I could not do so as he was in a far off compartment.
('15', 22, 8, 17, 40665) At Masjid the authorities collected from me the fare from Dadar and the usual penalty, notwithstanding my protest.
('15', 22, 8, 18, 40780) They ascertained too from the brakesman that I had duly informed him.
('15', 22, 8, 19, 40850) The authorities at Masjid said that in order to enable them to exempt me from the penalty, I should produce a certificate from the Guard or the Station Master.
('15', 22, 8, 20, 41010) You will see that I could not procure the certificate without the risk of missing the train.
('15', 22, 8, 21, 41103) I asked for the certificate from the only official whom I could safely approach.
('15', 22, 8, 22, 41184) And he would not grant one.
('15', 22, 8, 23, 41212) I bring this incident to your notice as I have often observed that 3rd class
('15', 22, 9, 24, 41289) 1 From the addressee’s reply 2 Superior
('15', 23, 0, 1, 41329) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 23, 1, 2, 41370) passengers are often punished without any fault of their own.
('15', 23, 1, 3, 41432) I shall be obliged if you will kindly inquire into this matter.
('15', 23, 1, 4, 41496) In my opinion, either Station Masters should be instructed not to charge penalties when information has been given about over travelling to any railway official of the company or strict instructions should be given as to promp issue of certificates by the officials concerned.
('15', 23, 1, 5, 41773) If it was not competent for the brakesman to issue the certificate, was it not his duty to immediately inform the Guard that a passenger wasover travelling and that he had applied for the usual certificate?
('15', 23, 1, 6, 41980) I enclose herewith the receipt for this fare and the penalty.

('15', 25, 6, 6, 45142) AHMEDABAD, July 9 [1915] 1
('15', 25, 7, 7, 45169) MY DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('15', 25, 7, 8, 45205) I must say I feel nothing about your being interned.
('15', 25, 7, 9, 45258) It was to come.
('15', 25, 7, 10, 45274) You have a rare opportunity for disciplining yourself and of affecting your neighbours.
('15', 25, 7, 11, 45362) You will have plenty of time to think.
('15', 25, 7, 12, 45401) This prolongation may mean more prolonged sepa ration between us.
('15', 25, 7, 13, 45467) But we shall learn to live together more intimately even though we may be separated bodily.
('15', 25, 7, 14, 45559) In thousand and one things I miss you.
('15', 25, 7, 15, 45598) In some experiences I feel glad you are not with me.
('15', 25, 7, 16, 45651) In fullness of time, when we meet, we shall [have] grown, let us hope, better and better able to reach our common goal.
('15', 25, 7, 17, 45771) The life here has become most regular and nobody has leisure for idle talk.
('15', 25, 7, 18, 45847) Boys who wanted to have their ambition fulfilled, I do not encroach upon their time for study.
('15', 25, 7, 19, 45942) They appreciate this very much.
('15', 25, 7, 20, 45974) My diet just now consists of soaked figs, monkey nuts and lemons.
('15', 25, 7, 21, 46040) This is a somewhat trying place for cheap fruit.
('15', 25, 7, 22, 46089) Those who were saltless remain so here also and some now and then become fruitarians for a week or so.
('15', 25, 7, 23, 46192) All are learning Hindi, Sanskrit, Tamil, Gujarati and Arithmetic.
('15', 25, 7, 24, 46258) They have 4 hours of study, apart from their morning study.
('15', 25, 7, 25, 46318) How about your cabinet making?
('15', 25, 7, 26, 46349) This ought not to be interrupted.
('15', 25, 7, 27, 46383) But I shall know more from week to week.
('15', 25, 8, 28, 46424) Yours, OLD FRIEND

('15', 26, 1, 2, 46593) 27. SPEECH AT BOMBAY PROVINCIAL CONFERENCE, POONA 1
('15', 26, 2, 3, 46645) July 11, 1915
('15', 26, 3, 4, 46659) MR. PRESIDENT, BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Perhaps, it is impudent on my part to add anything to the feeling words that have been spoken by Mrs. Ranade.
('15', 26, 3, 5, 46806) The fact that she is the widow of the master’s master adds solemnity to the proceedings, which I can only mar by any remarks I may make.
('15', 26, 3, 6, 46943) But, claiming as I do to be one of Mr. Gokhale’s disciples, you will forgive me if I say a few words which are personal titbits.
('15', 26, 3, 7, 47072) It was on board the Cronprinz some years ago, 2 that I found myself in the master’s company together with a common friend, Mr. Kallenbach 3, a German.
('15', 26, 3, 8, 47223) Let me say that all Germans are not fiends, nor; are all German soldiers Friend.
('15', 26, 3, 9, 47304) 4 Mr. Kallenbach is a German and a soldier, but I feel that no purer minded person to day walks the earth in Europe than Mr. Kallenbach.
('15', 26, 3, 10, 47441) He was accepted as a worthy companion by Mr. Gokhale, who used to play with him the game of quoits.
('15', 26, 3, 11, 47541) Mr. Gokhale had just then, during the voyage from England to Cape Town, picked up that g ame, and he very nearly gave Mr. Kallenbach a beating in the game.
('15', 26, 3, 12, 47697) I fancy that was a drawn game between them, and, let me add, Mr. Kallenbach, so far as I am aware, is one of the cleverest players of quoits in South Africa.
('15', 26, 3, 13, 47855) Just after that we had our meals at which Mr. Gokhale was talking to me with reference to the result of the game.
('15', 26, 3, 14, 47969) He thought I never indulged in such sports and that I was against them.
('15', 26, 3, 15, 48041) He expostulated with me in kind words and said, “Do you know why I want to enter into such competition with Europeans?
('15', 26, 3, 16, 48160) I certainly want to do at least as much as
('15', 26, 4, 17, 48203) 1 While seconding the following resolution moved by Mrs. Ramabai Ranade: “The Conference places on record its sense of, profound grief at the irreparable loss the country and the Empire have sustained in the untimely and the universally mourned death of the late Mr. Gopal Krishna Gokhale, than whom no more self sacrificing and devoted patriot and no more far sighted statesman ever consecrated his life in the cause of his country.” 2 In 1912 3 Gandhiji’s co worker in South Africa, who had placed at the disposal of the satyagrahis the Tolstoy Farm; Vide “Letter to H. Kallenbach”, 30 5 1910. 4 During the First World War, Britain and, with her, India considered Germany as an enemy country
('15', 27, 0, 1, 48897) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 27, 1, 2, 48938) they can do for the sake of our country.
('15', 27, 1, 3, 48979) It is said, rightly or wrongly, that we are an inferior people in many matters, and so far as I can do it”—and this he said in all humility—“I certainly want to show that we are at least their equals, if not their superiors.” That was one incident.
('15', 27, 1, 4, 49228) On board the same steamer, we were engaged in a hot discussion in connection with.
('15', 27, 1, 5, 49311) our dear motherland, and he was mapping out for me, as a father would for his child, a programme that I was to follow in India if I ever happened to see the motherland again, and, in connection therewith, there was one thing he said: “We lack in India character; we want religious zeal in the political field.” Shall we then follow the spirit of the master with the same thoroughness and the same religious zeal, so that we can safely teach a child politics?
('15', 27, 1, 6, 49770) One of his missions in life, I think, was to inculcate the lesson that whatever we do, we should do with thoroughness.
('15', 27, 1, 7, 49889) This it is not possible for us mortals to imitate in any degree of perfection.
('15', 27, 1, 8, 49968) Whatever he did, he did with a religious zeal; that was the secret of his success.
('15', 27, 1, 9, 50051) He did not wear his religion on his sleeve; he lived it.
('15', 27, 1, 10, 50108) Whatever he touched, he purified; wherever he went, he recreated an atmosphere around him which was fragrant.
('15', 27, 1, 11, 50218) When he came to South Africa, he electrified the people there not only by his magnificent eloquence but by the sincerity of his character and by the religious devotion with which he worked.
('15', 27, 1, 12, 50408) What was that devotion?
('15', 27, 1, 13, 50432) Ailing though he was, he was awake the whole night practically when he was to have seen General Smuts; he did so in order to prepare the case for his countrymen with a thoroughness that surprised the leader of the Boer Government.
('15', 27, 1, 14, 50663) What was the result?
('15', 27, 1, 15, 50684) The result was that he got the promise from the South African Government that the £3 tax would be gone in a few years, and the £3 tax is no more.
('15', 27, 1, 16, 50830) It is no more there to grind down so many thousands of our countrymen.
('15', 27, 1, 17, 50901) Mr. Gokhale is dead, but it is possible for you and for me to make his spirit live in us and through us.
('15', 27, 1, 18, 51006) (“Hear, hear.”) We are about to pass resolutions which would expect us, the chosen representatives, or, it may be, the self elected representatives of the people to do certain things.
('15', 27, 1, 19, 51190) Shall we discharge our trust with the master’s devotion?
('15', 27, 1, 20, 51247) The people we represent will base their verdict not upon our speeches but upon our actions, and how shall we act?
('15', 27, 1, 21, 51361) We have a right to pass this resolution if we act in the spirit of the master.
('15', 27, 1, 22, 51440) With these words, I have much pleasure in seconding this resolution.

('15', 29, 7, 9, 53498) 31. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('15', 29, 8, 10, 53531) AHMEDABAD, July 16 [1915]
('15', 29, 9, 11, 53557) MY DEAR FRIEND, There is no letter from you for this week.
('15', 29, 9, 12, 53616) There is a pencil letter from you complaining of want of news from me.
('15', 29, 9, 13, 53687) Events have moved with me so swiftly that I did not know what to say and what to omit.
('15', 29, 9, 14, 53774) Names of men and places I omitted as I could not give you the history of men and geography of places I visited.
('15', 29, 9, 15, 53886) Bolpur I left as it never was the intention to settle down there.
('15', 29, 9, 16, 53952) The boys’ services were required in the nursing department at a fair in a holy place and they left.
('15', 29, 9, 17, 54052) They then went to Gurukul whilst I was touring through Madras.
('15', 29, 9, 18, 54115) After finishing Madras I took up quarters at Ahmedabad and sent for the company.
('15', 29, 9, 19, 54196) At Madras the two friends who interested themselves in the scheme are lawyers of note.
('15', 29, 9, 20, 54283) But so many have interested themselves in it.
('15', 29, 9, 21, 54329) Few are willing to adopt it themselves.
('15', 29, 10, 22, 54369) 1 From C. F. Andrews’ reference to his illness in the letter to which this is a reply, this correspondence seems to have taken place in 1915. 2 Written to Gandhiji on July 11 from Simla where Andrews was convalescing.
('15', 29, 10, 23, 54587) The Ietter is not reproduced here.
('15', 29, 10, 24, 54622) 3 The Servants of India Society 4 Of recruitment of indentured labour in India

('15', 30, 1, 2, 54742) However I feel that it is the right thing.
('15', 30, 1, 3, 54785) There is something noble in a 7 year old lad thinking he is working for his meal and he is studying for his country.
('15', 30, 1, 4, 54902) There is something great if a boy of seven does not look forward to leaving the place when he is learning and altering his life.
('15', 30, 1, 5, 55031) After a number of years whether many will do this or not is not the question.
('15', 30, 1, 6, 55109) What is of importance is that some are making a serious attempt to live such a life.
('15', 30, 1, 7, 55194) There was a verse we read at the morning prayer today.
('15', 30, 1, 8, 55249) ‘Pain and pleasure, happiness and misery are without doubt results of some previous causes set in motion by ourselves.’ This thought gives us the faculty for bearing pains without fear or anxiety.
('15', 30, 1, 9, 55446) If we add to this the thought that what passes as a misery may not be misery at all but divine discipline.

('15', 40, 8, 26, 71677) Boys are also put on to that work.

('15', 40, 8, 28, 71757) With love from us all,
('15', 40, 9, 29, 71780) Yours sincerely, OLD FRIEND

('15', 45, 4, 9, 78428) 55. LETTER TO V. S. SRINIVASA SASTRI
('15', 45, 5, 10, 78465) AHMEDABAD, September 23 [1915] 1
('15', 45, 6, 11, 78498) DEAR MR. SHASTRIAR, When I took in Naiker, Mrs. Gandhi did not ‘kick’.
('15', 45, 6, 12, 78569) Now I had to decide whether I was to take in a grown up Gujarati Dhed 2 with his wife.
('15', 45, 6, 13, 78656) 3 I decided to take him and she rebelled against it and so did another lady at the Ashram.
('15', 45, 6, 14, 78747) There was quite a flutter in the Ashram.
('15', 45, 6, 15, 78788) There is a flutter even in Ahmedabad.
('15', 45, 6, 16, 78826) I have told Mrs. Gandhi she could leave me and we should part good friends.
('15', 45, 6, 17, 78902) The step is momentous because it so links me with the suppressed classes mission that I might have at no distant time to carry out the idea of shifting to some Dhed quarters and sharing their life with the Dheds.
('15', 45, 6, 18, 79115) It would mean much even for my staunchest co workers.
('15', 45, 6, 19, 79169) I have now given you the outline of the story.
('15', 45, 6, 20, 79216) There is nothing grand about it.
('15', 45, 6, 21, 79249) It is of importance to me because it enables me to demonstrate the efficacy of passive resistance in social questions and when I take the final step, it will embrace swaraj, etc.
('15', 45, 6, 22, 79428) Please share this with Dr. Deva and any other member you please.
('15', 45, 7, 23, 79493) Yours sincerely,
('15', 45, 8, 24, 79510) M. K. GANDHI

('15', 46, 2, 3, 80047) FROM M. K. GANDHI
('15', 46, 3, 4, 80065) AHMEDABAD, September 24, 1915
('15', 46, 4, 5, 80095) MY DEAR FRIEND, I have been regularly receiving your letters.
('15', 46, 4, 6, 80157) I do not care to ask others to write to you as we are full up to the brim with work.I had seven patients last week, all more or less in a bad state.
('15', 46, 4, 7, 80306) It was no ordinary illness.
('15', 46, 4, 8, 80334) I am thankful to say they are all convalescent now.
('15', 46, 4, 9, 80386) These included Ramdas and Devdas.
('15', 46, 4, 10, 80420) They were all treated after our fashion partial or total starvation and hip baths.
('15', 46, 4, 11, 80503) You know what a Pariah is.
('15', 46, 4, 12, 80530) He is what is called an untouchable.
('15', 46, 4, 13, 80567) The widow’s son whom I have taken is a Pariah but that did not shock Mrs. Gandhi so much.
('15', 46, 4, 14, 80657) Now I have taken one from our own parts and Mrs.Gandhi as also Maganlal’s wife were up in arms against me.
('15', 46, 4, 15, 80764) They made my life miserable so far as they could.
('15', 46, 4, 16, 80814) I told them they were not bound to stay with me.
('15', 46, 4, 17, 80863) This irritated them the more.
('15', 46, 4, 18, 80893) The storm has not yet subsided.
('15', 46, 4, 19, 80925) I am however unmoved and comparatively calm.
('15', 46, 4, 20, 80970) The step I have taken means a great deal.
('15', 46, 4, 21, 81012) It may alter my life a bit, i.e., I may have to completely take up Pariah work, i.e., I might have to become a Pariah myself.
('15', 46, 4, 22, 81138) We shall see.
('15', 46, 4, 23, 81152) Anyway let my troubles brace you up if they can.
('15', 46, 4, 24, 81201) Andrews and Pearson were with me for a day.
('15', 46, 4, 25, 81245) I lent the latter some of your books.
('15', 46, 4, 26, 81283) They are both on their way to Fiji in order to investigate the indenture question.
('15', 46, 4, 27, 81366) Harilal was here for a few days.
('15', 46, 4, 28, 81399) He is gone.
('15', 46, 4, 29, 81411) His wife is here with her children.
('15', 46, 4, 30, 81447) I am sending you a piece of cloth from what has been woven by us.
('15', 46, 4, 31, 81513) It is Manilal’s work.
('15', 46, 4, 32, 81535) Sewing is mine and Devdas’s.
('15', 46, 4, 33, 81564) May it serve to wipe your hand and may the spirit that has prompted the gift serve to strengthen the inner man in you.
('15', 46, 4, 34, 81683) With love,
('15', 46, 6, 35, 81694) OLD FRIEND

('15', 52, 4, 5, 90163) MY DEAR FRIEND, I hope you have received my letter the one that did not reach you in time.
('15', 52, 4, 6, 90254) There was no omission [on] my side.
('15', 52, 4, 7, 90290) We are all so short handed that I do not like to ask anyone to write to you.
('15', 52, 5, 8, 90367) Here there is no extensive piece of ground for cultivation hardly one acre.
('15', 52, 5, 9, 90443) There are two roomy houses with little plots of ground attached.
('15', 52, 5, 10, 90508) We are doing only a little vegetable gardening.
('15', 52, 5, 11, 90556) Water is drawn from two wells.
('15', 52, 5, 12, 90587) These are rustic wells, with primitive contrivances for drawing water.
('15', 52, 5, 13, 90658) The dispute was paltry, out of cussedness.
('15', 52, 5, 14, 90701) The man felt polluted because the boys fetched water from his side of the well.
('15', 52, 5, 15, 90781) It was no water dispute.
('15', 52, 6, 16, 90806) We are now weaving our own cloth, sewing things, too, ourselves.
('15', 52, 7, 17, 90871) The buildings were ready for our occupation.
('15', 52, 7, 18, 90916) They are hired houses.
('15', 52, 7, 19, 90939) We are not on our own ground yet.
('15', 52, 7, 20, 90973) Manilal has completed his weaving lessons.
('15', 52, 7, 21, 91016) He has now gone to a village to complete his course.
('15', 52, 7, 22, 91069) Maganlal too has nearly picked it up.
('15', 52, 7, 23, 91107) Devdas is becoming an expert tailor.
('15', 52, 7, 24, 91144) He is turning out a fine student.
('15', 52, 8, 25, 91178) But the life here owing to the untouchable problem has become most difficult for me.
('15', 52, 8, 26, 91263) Mrs. Gandhi is the cause.
('15', 52, 8, 27, 91289) And yet as I have told you I am internally at peace.
('15', 52, 8, 28, 91342) Now good bye.
('15', 52, 9, 29, 91356) Yours, OLD FRIEND

('15', 53, 1, 2, 91525) 63. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('15', 53, 2, 3, 91558) FROM M. K. GANDHI AHMEDABAD, October 23 [1915] 1
('15', 53, 3, 4, 91607) MY DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('15', 53, 3, 5, 91643) Mrs. Gandhi has become a little better but before she could regain her sanity I had to undertake partial starvation.
('15', 53, 3, 6, 91760) I lived without nuts for a few days.
('15', 53, 3, 7, 91797) Just now we have about 40 guests.
('15', 53, 3, 8, 91831) Of these 37 are from an institution about 150 miles from here.
('15', 53, 3, 9, 91894) So we have been obliged for the last 4 days to cook for about 80 people.
('15', 53, 3, 10, 91967) Fortunately there are some fine workers and the guests themselves do their share of the work.
('15', 53, 3, 11, 92061) They assist in the kitchen, in water carrying and grinding.
('15', 53, 3, 12, 92121) Carpentry is going strong.
('15', 53, 3, 13, 92148) We are making sectional book cases.
('15', 53, 3, 14, 92184) I think I mentioned this to you.
('15', 53, 3, 15, 92217) Your books will be housed in one of them.
('15', 53, 3, 16, 92259) When you see these you will like them.
('15', 53, 3, 17, 92298) There will be five sections to each.
('15', 53, 3, 18, 92335) The cost will come to about £6 each.
('15', 53, 3, 19, 92372) Cheap enough you will say.
('15', 53, 3, 20, 92399) But according to the measure here £6 for a book case is rather a heavy charge.
('15', 53, 3, 21, 92478) I wish I could give you a sketch of the handlooms but I cannot.
('15', 53, 3, 22, 92542) It is an intricate affair.
('15', 53, 3, 23, 92569) You cannot have any notion from my description because I cannot give you a technical description.
('15', 53, 3, 24, 92667) Suffice it to say that it has as much string work as wood work.
('15', 53, 3, 25, 92731) The cost of the simplest loom is under £7. Maganlal is to leave for Madras in a day or two in order to finish his Tamil study and his handloom experience.
('15', 53, 3, 26, 92886) There is a big and rather good handloom business in Madras.
('15', 53, 3, 27, 92946) Did I tell you that we all remain in the house bare bodied?
('15', 53, 3, 28, 93006) All we wear is dhotar the cloth round the waist.
('15', 53, 3, 29, 93055) It is the sanest thing we could have done.
('15', 53, 3, 30, 93098) I receive visitors, both English and Indian, in that condition.
('15', 53, 3, 31, 93162) So you will see that the cost of clothing will be very little.
('15', 53, 3, 32, 93225) We shall confine ourselves to our own production.
('15', 53, 3, 33, 93275) And now good bye.
('15', 53, 3, 34, 93293) The bell has gone to serve the boys.
('15', 53, 3, 35, 93330) Do come soon and take your share in the serving.
('15', 53, 4, 36, 93379) Yours always, OLD FRIEND From the original: Gandhi Kallenbach Correspondence.

('15', 54, 0, 1, 93583) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 55
('15', 54, 1, 2, 93624) SPEECH ON INDENTURED INDIAN LABOUR AT BOMBAY 1
('15', 54, 2, 3, 93671) October 28, 1915
('15', 54, 3, 4, 93688) Mr. Gandhi, who was loudly cheered by the audience, said that the question of indentured labour was just now a topical question, because those true and real friends of India, Messrs Andrews and Pearson, were conducting an enquiry 2 in Fiji.
('15', 54, 3, 5, 93929) The Fiji Islands absorbed the largest number of indentured Indians at the present moment.
('15', 54, 3, 6, 94019) Messrs Andrews and Pearson were not the first to interest the Indians in this question, but it was the deceased statesman, Mr. Gokhale, who first impressed Indians with the importance of their duties in connection with this question.
('15', 54, 3, 7, 94253) Mr. Gandhi here read the resolution 3 introduced by Mr. Gokhale in the Viceregal Council and his speech 4 upon it demanding the total abolition of the indenture system and commented upon it at some length.
('15', 54, 3, 8, 94459) The resolution which Mr. Gokhale brought before the Council was defeated by a majority, though all 5 the non official members of the Council voted for the abolition.
('15', 54, 3, 9, 94625) However much a benign and sympathetic Viceroy wished to remove this abominable system of indenture from the Indian Statute Book, there was a very serious difficulty in his way and that was the report by the two Commissioners, who were sent by Lord Hardinge, namely, Messrs MacNeill and Chimanlal, 6 which was contained in two bulky volumes.
('15', 54, 3, 10, 94966) All might not care to wade through the rather dull pages of those volumes, but to him who knew what real indentured labour was they were of great interest.
('15', 54, 3, 11, 95122) They might, however, take upon trust that the report recognised that indentured labour should continue just as it was, if certain conditions were fulfilled.
('15', 54, 3, 12, 95279) Those conditions, Mr. Gandhi said, were impossible of fulfilment.
('15', 54, 3, 13, 95345) And the recommendations, which these two great Commissioners made, showed that they really could not seriously have meant that the system of indenture which existed today in Fiji, Jamaica, Guiana and other colonies should be continued a minute longer than was actually necessary.
('15', 54, 3, 14, 95625) The speaker here referred to the previous commission and said that the defects which Messrs MacNeill and Chimanlal had pointed out were patent to all.
('15', 54, 3, 15, 95776) Their report contained nothing new.
('15', 54, 3, 16, 95812) But there was unofficial investigation on behalf of some philanthropic body in England some forty years
('15', 54, 4, 17, 95916) 1 Under the auspices of the District Congress Committee at the Empire Theatre, Sir Ibrahim Rahimtullah presiding 2 The results were published in their Report on Indentured Labour in Fiji.
('15', 54, 4, 18, 96104) 3 Recommending prohibition of recruitment of indentured labour in India; vide “Indenture or Slavery?”, December, 1915. 4 On March 4, 1912 5 22 in number 6 McNeill and Chimanlal were sent by the Indian Government to report on conditions prevailing in Jamaica, Trinidad, British Guiana and Fiji—Colonies where the indenture system was still permitted.
('15', 55, 0, 1, 96454) 56 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 55, 1, 2, 96495) ago, and in that book an unvarnished tale was given, which told in graphic language what were the hardships under the system.
('15', 55, 2, 3, 96621) In this connection, Mr. Gandhi quoted a statement made by the Prime Minister of Natal in which he said that the system of indenture was a most inadvisable thing and that the sooner it was terminated, the better for the indentured labourer and the employer.
('15', 55, 2, 4, 96878) Lord Selborne said the same thing when he was the High Commissioner in South Africa: he said that it was worse for the employer than the employed, because it was a system perilously near to slavery.
('15', 55, 2, 5, 97077) Sir William Hunter 1 wrote a beautiful series of letters in 1895 when he first brought himself to study the system personally and compared the system of indenture, after due investigation, to a state bordering on slavery.
('15', 55, 2, 6, 97299) On one occasion he used the expression ‘semi slavery’.
('15', 55, 2, 7, 97354) Mr. Gandhi said if he erred in making these statements, he erred in Lord Selborne’s company.
('15', 55, 2, 8, 97447) And it was in connection with this system that these two worthy gentlemen, the Commissioners, had seen fit to report and advise the fulfilment of certain conditions which in the very nature of the contract were impossible of fulfilment.
('15', 55, 2, 9, 97684) The conditions were that unsuitable emigrants be excluded; the proportion of females to males to be raised from 40 to 50 per cent.
('15', 55, 2, 10, 97815) The speaker could not understand what they meant by “unsuitable emigrants” being excluded.
('15', 55, 2, 11, 97906) The Commissioners themselves told them that it was not easy to find labour in India.
('15', 55, 2, 12, 97991) India was not pining to send her children out as semi slaves.
('15', 55, 2, 13, 98053) Lord Sanderson 2 stated that it was the surplus population from India that went out from dissatisfaction with the economic condition in India.
('15', 55, 2, 14, 98196) But they must remember that there were 500 recruiting licences issued in the year 1907. Could they conceive the significance of the extraordinary state of things which required one recruiter to 17 labourers?
('15', 55, 2, 15, 98404) The Colonial Governments had their sub agents in India for this indentured labour to be collected.
('15', 55, 2, 16, 98503) They were paid a sum of Rs. 25 for each cooly recruited, and this sum of Rs. 25 was divided between the recruiter and the sub agent.
('15', 55, 2, 17, 98636) Mr. Gandhi thought the mental state of those recruiters must be miserable, who could send so many of their countrymen as semi slaves.
('15', 55, 2, 18, 98770) After having seen what the recruiting agents did and after having read the many gross mis statements they made, he was not surprised that thousands and thousands of their countrymen were becoming indentured labourers.
('15', 55, 2, 19, 98988) The Commissioners devoted several pages to the immorality prevailing on the estates.
('15', 55, 2, 20, 99073) It was not forty women for sixty men, but the statement was made that these men did not marry these women, but kept them and that
('15', 55, 3, 21, 99203) 1 (1840 1900), historian, an authority on Indian affairs and author of Indian Empire; served in India for 25 years, was sympathetic to lndian aspirations; member of the British Committee of the Indian National Congress in London 2 Chairman of the Committee appointed by the British Government in England to investigate conditions in the Crown Colonies of Jamaica, Trinidad, British Guiana and Fiji.
('15', 56, 0, 1, 99602) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 57
('15', 56, 1, 2, 99643) many of these women were prostitutes.
('15', 56, 1, 3, 99681) Mr. Gandhi said he would decline to send his children out of the country under such an indenture, if he was worthy of his salt.
('15', 56, 1, 4, 99809) But thousands of men and women had gone.
('15', 56, 1, 5, 99850) What did they think of that in India?
('15', 56, 2, 6, 99888) The conditions were that rigorous provisions should be either expunged from the Ordinances and that the Protector should control employers.
('15', 56, 2, 7, 100028) As for the regulations made to protect these labourers, they could take it from him, Mr. Gandhi said, that there were a great many flaws in them and a coach and four could be easily driven through these.
('15', 56, 2, 8, 100232) The aim of the rules was to make the employer supreme.
('15', 56, 2, 9, 100287) Here was capital ranged against labour with artificial prop for capital and not labour.
('15', 56, 3, 10, 100375) Mr. Gandhi condemned the “protectors” of emigrants.
('15', 56, 3, 11, 100427) They were men belonging to that very class to which employers belonged; they moved among them and was it not only natural that they should have their sympathies on the side of the employers?
('15', 56, 3, 12, 100618) How was it then possible that they could do justice to the labourer against the employer?
('15', 56, 3, 13, 100708) He knew many instances when magistrates had meted out justice to the indentured labourer, but it was impossible to expect such a thing from the Protectors of Emigrants.
('15', 56, 3, 14, 100877) The labourer was bound hand and foot to the employer.
('15', 56, 3, 15, 100931) If he committed an offence against his employer, he first of all had to undergo a course of imprisonment; then the days that the labourer had spent in the jail were added to his indenture and he was taken back to his master to serve again.
('15', 56, 3, 16, 101171) The Commissioners had nothing to say against these rules.
('15', 56, 3, 17, 101229) There was nobody to judge the Protector of Emigrants if he gave a wrong judgment, but in the case of the magistrate he could be criticised.
('15', 56, 3, 18, 101369) Again, the Commissioners said that these prisoners should be put into separate jails.
('15', 56, 3, 19, 101455) But the Colonial Government would be bankrupt if they built jails for hundreds of prisoners that were imprisoned.
('15', 56, 3, 20, 101569) They were not able to build jails for the passive resisters.
('15', 56, 3, 21, 101630) Then the Commissioners said that the labourer should be allowed to redeem his indenture by payment of a graduated redemption fee.
('15', 56, 3, 22, 101760) They made a mistake in thinking him to be an independent man.
('15', 56, 3, 23, 101822) He was not his own master.
('15', 56, 3, 24, 101849) Mr. Gandhi said he had known of English girls, well educated, who were decoyed, and who were not indentured, unable to free themselves.
('15', 56, 3, 25, 101985) How was it then possible for an indentured labourer to do this?
('15', 56, 3, 26, 102049) Then the Commissioners said the special needs of Indian children in the matter of primary education should receive consideration.
('15', 56, 3, 27, 102179) As for education, Mr. Gandhi said, no doubt, some work of that kind was being done by some of the philanthropic missions, but nothing substantial was being done or could be expected.
('15', 56, 3, 28, 102362) Mr. Balfour 1 compared the labourer under an indenture to a soldier.
('15', 56, 3, 29, 102431) But the soldier was a responsible man and he could rise to a high position.
('15', 56, 3, 30, 102507) But an indentured labourer remained a labourer.
('15', 56, 3, 31, 102555) He had no privileges.
('15', 56, 3, 32, 102577) His wife was also included under his disabilities, so also his son.
('15', 56, 3, 33, 102645) In Natal the finger of scorn was pointed at these
('15', 56, 4, 34, 102695) 1 Arthur James Balfour (1848 1930), British statesman, Conservative leader and Prime Minister
('15', 57, 0, 1, 102789) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 57, 1, 2, 102830) people.
('15', 57, 1, 3, 102838) Never could an indentured Indian rise to a higher post than that of labourer.
('15', 57, 1, 4, 102916) And what did the labourer bring when he returned to India?
('15', 57, 1, 5, 102975) He returned a broken vessel, with some of the artificial and superficial signs of civilization, but he left more valuable things behind him.
('15', 57, 1, 6, 103116) He might bring some sovereigns also with him.

('15', 57, 2, 8, 103284) If they could consider well over what he had said, they would try and abolish the system in a year’s time and this one taint upon the nation would have gone and indentured labour would be a thing of the past.

('15', 58, 5, 16, 105795) 66. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('15', 58, 6, 17, 105828) FROM M. K. GANDHI
('15', 58, 7, 18, 105846) AHMEDABAD, October 30, 1915
('15', 58, 8, 19, 105874) MY DEAR FRIEND,
('15', 58, 9, 20, 105890) Not a week just now passes but has its surprises for me.
('15', 58, 9, 21, 105947) Chhaganlal seems to be dangerously ill.
('15', 58, 9, 22, 105987) He has been persistently coughing blood and says he is going down.
('15', 58, 9, 23, 106054) He eats little.
('15', 58, 9, 24, 106070) I had to telegraph saying he should be sent if still ill.

('15', 65, 1, 2, 117458) 73. SPEECH AT PHEROZESHAH MEHTA CONDOLENCE MEETING AT AHMEDABAD 1
('15', 65, 2, 3, 117524) November 15, 1915
('15', 65, 3, 4, 117542) The entrusting of this resolution to me has given me a welcome opportunity to express my sentiments about Sir Pherozeshah in public.
('15', 65, 3, 5, 117675) He was the lion of the Bombay Municipal Corporation and I too have sometimes heard the roaring of this lion.
('15', 65, 3, 6, 117784) Many were the battles he fought with Sir George Clarke 2, Lord Harris 3, successive Viceroys and many Governors in India.
('15', 65, 3, 7, 117906) No wonder that the whole of India mourns the death of such a valiant leader.
('15', 65, 3, 8, 117983) But there is selfishness behind this expression of grief.
('15', 65, 3, 9, 118041) If many more among us could live and die as he lived and died we would in that case have nothing to grieve for.
('15', 65, 3, 10, 118153) A little while ago, India was lamenting the death of the Hon’ble Mr. Gokhale.
('15', 65, 3, 11, 118231) Before these tears had dried, we have had another stunning blow.
('15', 65, 3, 12, 118296) It would not be fair to compare these two great men.
('15', 65, 3, 13, 118349) They did their best, each according to his lights.
('15', 65, 3, 14, 118400) Mr. Gokhale was a selfless man and as such deserved the title of rishi.
('15', 65, 3, 15, 118472) There are two epithets which describe Sir Pherozeshah.
('15', 65, 3, 16, 118527) In the first place, he was the Father of the Bombay Municipal Corporation and, in the second, he was the uncrowned king of Bombay, say rather, of the whole of India—a king chosen by the subjects themselves.
('15', 65, 3, 17, 118734) He took the lead on every public issue and the people had come to have such confidence in him that they would do whatever he wanted them to do.
('15', 65, 3, 18, 118878) That was because of the respect that people, not only of Bombay city but of the whole Presidency, had for his judgment.
('15', 65, 3, 19, 118998) There was none to challenge his position in the Presidency.
('15', 65, 3, 20, 119058) At a time when the people of India expect to win important political rights, no one is left, we may say, who could speak to the Government on our behalf.
('15', 65, 3, 21, 119212) I have read somewhere that those who love their friends dearly love them all the more in their death; likewise, if we are overflowing with love at this moment, it is because of the great qualities of Sir Pherozeshah.
('15', 65, 3, 22, 119429) We may have crossed him often enough when he was alive, spoken well or
('15', 65, 4, 23, 119500) 1 Held in Premabhai Hall, Sir Chinubhai presiding; Gandhiji proposed the condolence resolution.
('15', 65, 4, 24, 119596) 2 Lord Sydenham, ex Governor of Bombay 3 Ex Governor of Bombay and chairman of the Consolidated Gold Fields of South Africa, vide “Lord Harris and British Indians”, 19 11 1903.
('15', 66, 0, 1, 119773) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 67
('15', 66, 1, 2, 119814) ill of him; but, now that he has gone, we are not to look at his faults.
('15', 66, 1, 3, 119887) It is but our duty that we should hold a condolence meeting on his death.
('15', 66, 1, 4, 119961) We must not, however, stop with this.
('15', 66, 1, 5, 119999) It was Sir Pherozeshah’s desire that we, too, all of us, should render public service as he did and we shall have done our duty to him only if we render such service.
('15', 66, 1, 6, 120166) His body, which was mortal, has perished but what he did will live on.
('15', 66, 1, 7, 120237) His interest in public service was so keen that he would get his clients’ cases adjourned or let go his fees, suffer all manner of inconvenience even to attend meetings of the Bombay Municipal Corporation.
('15', 66, 1, 8, 120443) He would sometimes not go to the Assembly; he considered the work of the Corporation of greater importance.
('15', 66, 1, 9, 120551) He did not like being absorbed exclusively in political activities.
('15', 66, 1, 10, 120619) It was his principle that whatever one took up, one must carry to success and he, therefore, gave his best attention to the work of the Bombay Corporation.
('15', 66, 1, 11, 120775) There is no city in India in which a member has rendered such services in the field of municipal work as Sir Pherozeshah has done.
('15', 66, 1, 12, 120906) The world has admired the services of Mr. Chamberlain 1 as President of Birmingham Municipality, but Sir Pherozeshah did, single handed, work for Bombay which it would have taken four Chamberlains to do.
('15', 66, 1, 13, 121110) The right memorial to Sir Pherozeshah would be for all municipalities to work in the manner he did.
('15', 66, 1, 14, 121210) The daily political discussions in Sir Pherozeshah’s office were unfailingly echoed immediately in the public at large, so important and influential were his views.
('15', 66, 1, 15, 121375) He was more of an Indian than a Parsi and believed that the unity of India could be achieved only by turning the entire population into a single community.
('15', 66, 1, 16, 121531) The discussions in his office were mainly concerned with how we could fight fearlessly for our rights.
('15', 66, 1, 17, 121634) He had to suffer much while doing public service.
('15', 66, 1, 18, 121684) He once gave me the best advice on this subject.
('15', 66, 1, 19, 121733) I was insulted by an Englishman once and I was about to file a suit for damages against him.
('15', 66, 1, 20, 121826) Sir Pherozeshah told me then that, if I wished to do any good to myself or the country, I should swallow the insult and that I should swallow similar insults in future as well.
('15', 66, 1, 21, 122003) Indeed, I have had to swallow them on numerous occasions.
('15', 66, 1, 22, 122061) I must admit that whatever capacity for work I possess I owe to this advice.
('15', 66, 1, 23, 122138) If we pay tributes to him today, it is because of his good sense, his courage and faith.
('15', 66, 1, 24, 122227) I feel like making a suggestion about how we may perpetuate the memory of this great man whom Ahmedabad mourns today.
('15', 66, 1, 25, 122345) This public hall is so small that the city should be ashamed of
('15', 66, 2, 26, 122409) 1 Joseph
('15', 67, 0, 1, 122418) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 67, 1, 2, 122459) it, for towns even one fourth the size of Ahmedabad possess halls bigger than this.
('15', 67, 1, 3, 122543) It is my submission, therefore, that the people of Ahmedabad should build a big public hall in memory of Sir Pherozeshah Mehta.
('15', 67, 1, 4, 122671) His magnificence, too, deserves to be understood.
('15', 67, 1, 5, 122721) He was lavish in spending money.
('15', 67, 1, 6, 122754) Mr. Gokhale, Mr. Ishvar Chandra Vidyasagar 1 and others held one view about how one should live and Pherozeshah held another, which, however, did no harm.
('15', 67, 1, 7, 122909) Ahmedabad ought to put up a memorial to so great a man and I hope my appeal will find favour with the people of Ahmedabad.

('15', 68, 1, 2, 124261) 75. SPEECH AT RAJCHANDRA BIRTH ANNIVERSARY, AHMEDABAD
('15', 68, 2, 3, 124315) November 21,1915
('15', 68, 3, 4, 124332) At a public meeting held at the Premabhai Hall, Ahmedabad, on November 21, 1915, to celebrate the birthday of the famous philosopher of Gujarat, Shrimad Rajchandra 1, Gandhiji, who occupied the chair, dwelt in the course of his opening remarks on the appropriateness of the celebration of the great philosopher’s birthday.
('15', 68, 4, 5, 124655) Dealing with the life of Rajchandra, Mr. Gandhi mentioned that he had come in close personal contact with him and, so far as he was competent to judge, he declared it to be his deliberate opinion that the deceased was one of the best religious philosophers of modern times in India.
('15', 68, 4, 6, 124938) He was incomparable in true perception, he was free from attachment, and had true vairagya in him.
('15', 68, 4, 7, 125037) 2 He followed no narrow creed.
('15', 68, 5, 8, 125068) He was a universalist and had no quarrel with any religion in the world.
('15', 68, 5, 9, 125141) In the West, the speaker had found Tolstoy and Ruskin among the best philosophers and he did not hesitate to put the deceased above both of them.
('15', 68, 5, 10, 125287) The deceased outdid them in religious experience.
('15', 68, 5, 11, 125337) The faith of the deceased was a robust faith, such as could only be based upon the true realisation of the self.
('15', 68, 5, 12, 125450) Upon the speaker’s own life, the deceased had exercised a very powerful influence.
('15', 68, 5, 13, 125533) There was a suitable and certain sublimity and genuineness about the writings of the deceased, which gave them peculiar charm and enabled them to have a powerful hold upon the reader.
('15', 68, 6, 14, 125717) Concluding, Mr. Gandhi hoped that those who had attended the celebration would take the trouble of studying the writings of the deceased Mahatma and he promised that they would feel all the better for their trouble.
('15', 68, 7, 15, 125933) The Bombay Chronicle, 23 11 1915
('15', 68, 8, 16, 125966) 1 Son in law of Revashanker Jagjivan Mehta, elder brother of Gandhiji’s life long friend and supporter, Dr. Pranjivan Mehta.
('15', 68, 8, 17, 126091) Gandhiji first met him in 1891 at the suggestion of Dr. Mehta.
('15', 68, 8, 18, 126154) A business man and an expert jeweller, he lived his life in the spirit of karmayoga.
('15', 68, 8, 19, 126239) His was the first profound influence on Gandhiji in his mature years, comparable to that of Ruskin and Tolstoy later; vide An Autobiography, Part II, Ch. I. 2 Gujarati, 28 11 1915, has here: “He had gyana, vairagya and bhakti.”
