('15', 71, 1, 2, 129910) 78. SPEECH AT AHMEDABAD FUNCTION 1
('15', 71, 2, 3, 129945) November 28, 1915
('15', 71, 3, 4, 129963) I know that you will dislike my expressing, amidst all this gaiety, views which you will find unpleasant; I must, all the same, tell you what I feel.
('15', 71, 3, 5, 130113) It may, of course, be questioned whether, holding the views that I do, I should have come to a gathering such as this; it is still more open to question whether I should express them.
('15', 71, 3, 6, 130297) It is love which prompted me to come here and, again, it is love which has prompted me to stand up and speak.
('15', 71, 3, 7, 130407) You are all very happy and I too am happy to see you honour Bhai Nanalal.
('15', 71, 3, 8, 130481) He has succeeded in gaining admission into the Indian Civil Service.
('15', 71, 3, 9, 130550) 2 He deserves to be honoured for his hard work.
('15', 71, 3, 10, 130598) 3 But I should not like other students to follow his example and enter the civil service.
('15', 71, 3, 11, 130688) Our students do not need at present the kind of example Civilians provide; they stand in need of the example set by the lives of Mr. Dadabhai, Mr. Gokhale and Mr. Pherozeshah Mehta.
('15', 71, 3, 12, 130870) If I may use the words of the late Mr. Gokhale, what we need at present is characters not labels.
('15', 71, 3, 13, 130968) Bhai Nanalal’s father spent Rs. 30,000 to make him a Civilian; I believe he could have put that money to better use instead; and Bhai Nanalal, even if he had remained an ordinary man, could have rendered better service to India in some other capacity, if he had so chosen.
('15', 71, 3, 14, 131241) Civilians have to come to India in plenty, and many more will come; but it doesn’t look as if they have been particularly useful to the country.
('15', 71, 3, 15, 131386) Bhoja Bhagat 4 was a cobbler but, working as a cobbler, he succeeded in raising himself; and so also Akha Bhagat 5, who was a goldsmith.
('15', 71, 3, 16, 131523) Thus, if one wishes, one can progress spiritually even while pursuing one’s vocation.
('15', 71, 3, 17, 131609) And so also Bhai Nanalal could have been more useful to the country if he had devoted himself to its service while pursuing some vocation.
('15', 71, 3, 18, 131748) You are in love with labels and you think that it is something to have acquired one.
('15', 71, 3, 19, 131833) On the contrary, as I believe, the man is crushed beneath them, loses his truth.
('15', 71, 4, 20, 131914) 1 In honour of N. C. Mehta, who had been admitted to the Indian Civil Service 2 The source is damaged here.
('15', 71, 4, 21, 132022) 3 ibid 4 A Gujarati poet, 1785 1850 5 A metaphysical poet of the 17th century, famed for his satire; vedantin and rationalist
('15', 72, 0, 1, 132148) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 73
('15', 72, 1, 2, 132189) We have no need at present of labels like B.A., M.A., Baronet, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., Sir, the Hon’ble, etc.
('15', 72, 1, 3, 132293) We need men who will rise above the desire for all such honours and work.
('15', 72, 1, 4, 132367) People need education which will enable everyone to express his thoughts with the utmost freedom.
('15', 72, 1, 5, 132465) Today, all over the country there is an atmosphere of fear, so much so that we feel afraid, unnecessarily, even to express our views.
('15', 72, 1, 6, 132599) We need an education that will blow up all such notions and make us truly fearless.
('15', 72, 1, 7, 132683) We don’t need labels.
('15', 72, 1, 8, 132705) I know many of you will not like this discordant note.
('15', 72, 1, 9, 132760) But, whispering into my ear a little while ago, Bhai Nanalal asked me why the people in India are so much impressed by success at examinations.
('15', 72, 1, 10, 132904) He said he could speak nothing of this but asked me if I wouldn’t like to say something.
('15', 72, 1, 11, 132993) It is this hint from him which prompted me to say a few things which I had in mind.
('15', 72, 1, 12, 133077) You may accept what appeals to you and throw away or leave behind in this hall what may seem rubbish to you.
('15', 72, 1, 13, 133186) I wouldn’t mind it either way.
('15', 72, 1, 14, 133217) I wish Bhai Nanalal all success in doing his duty, that is, in loyally serving theGovernment and comporting himself with the people, over whom he will be placed in authority, not as their superior but as one of them; for he should know that the people are not the slaves of the officers, it is the officers who are their servants.
('15', 72, 1, 15, 133548) May God give Bhai Nanalal long life and may he fulfil all our dreams about his serving the country.
('15', 72, 1, 16, 133648) If he does, I should be happy.
('15', 72, 1, 17, 133679) If things do not turn out so and he goes the way others do, I wish that he then performs prayashchita 1 and, should I come to hear of it all, I too would do prayashchita for having attended this function and addressed it.
('15', 72, 1, 18, 133901) It is not enough merely to acquire a means to a good income; there is much else one has to do afterwards and we need at present the character, the education and the men that will teach us how to do this.

('15', 73, 0, 1, 134166) 74 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 73, 1, 2, 134207) 79. INDENTURE OR SLAVERY?
('15', 73, 2, 3, 134233) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM,
('15', 73, 3, 4, 134252) AHMEDABAD, Girmit 2 is a corrupt form of the English word agreement.
('15', 73, 3, 5, 134321) The term cannot be dispensed with.
('15', 73, 3, 6, 134356) What it suggests, “agreement” does not.
('15', 73, 3, 7, 134396) There is no alternative word in the language.
('15', 73, 3, 8, 134442) The document under which thousands of labourers used to emigrate and still emigrate to Natal and other countries on contract for five years is known by the labourers and the employers as girmit.
('15', 73, 3, 9, 134637) A labourer so emigrating under girmit is a girmitio 3. About 12,000 such indentured labourers emigrate annually from India, mostly to the Fiji Islands near Australia, Jamaica near South America, British Guiana, Dutch Guiana and Trinidad.
('15', 73, 3, 10, 134875) The late Mr. Gokhale, a brave soul, held indenture to be a state bordering on slavery; it was described in the same terms by the famous historian, the late Sir William Wilson Hunter; the same analogy was used by Mr. Harry Escombe, a well known former Minister of Natal.
('15', 73, 3, 11, 135145) Indenture is indeed a state of semi slavery.
('15', 73, 3, 12, 135190) Like the slave before him, the indentured labourer cannot buy his freedom.
('15', 73, 3, 13, 135265) A slavewas punished for not working; so also is an indentured labourer.
('15', 73, 3, 14, 135337) If he is negligent, does not attend work for a day, if he answers back,—he will suffer imprisonment for any one of these lapses.
('15', 73, 3, 15, 135466) A slave could be sold and handed over by one owner to another, so too the indentured labourer can be transferred from one employer to another.
('15', 73, 3, 16, 135609) The children of a slave inherited the taint of slavery; much in the same way, the children of an indentured labourer are subject to laws specially passed for them.
('15', 73, 3, 17, 135773) The only difference between the two states is that while slavery ended only with life, an indentured labourer can be free after a certain number of years.
('15', 73, 3, 18, 135928) It should be noted, moreover, that indenture came after the abolition of slavery and that indentured labourers were recruited to take the place of slaves.
('15', 73, 3, 19, 136083) The following facts concerning indentured labourers have been
('15', 73, 4, 20, 136145) 1 This appeared as an article in Samalochak.
('15', 73, 4, 21, 136190) 2 Indenture 3 Indentured labourer
('15', 74, 0, 1, 136224) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 75
('15', 74, 1, 2, 136265) established.
('15', 74, 1, 3, 136278) In the countries to which they emigrate, they receive no moral or religious education.
('15', 74, 1, 4, 136365) Most of them are unmarried.
('15', 74, 1, 5, 136393) On every ship carrying indentured labourers, there is provision for taking women to the extent of 40 per cent.
('15', 74, 1, 6, 136504) Some of these are women of ill fame.
('15', 74, 1, 7, 136541) They do not, as a rule, enter into a marriage alliance.
('15', 74, 1, 8, 136597) In this state of affairs, even if 20 per cent of the men wish to marry, they cannot.
('15', 74, 1, 9, 136682) Going to lands so far away, they get into the habit of drinking.
('15', 74, 1, 10, 136747) Women, who in India would never touch wine, are sometimes found lying dead drunk on the roads.
('15', 74, 2, 11, 136842) After all this degradation, the profit which they point to is that the economic condition of these people improves.
('15', 74, 2, 12, 136958) Everyone will admit that even though we may stand to gain economically by selling our souls, we ought not to do so.
('15', 74, 3, 13, 137074) How is it that this thing has been allowed to go on for fifty years now?
('15', 74, 3, 14, 137147) None of us will be prepared to submit himself to a condition such as this.
('15', 74, 3, 15, 137222) How then did we tolerate it for our own brethren?
('15', 74, 3, 16, 137272) In raising this question, I have not the least desire to make people feel sorry for the past, but the question helps us to realize our duty in the present.
('15', 74, 3, 17, 137428) The late Mr. Gokhale introduced, in March 1912, a resolution in the Imperial Legislative Council, asking for the repeal of the law governing indenture and demanding that the emigration of indentured labourers from India be stopped.
('15', 74, 3, 18, 137660) At that time, 22 members took a pledge that “they would bring forward the resolution every year till indenture was abolished”.
('15', 74, 3, 19, 137787) It is for us, the survivors, to fulfil that pledge.
('15', 74, 3, 20, 137839) Mr. Andrews and Mr. Pearson have gone to Fiji for this very purpose.
('15', 74, 3, 21, 137908) It is not too much to say, therefore, that every educated Indian is in duty bound to apply his mind to this question and join in discussing it so as to help in getting it finally settled.
('15', 74, 4, 22, 138096) This is not the place to go into details; for those, however, who wish to study the subject, there is literature in plenty and easily accessible: in particular, the debates in the Imperial Legislative Council on the resolution mentioned above, the Lord Sanderson Committee Report and the report of Messrs MacNeill and Chimanlal on the condition of indentured labourers.
('15', 74, 4, 23, 138466) If any paper gets a special note prepared on this literature, it is bound to prove useful.
('15', 74, 5, 24, 138557) [From Gujarati]
('15', 74, 6, 25, 138573) Samalochak, December, 1915

('15', 78, 0, 1, 143238) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 79
('15', 78, 1, 2, 143279) 86. A TALK 1
('15', 78, 2, 3, 143292) BHAVNAGAR, [On or after December 7, 1915] 2
('15', 78, 3, 4, 143336) Dignity of labour means that students should wash their own clothes and do their own personal work like cooking, cleaning of utensils and so on.
('15', 78, 3, 5, 143481) They should abandon any false sense of shame in body labour.
('15', 78, 3, 6, 143542) I am against machines because big industries like steel and coal dehumanize men.
('15', 78, 3, 7, 143623) Rather than destroy big and small industries we must establish a balance between them and give first place to village industries.
('15', 78, 3, 8, 143753) I do accept the importance of primary education.
('15', 78, 3, 9, 143802) But I know many person who cannot read and write, yet are able to work efficiently, because of their intuitive understanding.
('15', 78, 3, 10, 143928) Hence, we cannot afford to wait for education.
('15', 78, 3, 11, 143975) History today teaches strife, treachery and intrigue, whereas it should give greater importance to noble deeds.
('15', 78, 3, 12, 144087) Man has no right to drink milk, because whether in human beings or animals nature has intended milk only for the young.
('15', 78, 3, 13, 144207) Hence whatever the arguments, there is no justification for drinking milk.
('15', 78, 3, 14, 144282) I believe in varnashramadharma but I do not believe in castes.
('15', 78, 3, 15, 144345) Vranashramadharma means that a man should find satisfaction in getting his livelihood from his ancestral occupation.
('15', 78, 3, 16, 144462) I am always in quest of truth.
('15', 78, 3, 17, 144493) For the sake of truth I have abandoned many of my ideas and acquired new ones.
('15', 78, 3, 18, 144572) I have never hesitated to give up the old and accept the new and will never hesitate as long as I live.
('15', 78, 4, 19, 144676) [From Gujarati]
('15', 78, 5, 20, 144692) Sevamurti, p.
('15', 78, 6, 21, 144706) 1 With Veerchand Panachand Shah, Nanabhai Bhatt and others.
('15', 78, 6, 22, 144766) This is a summary of the talk as Reported by Panachand Shah.
('15', 78, 6, 23, 144827) 2 According to the source the talk took place at Bhavnagar towards the end of 1915. Gandhiji was in Bhavnagar from December 7 to 10 in 1915.

('15', 79, 1, 2, 145009) 87. SPEECH AT BHAVNAGAR FOR GOKHALE MEMORIAL FUND 1
('15', 79, 2, 3, 145061) December 8, 1915
('15', 79, 3, 4, 145078) He [Gandhiji] expressed his great happiness at the unprecedented enthusiasm displayed by the people of Bhavnagar that day and the day before and offered them his heartfelt thanks.
('15', 79, 3, 5, 145258) He gave very useful advice to students and youth in general, appealed to the people of Bhavnagar to subscribe to the Memorial Fund for his guru, the late widely respected Hon’ble Mr. Gopal Krishna Gokhale and explained the aims of the Servants of India Society established by him as also the great things expected of it.
('15', 79, 3, 6, 145579) Proceeding, he said: I was invited four months ago by the people of Bhavnagar to visit this place, but I could not do so then owing to certain circumstances.
('15', 79, 3, 7, 145737) But now that I am here, I see that my not coming here then has in a way furthered the purpose of my visit, for then Sir Prabhashanker was not here and, now that he is here, I have had the honour of receiving this address from the blessed hands of so popular an officer as he; what is more, there will be—I am perfectly sure of this—a most substantial gain to the Memorial Fund for the late Hon’ble Mr. Gokhale for which I have especially come here.
('15', 79, 4, 8, 146186) [From Gujarati]
('15', 79, 5, 9, 146202) Prajabandhu, 12 12 1915
('15', 79, 6, 10, 146226) 88. SPEECH AT RECEPTION BY BHAVNAGAR MODH COMMUNITY
('15', 79, 7, 11, 146278) [December 9 1915]
('15', 79, 8, 12, 146296) I am grateful to all my friends of the [Modh] community, who invited me here, for the love they have shown to me.
('15', 79, 8, 13, 146410) My Modh friends showed me the same love even when I landed in Bombay.
('15', 79, 8, 14, 146480) I do not deserve it, for I have rendered no service to the community.
('15', 79, 8, 15, 146550) Besides, my friends and members of the community ask me sometimes what good I have done to it, and accuse me of forsaking swadharma 2 and taking up paradharma 3. In reply, I shall merely say that I serve the
('15', 79, 9, 16, 146758) 1 In reply to an address from the citizens, Sir Prabhashanker Pattani, the State Diwan, presiding 2 Duty natural to oneself; vide Bhagavad Gita, III.
('15', 79, 9, 17, 146908) 35. 3 Duty natural to someone else
('15', 80, 0, 1, 146943) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 81
('15', 80, 1, 2, 146984) country to the best of my ability and that, the community being but a part of it, I believe service of the country includes that of the community.
('15', 80, 1, 3, 147131) You express unbounded love for me at the moment but remember, friends, not to obstruct me when I do something which you may not approve of.
('15', 80, 1, 4, 147271) Even in those circumstances, I shall crave your blessings.
('15', 80, 1, 5, 147330) I feel so sad that even my own people do not know me.
('15', 80, 1, 6, 147384) I cannot keep with me a thing like this 1 made of silver, since I observe the rule of non possession.
('15', 80, 1, 7, 147486) If I do, a thief may try to steal it and I may then have to resort to violence for protecting it; this, again, will violate my rule of non violence.
('15', 80, 1, 8, 147635) I will therefore get it melted and use the money for the purposes of the Ashram.
('15', 80, 1, 9, 147716) I thank you all, gentlemen, and my friends of the community.

('15', 83, 1, 2, 151804) 92. LETTER TO MAGANBHAI H. PATEL
('15', 83, 2, 3, 151837) HADALA, Sunday [December 12, 1915]
('15', 83, 3, 4, 151872) BHAISHRI 1 MAGANBHAI, I visited Bagasara today.
('15', 83, 3, 5, 151920) I got another batch of letters there.
('15', 83, 3, 6, 151958) There was one from Shivpujan too.
('15', 83, 3, 7, 151992) His argument seems to be correct.
('15', 83, 3, 8, 152026) We cannot experiment with the children who are put in our charge.
('15', 83, 3, 9, 152092) Therefore, if you consider it necessary, please introduce immediately provision of ghee and milk for the sick and for others who desire to take these.
('15', 83, 3, 10, 152243) Supply ghee to those who want it and arrange to get milk in sufficient quantity.
('15', 83, 3, 11, 152324) I think there is need to effect this change and watch matters for a few months.
('15', 83, 3, 12, 152404) It is certainly bad that so many should be in poor health.
('15', 83, 3, 13, 152463) If anyone needs buttermilk, we should give it to him and see.
('15', 83, 3, 14, 152525) Nobody should deprive himself of ghee from shyness.
('15', 83, 3, 15, 152577) Only those who are under a vow may abstain from ghee, or those who even though not under a vow want to do without it.
('15', 83, 3, 16, 152695) Shanti should not be given oil even in vegetables.
('15', 83, 3, 17, 152746) The expenditure on dried fruit should be brought down.
('15', 83, 3, 18, 152801) Shivpujan complains of undercooking.
('15', 83, 3, 19, 152838) Look into the matter.
('15', 83, 3, 20, 152860) Everything should be cooked well even if it takes more time.
('15', 83, 3, 21, 152921) I have nothing to say about the money sent for Anna.
('15', 83, 3, 22, 152974) Both of you enjoy a certain position and so what you have done at the moment can be justified.
('15', 83, 3, 23, 153069) This cannot be done for Mama 2. Payment could not be made to Krishnaswamy because there was no question of his becoming manager.
('15', 83, 3, 24, 153198) Mama of course has almost reached the position of manager.
('15', 83, 3, 25, 153257) Moreover in such work we must have one strict rule.
('15', 83, 3, 26, 153309) I am sending Shivpujan’s letter for you to see.
('15', 83, 3, 27, 153357) Be more lenient, not less, in my absence.
('15', 83, 3, 28, 153399) I do not wish that the students should have complaints to make against you.
('15', 83, 3, 29, 153475) It is necessary that Shivprasad, Shanti, Chhotam and others should get well at once.
('15', 83, 3, 30, 153560) Give milk to Sundaram.
('15', 83, 3, 31, 153583) He can have only a dhoti which we all have.
('15', 83, 3, 32, 153627) We cannot

('15', 86, 7, 14, 157470) 98. SPEECH AT INDUSTRIAL CONFERENCE, BOMBAY 1
('15', 86, 8, 15, 157516) December 24, 1915
('15', 86, 9, 16, 157534) Mr. Gandhi in support of the Resolution 2 said that they could not keep their industries if their industrial population went away from India and returned, if it ever did, a broken reed, a moral wreck.
('15', 86, 9, 17, 157735) The two adjectives, ‘injurious” and “immoral” were not chosen haphazard but they bore the “imprimatur” of their deceased countryman, Mr. Gokhale.
('15', 86, 9, 18, 157881) He urged them to insist on the abolition of the system even while the war was going on.
('15', 86, 10, 19, 157969) 1 At the eleventh session, with Sir Dorab Tata as President and Sir Dinshaw Petit as Chairman, Reception Committee 2 Which read: “This Conference tenders its respectful thanks to H. E. Lord Hardinge, Viceroy of India, for all he has done for Indian labour outside India and for recommending its abolition to the Secretary of State and submits that, in the highest interests of the country, the system of Indian indentured labour is undesirable and urges its abolition, looking to the highly injurious and immoral effects of the same, as soon as possible.”
('15', 87, 0, 1, 158525) 88 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 87, 1, 2, 158566) Mr. K. N. Aiya Iyer seconded the Resolution.
('15', 87, 1, 3, 158611) He said that this wretched system no human ingenuity could mend and, therefore, must be ended.
('15', 87, 2, 4, 158706) Mr. Muzumdar, in supporting, said that no more despicable system could be invented by man.
('15', 87, 3, 5, 158797) The Hindu, 25 12 1915
('15', 87, 4, 6, 158819) 99. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('15', 87, 5, 7, 158852) FROM M.K. GANDHI
('15', 87, 6, 8, 158869) BOMBAY, December 25, 1915
('15', 87, 7, 9, 158895) MY DEAR FRIEND, I have come to Bombay for the Congress week.
('15', 87, 7, 10, 158956) There is no sincerity about anything.
('15', 87, 7, 11, 158994) ‘Much cry and little work’ proverb applies most appropriately.
('15', 87, 7, 12, 159057) What I should have done I do not know.
('15', 87, 7, 13, 159096) The boys are with me as volunteers and they are not wanted.
('15', 87, 7, 14, 159156) I made a great mistake in bringing the boys at all.
('15', 87, 7, 15, 159208) Mrs. Gandhi is not here.
('15', 87, 7, 16, 159233) She does not yet appreciate my action about the Pariah friend.
('15', 87, 7, 17, 159296) Manilal too has remained behind.
('15', 87, 7, 18, 159329) Dr. Mehta is here.
('15', 87, 7, 19, 159348) He is likely to be here yet for a few days.
('15', 87, 7, 20, 159392) Imamsaheb and young Sorabji have arrived from Natal.
('15', 87, 7, 21, 159445) More next week.
('15', 87, 8, 22, 159461) Yours ever,
('15', 87, 9, 23, 159473) OLD FRIEND

('15', 87, 11, 26, 159574) 100. SPEECH ON INDIA AND THE COLONIES AT BOMBAY CONGRESS SESSION
('15', 87, 12, 27, 159639) December 28, 1915
('15', 87, 13, 28, 159657) Mr. M. K. Gandhi (Bombay) moved Resolution X regarding India and the Colonies on 28th December 1915 at the 30th Indian National Congress session held at Bombay.
('15', 87, 13, 29, 159818) He said:
('15', 87, 14, 30, 159827) MR. PRESIDENT AND FRIENDS, The resolution that stands in my name reads thus:
('15', 88, 0, 1, 159904) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 89
('15', 88, 1, 2, 159945) This Congress regrets that the existing laws affecting Indians in South Africa and Canada have not, in spite of the liberal and imperialistic declarations of Colonial statesmen, been justly and equally administered and this Congress trusts that the self governing Colonies will extend to the Indian emigrants equal rights with European emigrants and that theImperial Government will use all possible means to secure the rights which have been hitherto unjustly withheld from them, thus causing widespread dissatisfaction and discontent.
('15', 88, 1, 3, 160482) May I please appeal to the Press to alter the word “equally” to “equitably” because that was the word given last night at the Subjects Committee meeting?
('15', 88, 2, 4, 160636) Friends, it is an irony of fate that, whilst this vast assembly will be regretting the attitude, the hostile attitude that has been adopted by the self governing Colonies, a contingent of your countrymen formed in South Africa will be nearing the theatre of war in order to help the sick and the wounded.
('15', 88, 2, 5, 160941) I am in possession of facts in connection with this contingent formed in South Africa, which shows that it is composed of the middle classes which, according to The Times of India, are going to form the future self governing nation.
('15', 88, 2, 6, 161174) These men are drawn from ex indentured Indians and their children; they are drawn from the petty hawkers, the toilers and the traders—all these men compose this great contingent.
('15', 88, 2, 7, 161353) And yet the Colonies do not consider it necessary to alter their attitude, nor do I see the logic in their altering their policy.
('15', 88, 2, 8, 161483) It is the fashion now a days to consider that because we have taken our humble share in the war by not being disloyal to the Government at the present juncture, we are entitled to rights which have been hitherto withheld from us as if those rights were withheld from us because our loyalty was suspected.
('15', 88, 2, 9, 161788) No, my friends.
('15', 88, 2, 10, 161804) If they have been withheld from us, the reasons are different and those reasons will have to be altered.
('15', 88, 2, 11, 161909) They are due, some of them, to undying prejudices; they are due, some of them, to economic causes and these will have to be examined.
('15', 88, 2, 12, 162043) The prejudices will have to be borne down.
('15', 88, 2, 13, 162086) What are the hardships that our countrymen are labouring under in South Africa, in Canada and in the other self governing Colonies?
('15', 88, 2, 14, 162218) In South Africa, the settlement of 1914 secured what the passive resisters were fighting for and nothing more and they were fighting for the restoration of legal equality in connection with emigration
('15', 89, 0, 1, 162419) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 89, 1, 2, 162460) from British India and certain other things.
('15', 89, 1, 3, 162505) That legal equality has been restored, the other things granted, but the domestic troubles still remain, and if it was not the custom unfortunately inherited for the last thirty years that the language, the predominant language in the assembly, should be English, our Madras friends will have taken good care to learn one of the northern vernaculars and then there are men enough from South Africa who would tell you in one of our own tongues the difficulties that we have to go through even now in South Africa.
('15', 89, 1, 4, 163018) They are in connection with the holding oflanded property; they are in connection with men who, having been once domiciled in South Africa, return to South Africa; there are difficulties in connection with the admission of their children and in connection with trade licences.
('15', 89, 1, 5, 163295) These are, it I may call them so, bread and butter difficulties.
('15', 89, 1, 6, 163360) There are other difficulties which I shall not enumerate just now.
('15', 89, 1, 7, 163427) In Canada, it is not possible for those brave Sikhs who are domiciled there to bring their wives and children.
('15', 89, 1, 8, 163538) (Cries of “Shame”.) That is the difficulty in Canada.
('15', 89, 1, 9, 163592) The law is the same but the administration is vilely unequal.
('15', 89, 1, 10, 163654) I feel that this unequal administration will not be altered because of the splendid aid which India is said to have rendered to the Empire.
('15', 89, 1, 11, 163794) Then how are these difficulties to be met?
('15', 89, 1, 12, 163837) I do not intend to go into details, but the Congress proposes that this difficulty can be met by an appeal to the sense of justice of Colonial statesmen and by an appeal to the Imperial Government.
('15', 89, 1, 13, 164035) I fear that the Congress can only do this.
('15', 89, 1, 14, 164078) Lord Hardinge, only a few months ago, made a fervent appeal to Indian publicists and to Indian statesmen for helping him to come to an honourable solution which will retain the dignity of India and at the same time not cause any trouble to the self governing Colonies.
('15', 89, 1, 15, 164347) Lord Hardinge is still waiting for an answer.
('15', 89, 1, 16, 164393) That answer is not supplied by the Congress nor can it be supplied by the Congress.
('15', 89, 1, 17, 164477) It has to be supplied by associations such as the Imperial Citizenship Association, the specialists, if I may call them so.
('15', 89, 1, 18, 164601) The Congress has given them the lead and it is for these associations to frame the details in which they will have to examine the rival claims and offer to Lord Hardinge a detailed solution, a solution which will satisfy the Colonial Governments as well as the Indian people and will not take away any thing whatsoever from the just demands that this resolution makes.
('15', 89, 1, 19, 164970) With these words, I have much pleasure in proposing this resolution.
('15', 89, 1, 20, 165039) (Loud applause.)
('15', 89, 2, 21, 165056) Report of the Thirtieth Indian National Congress (Bombay), pp.
('15', 90, 0, 1, 165119) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 91

('15', 121, 8, 15, 206857) January 2, 1916
('15', 121, 9, 16, 206873) Please take it that the opening ceremony which I was invited to perform has been performed this very moment.
('15', 121, 9, 17, 206982) May the inmates of the temple imbibe its beauty.
('15', 121, 9, 18, 207031) I hope those who come to worship here and the members and admirers of the Arya Samaj 3, will acquire a fragrance that will endure even after this temple has come down some day.
('15', 121, 9, 19, 207208) May it prosper and may its prosperity in turn ensure that of the devotees visiting it.

('15', 122, 3, 4, 207767) Please expect no speech from me.

('15', 122, 6, 10, 208053) 106. SPEECH AT ARYA SAMAJ ANNUAL CELEBRATIONS, SURAT
('15', 122, 7, 11, 208106) January 2, 1916
('15', 122, 8, 12, 208122) You have laid me under a heavy debt by inviting me to attend this function and declare open the Arya Samaj temple and I am thankful likewise to the Samaj and to the people of Surat for asking me to preside over this celebration.
('15', 122, 8, 13, 208351) Let me tell you at the outset that I am not an Aryasamajist, as members of the Samaj, and others as well, know.
('15', 122, 8, 14, 208463) At the same time, I ought to say that I bear no ill will to the Samaj either.
('15', 122, 8, 15, 208541) I am not a member of this body just as I am not a member of any other body.
('15', 122, 8, 16, 208617) There are numerous other bodies like the Arya Samaj in India and they all do their best by way of service, but I have especial respect for the Samaj.
('15', 122, 8, 17, 208767) I have developed good relations with Munshiramji of the Gurukul at Hardwar.
('15', 122, 8, 18, 208843) My sons and other friends of mine had occasion to stay in that Gurukul 2 and it is not easy to forget the love which prompted all that was done for them.
('15', 122, 8, 19, 208997) The whole of India knows its work as much as I do.
('15', 122, 8, 20, 209048) Swami Dayanand, the adored founder of the Samaj, was a rare man and I must acknowledge that I have come under his influence.
('15', 122, 8, 21, 209173) I have had occasion to talk about the Arya Samaj at many places.
('15', 122, 8, 22, 209238) In my opinion, the Samaj could
('15', 122, 9, 23, 209269) 1 Gandhiji arrived at Surat to perform the opening ceremony of an Arya Samaj temple on January, 2, 1916; vide”Speech at Salej”, 9 1 1916
('15', 122, 10, 24, 209406) 2 The Phoenix party had stayed at Gurukul for some time and, in 1915 at the Kumbha Mela at Hardwar, it assisted the Volunteer Corps of the Servants of India Society.
('15', 122, 10, 25, 209572) Later, Gandhiji also joined the party.
('15', 123, 0, 1, 209611) 124 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 123, 1, 2, 209653) do very useful work if some change was brought about in it.
('15', 123, 1, 3, 209713) What needs to be changed is this,—that some of the spokesmen of the Samaj seem to be only too ready to enter into violent controversy to gain their end.
('15', 123, 1, 4, 209866) They could, however, achieve their purpose without recourse to controversy.
('15', 123, 1, 5, 209942) I discussed this matter in Hardwar and mention it again here today.
('15', 123, 1, 6, 210010) The service that the Arya Samaj renders is not different from that of the Hindu religion.

('15', 154, 6, 10, 281853) Mr. Gandhi was asked to explain briefly what he was about to say.

('15', 154, 7, 12, 282210) Mr. Gandhi, today, wrote a letter of explanation to the Maharaja of Darbhanga 3 in which, after expressing his regret at last night’s incident, he says: My sole object in referring to the Viceregal visit was to express the very strong views I hold against all acts of violence and so called anarchy.
('15', 154, 7, 13, 282510) In common with most of us, I felt deeply humiliated that extraordinary precautions should have been rendered necessary for the protection of the person of one of the noblest of Viceroys when he was, in a special sense, our honoured guest in this sacred city.
('15', 154, 7, 14, 282769) My mission in life is to preach and assist in securing the utmost freedom for my country but never by violence to the person of any human being, even under the greatest provocation.

('15', 156, 3, 4, 284709) Mr. Gandhi, who arrived in Bombay yesterday afternoon from Benares, being interviewed about the incident which interrupted his speech at Benares, said that he was unable to say what particular remarks of his were objected to, nor did Mrs. Besant point out any such remarks.
('15', 156, 3, 5, 284983) She only appealed to the Chairman to stop him.
('15', 156, 3, 6, 285030) Mr. Gandhi said his speech that evening was practically a repetition, in so far as it related to anarchism, of what he had said 1 at the Calcutta meeting last year of which the Hon.
('15', 156, 3, 7, 285212) Mr. Lyons was Chairman.
('15', 156, 3, 8, 285236) At this point, the audience wanted the speaker to go on, but Mr. Gandhi said that he would not do so unless he received the Chairman’s permission to continue.
('15', 156, 3, 9, 285395) He also asked the audience not to resent, as it was inclined, Mrs. Besant’s interruption, as anybody who might feel aggrieved against the speaker’s remarks had a right to ask for a ruling from the Chair.
('15', 156, 4, 10, 285599) Continuing, Mr. Gandhi said: And I proceeded with my speech only after the Maharaja of Darbhanga’s permission, which he gave after considering the matter for a while and cautioning me to explain matters briefly.
('15', 156, 4, 11, 285811) I proceeded, but still noticed a stir on the platform, and that Mrs. Besant was whispering to the Princes who were sitting near her that I was neither withdrawing nor explaining and saying that they ought not to stay.
('15', 156, 5, 12, 286029) The next thing I observed was that the Princes rose one after another and as the Chairman also left, I could not finish my speech.
('15', 156, 6, 13, 286160) In reply to a question whether he would like to withdraw any of the remarks he had made at the meeting, Mr. Gandhi emphatically declared that every word was well considered and well weighed.
('15', 156, 6, 14, 286351) Continuing, he said: That I could ever endorse methods of violence is unthinkable.
('15', 156, 6, 15, 286434) I was not eager to speak at all.
('15', 156, 6, 16, 286467) I did so under great pressure from friends, as I was credited with having some influence over the student population of the country.

('15', 157, 4, 12, 288239) 127. SPEECH ON SWADESHI AT MISSIONARY CONFERENCE, MADRAS 1
('15', 157, 5, 13, 288298) February 14, 1916
('15', 157, 6, 14, 288316) It was not without much diffidence that I undertook to speak to you at all.
('15', 157, 6, 15, 288392) And I was hard put to it in the selection of my subject.
('15', 157, 6, 16, 288449) I have chosen a very delicate and difficult subject.
('15', 157, 6, 17, 288502) It is delicate because of the peculiar views I hold upon swadeshi, and it is difficult because I have not that command of language which is necessary for giving adequate expression to my thoughts.
('15', 157, 6, 18, 288699) I know that I may rely upon your indulgence for the many shortcomings you will no doubt find in my address, the more so when I tell you that there is nothing in what I am about to say, that I am not either already practising or am not preparing to practise to the best of my ability.
('15', 157, 6, 19, 288983) It encourages me to observe that last month you devoted a week to prayer in the place of an address.
('15', 157, 6, 20, 289084) I have earnestly prayed that what I am about to say may bear fruit and I know that you will bless my words with a similar
('15', 157, 7, 21, 289206) 1 Text of the paper read by Gandhiji.
('15', 157, 7, 22, 289244) It was reprinted In Young India 21 6 1919
('15', 158, 0, 1, 289286) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 159
('15', 158, 1, 2, 289328) prayer.
('15', 158, 1, 3, 289336) After much thinking, I have arrived at a definition of swadeshi that perhaps best illustrates my meaning.
('15', 158, 1, 4, 289442) Swadeshi is that spirit in us which restricts us to the use and service of our immediate surroundings to the exclusion of the more remote.
('15', 158, 1, 5, 289581) Thus, as for religion, in order to satisfy the requirements of the definition, I must restrict myself to my ancestral religion.
('15', 158, 1, 6, 289709) That is the use of my immediate religious surroundings.
('15', 158, 1, 7, 289765) If I find it defective, I should serve it by purging it of its defects.
('15', 158, 1, 8, 289837) In the domain of politics, I should make use of the indigenous institutions and serve them by curing them of their proved defects.
('15', 158, 1, 9, 289968) In that of economics, I should use only things that are produced by my immediate neighbours and serve those industries by making them efficient and complete where they might be found wanting.
('15', 158, 1, 10, 290160) It is suggested that such swadeshi, if reduced to practice, will lead to the millennium.
('15', 158, 1, 11, 290249) And as we do not abandon our pursuit after the millennium because we do not expect quite to reach it within our time, so may we not abandon swadeshi even though it may not be fully attained for generations to come.
('15', 158, 1, 12, 290464) Let us briefly examine three branches of Swadeshi as sketched above.
('15', 158, 1, 13, 290533) Hinduism has become a conservative religion and therefore a mighty force because of the Swadeshi spirit underlying it.
('15', 158, 1, 14, 290652) It is the most tolerant because it is non proselytising, and it is as capable of expansion today as it has been found to be in the past.
('15', 158, 1, 15, 290789) It has succeeded not in driving, as I think it has been erroneously held, but in absorbing Buddhism.
('15', 158, 1, 16, 290890) By reason of the swadeshi spirit, a Hindu refuses to change his religion not necessarily because he considers it to be the best, but because he knows that he can complement it by introducing reforms.
('15', 158, 1, 17, 291090) And what I have said about Hinduism is, I suppose, true of the other great faiths of the world, only it is held that it is specially so in the case of Hinduism.
('15', 158, 1, 18, 291251) But here comes the point I am labouring to reach.
('15', 158, 1, 19, 291301) If there is any substance in what I have said, will not the great missionary bodies of India, to whom she owes a deep debt of gratitude for what they have done and are doing, do still better and serve the spirit of Christianity better, by dropping the goal of proselytising but continuing their philanthropic work?
('15', 158, 1, 20, 291616) I hope you will not consider this to be an impertinence on my part.
('15', 158, 1, 21, 291684) I make the suggestion in all sincerity and with due humility.
('15', 158, 1, 22, 291746) Moreover, I have some claim upon your attention.
('15', 158, 1, 23, 291795) I have endeavoured to study the Bible.
('15', 158, 1, 24, 291834) I consider it as part of my scriptures.
('15', 158, 1, 25, 291874) The spirit of the Sermon
('15', 159, 0, 1, 291899) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 159, 1, 2, 291941) on the Mount competes almost on equal terms with the Bhagavad Gita for the domination of my heart.
('15', 159, 1, 3, 292040) I yield to no Christian in the strength of devotion with which I sing, “Lead, kindly Light” and several other inspired hymns of a similar nature.

('15', 166, 1, 2, 309447) VOW OF TRUTH
('15', 166, 2, 3, 309460) Not truth simply as we ordinarily understand it, that as far as possible we ought not to resort to a lie, that is to say, not truth which merely answers the saying, “Honesty is the best policy”— implying that if it is not the best policy, we may depart from it.
('15', 166, 2, 4, 309722) But here Truth, as it is conceived, means that we have to rule our life by this law of Truth at any cost.
('15', 166, 2, 5, 309828) And in order to satisfy the definition, I have drawn upon the celebrated illustration of the life of Prahlad 1. For the sake of Truth, he dared to oppose his own father, and he defended himself, not by retaliation by paying his father back in his own coin, but in defence of Truth, as he knew it, he was prepared to die without caring to return the blows that he had received from his father or from those who were charged with his father’s instructions.
('15', 166, 2, 6, 310283) Not only that: he would not in any way even parry the blows.
('15', 166, 2, 7, 310344) On the contrary, with a smile on his lips, he underwent the innumerable tortures to which he was subjected, with the result that at last, Truth rose triumphant, not that Prahlad suffered the tortures because he knew that some day or other in his very life time he would be able to demonstrate the infallibility of the law of Truth.
('15', 166, 2, 8, 310676) That fact was there; but if he had died in the midst of torture, he would still have adhered to Truth.
('15', 166, 2, 9, 310779) That is the Truth that I would like us to follow.

('15', 178, 3, 24, 341911) 130. REPLY TO MRS.
('15', 178, 4, 25, 341930) [Before February 17, 1916]
('15', 178, 5, 26, 341957) Mr. M. K. Gandhi writes to us: Mrs. Besant’s reference in New India and certain other references to the Benares Incident perhaps render it necessary for me to return to the subject, however disinclined I may be to do so.
('15', 178, 5, 27, 342178) Mrs. Besant denies my statement with reference to her whispering to the
('15', 179, 0, 1, 342250) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 179, 1, 2, 342292) Princes.
('15', 179, 1, 3, 342301) 1 I can only say that if I can trust my eyes and my ears, I must adhere to the statement I have made.
('15', 179, 1, 4, 342403) She occupied a seat on the left of the semi circle on the other side of the Maharaja of Darbhanga, who occupied the chair, and there was at least one Prince, perhaps, there were two who were sitting on her side.
('15', 179, 1, 5, 342615) Whilst I was speaking, Mrs. Besant was almost behind me.
('15', 179, 1, 6, 342672) When the Maharaja rose, Mrs. Besant had also risen.
('15', 179, 1, 7, 342724) I had ceased speaking before the Rajahs actually left the platform.
('15', 179, 1, 8, 342792) She was discussing the incident with a group round her on the platform.
('15', 179, 1, 9, 342864) I gently suggested to her that she might have refrained from interrupting, but that if she disapproved of the speech after it was finished, she could have then dissociated herself from my sentiments.
('15', 179, 1, 10, 343064) But she, with some degree of warmth, said, “How could we sit still when you were compromising everyone of us on the platform?
('15', 179, 1, 11, 343190) You ought not to have made the remarks you did.” This answer of Mrs. Besant’s does not quite tally with her solicitude for me which alone, according to her version of the incident, prompted her to interrupt the speech.
('15', 179, 1, 12, 343409) I suggest that if she merely meant to protect me, she could have passed a note round or whispered into my ears her advice.
('15', 179, 1, 13, 343532) And, again, if it was for my protection, why was it necessary for her to rise with the Princes and to leave the hall as I hold she did along with them?
('15', 179, 1, 14, 343684) So far as my remarks are concerned, I am yet unable to know what it was in my speech that seems to her to be open to such exception as to warrant her interruption.
('15', 179, 1, 15, 343848) After referring to the Viceregal visit and the necessary precautions that were taken for the Viceroy’s safety, I showed that an assassin’s death was anything but an honourable death, and said that anarchism was opposed to our shastras and had no room in India.
('15', 179, 1, 16, 344109) I said then where there was honourable death, it would go down history as men who died for their conviction.
('15', 179, 1, 17, 344218) But when a bomb thrower died, secretly plotting all sorts of things, what could he gain?
('15', 179, 1, 18, 344307) I then went on to state and deal with the fallacy that had not bomb throwers thrown bombs, we should never have gained what we did with reference to the Partition Movement.
('15', 179, 1, 19, 344480) It was at about this stage that Mrs. Besant appealed to the chair to stop me.
('15', 179, 1, 20, 344558) Personally, I will desire a publication of the whole of my speech 2
('15', 179, 2, 21, 344626) whose trend was a sufficient warrant for showing that I could not possibly incite the students to deeds of violence.
('15', 179, 2, 22, 344743) Indeed it was

('15', 180, 1, 3, 344987) I began by saying that it was a humiliation for the audience and myself that I should have to speak in English.
('15', 180, 1, 4, 345099) I said that English having been the medium of instruction, it had done a tremendous injury to the country, and as I conceive I showed successfully that had we received training during the past 50 years in higher thought in our own vernaculars, we would be today within reach of our goal.
('15', 180, 1, 5, 345387) I then referred to the self government Resolution passed at the Congress and showed that whilst the All India Congress Committee and theAll India Moslem League would be drawing up their paper about the future constitution, their duty was to fit themselves by their own action for self government.
('15', 180, 1, 6, 345684) And in order to show how short we fell of our duty, I drew attention to the dirty condition of the labyrinth of lanes surrounding the great temple of Kashi Viswanath and the recently erected palatial buildings without any conception as to the straightness or the width of the streets.
('15', 180, 1, 7, 345969) I then took the audience to the gorgeous scene that was enacted on the day of the foundation and suggested that if a stranger not knowing anything about Indian life had visited the scene, he would have gone away under the false impression that India was one of the richest countries in the world— such was the display of jewellery worn by our noblemen.
('15', 180, 1, 8, 346322) And turning to the Maharajas and the Rajahs, I humorously suggested that it was necessary for them to hold those treasures in trust for the nation before we could realise our ideals, and I cited 1 the action of the Japanese noblemen who considered it a glorious privilege, even though there was no necessity for them, to dispossess themselves of treasures and lands which were handed to them from generation to generation.
('15', 180, 1, 9, 346745) I then asked the audience to consider the humiliating spectacle of he Viceroy’s person having to be protected from ourselves when he was our honoured guest.
('15', 180, 1, 10, 346902) And I was endeavouring to show that the blame for these precautions was also on ourselves, in that they were rendered necessary because of the introduction of organised assassination in India.
('15', 180, 1, 11, 347095) Thus I was endeavouring to show, on the one hand, how the students could usefully occupy themselves in assisting to rid the society of its proved defects and, on the other, wean themselves even in thought from methods of violence.

('15', 181, 1, 3, 347621) I was following closely how the speech was being taken and I certainly did not notice that the student world was being adversely affected.
('15', 181, 1, 4, 347760) Indeed some of them came to me the following morning and told me that they perfectly understood my remarks which had gone home.
('15', 181, 1, 5, 347888) One of them, a keen debater, even subjected me to cross examination and seemed to feel convinced by a further development of the argument such as I had advanced in the course of my speech.

('15', 181, 1, 8, 348638) He thinks that the general impression was not that I was encouraging the anarchists but that I was playing the role of an apologist for the Civilian bureaucrat The whole of Mr. Setlur’s attack upon me shows that if he is right I was certainly not guilty of any incitement to violence and that the offence consisted in my reference to jewellery, etc.
('15', 181, 1, 9, 348988) In order that the fullest justice might be done both to Mrs. Besant and myself, I would make the following suggestion.
('15', 181, 1, 10, 349107) She says that she does not propose to defend herself by quoting the sentence which drove the Princes away and that that would be playing into the enemies’ hands; according to her previous statement, my speech is already in the hands of detectives so that, so far as my safety is concerned, her forbearance is not going to be of the slightest use.
('15', 181, 1, 11, 349454) Would it not therefore be better that she should either publish a verbatim report if she has it or reproduce such sentiments in my speech as in her opinion necessitated her interruption and the Princes’ withdrawal?
('15', 181, 1, 12, 349669) I will, therefore, conclude this statement by repeating what I have said before; 1 that but for Mrs. Besant’s interruption, I would have concluded my speech within a few minutes and no possible misconception about my views on anarchism would have arisen.

('15', 182, 5, 7, 350442) 132. SPEECH ON VERNACULARS AND EDUCATION, MADRAS
('15', 182, 6, 8, 350491) [February 17, 1916]
('15', 182, 7, 9, 350511) Last evening at the Anderson Hall, Madras, under the auspices of the Christian College Associated Societies, a joint debate was held on the subject, “Shall the Vernaculars be the Media of Instruction in our Schools and Colleges?” with Mr. M. K. Gandhi in the chair.
('15', 182, 8, 10, 350777) Mr. A. S. Rajam opened the debate on the subject in a short speech.
('15', 182, 9, 11, 350845) The Chairman then wound up the debate and said that certainly the question of racial difference would not occur if vernaculars were to be made the media of instruction in schools and colleges.
('15', 182, 9, 12, 351038) In our country, they were one Nation, and even before the English advent, they did form one Nation and had one common religion.
('15', 182, 9, 13, 351166) There were histories to show that our sacred saga had travelled from one part of the country to another in those days for the purpose of religious gatherings, and thus brotherly feelings always existed among the people.
('15', 182, 9, 14, 351386) For the real progress of the country and for the welfare of the masses, this problem ought to be solved by the authorities concerned at an early date.
('15', 182, 9, 15, 351537) These objections against the introduction of vernaculars were all baseless and the best thing was for the people themselves to solve this question, and educate the masses of the country through the media of vernaculars.
('15', 182, 9, 16, 351757) The rulers themselves would then have to learn the vernaculars of the country in the interests of proper administration.
('15', 182, 10, 17, 351878) A hearty vote of thanks to the Chairman terminated the proceedings.
('15', 182, 10, 18, 351946) New India, 18 2 1916

('15', 183, 1, 2, 352036) 133. SPEECH AT POONA ON GOKHALE ANNIVERSARY
('15', 183, 2, 3, 352080) February 19, 1916
('15', 183, 3, 4, 352098) A meeting to celebrate the anniversary of the late Mr. Gokhale’s death was held in the Kirloskar Theatre, Poona City, on the 19th instant.
('15', 183, 4, 5, 352237) There were about 2,000 persons present.
('15', 183, 5, 6, 352277) Mr. H. W. Wadia, Bar at Law, presided.
('15', 183, 6, 7, 352316) Mr. Gandhi, who came down to Poona at the invitation of the Deccan Sabha, hoped that the anniversary would be celebrated with due regularity and it would take the form of stock taking on the part of those who revered the memory of the deceased and wanted to show their reverence by taking some part of the activity of the deceased.
('15', 183, 6, 8, 352648) 1 Mr. Gokhale’s work in the Imperial Council and on the Public Service Commission showed great ability and patriotism.
('15', 183, 6, 9, 352767) He worked on the South African question regardless of his health and it had, in Mr. Gandhi’s opinion, cost him ten years of his life.
('15', 183, 6, 10, 352901) The speaker suggested that behind all the work of Mr. Gokhale lay his great spirituality.
('15', 183, 6, 11, 352991) It was because Mr. Gokhale felt it necessary to spiritualise the political life of the country that he had brought the Servants of India Society into being.
('15', 183, 6, 12, 353148) Mr. Gokhale once said to the speaker that there were moments when he doubted the efficacy of much of the political work and was distressed by severe disappointments, but he was saved from such a situation by a consciousness of the faith that he had deep down in him in the existence of the permanent element and it was this faith, thought Mr. Gandhi, which made him triumph over all disappointments and persist in the work.
('15', 183, 7, 13, 353572) The speaker said that he had toured the country during the past year in accordance with the wishes of Mr. Gokhale, and now without his advice to guide him, he was at a loss to know whether he was drifting in the right or the wrong direction.
('15', 183, 7, 14, 353814) In the course of his travels, he found that the country was vibrating with a passionate spirit of patriotism, but the bugbear of “fear” loomed large on the horizon.
('15', 183, 7, 15, 353979) Social endeavour was impeded by the overawing power of spiritual authority, and in the path of political activity lay the barrier of political authority.
('15', 183, 7, 16, 354133) They were the slaves of circumstances, but they were themselves to blame.
('15', 183, 7, 17, 354207) It had become impossible for them to voice in public the opinions uttered in their homes.
('15', 183, 7, 18, 354297) The spiritual liberty of the people was usurped by the priests; in politics they were afraid to give expression to their views.
('15', 183, 7, 19, 354425) This was a regrettable state of affairs and showed that they were lacking

('15', 187, 4, 7, 360924) 137. INDENTURED LABOUR
('15', 187, 5, 8, 360947) The question of indentured labour is a seasonable subject for more reasons than one.
('15', 187, 5, 9, 361032) Messrs Andrews and Pearson have just re turned from Fiji after finishing their self imposed labours for the sake of India which they have learnt to love as they love their mother land.
('15', 187, 5, 10, 361217) Their report is about to be issued.
('15', 187, 5, 11, 361253) There Mr. Malaviya has given notice for leave to move a resolution 2 in the Imperial Council which will, if adopted, commit the Government to a repeal of the system of indentured labour.
('15', 187, 5, 12, 361440) Mr. Malaviya’s resolution will be, it may be re called, a continuation of the late Mr. Gokhale’s work in 1912, when in a speech full of fervour and weighted with facts and figures, he moved his resolution demanding repeal of this form of labour.
('15', 187, 5, 13, 361686) The deceased statesman’s resolution was thrown out only by the force of official majority.
('15', 187, 5, 14, 361777) The moral victory lay with Mr. Gokhale.
('15', 187, 5, 15, 361817) The death knell of the system was rung when that resolution was moved.
('15', 187, 5, 16, 361888) The Govern ment, as it could not then abolish the system, outvoted Mr. Gokhale but did not fail to note that they must hurry forward to do so at an early date.
('15', 187, 5, 17, 362048) Mr. Malaviya’s proposed resolution and the report of Messrs Andrews and Pearson, which latter, it is known, is to suggest total abolition of the system, will enable Lord Hardinge fittingly to close his most eventful viceroyalty removing this long standing and acknowledged grievance.
('15', 187, 5, 18, 362332) These lines will be merely an attempt to give personal observations and to indulge in a few reflections upon the question.
('15', 187, 5, 19, 362455) For facts and figures, the readers and the public workers must look up Mr. Gokhale’s speech referred to above and Messrs Andrews and

('15', 188, 1, 2, 362795) Pearson’s forthcoming report.
('15', 188, 2, 3, 362825) Indentured labour is admittedly a remnant of slavery.
('15', 188, 2, 4, 362879) The late Sir William Wilson Hunter, when his attention was drawn to it in 1895, was the first to call it a state ‘perilously near to slavery’.
('15', 188, 2, 5, 363022) Most legislation only partly reflects the public opinion of its time.
('15', 188, 2, 6, 363092) Legislation abolishing slavery was really a bit in advance of public opinion, and that was a big bit.
('15', 188, 2, 7, 363194) And its effect, like that of all such legislation, was largely neutralized by the dissatisfied slave owner resorting to the dodge of indentured labour.
('15', 188, 2, 8, 363346) The yoke, if it fell from the Negro’s black neck, was transferred to the brown neck of the Indian.
('15', 188, 2, 9, 363445) In the process of transfer, it had to be somewhat polished, it had to be lightened in weight and even disguised.
('15', 188, 2, 10, 363558) Nevertheless, in all its essentials, it retained its original quality.
('15', 188, 2, 11, 363629) The hideousness of the system was forcefully demonstrated when the curse descended upon South Africa in the shape of indentured labourers from China for working the gold mines.
('15', 188, 2, 12, 363806) It was no mere election cry that the l ate Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman 1 had taken up when he made the British Isles from end t o end ring with denunciation of t he system.
('15', 188, 2, 13, 363980) No cost was counted as too great for ridding South Africa of the evil.

('15', 188, 2, 15, 364164) They asked for breathing time.
('15', 188, 2, 16, 364195) The House of Commons remained unmoved.

('15', 188, 2, 19, 364336) The mines were threatened to be closed.

('15', 188, 2, 22, 364469) The House laughed.
('15', 188, 2, 23, 364488) Within six months of the passage of the measure for the abolition of Chinese indentured labour, every Chinese labourer had been repatriated bag and baggage.
('15', 188, 2, 24, 364645) The mines survived the shock.
('15', 188, 2, 25, 364675) They discovered other methods of life.
('15', 188, 2, 26, 364714) And now be it said to the credit of the mine owners as well as of the Conservatives who opposed the measure, that both these classes recognize that the abolition was a great deliverance.
('15', 188, 3, 27, 364901) Indian indentured labour is not less demoralising.
('15', 188, 3, 28, 364952) It has persisted because its bitterness like that of a sugared pill has been cleverly though unconsciously concealed.

('15', 189, 1, 16, 366264) And it is suggested that no amount of figures adduced to show that the labourer is far richer at the end of his contract of labour than when he entered upon it can be allowed to be any set off against the moral degradation it involves.
('15', 189, 2, 17, 366500) There is another most powerful consideration to be urged against the continuance of this system.
('15', 189, 2, 18, 366597) The relations between Englishmen and Indians in India are not of the happiest.
('15', 189, 2, 19, 366676) The average Englishman considers himself to be superior to the average Indian and the latter is generally content to be so considered.
('15', 189, 2, 20, 366811) Such a state of things is demoralizing to both and a menace to the stability of the British Empire.

('15', 189, 2, 22, 367098) Be thatas it may, this unnatural relationship is reflected in an exaggerated form outside India when the artificial state of indentured service under the white employer is set up.
('15', 189, 2, 23, 367278) Unless, therefore, the relation between the English and ourselves is put on a correct footing in India, any transference of Indian labourers to far off lands, whether parts of the Empire or otherwise, even under a free contract must harm both employer and employed.

('15', 189, 2, 25, 367638) They were their men.

('15', 189, 2, 27, 367764) I use this language in no uncharitable spirit.
('15', 189, 2, 28, 367811) The humanest of employers cannot escape the limitations of his class.
('15', 189, 2, 29, 367881) He instinctively feels that the Indian labourer is inferior to him and can never be equal to him.
('15', 189, 2, 30, 367979) Surely no indentured Indian, no matter how clever and faithful he may be, has ever

('15', 190, 1, 4, 368268) It is not the Englishman’s fault that the relationship with his Indian employees has not been progressive.
('15', 190, 1, 5, 368375) It is beyond the scope of these lines to distribute the blame, if there is any, on either side, or to examine the causes for the existence of such a state of things.
('15', 190, 1, 6, 368541) I have been obliged to advert to it to show that apart from all other considerations, the system of indentured labour is demonstrably so degrading to us as a nation that it must be stopped at any cost and that now.

('15', 190, 3, 8, 368778) 138. SPEECH AT RECEPTION IN HYDERABAD, SIND
('15', 190, 4, 9, 368822) February 26, 1916
('15', 190, 5, 10, 368840) About seven thousand people led by the Hon’ble Mr. Bhurgri and the Hon’ble Mr. Ghulam Hussein, both Mahomedan members of the Bombay Legislative Council, gave a public reception to Mr. Gandhi at Hyderabad and a procession of fifty carriages took three hours to pass through the crowded streets owing to numerous stops for Mr. Gandhi to be garlanded.
('15', 190, 5, 11, 369189) A eulogistic address in a sandalwood casket was presented to Mr. Gandhi at a public meeting, where all the speeches were in English except that of Mr. Gandhi, who preferred to speak in Hindustani.
('15', 190, 6, 12, 369386) Mr. Gandhi said that his political guru, the late Mr. Gokhale, had imposed on him one year’s silence and had bidden him to travel and see things.
('15', 190, 6, 13, 369532) The period had passed now and he could speak.
('15', 190, 6, 14, 369578) Self government for India was in the air.
('15', 190, 6, 15, 369620) A scheme was to be framed by the Congress and the League leaders at Allahabad, but how many knew what was wanted?
('15', 190, 6, 16, 369734) It could not be given and taken mechanically.
('15', 190, 6, 17, 369780) They could only get as much of swaraj as they fitted themselves for, they had to fulfil certain conditions and they could fulfil them.
('15', 190, 6, 18, 369915) One condition was that they should adopt swadeshi whole heartedly.
('15', 190, 6, 19, 369982) Swaraj and swadeshi must go together.
('15', 190, 6, 20, 370020) Then their motto should be “Fear God rather than man, be the man King or Guru or Moulvi.” Then they must treat their depressed and poor brethren as human beings.
('15', 190, 6, 21, 370182) Mr. Gandhi also reminded his hearers that they could best honour their leaders by copying the virtues which they ascribed to those leaders.
('15', 190, 6, 22, 370322) He concluded with an appeal for funds being raised for the Servants of India Society.
('15', 190, 7, 23, 370408) At the conclusion of his speech, he was loudly cheered.
('15', 190, 7, 24, 370464) At the end “Vande Mataram” and another national song of the famous Digambar 1 were sung, the audience standing.

('15', 191, 2, 3, 370697) February 27, 1916
('15', 191, 3, 4, 370715) On 27th February, l916, Gandhiji unveiled before a large gathering the portrait of the late Mr. G. K. Gokhale in the Holmstead Hall, Hyderabad (Sind).
('15', 191, 3, 5, 370866) The Collector was also amongst those present.
('15', 191, 4, 6, 370912) Mr. Gandhi, speaking Hindustani, said that character was the cornerstone of Mr. Gokhale’s work and success.
('15', 191, 4, 7, 371020) Not only public men, but Government officials, traders, clerks, coolies and others could elevate and serve the country if duty, and not authority or self, was the ruling motive.
('15', 191, 4, 8, 371198) Want of a sense of duty and the spirit of service caused their miseries.
('15', 191, 4, 9, 371271) Mr. Gokhale founded the Servants of India Society for development of character and he wanted to spiritualise political life.
('15', 191, 4, 10, 371396) The leaders must not seek praise but serve the country as a duty.
('15', 191, 4, 11, 371462) If I did not emulate the virtues of Mr. Gokhale, I would prove myself unworthy of this unveiling of his portrait.
('15', 191, 4, 12, 371576) And if you would not emulate his virtues, you would prove yourself unfit for joining in this ceremony.
('15', 191, 5, 13, 371679) In conclusion, Mr. Gandhi appealed for aid for the Servants of India Society.

('15', 191, 7, 15, 371789) 140. SPEECH AT HYDERABAD ON VACCINATION
('15', 191, 8, 16, 371829) February 28, 1916
('15', 191, 9, 17, 371847) During the course of the day, Mr. Gandhi visited the Narishala, Navalrai Hiranand Academy, Nava Vidyalaya High School, and Kundanmal Girls’ School.
('15', 191, 9, 18, 371995) In the afternoon, Mr. Gandhi was the guest of the Gujarati and Deccani residents of Hyderabad, who had assembled in the house of Mr. P. G. Mankad in Hirabag.
('15', 191, 9, 19, 372153) Mr. Gandhi was given an address and garlanded.
('15', 191, 9, 20, 372200) After that he drove to the Central Jail accompanied by Diwan Wadhumal Belaram and his brothers, and strange to say that the request made to the Superintendent to allow Mr. Gandhi to see the inside of the Jail was ungraciously refused by him for reasons best known to him.
('15', 191, 9, 21, 372472) Mr. Gandhi then went to the Holmstead Hall where he gave a short discourse on vaccination.
('15', 191, 10, 22, 372563) He said that he had not given special attention to the subject, but had bestowed some thought on it.
('15', 191, 10, 23, 372664) He thought as the vaccine serum was obtained by a process which spelt torture to the cow, vaccination contravened the fundamental principle of
('15', 191, 11, 24, 372807) 1 These two sentences are from Gujarati, 5 3.1916.
('15', 192, 0, 1, 372858) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 193
('15', 192, 1, 2, 372900) Hinduism which is ahimsa.
('15', 192, 1, 3, 372926) He said that orthodox Hindus objected to vaccination, since injection through the arm was tantamount to taking through the mouth.
('15', 192, 1, 4, 373056) He then said that vaccination with human lymph was open to objection not only on the same grounds, but also because it involved the risk of contracting infectious diseases.
('15', 192, 1, 5, 373229) He said that it was not a fact that all those who were not vaccinated were attacked with small pox, nor that those who were so attacked succumbed to it.
('15', 192, 1, 6, 373382) He further stated that it was left to the choice of every individual to go in for vaccination or not.
('15', 192, 1, 7, 373484) But if the law of compulsory vaccination was in force in a place and if some person objected to vaccination on religious grounds, every Indian should stand by him, for compulsion in one form might lead to compulsion in other directions also.

('15', 192, 5, 12, 374209) All brothers of Hindustan without distinction of creed or caste have been showing this attachment.

('15', 192, 5, 14, 374609) It is undoubtedly this consideration which leads you to be so very kind to me.
('15', 192, 5, 15, 374688) It was they who won the struggle and it was by reason of their unflinching determination to “do or die” that so much was achieved.
('15', 192, 5, 16, 374819) Hence I take it that whatever tribute is paid to me, is in reality and in truth paid to them.
('15', 192, 6, 17, 374913) In the course of my tour in India, I have been particularly struck with one thing and that is the awakening of the Indian people.
('15', 192, 6, 18, 375043) A new hope has filled the hearts of the people, hope that something is

('15', 194, 2, 3, 377862) February 29, 1916
('15', 194, 3, 4, 377880) Unveiling the portrait of Gokhale at the Khalihdina Hall, Karachi, on Tuesday
('15', 194, 4, 5, 377958) the 29th February 1916, Mahatma Gandhi spoke as follows:
('15', 194, 5, 6, 378015) In Hyderabad, Sind, also, I was asked to unveil a portrait of Mr. Gokhale; and there I put to myself and to those present a question which I put to myself and to you now.
('15', 194, 5, 7, 378186) That question is: What right have I to unveil the portrait of Mr. Gokhale and what right have you to join in the ceremony?
('15', 194, 5, 8, 378309) Of course, to unveil a portrait or to join in it is nothing great or important in itself.
('15', 194, 5, 9, 378399) But the question really involved in the ceremony is important, viz., are your hearts and is my heart in reality so much moved as to copy the glorious example of the great man?
('15', 194, 5, 10, 378575) The function will have no real significance unless we follow in his footsteps.
('15', 194, 5, 11, 378654) And if we do follow him, we shall be able to achieve a great deal.
('15', 194, 5, 12, 378721) Of course, it is not possible for all of us to achieve what Mr. Gokhale did in the Imperial Legislative Council.
('15', 194, 5, 13, 378834) But the way in which he served the Motherland, the whole hearted devotion with which he did it day and night without ceasing all this it is in our power to do as the great one did.
('15', 194, 5, 14, 379015) And I hope that when you leave this hall, you will bear in mind to follow him and the give expression to your regard for him.
('15', 194, 5, 15, 379141) You know that the best achievement of Mr. Gokhale according to himself was the establishment of the Servants of India Society.
('15', 194, 5, 16, 379268) This great institution he has left behind him; and it lies with us to support it and continue its noble work.
('15', 194, 5, 17, 379378) It would be best if we could join the Society.
('15', 194, 5, 18, 379425) But that will involve the question of our being fit for it.

('15', 195, 2, 3, 379757) February 29, 1916
('15', 195, 3, 4, 379775) I am very grateful to the friends from Gujarat for the honour they have done me today.
('15', 195, 3, 5, 379862) Wherever I have gone, Gujaratis have welcomed me as they have done here.
('15', 195, 3, 6, 379935) They are more my neighbours—though all the people in the country are my neighbours— and I wish therefore to be of special service to them.
('15', 195, 3, 7, 380074) However, I must tour the whole of India and it would not be right for me, therefore, to stay in Gujarat all the time.
('15', 195, 3, 8, 380192) I have observed that Gujaratis have spread out as far as Calcutta, to the Madras as well as the Bengal Presidency for purposes of business.
('15', 195, 3, 9, 380332) Even in South Africa, the major part of the business community is from Gujarat.
('15', 195, 3, 10, 380412) In Karachi, the Gujarati population is much larger than at any of these places, so much so that, though the Sindhis are in a majority here, Karachi being a part of Sind, at first sight it might appear that the Gujarati population in the city was larger than the Sindhi.
('15', 195, 3, 11, 380682) There are three communities in Gujarat—Gujarati Hindus, Gujarati Parsis and Gujarati Muslims, and all these three have spread over different parts of the country, most of them for business.
('15', 195, 3, 12, 380872) It is not the right way for a business man merely to earn and lay by money and get rich anyhow by exploiting the poor.
('15', 195, 3, 13, 380991) In that way, even the Pindaris used to get wealthy by robbing people.
('15', 195, 3, 14, 381061) I see no difference between a man who cheats in business and one who slaps another and forces him to partwith his money.
('15', 195, 3, 15, 381182) Business men should follow truth in their business and not bear hard on people through their operations.
('15', 195, 3, 16, 381287) I don’t mean to suggest that this is what you do in your business.
('15', 195, 3, 17, 381354) Whenever you may have committed sins, you must have felt the fear of God as well and you must have done kindness, too, now and then.
('15', 195, 3, 18, 381487) It should be the chief aim of a business man to study this virtue of kindness.
('15', 195, 3, 19, 381566) Our education is no education if it only makes us physicians or lawyers.
('15', 195, 3, 20, 381639) We should try to develop our business.
('15', 195, 3, 21, 381678) One living example of this is provided by Sir Dorab 2 and Ratan Tata.
('15', 195, 3, 22, 381748) Sir Dorab does not educate any of his sons for the profession of a physician or a lawyer.
