('15', 202, 1, 2, 393201) 153. SPEECH AT GURUKUL ANNIVERSARY
('15', 202, 2, 3, 393236) March 20, 1916
('15', 202, 3, 4, 393251) The following is the text of Mr. Gandhi’s speech at the anniversary of the Gurukul, as written out by himself: I propose to reproduce only as much of it as in my opinion is worth placing on record with additions where they may be found necessary.
('15', 202, 3, 5, 393498) The speech, it may be observed, was delivered in Hindi.
('15', 202, 3, 6, 393554) After thanking Mahatmaji Munshi Ram for his great kindness to my boys to whom he gave shelter on two occasions and acted as father to them and after stating that the time for action had arrived rather than for speeches, I proceeded: I owe a debt of gratitude to the Arya Samaj.
('15', 202, 3, 7, 393832) I have often derived inspiration from its activity.
('15', 202, 3, 8, 393884) I have noticed among the members of the Samaj much self sacrifice.
('15', 202, 3, 9, 393951) During my travels in India, I came across many Arya Samajists who were doing excellent work for the country.
('15', 202, 3, 10, 394060) I am therefore grateful to Mahatmaji, that I am enabled to be in your midst.
('15', 202, 3, 11, 394137) At the same time, it is but fair to state that I am frankly a Sanatanist.
('15', 202, 3, 12, 394211) For me Hinduism is all sufficing.
('15', 202, 3, 13, 394245) Every variety of belief finds protection under its ample fold.
('15', 202, 3, 14, 394308) And though the Arya Samajists and the Sikhs and the Brahmo Samajists may choose to be classed differently from the Hindus, I have no doubt that at no distant future they will be all merged in Hinduism and find in it their fullness.
('15', 202, 3, 15, 394540) Hinduism, like every other human institution, has its drawbacks and its defects.
('15', 202, 3, 16, 394621) Here is ample scope for any worker to strive for reform, but there is little cause for secession.
('15', 202, 4, 17, 394719) SPIRIT OF FEARLESSNESS Throughout my travels, I have been asked about the immediate need for India.
('15', 202, 4, 18, 394819) And, perhaps, I would not do better than repeat this afternoon the answer I have given elsewhere.
('15', 202, 4, 19, 394917) In general terms, a proper religious spirit is the greatest and most immediate need.
('15', 202, 4, 20, 395002) But I know that this is too general an answer to satisfy anybody.
('15', 202, 4, 21, 395068) And it is an answer true for all time.
('15', 202, 4, 22, 395107) What, therefore, I desire to say is, that owing to the religious spirit being dormant in us, we are living in a state of perpetual fear.
('15', 202, 4, 23, 395244) We fear the temporal as well as the spiritual authority.
('15', 202, 4, 24, 395301) We dare not speak out our minds before our priests and our pandits.
('15', 202, 4, 25, 395369) We stand in awe of the temporal power.
('15', 202, 4, 26, 395408) I am sure that in so doing we do a disservice to them and us.
('15', 202, 4, 27, 395470) Neither the spiritual teachers nor our
('15', 203, 0, 1, 395509) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 203, 1, 2, 395551) political governors could possibly desire that we should hide the truth from them.
('15', 203, 1, 3, 395634) Lord Wellington, speaking to a Bombay audience, has been saying recently that he had observed that we hesitated to say ‘No’ when we really meant it and advised his audience to cultivate a fearless spirit.
('15', 203, 1, 4, 395839) Of course, fearlessness should never mean want of due respect or regard for the feelings of others.
('15', 203, 1, 5, 395939) In my humble opinion, fearlessness is the first thing indispensable before we could achieve anything permanent and real.
('15', 203, 1, 6, 396060) This quality is unattainable without religious consciousness.
('15', 203, 1, 7, 396122) Let us fear God and we shall cease to fear man.
('15', 203, 1, 8, 396170) If we grasp the fact that there is a divinity within us which witnesses everything we think or do and which protects us and guides us along the true path, it is clear that we shall cease to have any other fear on the face I if the earth, save the fear of God.
('15', 203, 1, 9, 396430) Loyalty to the Governor of governors supersedes all other loyalty and gives an intelligent basis to the latter.
('15', 203, 2, 10, 396542) MEANING OF SWADESHI
('15', 203, 3, 11, 396562) And when we have sufficiently cultivated this spirit of fearlessness, we shall see that there is no salvation for us without true swadeshi, not the swadeshi which can be conveniently put off.
('15', 203, 3, 12, 396754) Swadeshi for me has a deeper meaning.
('15', 203, 3, 13, 396792) I would like us to apply it in our religious, political and economic life.
('15', 203, 3, 14, 396867) It is not, therefore, merely confined to wearing on occasion swadeshi cloth.
('15', 203, 3, 15, 396944) That we have to do for all time, not out of a spirit of jealousy or revenge, but because it is a duty we owe to our dear country.
('15', 203, 3, 16, 397074) We commit a breach of the swadeshi spirit certainly if we wear foreign made cloth, but we do so also if we adopt the foreign cut.
('15', 203, 3, 17, 397204) Surely, the style of our dress has some correspondence with our environment.
('15', 203, 3, 18, 397281) In elegance and tastefulness, it is immeasurably superior to the trousers and the jacket.
('15', 203, 3, 19, 397371) An Indian, wearing a shirt flowing over his pyjamas with a waist coat on it without a necktie and its flaps hanging loose behind, is not a very graceful spectacle.
('15', 203, 3, 20, 397535) Swadeshi in religion teaches one to measure the glorious past and re enact it in the present generation.
('15', 203, 3, 21, 397640) The pandemonium that is going on in Europe shows that modern civilization represents forces of evil and darkness, whereas the ancient, i.
('15', 203, 3, 22, 397778) e., Indian, civilization represents in its essence the divine force.
('15', 203, 3, 23, 397847) Modern civilization is chiefly materialistic, as ours is chiefly spiritual.
('15', 203, 3, 24, 397923) Modern civilization occupies self in the investigation of the laws of matter, and employs human ingenuity in inventing of discovering means of production and weapons of destruction; ours is chiefly
('15', 204, 0, 1, 398121) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 205
('15', 204, 1, 2, 398163) occupied in exploring spiritual laws.
('15', 204, 1, 3, 398201) Our shastras lay down unequivocally that a proper observance of truth, chastity, scrupulous regard for all life, abstention from coveting others’ possessions and refusal to hoard anything but what is necessary for our daily wants is indispensable for a right life; that without it a knowledge of the divine element is an impossibility.
('15', 204, 1, 4, 398537) Our civilization tells us with daring certainty that a proper and perfect cultivation of the quality of ahimsa which, in its active form means purest love and pity, brings the whole world to our feet.
('15', 204, 1, 5, 398738) The author of this discovery gives a wealth of illustration which carries conviction with it.
('15', 204, 2, 6, 398832) THE DOCTRINE OF AHIMSA Examine its result in the political life.
('15', 204, 2, 7, 398897) There is no gift so valued by our shastras as the gift of life.
('15', 204, 2, 8, 398961) Consider what our relations would be with our rulers if we gave absolute security of life to them.
('15', 204, 2, 9, 399060) If they could but feel that, no matter what we might feel about their acts, we would hold their bodies as sacred as our own, there would immediately spring up an atmosphere of mutual trust, and there would be such frankness on either side as to pave the way for an honourable and just solution of many problems that worry us today.
('15', 204, 2, 10, 399392) It should be remembered that in practising ahimsa, there need not be any reciprocation, though, as a matter of fact, in its final stages, it commands reciprocation.
('15', 204, 2, 11, 399557) Many of us believe, and I am one of them, that through our civilization we have a message to deliver to the world.
('15', 204, 2, 12, 399672) I render my loyalty to the British Government quite selfishly.
('15', 204, 2, 13, 399735) I would like to use the British race for transmitting this mighty message of ahimsa to the whole world.
('15', 204, 2, 14, 399839) But that can only be done when we have conquered our so called conquerors; and you, my Arya Samaj friends, are perhaps specially elected for this mission.
('15', 204, 2, 15, 399994) You claim to examine our scriptures critically; you take nothing for granted and you claim not to fear to reduce your belief to practice.
('15', 204, 2, 16, 400132) I do not think that there is any room for trifling with or limiting the doctrine of ahimsa.
('15', 204, 2, 17, 400224) You dare, then, to reduce it to practice regardless of immediate consequences which would certainly test the strength of your convictions.
('15', 204, 2, 18, 400363) You would not only produce salvation for India, but you would render the noblest service that a man can render to humanity—a service moreover, which you would rightly assert the great Swami 1 was born for.
('15', 204, 2, 19, 400569) This swadeshi is to be considered as a very active force to be ceaselessly employed with an ever increasing
('15', 204, 3, 20, 400677) 1 Dayanand Saraswati
('15', 205, 0, 1, 400698) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 205, 1, 2, 400740) vigilance, searching self examination.
('15', 205, 1, 3, 400779) It is not meant for the lazy, but it is essentially meant for them who would gladly lay down their lives for the sake of truth.
('15', 205, 1, 4, 400907) It is possible to dilate upon several other phases of swadeshi, but I think I have said enough to enable you to understand what I mean.
('15', 205, 1, 5, 401043) I only hope that you, who represent a school of reformers in India, will not reject what 1 have said without thorough examination.
('15', 205, 1, 6, 401174) And, if my word has commended itself to you, your past record entitles me to expect you to enforce in your own lives the things of eternity about which I have ventured to speak to you this afternoon, and cover the whole of India with your activity.
('15', 205, 2, 7, 401423) WORK OF THE ARYA SAMAJ
('15', 205, 3, 8, 401446) In concluding my report of the above speech, I would like to state what I did not in speaking to that great audience and it is this.
('15', 205, 3, 9, 401579) I have now twice visited the Gurukul.
('15', 205, 3, 10, 401617) In spite of some vital difference with my brethren of the Arya Samaj, I have a sneaking regard for them, and it, and perhaps the best result of the activity of the Arya Samaj is to be seen in the establishment and the conduct of the Gurukul.
('15', 205, 3, 11, 401859) Though it depends for its vitality entirely upon the inspiring presence of Mahatmaji Munshi Ram, it is truly a national and self governing and self governed institution.
('15', 205, 3, 12, 402029) It is totally independent of Government aid or patronage.
('15', 205, 3, 13, 402087) Its war chest is filled not out of monies received from the privileged few, but from the poor many who make it a point of honour from year to year to make a pilgrimage to Kangri and willingly give their mite for maintaining this National College.
('15', 205, 3, 14, 402334) Here at every anniversary a huge crowd gathers and the manner in which it is handled, housed and fed evinces no mean power of organisation.
('15', 205, 3, 15, 402474) But the most wonderful thing about it all is that the crowd consisting of about the thousand men, women and children is managed without the assistance of a single policeman and without any fuss or semblance of force, the only force that subsists between the crowd and the managers of the institution is that of love and mutual esteem.
('15', 205, 3, 16, 402809) Fourteen years are nothing in the life of a big institution like this.
('15', 205, 3, 17, 402880) What the collegiates who have been just turned out during the last two or three years will be able to show, remains to be seen.
('15', 205, 3, 18, 403008) The public will not and cannot judge men or institutions except through the results that they show.
('15', 205, 3, 19, 403108) It makes no allowance for failures, it is a most exacting judge.
('15', 205, 3, 20, 403173) The final appeal of the Gurukul as of all popular institutions must be to this judge.
('15', 205, 3, 21, 403259) Great responsibility therefore rests upon the shoulders of the students who have been discharged from
('15', 206, 0, 1, 403361) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 207
('15', 206, 1, 2, 403403) the college and who have entered upon the thorny path of life.
('15', 206, 1, 3, 403466) Let them beware.
('15', 206, 1, 4, 403483) Meanwhile hose who are well wishers of this great experiment may derive satisfaction from the fact that we have it as an indisputable rule of life, that as the tree is, so will the fruit be.
('15', 206, 1, 5, 403674) The tree looks lovely enough.
('15', 206, 1, 6, 403704) He who waters it is a noble soul.
('15', 206, 1, 7, 403738) Why worry about what the fruit is likely to be?
('15', 206, 2, 8, 403786) INDUSTRIAL TRAINING
('15', 206, 3, 9, 403806) As a lover of the Gurukul, I may be permitted to offer one or two suggestions to the Committee and the parents.
('15', 206, 3, 10, 403918) The Gurukul boys need a thorough industrial training if they are to become self reliant and self supporting.
('15', 206, 3, 11, 404027) It seems to me that in our country in which 85 per cent of the population is agricultural and perhaps 10 per cent occupied in supplying the wants of the peasantry, it must be part of the training of every youth that he has a fair practical knowledge of agriculture and hand weaving.
('15', 206, 3, 12, 404310) He will lose nothing if he knows a proper use of tools, can saw a piece of board straight and build a wall that will not come down through a faulty handling of the plumber’s line.
('15', 206, 3, 13, 404490) A boy who is thus equipped will never feel helpless in battling with the world and never be in want of employment.
('15', 206, 3, 14, 404605) A knowledge of the laws of hygiene and sanitation as well as the art of rearing children should also form a necessary part of [the training of] the Gurukul lads.
('15', 206, 3, 15, 404767) The sanitary arrangements at the fair left much to be desired.
('15', 206, 3, 16, 404830) The plague of flies told its own tale.
('15', 206, 3, 17, 404869) These irrepressible sanitary inspectors incessantly warned us that in point of sanitation all was not well with us.
('15', 206, 3, 18, 404985) They plainly suggested that the remains of our food and excreta needed to be properly buried.
('15', 206, 3, 19, 405079) It seemed to me to be such a pity that a golden opportunity was being missed of giving to the annual visitors practical lessons on sanitation.
('15', 206, 3, 20, 405222) But the work must begin with the boys.
('15', 206, 3, 21, 405261) Then the management would have at the annual gathering three hundred practical sanitary teachers.
('15', 206, 3, 22, 405359) Last but not least, let the parents and the Committee not spoil their lads by making them ape European dress or modern luxuries.
('15', 206, 3, 23, 405488) These will hinder them in their afterlife and are antagonistic to brahmacharya.
('15', 206, 3, 24, 405568) They have enough to fight against in the evil inclinations common to us all.
('15', 206, 3, 25, 405645) Let us not make their fight more difficult by adding to their temptations.
('15', 206, 4, 26, 405720) Speeches and Writings of Mahatma Gandhi (4th Ed.), pp.

('15', 207, 1, 2, 405817) 154. SPEECH AT HARDWAR
('15', 207, 2, 3, 405840) March 23, 1916
('15', 207, 3, 4, 405855) The Dayanand Anglo Vedic School boys were taken to the Arya Samaj hall in the evening and Mr. Gandhi addressed them for a short time only as he was feeling unwell.
('15', 207, 4, 5, 406019) He exhorted the audience to have the courage of their convictions, and in copying or imitating those who directed or ruled, not to be guided by outward show, such as styles, dress, or by customs, such as meat eating.
('15', 207, 4, 6, 406236) He exhorted them to be true to themselves and then they would be true to India.

('15', 209, 2, 3, 408683) FROM M.K. GANDHI AHMEDABAD, April 1 [1916] 1
('15', 209, 3, 4, 408728) MY DEAR FRIEND, I am at last in Ahmedabad, for some weeks at any rate.Your things are now being collected.
('15', 209, 3, 5, 408835) The next mail you should receive them.
('15', 209, 3, 6, 408874) I am trying to manufacture biscuits without an oven.
('15', 209, 3, 7, 408927) You will like them.
('15', 209, 3, 8, 408947) I never previous to the letter under reply received any letter regarding your things.
('15', 209, 3, 9, 409033) I never received the wooden pillow you have referred to in several letters of yours.
('15', 209, 3, 10, 409118) During the week I resolved not to admit to the Ashram for one year anyone either young or old.
('15', 209, 3, 11, 409213) Newcomers have taxed me too much and they have disturbed the ever tenor of the life of the Ashram.
('15', 209, 3, 12, 409312) I know you would have, had you been here, long ago pushed me to this decision.
('15', 209, 3, 13, 409391) However, I have come to it after bitter experience.
('15', 209, 3, 14, 409443) We are now exactly 30, young and old.
('15', 209, 3, 15, 409481) Of these Maganlal and Jamnadas are in Madras training in Tamil and hand weaving.
('15', 209, 3, 16, 409562) Jamnadas’s wife is also learning hand weaving.
('15', 209, 3, 17, 409609) The Pariah member’s wife having proved untrustworthy has left the Ashram.
('15', 209, 3, 18, 409683) During the travels just completed, I went to a place called Dehradun.
('15', 209, 3, 19, 409753) It is at the base of the Himalayas.
('15', 209, 3, 20, 409789) You will love the place.
('15', 209, 3, 21, 409814) The air is bracing and there are so many walks to the Himalayan hills.
('15', 209, 3, 22, 409885) Of course I was there only for a day but was able to know much about the place.
('15', 209, 3, 23, 409965) Ramdas, Prabhudas and Devdas were with me.
('15', 209, 3, 24, 410008) Have I told you that I have just begun to take cooked food?
('15', 209, 3, 25, 410068) The price of fruitarian food is prohibitive here and one cannot get even dates and monkey nuts at certain places for love or money.
('15', 209, 3, 26, 410200) This is a sad discovery.
('15', 209, 3, 27, 410225) It tells its own tale.
('15', 209, 3, 28, 410248) It is there however and one has to put up with it.
('15', 209, 3, 29, 410299) This is the 6th day of cooked food.
('15', 209, 3, 30, 410335) I take rice and dholl, a vegetable and a lemon.
('15', 209, 3, 31, 410383) This makes 4 articles.
('15', 209, 3, 32, 410406) Today I am

('15', 212, 7, 12, 414067) 159. SPEECH AT CONDOLENCE MEETING, AHMEDABAD 2
('15', 212, 8, 13, 414114) April 16, 1916 Mr. Patil was one of the ornaments of Ahmedabad.
('15', 212, 8, 14, 414178) If Ahmedabad had appreciated this, the people would have filled this hall to crowding.
('15', 212, 8, 15, 414265) When I received the invitation to settle in Ahmedabad, leaving Bombay, one of my friends assured me that, Mr. Patil being one of the signatories to the invitation, it was safe to accept it.
('15', 212, 8, 16, 414455) This showed that Mr. Patil was true to his word and modest as well.
('15', 212, 8, 17, 414523) Next, as for the premature death of Mr. Patil, I would suggest that we should inquire 3 why political leaders die at an early age.
('15', 212, 8, 18, 414654) In my opinion, such deaths are due to their neglecting their health.
('15', 212, 9, 19, 414723) [From Gujarati] Prajabandhu, 23 4 1916
('15', 212, 10, 20, 414762) 1 The addressee, editor of The Comrade, had been interned in October, 1914, along with his brother, Shaukat Ali, for publishing an article entitled “Evacuate Egypt”.
('15', 212, 10, 21, 414928) 2 On the death of Govindrao Appaji Patil, a lawyer and social worker 3 Vide the following item.
('15', 213, 0, 1, 415024) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 213, 1, 2, 415066) 160. LETTER TO “PRAJABANDHU” 1
('15', 213, 2, 3, 415097) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, AHMEDABAD, Chaitra Vad 2, Thursday, April 20, 1916
('15', 213, 3, 4, 415167) THE EDITOR, PRAJABANDHU
('15', 213, 4, 5, 415191) SIR, I write this hoping that you will permit me to place before your readers some of the many reflections which have occurred to me, and still occur, by reason of Bhai Govindrao Appaji Patil’s death at a premature age.
('15', 213, 4, 6, 415411) I have purposely used the adjective ‘premature’ to denote the age of the deceased.
('15', 213, 4, 7, 415494) Any age below 50 should be considered premature, and Bhai Govindrao died before he was 50. It is a matter of no small grief that the untimely death of our first leaders deprives us of the benefit of their ripest years.
('15', 213, 4, 8, 415713) It seems we suffer from a kindof vanity.
('15', 213, 4, 9, 415754) We and our leaders seem to believe that there is some virtue in remaining more or less ailing and, accordingly, if the leaders leave us in their premature age, we see an especial virtue in the fact.
('15', 213, 4, 10, 415953) I think our leaders, and others too, but particularly our leaders, should consider it a sin to be taken ill or to remain ill, even if illness should come to them while serving the public.
('15', 213, 4, 11, 416141) If we go over all such cases among the leaders, right from the late Justice Telang 2 down to Bhai Govindrao we shall find that the illness of many of them was such as could have been prevented.
('15', 213, 4, 12, 416335) It is the duty of every one of us, especially of our leaders, to know how to maintain sound health.
('15', 213, 4, 13, 416435) I know from experience that we ourselves, in many cases, sow the seeds of premature death in our very childhood and, in some measure, our parents do this for us out of their ignorance and inordinate affection.
('15', 213, 4, 14, 416645) We generally depart from physical brahma charya, through marriage, or even otherwise, right in our childhood.
('15', 213, 4, 15, 416755) We choose many articles of food merely for their taste or only for the purpose of putting on fat.
('15', 213, 4, 16, 416853) The diet of those who have to use mental
('15', 213, 5, 17, 416894) 1 Published under the caption, “Why Do We Die Prematurely?” 2 Of the Bombay High Court, one of the founders of the Indian National Congress
('15', 214, 0, 1, 417034) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 215
('15', 214, 1, 2, 417076) energy and who lead a sedentary life should differ in its composition from that of others.
('15', 214, 1, 3, 417167) As a matter of fact, the diet of such people is seldom chosen in the light of this consideration.
('15', 214, 1, 4, 417265) I believe that, in a climate like that of Ahmedabad, excessive use of ghee is sure to damage the health of those who work only with the brain.
('15', 214, 1, 5, 417408) They should use pulses in very small quantities.
('15', 214, 1, 6, 417457) Those who have to do physical labour cannot do without a liberal use of pulses, but to others who do little physical work, too much of pulses will be like poison.
('15', 214, 1, 7, 417620) Almost all students complain of constipation, the reason being that they have in their diet an excessive quantity of spices, pulses and such other things, which are bound to lead to constipation.
('15', 214, 1, 8, 417816) They then damage their stomach by taking castor oil, Epsom salt or fruit salt, and ultimately fall a prey to death.
('15', 214, 1, 9, 417932) Our normal diet does not contain the vitamins which fresh fruits provide.
('15', 214, 1, 10, 418006) If we regularly ate fresh fruits in place of the usual diet, on a particular day of the week, constipation would disappear and our blood would become pure.
('15', 214, 1, 11, 418162) I do not suggest that a major change should be introduced in our diet at once.
('15', 214, 1, 12, 418241) I realize that our people would not agree to do so.
('15', 214, 1, 13, 418293) But they can, in order to ensure good health, reduce the quantity of spices, make a cautious use of pulses and begin taking fruits, etc.
('15', 214, 1, 14, 418430) It cannot be arguedthat this will require any very strenuous efforts.
('15', 214, 1, 15, 418500) The habit of taking tea or cocoa is really very dangerous.
('15', 214, 1, 16, 418559) I think those who insist on having tea would do well to study what the people of the tea drinking countries do and how they prepare tea.
('15', 214, 1, 17, 418696) But we have made no such study.
('15', 214, 1, 18, 418728) I do not know if people elsewhere consume all the tannin in tea, as we do here.
('15', 214, 1, 19, 418808) The Chinese do not allow tea leaves to remain in boiling water for more than half a minute; they strain the tea soon after adding the leaves.
('15', 214, 1, 20, 418950) The colour of the mixture would show that very little tannin had been absorbed in the water.
('15', 214, 1, 21, 419043) It should not be allowed to become more yellow than blades of hay, and never reddish in any case.
('15', 214, 1, 22, 419141) This is the kind of tea which millions of Chinese drink.
('15', 214, 1, 23, 419198) They never use milk in their tea.
('15', 214, 1, 24, 419232) They do not know what it is to milk cows.
('15', 214, 1, 25, 419274) They rarely use sugar in their tea.
('15', 214, 1, 26, 419310) If at all tea can be prepared so as to cause no harm, this is the way.
('15', 214, 1, 27, 419381) Here is what a man, highly experienced and famous, Doctor Cantlie by name, has to say.
('15', 214, 1, 28, 419468) He believes that the Chinese take tea because it is the easiest way of drinking pure water.
('15', 214, 1, 29, 419560) Below the boiling point, water cannot absorb the colour of tea, and so they take tea in place of simple water; that is, they use water which has been tested [for its temperature].
('15', 214, 1, 30, 419740) We are as careless about exercise as about diet.
('15', 214, 1, 31, 419789) To stroll one or
('15', 215, 0, 1, 419806) 216 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 215, 1, 2, 419848) two miles at a leisurely pace is no exercise.
('15', 215, 1, 3, 419894) To hit a billiard ball one or two hundred times with a cue is also no exercise.
('15', 215, 1, 4, 419974) When exercise is taken in this manner in a room with foul smelling air, the effect is bound to be harmful.
('15', 215, 1, 5, 420081) In our predicament, when no other form of exercise is convenient, walking is the best exercise.
('15', 215, 1, 6, 420177) But exercise is worth the name only if one can walk six miles at a stretch in the morning and again in the evening.
('15', 215, 1, 7, 420293) The walking should be done briskly, at a speed of four miles an hour.
('15', 215, 1, 8, 420363) Thoreau used to walk for eight hours daily when he wrote his best book.
('15', 215, 1, 9, 420435) Tolstoy testifies to the fact that while writing his best books he never used to sit at his desk before he had had plenty of exercise.
('15', 215, 1, 10, 420570) He always used to work on a farm.
('15', 215, 1, 11, 420604) [Some people say:] ‘We cannot spare a minute from the lients’ work or from public work, and take exercise.” Such talk is s heer vanity.
('15', 215, 1, 12, 420740) It would seem to proceed from a belief that but for us public work would go to the dogs.
('15', 215, 1, 13, 420829) The Grand Old Man of India, Dadabhai 1, has been observing all the general rules of hygiene and has never departed from his routine of exercise, etc.
('15', 215, 1, 14, 420979) Hence, we see him alive to this day, and it would be in no way surprising if this rishi were to live a hundred years like those of old times.
('15', 215, 1, 15, 421121) We violate one of the precepts of the Gita and suffer dire consequences.
('15', 215, 1, 16, 421194) It says that a person who eats without performing yajna is a thief; 2 the true meaning of yajna here is physical labour on a farm.
('15', 215, 1, 17, 421325) If we would make it a rule to work hard, to work, that is, with a shovel for four hours every day in a field, for the purpose of digesting our food, and would observe other rules [of hygiene], premature deaths might be far fewer among us.
('15', 215, 1, 18, 421564) When we begin to feel ashamed of falling ill, we shall undoubtedly acquire good health.
('15', 215, 1, 19, 421652) In my humble opinion it is the person, whether man or woman, that has discovered, by experiments, the rules to be followed in order to preserve his or her health even while engaged in public work, who can render any great service to the country.

('15', 218, 8, 11, 425559) 164. SPEECH AT BELGAUM
('15', 218, 9, 12, 425582) April 30, 1916
('15', 218, 10, 13, 425597) A large gathering of people (about 1,000) assembled in Khotibis Wada in Raviwar Peth, Belgaum, on the night of the 30th of April, to hear Mr. M. K. Gandhi speak on the subject of “The Depressed Classes”.
('15', 218, 10, 14, 425801) The audience was mainly composed of Lingayats and “Untouchables”.
('15', 218, 10, 15, 425867) R. S. Shivmurti Swami Kanabargi presided.
('15', 218, 11, 16, 425909) Mr. Gandhi then rose and said that as he was ill, he would only speak to them for a minute.
('15', 218, 11, 17, 426001) He deprecated their opposition to the holding of the Provincial Conference in Belgaum.
('15', 218, 11, 18, 426088) The principal object for the holding of the Conference was to effect a reconciliation between the two political parties.
('15', 218, 11, 19, 426209) 4 Home Rule must be granted to India and all classes should present a united front in demanding it.
('15', 218, 11, 20, 426309) If Home Rule should be granted, no particular class would dominate, otherwise it would not be Home Rule.
('15', 218, 11, 21, 426414) He for one would oppose any party or class that wanted to set itself above the others.
('15', 218, 11, 22, 426501) He made no distinction between the higher and the lower classes and did not look with disdain upon a man simply because he was a sweeper or a barber, nor did
('15', 218, 12, 23, 426659) 1 A political worker of Karnatak, popularly known as “Lion of Karnatak 2 Gandhiji arrived in Belgaum on April 29 to attend the Bombay Provincial Conference.
('15', 218, 12, 24, 426816) 3 Gandhiji had accepted the invitation to attend the Conference but later on there were rumours that he might not attend it.

('15', 219, 1, 4, 427215) Home Rule would not be granted so long as there were differences between them.

('15', 219, 3, 7, 427393) 165. SPEECH AT BOMBAY PROVINCIAL CONFERENCE AT BELGAUM 1
('15', 219, 4, 8, 427450) May 1, 1916
('15', 219, 5, 9, 427462) Mr. Gandhi spoke as follows in Hindustani....
('15', 219, 5, 10, 427508) He was an outsider in the sense that he was not a member of the nationalist party or for that matter of any party.
('15', 219, 5, 11, 427623) He had no mental desire for listening to the speeches or to his own voice but he had felt it his duty as an aspirant for national service to study all the institutions he could and hence it was that he found himself at the Belgaum Conference.
('15', 219, 5, 12, 427866) He was desirous of being present there as he was anxious to see the inauguration of an era of peace between the two great parties which, he was assured, would take place at Belgaum.
('15', 219, 5, 13, 428048) It was a matter to him, therefore, of great pleasure that the foundation for unity was being laid at the Conference.
('15', 219, 5, 14, 428165) He heartily supported the resolution 2 moved by Mr. Tilak.
('15', 219, 5, 15, 428224) He was sure he was not expected to endorse every word of the resolution on the report that was adopted.
('15', 219, 5, 16, 428328) It should be enough that he found himself in agreement with the main draft of the resolution.
('15', 219, 5, 17, 428422) Had the wording of the resolution been in his own hand, he would probably have omitted some expressions.
('15', 219, 5, 18, 428527) Mr. Tilak’s speech left nothing to be desired and he if worked as he was sure he would, and the nationalist party as a whole also worked truly in the spirit of the resolution and Mr.
('15', 219, 6, 19, 428710) 1 This Conference, held from 29th April to 1st May, was attended by leading Nationalists from Bombay, C.P. and Berar and was held after the Poona meeting of January 16, 1916, which had postponed settlement of the question of limitation on the number of delegates from political bodies of two years’ standing which had received automatic affiliation after the amendment of the Congress constitution in 1915. 2 Tilak’s resolution, carried unanimously, read as follows: “That this conference adopts the reports of Messrs Belvi, Baptista and Tilak, and as in the interest of our Motherland under the present circumstances it is desirable to unite, resolves to accept, the constitution of the Congress as amended at its last sessions, though the amendment is highly unsatisfactory, and appoints a Committee composed of the following gentlemen, to do further work from within: G. S. Khaparde, J. Baptista, D. V. Belvi, B. G. Tilak and N. C. Kelkar (Secretary).” Vide Source Material for a History of the Freedom Movement in India (Bombay Government),”Letter to F.S. ('15', 220, 1, 2, 429837) Tilak’s remarks, he was sure that the coming union would be a great blessing to the motherland.
('15', 220, 1, 3, 429933) It was for that reason that he found himself in disagreement with Mr. Baptista, who seemed to be so much in tune with the pleaders.

('15', 224, 1, 2, 436008) 170. SPEECH AT CONFERENCE OF COMMUNITIES AHMEDABAD 1
('15', 224, 2, 3, 436061) June 4, 1916
('15', 224, 3, 4, 436074) I am tired of conferences and speeches and now of hearing my own voice as well.
('15', 224, 3, 5, 436154) When Lord Buddha decided to work for the emancipation of the world, he did not convene a conference and get it to pass resolutions.
('15', 224, 3, 6, 436286) Nor did Jesus Christ do anything of the sort.
('15', 224, 3, 7, 436332) But not being blessed with such greatness, we convene such conferences because, I think I am right in this, we lack the requisite strength for our work.
('15', 224, 3, 8, 436485) This happens all over the country; and so I don’t say that yours is the only instance.
('15', 224, 3, 9, 436572) There is something novel about the origin of this conference and its procedure of work.
('15', 224, 3, 10, 436660) I believe at the same time that it does serve a useful purpose.
('15', 224, 3, 11, 436724) The work here is not done through long speeches.
('15', 224, 3, 12, 436773) I am glad to see that everyone speaks to the point and keeps himself to the subject.
('15', 224, 3, 13, 436858) We must have formed the habit of speaking briefly and to the point through the business atmosphere of Gujarat.
('15', 224, 3, 14, 436969) In the changes taking place today in our communities, we have observed [their] rise and fall through their own actions and deserts.
('15', 224, 3, 15, 437101) Champaneri Banias were once Vaniks 2; then by vocation they became Ghanchis 3. In the caste set up of India, it is in no way impossible that through better education and economic advance they may again become Vaniks or attain even a higher status, or that they may be degraded to a level lower than that of Ghanchi.
('15', 224, 3, 16, 437417) Our sin in despising the Antyajas 4 degrades the entire Hindu society.
('15', 224, 3, 17, 437488) Dhulabhai 5 Dhed, who stays with me and who has accompanied me here, once asked a woman for some water.

('15', 224, 4, 22, 437804) 1 At the Conference of Friendly Associations of Communities 2 Members of a Hindu caste traditionally engaged in trade, commerce and banking 3 Those who make and sell seed oils 4 Lowest caste among Hindus traditionally charged with sanitary duties 5 Probably a misprint for Dudabhai, who had joined the Ashram on September 26, 1915; vide “Diary for 1915”

('15', 226, 1, 3, 440595) Certainly, there is a difference between varnavyavastha in the West and among us; but there is varnavyavastha everywhere, all the same.
('15', 226, 1, 4, 440731) So long as there are among human beings impulses which tend to a godly life and those which tend to a demoniac life, so long will the division of society into communities remain.
('15', 226, 1, 5, 440910) It is a vain effort to replace this structure by one single community.
('15', 226, 1, 6, 440981) Communities, too, may be born and may die.
('15', 226, 1, 7, 441024) Mr. Lyall has affirmed in a book of his not only that among Hindus communities have made their appearance and died out, but also that, while outsiders may have joined the Hindu fold, there is no evidence that the Hindu society converted others to the Hindu faith as Christians did to theirs.
('15', 226, 1, 8, 441316) Members of non Hindu faiths and sects became Hindus in course of time.

('15', 229, 4, 32, 448371) 175. SPEECH AGAINST PRESS ACT 1
('15', 229, 5, 33, 448403) June 24, 1916
('15', 229, 6, 34, 448417) A public meeting of the citizens of Bombay was held in the Empire Theatre on the evening of Saturday, the 24th June 1916, ‘to uphold the liberty of the Press and protest against the Press Act of 1910’, under the auspices of the ‘Indian Press Association’.
('15', 229, 6, 35, 448673) Mr. B. G. Horniman, Editor of the Bombay Chronicle, presided.
('15', 229, 7, 36, 448735) 1 A brief report of this appeared in The Bombay Chronicle, 26 6 1916.
('15', 230, 0, 1, 448805) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 231
('15', 230, 1, 2, 448847) It was a very largely attended meeting.
('15', 230, 1, 3, 448887) There were not a few Hindu— Deccani and Gujarati—ladies among the audience.
('15', 230, 1, 4, 448963) Principal among them was the wife of the Honourable Mr. Chimanlal Setalvad with her daughters and daughters in law.
('15', 230, 2, 5, 449079) Messrs Gandhi, Horniman and Jamnadas D. Dharamsey were received on arrival with loud cheers.
('15', 230, 2, 6, 449172) In the case of Mr. Gandhi cheers were called for ‘once more’ by an occupant of one of the upper galleries.
('15', 230, 2, 7, 449279) Mr. Gandhi delivered his address in Gujarati, urging that that was the true way of being faithful to his motherland.
('15', 230, 3, 8, 449396) Mr. Gandhi said:
('15', 230, 4, 9, 449413) MR. PRESIDENT, DEAR SISTERS AND BROTHERS, I see that in this hall there are several persons laughing, because I have commenced to speak in Gujarati.
('15', 230, 4, 10, 449562) (Laughter.) You see we want to have swaraj; and when we get it, I am sure you will agree with me that we ought to carry on our business in the Gujarati tongue.
('15', 230, 4, 11, 449722) (Laughter.) Crores and crores of our people for whom the swaraj will have to be carried on, it is impossible to deal with in English, to which they are quite foreign.
('15', 230, 4, 12, 449889) It is undoubtedly the fact that in this assembly we have to speak to a majority of English speaking people, and to them I beg to tender an apology for venturing to address the meeting in my own native tongue.
('15', 230, 4, 13, 450098) (Laughter.) It may be said that besides those who know English in this hall, there are not a few who speak Marathi.
('15', 230, 4, 14, 450214) I know that there are those who speak that language, but to them I would respectfully say that hereafter they should learn the Gujarati language, so that when they have occasion to hear my Gujarati speech, they will be able to follow me somehow or other.
('15', 230, 4, 15, 450469) (Laughter.) The resolution that is placed in my hands runs thus: That this meeting of loyal and law abiding Indian subjects of His Majesty the King Emperor, believing the existence of a free public Press to be one of the first essentials of a healthy and progressive State and necessary to the proper development, political and moral, of civilized peoples; and further that the extension and maintenance of freedom in all departments of public life is the surest guarantee of popular progress and contentment and of mutual trust between the Government and the people, asks that the Press in this country should enjoy the utmost liberty of expression, subject to the legal restraints of the ordinary law and of penalties inflicted only after proper trial and conviction.
('15', 230, 4, 16, 451239) (Cheers.)
('15', 230, 5, 17, 451249) (Mr. Gandhi explained the resolution in Gujarati.) Up to now, this Press Act was considered to be innocent and
('15', 231, 0, 1, 451360) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 231, 1, 2, 451402) innocuous, so far as the high class journalists were concerned; in fact, that was the promise given by the Government at the time when this law was passed to the elected members of the Legislative Council of His Excellency the Viceroy and Governor General.
('15', 231, 1, 3, 451659) Those members accepted the enactment under that promise.
('15', 231, 1, 4, 451716) They were assured thatthe law would be made operative against only offending journalists.
('15', 231, 1, 5, 451806) But from what has now happened in the case of New India, it may be said that the promise was illusory.

('15', 233, 6, 13, 457264) He will not help.
('15', 233, 6, 14, 457282) Indenture system has to go because it is bad in itself and is a remnant of slavery.
('15', 233, 6, 15, 457366) If it can be done away with today, it should be without considering any interest whatsoever.

('15', 233, 10, 18, 457555) 177. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('15', 233, 11, 19, 457589) FROM M. K. GANDHI AHMEDABAD, July 24, 1916
('15', 233, 12, 20, 457632) MY DEAR FRIEND, The wooden pillow you describe never reached me.
('15', 233, 12, 21, 457697) I am asking Dr. Jivraj Mehta.
('15', 233, 12, 22, 457727) All of us appreciated the portrait of yourself and companions you have sent.
('15', 233, 12, 23, 457804) We all think that you are looking well.
('15', 233, 12, 24, 457844) But I know that you are not mentally as happy as you ought to be.
('15', 233, 12, 25, 457910) I have been reading Pilgrim’s Progress to the boys.
('15', 233, 12, 26, 457962) Christian and Hopeful are in the grip of Giant Despair.
('15', 233, 12, 27, 458018) The latter suggests to them suicide.
('15', 233, 12, 28, 458055) Christian half succumbs to the suggestion.
('15', 233, 12, 29, 458098) Hopeful strenuously fights against it and argues that when we find ourselves in a tight corner, we should think of those who might be in a still tighter [one].
('15', 233, 12, 30, 458258) The argument is good.
('15', 233, 12, 31, 458280) There are millions in a much worse condition than you are in.
('15', 233, 12, 32, 458342) And then, after all, happiness is a mental state.
('15', 233, 12, 33, 458392) And no one
('15', 234, 0, 1, 458403) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 235
('15', 234, 1, 2, 458445) but ourselves can control that state.
('15', 234, 1, 3, 458483) In the midst of plenty a man may be most miserable and another amid penury may be as happy as the smiling sun.
('15', 234, 1, 4, 458594) Why worry about your South Africa affairs?
('15', 234, 1, 5, 458637) After all you were ready to let them go.
('15', 234, 1, 6, 458678) Let them go.
('15', 234, 1, 7, 458691) So much the less burden.

('15', 234, 1, 9, 458761) When the restraint is removed, you will come to the Ashram and bring with you a pair of sturdy hand and feet.

('15', 234, 4, 16, 459125) 178. RAILWAY PASSENGERS 1
('15', 234, 5, 17, 459151) [Before July 26, 1916] 2
('15', 234, 6, 18, 459176) No one doubts that railway passengers are put to many hardships.
('15', 234, 6, 19, 459241) Against many of these, we have the remedy in our own hands.
('15', 234, 6, 20, 459301) Unity is in the air all over India.
('15', 234, 6, 21, 459337) If we did no more than resort to this, quite a few of the hardships could be overcome.
('15', 234, 6, 22, 459424) This article makes some suggestions on how they could be.
('15', 234, 6, 23, 459482) Those into whose hands this may fall are requested to read it carefully and afterwards to read it out to others who cannot read.
('15', 234, 6, 24, 459611) The reader will easily guess that the cost of paper and printing must have been met by someone with a public spirit and, in view of that at any rate, he will realize that the article should not be treated lightly merely because he has got it free.
('15', 234, 6, 25, 459859) To the authorities, I shall say: If you are a station master, you can remove many of the hardships of passengers.
('15', 234, 6, 26, 459973) Using courtesy in your dealings with poor passengers, you set an example to your subordinates.
('15', 234, 6, 27, 460068) If you are a ticket collector, with a little reflection you will realize that the poor should receive the same time and attention that
('15', 234, 7, 28, 460203) 1 This was published as a pamphlet and distributed gratis in Gujarat during 1916 17. 2 A summary of this pamphlet appeared in Kathiawar Times, 26 7 1916.
('15', 235, 0, 1, 460357) 236 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 235, 1, 2, 460399) you give to first and second class passengers.
('15', 235, 1, 3, 460446) The railways depend on the poor for their existence and you owe your salaries largely to the money received from them.
('15', 235, 1, 4, 460565) Some booking clerks abuse the poor, address them slightingly, and on top of that delay issuing tickets to them as long as they can.
('15', 235, 1, 5, 460697) This is no way of showing one’s importance.
('15', 235, 1, 6, 460741) Issuing a ticket without delay to anyone asking for it saves the latter’s time and you lose nothing by doing so.
('15', 235, 1, 7, 460854) If you are a policeman, you should refrain from accepting bribes, resolve not to shove the poor people about but behave towards them with kindness.
('15', 235, 1, 8, 461002) You should understand that you are servants of the people and not their masters.
('15', 235, 1, 9, 461083) It is your duty to help them out of their difficulties.
('15', 235, 1, 10, 461139) That you should yourself become the cause of difficulties is sheer injustice.
('15', 235, 1, 11, 461217) To educated passengers, I shall say: Most of you like showing that you are educated and that you have some patriotism in you.
('15', 235, 1, 12, 461343) If you use your patriotism in doing good to the illiterate and poor passengers with whom you come into contact, you will be doing national service without having to search for an occasion.
('15', 235, 1, 13, 461532) For instance, if a passenger is being ill treated, you can help him in a number of ways, Even if you do not generally travel third class, your doing so occasionally just to get experience is likely to benefit the third class passengers very much.
('15', 235, 1, 14, 461779) If you go in their midst, without disclosing your status, for purchasing tickets, etc., it will be easy for you to find a remedy for the difficulties you will experience in the process and the facilities offered to you will be available before long to the people at large.
('15', 235, 1, 15, 462052) Sometimes educated people themselves become the cause of injustice to third class passengers.
('15', 235, 1, 16, 462146) They are impatient to get their tickets first, may enjoy special facilities in trains and occupy more space than they need; the poor are put to difficulties in consequence.
('15', 235, 1, 17, 462319) The educated class must certainly refrain from making itself a cause of injustice in this manner, if it can do nothing else.
('15', 235, 1, 18, 462444) It is your duty to write to the authorities about any deficiencies that you may observe on stations or trains.
('15', 235, 1, 19, 462555) To passengers in general, I shall say: No matter what category of passengers you belong to, educated
('15', 236, 0, 1, 462656) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 237
('15', 236, 1, 2, 462698) or uneducated, rich or poor, if you bear in mind the following suggestions, 75 per cent of the hardships of passengers will disappear in a moment: 1. You will lose nothing, and others will gain through your restraint, if, instead of pushing yourself forward when getting to the platform or boarding the train, you don’t mind being the last and act accordingly.
('15', 236, 1, 3, 463059) 2. Having taken your seat in the train, you should know that, up to the number indicated, others have as much right to a seat [in the compartment] as you.
('15', 236, 1, 4, 463214) Hence, if you stop others from entering, you will violate the moral law through falsehood and will also break a Railway regulation.
('15', 236, 1, 5, 463346) 3. If you have with you only as much luggage as third class passengers are entitled to carry, others will be able to sit in comfort.
('15', 236, 1, 6, 463479) If you can afford to carry more luggage, you had better put the excess in the luggage van and pay the additional charge.
('15', 236, 1, 7, 463600) 4. Your luggage should be of a kind that can be easily stowed away under a bench or placed on the shelf.
('15', 236, 1, 8, 463705) 5. If you are well to do and have no philanthropic intentions, you should seek your comfort by purchasing an upper class ticket.
('15', 236, 1, 9, 463834) By purchasing a third class ticket out of sheer miserliness, you will make yourself a burden on the poor.
('15', 236, 1, 10, 463940) But even if you do not want to travel upper class, you should certainly not use your funds so as to make your luggage and yourself a nuisance to your fellow passengers.
('15', 236, 1, 11, 464109) 6. You should bear in mind that all long distance passengers are entitled to some facility for sleeping; you can have, therefore, no more than your share of sleep.
('15', 236, 1, 12, 464273) 7. If you are a smoker, you should consider that, being in a train, you can smoke only with others’ permission and so as not to inconvenience them.
('15', 236, 1, 13, 464421) 8. If, when you want to spit, you do so where the passengers rest their feet, the place will become extremely dirty and there is a risk of one contracting some disease; those other passengers, moreover, who are particular about rules of cleanliness will find your dirty habit intolerably painful.
('15', 236, 1, 14, 464718) 9. If you use the railway lavatories with due care, everyone will be the happier for that.
('15', 236, 1, 15, 464809) In using them carelessly, you take no thought of the passengers who may follow you.
('15', 237, 0, 1, 464893) 238 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 237, 1, 2, 464935) 10. Instead of making distinctions when you travel, such as that you are a brahmin or a Vaisya or a Sudra and someone else belongs to another class or that you are a Hindu and another a Muslim, or that you are from Bombay Presidency and another from Madras Presidency, and creating ill will in consequence, if you think of all as children of India who have for the once assembled under one roof, and cherish a brotherly feeling for all, you will be happy this very moment and bring glory to India.
('15', 237, 2, 3, 465433) [From Gujarati]
('15', 237, 3, 4, 465449) Mahatma Gandhini Vicharsrishti
('15', 237, 4, 5, 465480) 179. SPEECH ON ‘THE SECRET OF SATYAGRAHA IN SOUTH AFRICA’ 1
('15', 237, 5, 6, 465540) July 27, 1916
('15', 237, 6, 7, 465554) In brief, the significance of satyagraha consists in the quest for a principle of life.
('15', 237, 6, 8, 465642) We did not say to anyone in so many words that our fight was in pursuance of this quest.
('15', 237, 6, 9, 465731) If we had said so, the people there would only have laughed at us.
('15', 237, 6, 10, 465798) We only made known the secondary aim of our movement, which was that the Government there, thinking us lowly and mean, was making laws to oust us from the country, and that it was right for us to defy these laws and show that we were brave.
('15', 237, 6, 11, 466039) Suppose the Government passes a law saying that Coloured persons shall wear yellow caps; in fact, a law of this kind was made in Rome for the Jews.
('15', 237, 6, 12, 466187) If the Government intended to treat us in a similar fashion and made a Law that appeared to humiliate us, it was for us to make it clear to the Government that we would not obey such a law.
('15', 237, 6, 13, 466377) If a child says to his father: ‘Please put on your turban the wrong side up for me’, the father understands that the child wants to have a laugh at his expense and at once obeys the command.
('15', 237, 6, 14, 466568) But when someone else, with uncharitable motives, says the same thing, he clearly answers, ‘Look, brother, so long as my head is on my shoulders, you cannot humiliate me in this manner.
('15', 237, 6, 15, 466754) You conquer my head first and then make me wear my turban in any fashion you please.’ The Government there in a similar way, thinking the Indians lowly, wanted to treat them as slaves and as far as possible to prevent their coming
('15', 237, 7, 16, 466985) 1 In reply to a question during a post prayer meeting at Satyagraha Ashram near Kochrab, Ahmedabad
('15', 238, 0, 1, 467084) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 239
('15', 238, 1, 2, 467126) into the country.
('15', 238, 1, 3, 467144) And with this end in view, it began inventing ever new laws such as putting names of Indians in a separate register, making them give finger prints in the manner of thieves and bandits, forcing them to live in particular areas, forbidding their movement beyond a specified boundary, making rules for them to walk on particular foot paths and board specified carriages in trains, treating their wives as concubines if they could not produce marriage certificates, levying from them an annual tax of forty five rupees per capita, etc., etc.
('15', 238, 1, 4, 467683) Often a disease manifests itself in the body in various forms.
('15', 238, 1, 5, 467746) The disease in this case, as has been explained, was the evil purpose of the Government of South Africa, and all the rules and regulations mentioned above were the various forms that it took.
('15', 238, 1, 6, 467938) We, therefore, had to prepare ourselves to fight against these.
('15', 238, 1, 7, 468002) There are two ways of countering injustice.
('15', 238, 1, 8, 468046) One way is to smash the head of the man who perpetrates injustice and to get your own head smashed in the process.
('15', 238, 1, 9, 468161) All strong people in the world adopt this course.
('15', 238, 1, 10, 468211) Everywhere wars are fought and millions of people are killed.
('15', 238, 1, 11, 468273) The consequence is not the progress of a nation but its decline.
('15', 238, 1, 12, 468338) Soldiers returning from the front have become so bereft of reason that they indulge in various anti social activities.
('15', 238, 1, 13, 468457) One does not have to go far for examples.
('15', 238, 1, 14, 468499) In the Boer War, when the British won a victory at Mafeking, the whole of England, and London in particular, went so mad with joy that for days on end everyone did nothing but dance night and day!
('15', 238, 1, 15, 468696) They freely indulged in wickednesses and rowdyism and did not leave a single bar with a drop of liquor in it.
('15', 238, 1, 16, 468806) The Times, commenting, said that no words could describe the way those few days were spent, that all that could be said was that “the English nation went amafficking [a Mafeking]”.
('15', 238, 1, 17, 468987) 1 Pride makes a victorious nation bad tempered.
('15', 238, 1, 18, 469035) It falls into luxurious ways of living.
('15', 238, 1, 19, 469075) Then for a time, it may be conceded, peace prevails.
('15', 238, 1, 20, 469128) But after a short while, it comes more and more to be realized that the seeds of war have not been destroyed but have become a thousand times more nourished and mighty.
('15', 238, 1, 21, 469297) No country has ever become, or will ever become, happy through victory in war.
('15', 238, 1, 22, 469376) A nation does not rise that way, it only falls further.
('15', 238, 1, 23, 469432) In fact, what comes to it is defeat, not victory.
('15', 238, 1, 24, 469482) And if, perchance, either our act or our purpose was ill conceived, it brings disaster to both belligerents.
('15', 238, 2, 25, 469591) 1 The London crowds behaved extravagantly on the relief of Mafeking (May 17, 1900).
('15', 239, 0, 1, 469675) 240 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 239, 1, 2, 469717) But through the other method of combating injustice, we alone suffer the consequences of our mistakes, and the other side is wholly spared.
('15', 239, 1, 3, 469857) This other method is satyagraha.
('15', 239, 1, 4, 469890) One who resorts to it does not have to break another’s head; he may merely have his own head broken.
('15', 239, 1, 5, 469991) He has to be prepared to die himself suffering all the pain.
('15', 239, 1, 6, 470052) In opposing the atrocious laws of the Government of South Africa, it was this method that we adopted.
('15', 239, 1, 7, 470154) We made it clear to the said Government that we would never bow to its outrageous laws.
('15', 239, 1, 8, 470242) No clapping is possible without two hands to do it, and no quarrel without two persons to make it.
('15', 239, 1, 9, 470341) Similarly, no State is possible without two entities [the rulers and the ruled].
('15', 239, 1, 10, 470422) You are our sovereign, our Government, only so long as we consider ourselves your subjects.
('15', 239, 1, 11, 470514) When we are not subjects, you are not the sovereign either.
('15', 239, 1, 12, 470574) So long as it is your endeavour to control us with justice and love, we will let you to do so.
('15', 239, 1, 13, 470669) But if you wish to strike at us from behind, we cannot permit it.
('15', 239, 1, 14, 470735) Whatever you do in other matters, you will have to ask our opinion about the laws that concern us.
('15', 239, 1, 15, 470834) If you make laws to keep us suppressed in a wrongful manner and without taking us into confidence, these laws will merely adorn the statute books.
('15', 239, 1, 16, 470981) We will never obey them.
('15', 239, 1, 17, 471006) Award us for it what punishment you like, we will put up with it.
('15', 239, 1, 18, 471072) Send us to prison and we will live there as in a paradise.
('15', 239, 1, 19, 471131) Ask us to mount the scaffold and we will do so laughing.
('15', 239, 1, 20, 471188) Shower what sufferings you like upon us, we will calmly endure all and not hurt a hair of your body.
('15', 239, 1, 21, 471289) We will gladly die and will not so much as touch you.
('15', 239, 1, 22, 471343) But so long as there is yet life in these our bones, we will never comply with your arbitrary laws.
('15', 239, 2, 23, 471443) It all began on a Sunday evening in Johannesburg when I sat on a hillock with another gentleman called Hemchandra.
('15', 239, 2, 24, 471558) The memory of that day is so vivid that it might have been yesterday.
('15', 239, 2, 25, 471628) At my side lay a Government Gazette.
('15', 239, 2, 26, 471665) It contained the several clauses of the law concerning Indians.
('15', 239, 2, 27, 471729) As I read it, I shook with rage.
('15', 239, 2, 28, 471762) What did the Government take us for?
('15', 239, 2, 29, 471799) Then and there I produced a translation of that portion of the Gazette which contained the said laws and wrote under it: “I will never let these laws govern me.” This was at once sent for publication to Indian Opinion at Phoenix.
('15', 239, 2, 30, 472029) I did not dream at the time that even a single Indian would be capable of the unprecedented heroism the Indians revealed or that the satyagraha movement would gain the momentum it did.
('15', 239, 3, 31, 472214) Immediately, I made my view known to fellow Indians and
('15', 240, 0, 1, 472270) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 241
('15', 240, 1, 2, 472312) many of them declared their readiness for satyagraha.
('15', 240, 1, 3, 472366) In the first conflict, people took part under the impression that our aim would be gained after only a few days of suffering.
('15', 240, 1, 4, 472492) In the second conflict, there were only a very few people to begin with but later many more came along.
('15', 240, 1, 5, 472596) Afterwards when, on the visit of Mr. Gokhale, the Government of South Africa pledged itself to a settlement, the fight ceased.
('15', 240, 1, 6, 472723) Later, the Government treacherously refused to honour its pledge; on which a third satyagraha battle became necessary.
('15', 240, 1, 7, 472842) Gokhale at that time asked me how many people I thought would take part in the satyagraha.
('15', 240, 1, 8, 472933) I wrote saying they would be between 30 and 60. But I could not find even that number.
('15', 240, 1, 9, 473020) Only 16 of us took up the challenge.
('15', 240, 1, 10, 473057) We were firmly decided that so long as the Government did not repeal its atrocious laws or make some settlement, we would accept every penalty but would not submit.
('15', 240, 1, 11, 473222) We had never hoped that we should find many fellow fighters.
('15', 240, 1, 12, 473283) But the readiness of one person without self interest to offer himself for the cause of truth and country always has its effect.
('15', 240, 1, 13, 473412) Soon there were twenty thousand people in the movement.
('15', 240, 1, 14, 473468) There was no room for them in the prisons, and the blood of India boiled.
('15', 240, 1, 15, 473542) Many people say that if Lord Hardinge had not intervened, a compromise would have been impossible.
('15', 240, 1, 16, 473641) But these people forget to ask themselves why it was that Lord Hardinge intervened.
('15', 240, 1, 17, 473725) The sufferings of the Canadian Indians were far greater than those of the South African Indians.
('15', 240, 1, 18, 473822) Why did he not use his good offices there?
('15', 240, 1, 19, 473865) Where the spiritual might of thousands of men and women has been mustered, where innumerable men and women are eager to lay down their lives, what indeed is impossible?
('15', 240, 1, 20, 474034) There was no other course open for Lord Hardinge than to offer mediation and he only showed his wisdom in adopting it.
('15', 240, 1, 21, 474153) What transpired later is well known to you: the Government of South Africa was compelled to come to terms with us.
('15', 240, 1, 22, 474268) All of which goes to show that we can gain everything without hurting anybody and through soul force or satyagraha alone.
('15', 240, 1, 23, 474390) He who fights with arms has to depend on arms and on support from others.
('15', 240, 1, 24, 474464) He has to turn from the straight path and seek tortuous tracks.
('15', 240, 1, 25, 474528) The course that a satyagrahi adopts in his fight is straight and he need look to no one for help.
('15', 240, 1, 26, 474626) He can, if necessary, fight by himself alone.
('15', 240, 1, 27, 474672) In that case, it is true, the outcome will be somewhat delayed.
('15', 240, 1, 28, 474736) If I had not found as many comrades in the South African fight as I did, all that would have happened is that you would not have seen me here in your midst today.
('15', 240, 1, 29, 474899) Perhaps all my life would have had to be spent in the struggle there.
('15', 240, 1, 30, 474969) But what of that?
('15', 240, 1, 31, 474987) The gain
('15', 241, 0, 1, 474996) 242 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 241, 1, 2, 475038) that has been secured would only have been a little late in coming.
('15', 241, 1, 3, 475106) For the battle of satyagraha one only needs to prepare oneself.
('15', 241, 1, 4, 475170) We have to have strict self control.
('15', 241, 1, 5, 475207) If it is necessary for this preparation to live in forests and caves, we should do so.
('15', 241, 1, 6, 475294) The time that may be taken up in this preparation should not be considered wasted.
('15', 241, 1, 7, 475377) Christ, before he went out to serve the world, spent forty days in the wilderness, preparing himself for his mission.
('15', 241, 1, 8, 475495) Buddha too spent many years in such preparation.
('15', 241, 1, 9, 475544) Had Christ and Buddha not undergone this preparation, they would not have been what they were.
('15', 241, 1, 10, 475639) Similarly, if we want to put this body in the service of truth and humanity, we must first raise our soul by developing virtues like celibacy, non violence and truth.
('15', 241, 1, 11, 475806) Then alone may we say that we are fit to render real service to the country.
('15', 241, 1, 12, 475883) In brief, the aim of the satyagraha struggle was to infuse manliness in cowards and to develop the really human virtues, and its field was the passive resistance against the Government of South Africa.
('15', 241, 2, 13, 476085) [From Hindi] Mahatma Gandhi by Ramchandra Varma

('15', 243, 1, 2, 477872) 183. LETTER TO MILLIE GRAHAM POLAK
('15', 243, 2, 3, 477907) AHMEDABAD, September 5 [1916] 1
('15', 243, 3, 4, 477939) MY DEAR MILLIE, I have your letter today.

('15', 245, 7, 21, 482793) MY DEAR FRIEND, I was assisting the carpenter yesterday.
('15', 245, 7, 22, 482850) Here carpenters have to practically make their own tools.
('15', 245, 7, 23, 482908) They make their own handles.
('15', 245, 7, 24, 482937) They turn one tool into some other.
('15', 245, 7, 25, 482973) The carpenter here wanted a handle to his screwdriver.
('15', 245, 7, 26, 483028) I had to assist him at that.
('15', 245, 7, 27, 483057) He made it out of a piece of ebony.
('15', 245, 7, 28, 483093) I thought he had turned out a piece of art in about two hours.
('15', 245, 7, 29, 483156) You will probably laugh at it.
('15', 245, 7, 30, 483187) As I was sitting opposite the carpenter, I thought of you and asked myself what you would say to it all ≈ the manner of working it, pressing two hours in the middle of his work, giving so much time to a mere handle!
('15', 245, 7, 31, 483403) Such is life here.
('15', 245, 7, 32, 483422) For me there is poetry in it.
('15', 245, 7, 33, 483452) There is no mad rush in this sort of life.
('15', 245, 7, 34, 483495) Polak is expected here in a month’s time.
('15', 245, 7, 35, 483537) There is no cable yet.
('15', 245, 7, 36, 483560) I may receive one any day.
('15', 245, 7, 37, 483587) Naransamy, Parthasarathy and Bala are all down.
('15', 245, 7, 38, 483635) The first two have a violent attack of indigestion.
('15', 245, 7, 39, 483687) Naransamy is out of danger now.
('15', 245, 7, 40, 483719) The other two have been very severely ill but they were never in the danger zone.
('15', 245, 7, 41, 483801) All have yielded to home treatment.

('15', 250, 0, 1, 489465) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 251
('15', 250, 1, 2, 489507) 191. ON AHIMSA: REPLY TO LALA LAJPAT RAI
('15', 250, 2, 3, 489548) October, 1916
('15', 250, 3, 4, 489562) Had Lala Lajpat Rai 1 first ascertained what I had actually said on ahimsa, his remarks 2 in The Modern Review for last July would not have seen the light of day.
('15', 250, 3, 5, 489725) Lalaji rightly questioned whether I actually made the statements imputed to me.
('15', 250, 3, 6, 489805) He says, that if I did not, I should have contradicted them.
('15', 250, 3, 7, 489866) In the first place, I have not yet seen the papers which have reported the remarks in question or those wherein my remarks were criticised.
('15', 250, 3, 8, 490006) Secondly, I must confess that I would not undertake to correct all the errors that creep into reports that appear in the public press about my speeches.
('15', 250, 3, 9, 490159) Lalaji’s article has been much quoted in the Gujarati newspapers and magazines; and it is perhaps as well for me to explain my position.
('15', 250, 3, 10, 490296) With due deference to Lalaji, I must join issue with him when he says that the elevation of the doctrine of ahimsa to the highest position contributed to the downfall of India.
('15', 250, 3, 11, 490473) There seems to be no historical warrant for the belief that an exaggerated practice of ahimsa synchronised with our becoming bereft of many virtues.
('15', 250, 3, 12, 490622) During the past fifteen hundred years, we have as a nation given ample proof of physical courage, but we have been torn by internal dissensions and have been dominated by love of self instead of love of country.
('15', 250, 3, 13, 490834) We have, that is to say, been swayed by the spirit of irreligion rather than of religion.
('15', 250, 4, 14, 490924) I do not know how far the charge of unmanliness can be made good against the Jains.
('15', 250, 4, 15, 491008) I hold no brief for them.
('15', 250, 4, 16, 491034) By birth I am a Vaishnavite 3, and was taught ahimsa in my childhood.
('15', 250, 4, 17, 491104) I have derived much religious benefit from Jain religious works, as I have from scriptures of the other great faiths of the world.
('15', 250, 4, 18, 491235) I owe much to the living company of the deceased philosopher Raja Chand Kavi 4 who was a Jain by birth.
('15', 250, 4, 19, 491339) Thus though my views on ahimsa are a result of my study of most of the faiths of the world, they are now no longer
('15', 250, 5, 20, 491454) 1 (1865 1928), social reformer, writer and political leader; deported in 1907; founder of the Servants of People Society; President, Indian National Congress 1920 2 For the article “Ahimsa Paramo Dharmah—A Truth or a Fad”, vide “Lane’s Letter to Gandhiji”, 21 4 1911. 3 Follower of Vishnu (the Preserver) 4 Shrimad Rajchandra; vide “Speech at Rajchandra Birth Anniversary”, 21 11 1915.
('15', 251, 0, 1, 491840) 252 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 251, 1, 2, 491882) dependent upon the authority of these works.
('15', 251, 1, 3, 491927) They are a partof my life and if I suddenly discovered that the religious books read by me bore a different interpretation from the one I had learnt to give them, I should still hold to the new of ahimsa as I am about to set forth here.
('15', 251, 2, 4, 492164) Our shastras seem to teach that a man who really practises ahimsa in its fullness has the world at his feet, he so affects his surroundings that even the snakes and other venomous reptiles do him no harm.
('15', 251, 2, 5, 492369) This is said to have been the experience of St. Francis of Assisi.
('15', 251, 3, 6, 492436) In its negative form, it means not injuring any living being, whether by body or mind.
('15', 251, 3, 7, 492523) I may not therefore hurt the person of any wrong doer, or bear any ill will to him and so cause him mental suffering.
('15', 251, 3, 8, 492641) This statement does not cover suffering caused to the wrong doer by natural acts of mine which do not proceed from ill will.
('15', 251, 3, 9, 492766) It, therefore, does not prevent me from withdrawing from his presence a child whom he, we shall imagine, is about to strike.
('15', 251, 3, 10, 492891) Indeed the proper practice of ahimsa required me to withdraw the intended victim from the wrong doer, if I am in any way whatsoever the guardian of such a child.
('15', 251, 3, 11, 493053) It was therefore most proper for the passive resisters of South Africa to have resisted the evil that the Union Government sought to do to them.
('15', 251, 3, 12, 493198) They bore no ill will to it.
('15', 251, 3, 13, 493227) They showed this by helping the Government whenever it needed their help.
('15', 251, 3, 14, 493301) Their resistance consisted of disobedience of the orders of the Government, even to the extent of suffering death at their hands.
('15', 251, 3, 15, 493431) Ahimsa requires deliberate self suffering, not a deliberate injuring of the supposed wrong doer.
('15', 251, 4, 16, 493528) In its positive form, ahimsa means the largest love, the greatest charity.
('15', 251, 4, 17, 493603) If I am a follower of ahimsa, I must love my enemy.
('15', 251, 4, 18, 493655) I must apply the same rule to the wrong doer who is my enemy or a stranger to me, as I would to my wrong doing father or son.
('15', 251, 4, 19, 493781) This active Ahimsa necessarily includes truth and fearlessness.
('15', 251, 4, 20, 493845) A man cannot deceive the loved ones; he does not fear or frighten him or her.
('15', 251, 4, 21, 493923) vHk;nku (Gift of life) is the greatest of all gifts.
('15', 251, 4, 22, 493976) A man who gives it in reality disarms all hostility.
('15', 251, 4, 23, 494029) He has paved the way for an honourable understanding.
('15', 251, 4, 24, 494083) And none who is himself subject to fear can bestow that gift.
('15', 251, 4, 25, 494145) He must therefore be himself fearless.
('15', 251, 4, 26, 494184) A man cannot then practise ahimsa and be a coward at the same time.
('15', 251, 4, 27, 494252) The practice of ahimsa calls forth the greatest courage.
('15', 251, 4, 28, 494309) It is the most soldierly of a
('15', 252, 0, 1, 494339) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 253
('15', 252, 1, 2, 494381) soldier’s virtues.
('15', 252, 1, 3, 494400) General Gordon 1 has been represented in a famous statue as bearing only a stick.
('15', 252, 1, 4, 494482) This takes us far on the road to ahimsa.
('15', 252, 1, 5, 494523) But a soldier, who needs the protection of even a stick, is to that extent so much the less a soldier.
('15', 252, 1, 6, 494626) He is the true soldier who knows how to die and stand his ground in the midst of a hail of bullets.
('15', 252, 1, 7, 494726) Such a one was Ambarish who stood his ground without lifting a finger, though Durvasa did his worst?
('15', 252, 1, 8, 494827) The Moors, who were being powdered by the French gunners, rushed into the guns’ mouth with ‘Allah’ on their lips, showed much the same type of courage.

('15', 253, 5, 21, 498513) We think as little about the meaning of education, as about its aims and objects!

('15', 253, 5, 24, 498908) In our schools we find boys belonging to various vocational communities such as masons, blacksmiths, carpenters, tailors, cobblers, etc.

('15', 257, 1, 2, 507541) 193. THE HINDU CASTE SYSTEM 1
('15', 257, 2, 3, 507571) The Hindu social structure has endured, I believe, on the foundation of the caste system.
('15', 257, 2, 4, 507661) Sir William Hunter says in his History of India that, thanks to the continuing existence of the institution of caste, there has been no need for any law for the poor (pauper law) in India.
('15', 257, 2, 5, 507850) This seems to me a sound view.
('15', 257, 2, 6, 507881) The caste system contains within it the seed of swaraj.
('15', 257, 2, 7, 507937) The different castes are so many divisions of an army.
('15', 257, 2, 8, 507992) The general does not know the soldiers individually but gets them to work through the respective captains.
('15', 257, 2, 9, 508099) In like manner, we can carry out social reform with ease through the agency of the caste system and order through it our religious, practical and moral affairs as we choose.
('15', 257, 2, 10, 508273) The caste system is a perfectly natural institution.
('15', 257, 2, 11, 508326) In our country, it has been invested with a religious meaning; elsewhere, its utility was not fully realized and so it remained a mere form, with the result that the countries concerned did not derive much benefit from it.
('15', 257, 2, 12, 508549) These being my views, I am opposed to the movements which are being carried on for the destruction of the system.
('15', 257, 2, 13, 508663) However, any defects in the caste system which we may find must certainly be removed and for that purpose we must first study its real nature.
('15', 257, 2, 14, 508806) As I pointed out earlier, we have given a religious meaning to the system.
('15', 257, 2, 15, 508881) It is merely an agency for ensuring self control.
('15', 257, 2, 16, 508931) The caste defines the limits within which one may enjoy life; that is to say, we are not free to seek any happiness outside the caste.
('15', 257, 2, 17, 509066) We do not associate with members of other communities for eating or enter into marriage relationships with them.
('15', 257, 2, 18, 509179) With an arrangement of this kind, there is a good chance that loose conduct will be kept down.
('15', 257, 2, 19, 509274) The idea that coming together for purposes of eating promotes friendship is contradicted by experience.

('15', 257, 2, 21, 509457) The bitterest quarrels are among relatives.

('15', 260, 3, 6, 514905) The words proceeded from the pride of kingly power and wealth.

('15', 261, 4, 8, 517336) 196. SPEECH ON DEFENCE OF INDIA ACT
('15', 261, 5, 9, 517372) October 22, 1916
('15', 261, 6, 10, 517389) At the Bombay Provincial Conference held in Ahmedabad, Gandhiji moved, on October 22, 1916, the following resolution:
('15', 261, 7, 11, 517507) That this Conference views with deep concern and alarm the working of the Defence of India Act as exemplified in the recent cases of Mrs. Besant and others and strongly urges upon Government the immediate necessity of providing in connection with the Defence of India Act the same safeguards as exist in England in relation to the Defence of the Realm Act.
('15', 261, 7, 12, 517864) It respectfully requests that Government may also be pleased to cancel at an early date the order prohibiting Mrs. Annie Besant from entering the limits of this Presidency.
('15', 261, 8, 13, 518037) Speaking in Gujarati, Mr. Gandhi said he thought the only thing Mrs. Besant seemed to have done was that she had been actively conducting the Home Rule agitation in India, and if that was the reason why the Bombay Government had prohibited her, then their late Viceroy Lord Hardinge was equally liable to be prohibited from entering the Presidency because it was His Lordship who had first raised this question.
('15', 261, 8, 14, 518449) Apart from that, there were three other grounds on which they should stand by Mrs. Besant, viz., gallantry, pity, and self interest.
('15', 261, 8, 15, 518582) Government had, as it were, laid its hands on a lady and, as a nation noted for chivalry, they should do all they could do to remove the indignity.
('15', 261, 8, 16, 518730) Then there was the question of pity.
('15', 261, 8, 17, 518767) They felt pity for Government because, with all its powers to bring the offending person to justice under the existing laws, it had found it necessary to resort to this measure against a lady.
('15', 261, 8, 18, 518960) Lastly, the question of self interest lay in the fact that they wanted Mrs. Besant in their Presidency because nobody could carry on the agitation better
('15', 262, 0, 1, 519114) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 263
('15', 262, 1, 2, 519156) than she.
('15', 262, 1, 3, 519166) The fact that no reason was given for the Government order was significant.
('15', 262, 1, 4, 519242) He warmly commended the resolution for acceptance.
('15', 262, 2, 5, 519293) The Bombay Chronicle, 24 10 1916

('15', 263, 1, 2, 520730) 198. RESOLUTION ON INDENTURE SYSTEM, AHMEDABAD
('15', 263, 2, 3, 520777) October 23, 1916
('15', 263, 3, 4, 520794) On 23rd October, 1916, the third and concluding day of the Bombay Provincial Conference at Ahmedabad, Gandhiji moved the following resolution: That this Conference strongly urges the necessity of abolition of the indenture system as early as possible, the system being a form of slavery which socially and politically debases labourers and is seriously detrimental to the economic and moral interests of the country.
('15', 263, 4, 5, 521211) Mr. Gandhi, in moving the resolution, spoke in Gujarati explaining the various difficulties existing at present.
('15', 263, 5, 6, 521324) The Bombay Chronicle, 24 10 1916
