('15', 269, 1, 2, 529641) 206. LETTER TO A. H. WEST
('15', 269, 2, 3, 529667) AHMEDABAD, December 12, 1916
('15', 269, 3, 4, 529696) MY DEAR WEST, This is not the draft letter that Polak refers to in his letter to you herewith.
('15', 269, 3, 5, 529791) But what I am now saying is in substance what is in the draft letter.
('15', 269, 3, 6, 529861) We have all thought over your proposal and feel that we can no longer rely upon support from the P. R. fund.
('15', 269, 3, 7, 529970) The Phoenix trustees are not all agreed upon the support being so received.
('15', 269, 3, 8, 530046) The Committee here will at the most just tolerate the withdrawal of fund[s] for sustaining Indian Opinion.
('15', 269, 3, 9, 530153) And the public there will also look upon such support with strong disfavour.
('15', 269, 3, 10, 530230) In the circumstances, we can only fall back upon local support or failing that reduce the paper to any extent we choose.
('15', 269, 3, 11, 530351) In this matter you should have absolute control.
('15', 269, 3, 12, 530400) By you, I mean you, Devi 1 and Sam 2 and anyone who may be sent from here.

('15', 269, 3, 14, 530513) He wants to.
('15', 269, 3, 15, 530526) Bhaga too goes.
('15', 269, 3, 16, 530542) Chhaganlal is ready to come over and work under you loyally.
('15', 269, 3, 17, 530603) Or if you will not shoulder the responsibility, he will work the paper with your loyal co operation.
('15', 269, 3, 18, 530704) I do hope you will agree to Chhaganlal’s return.
('15', 269, 3, 19, 530753) If you don’t, Chhaganlal will come with his family to work on the same terms as above.
('15', 269, 3, 20, 530840) And if you do not favour Maganlal’s return, Manilal and Ramdas can be sent.
('15', 269, 3, 21, 530916) They of course can only work under your directions.
('15', 269, 3, 22, 530968) Manilal should find no difficulty in gradually editing the Gujarati part.
('15', 269, 3, 23, 531042) For the time being, he will simply translate what you want him to.
('15', 269, 3, 24, 531109) If you favour Chhaganlal’s return, cable simply ‘Chhaganlal’ and I shall know.
('15', 269, 3, 25, 531188) If you want Maganlal, cable simply ‘Maganlal’.
('15', 269, 3, 26, 531235) And if you want Manilal and Ramdas, cable simply ‘Manilal’.
('15', 269, 3, 27, 531295) If you want only Manilal, you may cable ‘Manilal without Ramdas’.
('15', 269, 3, 28, 531361) I shall write later about the accounts.
('15', 269, 3, 29, 531401) We do not need to publish

('15', 271, 7, 16, 534267) Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya presided.

('15', 272, 4, 14, 536695) You are an economic society.
('15', 272, 4, 15, 536724) You have chosen distinguished specialists for the subjects included in your syllabus for this year and the next.

('15', 273, 2, 8, 539083) By economic progress, I take it, we mean material advancement without limit and by real progress we mean moral progress, which again is the same thing as progress of the permanent element in us.
('15', 273, 2, 9, 539278) The subject may therefore be stated thus: “Does not moral progress increase in the same proportion as material progress?” I know that this is a wider proposition than the one before us.
('15', 273, 2, 10, 539464) But I venture to think that we always mean the larger one even when we lay down the smaller.
('15', 273, 2, 11, 539557) For we know enough of science to realise that there is no such thing as perfect rest or repose in this visible universe of ours.

('15', 280, 0, 1, 556962) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 281
('15', 280, 1, 2, 557004) service was the aim of their education.
('15', 280, 1, 3, 557044) Their highest ambition was to become members of the Imperial Legislative Council.
('15', 280, 1, 4, 557126) The boys abandoned their hereditary occupations, and forsook their mother tongue.
('15', 280, 1, 5, 557208) They were adopting the English language, European ideas and European dress.
('15', 280, 1, 6, 557284) They thought in English, conducted all their political and social work and all commercial transactions, etc., in English and thought that they could not do without the English language.
('15', 280, 1, 7, 557470) They had come to think that there was no other road.
('15', 280, 1, 8, 557523) Education through English had created a wide gulf between the educated few and the masses.
('15', 280, 1, 9, 557614) It had created a gulf in the families also.
('15', 280, 1, 10, 557658) An English educated man had no community of feelings and ideas with the ladies of his family.
('15', 280, 1, 11, 557752) And, as had been said, the aspirations of the English educated men were fixed on Government service and at the most on membership of the Imperial Legislative Council.
('15', 280, 1, 12, 557919) He for one could never commend a system of education which produced such a state of things and men educated under such system could not be expected to do any great service to the country.
('15', 280, 1, 13, 558107) Mr. Gandhi did not mean that the English educated leaders did not feel for the masses.
('15', 280, 1, 14, 558194) On the other hand, he acknowledged that the Congress and other great public movements were initiated and conducted by them.
('15', 280, 1, 15, 558318) But, at the same time, he could not help feeling that the work done during all these years would have been much more and much greater progress would have been made if they had been taught in their mother tongue.
('15', 280, 1, 16, 558530) It was unfortunate, said the speaker, that a feeling had come over them that there was no path to progress other than that which I was being followed.
('15', 280, 1, 17, 558681) They found themselves helpless.
('15', 280, 1, 18, 558713) But it was not manliness to assume all attitude of helplessness.
('15', 280, 2, 19, 558778) Mr. Gandhi then described the ancient system of education and said that even elementary education imparted by the village teacher taught the student all that was necessary for their occupations.
('15', 280, 2, 20, 558973) Those who went in for higher education became fully conversant with the science of wealth, Artha Shastra, ethics and religion, Dharma Shastra.
('15', 280, 2, 21, 559116) In ancient times, there were no restrictions on education.
('15', 280, 2, 22, 559175) It was not
('15', 280, 3, 23, 559186) controlled by the State but was solely in the hands of the Brahmins who shaped the system of education solely with an eye to the welfare of the people.
('15', 280, 3, 24, 559338) It was based on restraint and brahmacharya.
('15', 280, 3, 25, 559382) It was due to such a system of education that Indian
('15', 280, 4, 26, 559435) civilization had outlived so many vicissitudes through thousands of years, while such ancient civilizations as those of Greece, Rome and Egypt had become extinct.
('15', 280, 4, 27, 559598) No doubt the wave of a new civilization had been passing through India.
('15', 280, 4, 28, 559670) But he was sure that it was transitory, it would soon pass away and Indian civilization would be revivified.
('15', 280, 4, 29, 559779) In ancient times, the basis of life was self restraint but now it was enjoyment.
('15', 280, 4, 30, 559860) The result was that people had become powerless cowards and forsook the truth.
('15', 280, 4, 31, 559939) Having come under the influence of another civilization, it might be necessary to adapt our own civilization in certain respects to our new environment but we should not make any radical change in a civilization which was acknowledged even by some western scholars to be the best.
('15', 280, 4, 32, 560220) It might be urged that it was necessary to
('15', 281, 0, 1, 560263) 282 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 281, 1, 2, 560305) adopt the methods and instruments of western civilization to meet the material forces of that civilization.
('15', 281, 1, 3, 560413) But the forces born of spirituality, the bedrock of Indian civilization, were more than a match for material forces.
('15', 281, 1, 4, 560530) India was pre eminently the land of religion.
('15', 281, 1, 5, 560576) It was the first and the last duty of Indians to maintain it as such.
('15', 281, 1, 6, 560646) They should draw their strength from the soul, from God.
('15', 281, 1, 7, 560703) If they adhered to that path, swarajya which they were aspiring to and working for would become their handmaid.

('15', 281, 4, 9, 560891) 210. SPEECH AT LUCKNOW CONGRESS
('15', 281, 5, 10, 560923) December 28, 1916
('15', 281, 6, 11, 560941) Mr. M. K. Gandhi (Bombay) moving Resolution No.
('15', 281, 6, 12, 560989) IX on “Indentured Labour” on 28th December 1916 at the 31st Indian National Congress Session held at Lucknow said:
('15', 281, 7, 13, 561104) MR. PRESIDENT, BROTHER DELEGATES, LADIES AND GENTLEMEN, I notice that there is an appeal made to me by my Tamil brethren that I should speak to them in English and I am going partly to accede to their importunity, but I want to make an appeal in return that during the next year if they do not learn the lingua franca, which I know will be the lingua franca (“Hear, hear”), when swaraj is granted to the whole of India, if you do not do so during the ensuing year, you will do so at your peril, so far as I am concerned.
('15', 281, 7, 14, 561625) (Cheers.) I shall read the resolution in English, which I propose to read afterwards in Hindi also.
('15', 281, 7, 15, 561725) The resolution runs as follows: (a) This Congress strongly urges that indentured emigration should be stopped by prohibiting the recruitment of such labour within the ensuing year.
('15', 281, 7, 16, 561906) (b) In the opinion of this Congress, it is highly desirable that at least one representative Indian selected after consultation with associations voicing Indian public opinion be appointed by the Government of India to take part in the forthcoming inter departmental Conference to be held in London for the consideration of this question.
('15', 281, 7, 17, 562245) (c) This Congress earnestly requests that the reports of Mr. Marjoribanks and Hon’ble Mr. Thambi Marakkyar and of the inter departmental Committee be published for general
('15', 282, 0, 1, 562417) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 283
('15', 282, 1, 2, 562459) information and discussion before any action is taken thereupon.
('15', 282, 1, 3, 562524) The pressmen and the delegates who have copies of the resolution with them will kindly note that there is a verbal alteration in clause (a), that instead of the word “during”, the resolution will read “within”.
('15', 282, 1, 4, 562735) It is made at the instance of a friend who is afraid that the Government might consider that we would be satisfied if indentured emigration was suspended during the ensuing year, whereas our meaning is that it should be abolished for ever.
('15', 282, 1, 5, 562975) In clause (b) also, you will note that there is an addition of the word “Indian” before the words “public opinion”.
('15', 282, 2, 6, 563091) Mr. Gandhi read the resolution in Hindi and explained the object of the resolution.
('15', 282, 3, 7, 563175) Report of the Thirty first Indian National Congress, pp.
('15', 282, 4, 8, 563232) 211. SPEECH AT ALL INDIA COMMON SCRIPT AND COMMON LANGUAGE CONFERENCE, LUCKNOW 1
('15', 282, 5, 9, 563313) December 29, 1916
('15', 282, 6, 10, 563331) What I have got to say I shall say afterwards.
('15', 282, 6, 11, 563378) I shall begin with the lessons I have learnt from the speakers who have preceded me.
('15', 282, 6, 12, 563463) I hail from Gujarat.
('15', 282, 6, 13, 563484) My Hindi is broken.
('15', 282, 6, 14, 563504) I speak to you, brothers, in that broken Hindi of mine, because even if I speak a little of English, I have the feeling that I am committing a sin.
('15', 282, 6, 15, 563652) I need not speak to you about the glories of Hindi.
('15', 282, 6, 16, 563704) Your desire to hear from me about the glories of Hindi is as if someone who regularly bathes in the Ganga should invoke that river to come to him.
('15', 282, 6, 17, 563851) If someone living in Rajputana were to make such a supplication, it would be different.
('15', 282, 6, 18, 563939) That you should study Hindi and master Devnagari is not for me to tell you.
('15', 282, 6, 19, 564015) It is as absurd as asking Muslims to learn Urdu.
('15', 282, 6, 20, 564064) You say, I am a man not of speech but of action.
('15', 282, 6, 21, 564113) Then do what I say.
('15', 282, 6, 22, 564133) Gentlemen, you see that the Christian Literature Depot and Bible Society is going all round the world.
('15', 282, 6, 23, 564236) It scatters its books everywhere.
('15', 282, 6, 24, 564270) It has them translated into all the languages and then distributes them at the right places.
('15', 282, 6, 25, 564363) Even to the aborigines and working people in Africa it provides the Bible in their own languages.
('15', 282, 6, 26, 564461) It spends crores of rupees on this job.
('15', 282, 6, 27, 564501) They do not simply hold conferences like we do.
('15', 282, 7, 28, 564549) 1 Gandhi presided at the Conference.
('15', 283, 0, 1, 564586) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 283, 1, 2, 564628) Sometimes they do meet but only to collect money or to submit their reports.
('15', 283, 1, 3, 564705) If we had men to teach Hindi, to do work, even the people of Madras would be knowing Hindi today.
('15', 283, 1, 4, 564803) It is not mere conferences but work that we need—work such as the Christian Literature Depot and Bible Society is doing.
('15', 283, 1, 5, 564924) All work requires money.
('15', 283, 1, 6, 564949) But there is no paucity of money.
('15', 283, 1, 7, 564983) There is paucity only of workers.
('15', 283, 1, 8, 565017) If we have workers, people in Gujarat, Madras, South India and elsewhere can learn Hindi.
('15', 283, 1, 9, 565107) Let more and more books be translated into Hindi, let people go out and teach, and let those coming in be taught.
('15', 283, 1, 10, 565221) If workers are sent to the South or to Gujarat to teach and disseminate Hindi, they will not be entirely unpaid, they will get subsistence wages.
('15', 283, 1, 11, 565367) In olden times, the age of the rishis, there was great self sacrifice, and learning was imparted without payment.
('15', 283, 1, 12, 565481) I wanted to learn Hindi but found no one in Ahmedabad to teach me.
('15', 283, 1, 13, 565548) I learnt my Hindi from a Gujarati gentleman who had only a working knowledge of the language and who had spent 15 or 20 years in Benares.
('15', 283, 1, 14, 565686) If the conference sends out men, a large number of people will be able to learn Hindi.
('15', 283, 1, 15, 565773) You want swaraj.
('15', 283, 1, 16, 565790) So do I. But the way to gain swaraj is a different one altogether [from what is usually adopted].
('15', 283, 1, 17, 565888) Swaraj cannot be got by mere talking.
('15', 283, 1, 18, 565926) You must first do some work yourselves and then only seek aid from the Government.
('15', 283, 1, 19, 566009) Government aid will not be forthcoming before that.
('15', 283, 1, 20, 566061) If you first go forward on your own, the Government will follow you.
('15', 283, 1, 21, 566130) A Government never of itself takes the first step.
('15', 283, 1, 22, 566181) You go out and teach Hindi to people and put in earnest work.
('15', 283, 1, 23, 566243) Only when you have done some work will the Government listen to you, otherwise it will throw your applications aside.
('15', 283, 1, 24, 566361) The task is a big one, but if you have the will you can construct the edifice of swaraj.
('15', 283, 1, 25, 566450) Panditji (Malaviyaji) has dwelt at length on our past glory.
('15', 283, 1, 26, 566511) English first had a vocabulary of a thousand words.
('15', 283, 1, 27, 566563) Now it has increased to a hundred thousand.
('15', 283, 1, 28, 566607) There are books in that language on all subjects, such as jurisprudence, medicine, etc.
('15', 283, 1, 29, 566695) People say Hindi has nothing and that we cannot do without English.
('15', 283, 1, 30, 566763) At times people have to put up with great inconvenience owing to ignorance of English.
('15', 283, 1, 31, 566850) I grant that it is so.
('15', 283, 1, 32, 566873) On the trains people have to suffer much on account of English.
('15', 283, 1, 33, 566937) So much so, that people like me get pushed about for speaking Hindi.
('15', 283, 1, 34, 567006) But those who have work to do cannot take notice of it.
('15', 283, 1, 35, 567062) However backward Hindi may be as compared to English, we must advance its status.
('15', 283, 1, 36, 567144) Our ancient rishis lived under rigid rules of conduct.
('15', 283, 1, 37, 567199) They showed great self sacrifice.
('15', 283, 1, 38, 567233) We must gird up our loins and do them honour by renouncing all self interest.
('15', 283, 1, 39, 567311) In Government

('15', 284, 1, 2, 567367) councils English alone counts.
('15', 284, 1, 3, 567398) It is said that the Viceroy and others know no language except English and that therefore it is necessary to use only English.
('15', 284, 1, 4, 567525) But I assert that if I know how to speak and if there is something in my speech from which the Viceroy may benefit, he will certainly hear it even if it is made in Hindi.

('15', 285, 4, 12, 569891) 213. INTERVIEW AT LUCKNOW
('15', 285, 5, 13, 569917) [About December 29/31, 1916]
('15', 285, 6, 14, 569946) NATIONAL LANGUAGE
('15', 285, 7, 15, 569964) Q. Do you consider it necessary that the business of the Congress should be conducted in Hindi, our national language?
('15', 285, 7, 16, 570083) A. I do.
('15', 285, 7, 17, 570092) So long as public business is not conducted in Hindi, the country cannot make progress.
('15', 285, 7, 18, 570180) So long as the Congress does not use Hindi for all its work, swaraj is not possible.
('15', 285, 8, 19, 570265) Q. But how can it be possible for people of all the provinces all of a sudden to learn Hindi and start speaking it?
('15', 285, 8, 20, 570381) A. I do not say that the provinces should all give up their own languages and start speaking, and writing Hindi.
('15', 285, 8, 21, 570494) In provincial matters, the provincial languages may be used.
('15', 285, 8, 22, 570555) But national questions ought to be deliberated in the national language only.
('15', 285, 8, 23, 570633) It is not a very difficult mater.
('15', 285, 8, 24, 570667) It can be easily done.
('15', 285, 8, 25, 570690) We should use Hindi for the work that we are today doing in English.
('15', 285, 9, 26, 570759) SWARAJ OF CONGRESS
('15', 285, 10, 27, 570778) Q. What do you think of the swaraj resolution passed by the Congress and the way it is going to be implemented A. It may be good or it may be bad, but I do not have any high opinion of it.
('15', 285, 11, 28, 570967) Q. Why so?
('15', 285, 11, 29, 570978) A. Because ill will is inherent in it.
('15', 285, 12, 30, 571017) Q. There wouldn’t seem to be any ill will in it and if it has it is only towards
('15', 286, 0, 1, 571098) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 287
('15', 286, 1, 2, 571140) the bureaucracy.
('15', 286, 1, 3, 571157) A. It may be towards the bureaucracy, but it is ill will all the same.
('15', 286, 1, 4, 571228) Therefore I have no high opinion of it.
('15', 286, 1, 5, 571268) But I cannot say that the venture is unworthy or that it will fail.
('15', 286, 1, 6, 571336) Ill will does not everywhere do harm.
('15', 286, 1, 7, 571374) Ill will has to be shown towards ill will when we wish to remove it from our hearts.
('15', 286, 1, 8, 571459) But this is not my way.
('15', 286, 1, 9, 571483) This is not the Indian way—the ancient, traditional way; this is the Western way.
('15', 286, 2, 10, 571565) Q. Then what is your or rather our own Indian way?
('15', 286, 2, 11, 571616) A. We shall not go into it now.
('15', 286, 3, 12, 571648) INSTITUTION OF “VARNASHRAM”
('15', 286, 4, 13, 571676) Q. What are your views on the system of the four varnas?
('15', 286, 4, 14, 571733) A. It is a very good institution.
('15', 286, 4, 15, 571767) It has done much good to the country.
('15', 286, 4, 16, 571805) It must be preserved.
('15', 286, 5, 17, 571827) Q. If there are only four varnas in Hindu society and if they are to remain as they are, in which varna would you include the untouchable castes?
('15', 286, 5, 18, 571973) A. The untouchable castes owe their existence to the excesses of the system.
('15', 286, 5, 19, 572050) The four varnas ostracised them through undue excesses.
('15', 286, 5, 20, 572106) Their place is inside the system.
('15', 286, 6, 21, 572140) Q. If that is so, in which varna ought they to be placed?
('15', 286, 7, 22, 572198) Answering this question, Gandhiji explained at length how in the normal flow of society they would all find the varnas to which they were entitled.
('15', 286, 8, 23, 572346) “SHUDDHI” MOVEMENT OF ARYA SAMAJ
('15', 286, 9, 24, 572379) Q. What will be the solution of the Hindu Muslim question?
('15', 286, 9, 25, 572438) A. This question cannot be solved finally.
('15', 286, 9, 26, 572481) What happened in other countries will happen here.
('15', 286, 9, 27, 572532) Hindus and Muslims will remain as two communities and this will do no harm to the country.
('15', 286, 10, 28, 572623) Q. The Arya Samaj converts Muslims to Hinduism through shuddhi.
('15', 286, 10, 29, 572687) If this
('15', 286, 11, 30, 572695) practice does not violate religion and if one can conceive that through it all the Muslims can become Hindus, will it not solve the question?
('15', 286, 11, 31, 572837) A. But it is not the right path.
('15', 286, 11, 32, 572870) It is not the path of religion.
('15', 286, 11, 33, 572902) It is not natural and the dream of converting all the Muslims to Hinduism is a vain one.
('15', 286, 12, 34, 572991) [From Hindi]
('15', 286, 13, 35, 573004) Mahatma Gandhi by Ramchandra Varma

('15', 287, 1, 2, 573081) 214. SPEECH AT MUSLIM LEAGUE CONFERENCE, LUCKNOW
('15', 287, 2, 3, 573130) December 31, 1916
('15', 287, 3, 4, 573148) The Muslim League resumed its sitting this morning, the attendance being as large as yesterday.
('15', 287, 3, 5, 573244) Mr. Wazir Hassan, Secretary of the League, presented the report of the reform committee appointed at Bombay last year.
('15', 287, 3, 6, 573363) The report was on the same lines as the report that was placed before the National Congress this year.
('15', 287, 4, 7, 573466) A resolution protesting against the treatment of Indians in the Colonies was next put from the chair (Mr. Jinnah) and carried.
('15', 287, 5, 8, 573593) At this stage, Mr. Gandhi who was present at the meeting was asked to address the meeting.
('15', 287, 6, 9, 573684) He exhorted them to conduct their proceedings in Urdu if they wished to carry out their resolution to maintain Urdu as the lingua franca of India.
('15', 287, 6, 10, 573831) He further urged
('15', 287, 7, 11, 573848) them to take some interest in Hindu literature which would enable them to arrive at a permanent rapprochement with the Hindus.
('15', 287, 7, 12, 573975) In the Colonies, Hindus and Mussalmans had always co operated in taking concerted measures and, if that example was followed in India, the coveted prize would soon be theirs.
('15', 287, 7, 13, 574150) He also advised them that in the course of their propaganda they should not be afraid of the Government because it was in the nature of Englishmen to bow before the strong and ride over the weak.

('15', 290, 10, 16, 578038) 220. STATEMENT ON LIONEL CURTIS’ LETTER
('15', 290, 11, 17, 578078) [Before January 14, 1917] 3
('15', 290, 12, 18, 578106) It turns out that the discoverer of Mr. Lionel Curtis’ 4 letter 5 to the Secretary of the Round Table was Mr. Gandhi.
('15', 290, 12, 19, 578224) New India writes: “An Ahmedabad correspondent writing to the Hindustan of Bombay gives details of an explanation given by Mr.
('15', 290, 13, 20, 578350) Gandhi at his Ashram at Ahmedabad regarding the “private” letter of Mr. Curtis, Mr. Gandhi says:
('15', 290, 14, 21, 578447) 1 From the postmark 2 A Congress leader of Surat district 3 Gujarati, 14 1 1917, also published this 4 Member of the Round Table group touring India; formerly, Town Clerk, Johannesburg, 1902 3, Assistant Colonial Secretary for Urban Affairs, Transvaal, 1903 6; member, Transvaal Legislative Council, vide “Interview to the Star”, 6 1 1908. 5 Dated 13th December 1916, reproduced in New India, 27 12 1916. The letter contained proposals “to subordinate India to the control of the Domi nions”.
('15', 291, 0, 1, 578940) 292 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 291, 1, 2, 578982) It was at Agra that this letter came accidentally to my hands.
('15', 291, 1, 3, 579045) It was printed in the Government press and was marked ‘private’.
('15', 291, 1, 4, 579110) But it came to my hands through the mistake of some pressman along with a book.
('15', 291, 1, 5, 579190) The moment I saw it I was startled, and on seeing the danger that stood before the country, I resolved to expose the conspiracy before the Congress somehow or other, and I handed it over to Mr. Horniman 1. But at that time l made a suggestion that Mr. Curtis should be given 24 hours’ notice to make any explanation which he thought fit.
('15', 291, 1, 6, 579528) But others thought it was one’s duty to publish it then and there, and that there was no necessity to give such a notice; I also agreed to this.
('15', 291, 1, 7, 579673) If underneath our houses somebody digs a mine and fills it with explosives, and if our enemy thinks of blowing it up when there is a gathering there, and he sends a chit round marked ‘Private and confidential’, it is our duty to catch hold of it and expose it.
('15', 291, 1, 8, 579934) I know Mr. Curtis for a long time.
('15', 291, 1, 9, 579969) His brother was in South Africa.
('15', 291, 1, 10, 580002) I think that because of the publication of this letter, the game of putting India under the dominance of the Colonies will not come to pass.
('15', 291, 2, 11, 580143) The Indian Social Reformer, 21 1 1917

('15', 295, 0, 1, 585758) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 295, 1, 2, 585800) 226. NATIONAL GUJARATI SCHOOL
('15', 295, 2, 3, 585830) [After January 18, 1917] 1
('15', 295, 3, 4, 585857) PROSPECTUS
('15', 295, 4, 5, 585868) For many years past, several friends and I have felt that our present education is not national and that in consequence people do not get from it the benefit they ought to.
('15', 295, 4, 6, 586041) Our children languish as a result of this education.
('15', 295, 4, 7, 586094) They become incapable of any great achievement and the knowledge they acquire does not spread among the masses—not even in their families.
('15', 295, 4, 8, 586233) Nor do the young people have any aim in mind in taking this modern education except to get a job and make money.
('15', 295, 4, 9, 586346) It is one of the fundamental principles of education that it should be planned with a view to the needs of the people.
('15', 295, 4, 10, 586465) This idea finds no place at all in our schools.
('15', 295, 4, 11, 586513) Wherever I have travelled in India, I have discussed this question with the leaders and, without exception, almost every one has admitted that our educational system must change.
('15', 295, 4, 12, 586692) To look to the Government for this will be sheer waste of time.
('15', 295, 4, 13, 586756) The Government will wait on public opinion and, being foreign, move very timidly; it cannot understand our needs, its advisers may be ill informed or they may have interests of their own to serve.
('15', 295, 4, 14, 586953) For a variety of such reasons, it will probably be quite long before there is any serious change in the present system; the time that passes meanwhile is so much loss to the people.
('15', 295, 4, 15, 587135) It is, however, not intended to suggest here that we should not try to get the Government to move.
('15', 295, 4, 16, 587234) Let petitions be made to it and let public opinion be ascertained.
('15', 295, 4, 17, 587301) But the best petition to the Government will be an actual demonstration by us and this will also be the easiest way of cultivating public opinion.
('15', 295, 4, 18, 587448) It has accordingly been decided, in consultation with some educated gentlemen, to start a national school.
('15', 295, 4, 19, 587555) Education in the School Basic principle: The education will be physical, intellectual and religious.
('15', 295, 4, 20, 587656) For physical education, there will be training in agriculture and hand weaving and in the use of carpenter’s and blacksmith’s tools incidental to these.
('15', 295, 4, 21, 587809) That will provide sufficient exercise for the pupils.
('15', 295, 5, 22, 587863) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('15', 296, 0, 1, 587890) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 297
('15', 296, 1, 2, 587932) In addition, they will be given drill, which is both an entertainment [and a practical utility] 1 and, as part of this, they will be taught how to march in squads and how each one may work with quiet efficiency in case of accidents such as fire.
('15', 296, 1, 3, 588178) They will have instruction on how to preserve health and on home remedies for ordinary ailments, with as much of physiology and botany as may be necessary for the purpose.
('15', 296, 1, 4, 588350) For intellectual training, they will study Gujarati, Marathi, Hindi and Sanskrit as compulsory subjects.
('15', 296, 1, 5, 588455) Urdu, Tamil and Bengali will also be taught.
('15', 296, 1, 6, 588500) There will be no teaching of English during the first three years.
('15', 296, 1, 7, 588567) In addition, the pupils will be taught Mathematics (Arithmetic, Algebra and Geometry).
('15', 296, 1, 8, 588654) Instruction in multiplication tables, Indian book keeping and the measures, weights, etc., currently in use will begin at once and the rest of the curriculum will be covered progressively.
('15', 296, 1, 9, 588843) There will be instruction in History, Geography, Elements of Astronomy and Elements of Chemistry.
('15', 296, 1, 10, 588941) By way of instruction in religion, pupils will be taught general ethical principles and we are hopeful that the teachers will demonstrate by their conduct that the essence of religion is good character.
('15', 296, 1, 11, 589144) All teaching will be through Gujarati, right up to the highest stage, and most of it will be oral during the first few years.
('15', 296, 1, 12, 589270) The intention is to put across to the children, before they learn to read and write, quite a few things orally by way of stories, as was the practice in old days, and so help their minds to grow, and to give them some general knowledge as they play about, rather than repress them by doing nothing more than remarking, “Oh dear, dear!
('15', 296, 1, 13, 589605) How dirty”, and so on.
('15', 296, 2, 14, 589628) EXPLANATION
('15', 296, 3, 15, 589640) The aim at present is that after a few years of such education, the student’s equipment will approximate to that of a well informed graduate.
('15', 296, 3, 16, 589782) That is, he will have a reduced load by way of learning English and, during the time so saved, he will be given all the useful knowledge a graduate acquires.
('15', 296, 3, 17, 589940) He will be freed from the fear of examinations.
('15', 296, 3, 18, 589988) All the students will be tested from time to time, but that
('15', 296, 4, 19, 590048) 1 The original is very faint here.
('15', 297, 0, 1, 590083) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 297, 1, 2, 590125) will be by the teachers of the school itself.
('15', 297, 1, 3, 590171) The use to which the student puts his abilities after leaving school will be the true measure of the worth of his education.
('15', 297, 1, 4, 590296) Every opportunity will be taken to rid his mind of the fallacious notion that the aim of education is to get employment.
('15', 297, 1, 5, 590417) And, finally, every pupil joining this school is likely to develop such self confidence in a few years that he will not be troubled with doubts or fears about how he will make a living.
('15', 297, 1, 6, 590603) A pupil who has been in the school for five years will be fixed up, if he so desires, in some work in the school itself and be paid for it.
('15', 297, 1, 7, 590743) The school will make arrangements with some factories, etc., so that they provide training in vocations and give a start to those who wish to set themselves up independently.
('15', 297, 1, 8, 590918) If, after ten years of study, anyone wants to pursue a subject further, necessary arrangements for the purpose are left to the future.
('15', 297, 2, 9, 591053) FREE EDUCATION No fees will be charged in this school, the expenses being met from donations received.
('15', 297, 3, 10, 591156) TEACHERS Paid teachers will be engaged and will be, all of them, grown up men who have reached the college level or possess equivalent attainments.
('15', 297, 3, 11, 591304) The idea is that children should have the best teachers in the early stages.
('15', 297, 4, 12, 591381) SYLLABUS FOR FIRST YEAR The following syllabus is reproduced as a specimen: 1

('15', 299, 5, 11, 594338) 229. INTRODUCTION TO “VERNACULARS AS MEDIA OF INSTRUCTION”
('15', 299, 6, 12, 594397) [February 1, 1917] 2
('15', 299, 7, 13, 594418) The following is the introduction written by Mr. M. K. Gandhi to Dr. P. J. Mehta’s ‘Self Government Series’ Pamphlet No.
('15', 299, 7, 14, 594539) I entitled Vernaculars as Media of Instruction in Indian Schools and Colleges: It is to be hoped that Dr. Mehta’s labour of love will receive the serious attention of English educated India.
('15', 299, 7, 15, 594730) The following pages were written by him for the Vedanta Kesari of Madras and are now printed in their present form for circulation throughout India.
('15', 299, 7, 16, 594879) The question of vernaculars as media of instruction is of national importance; neglect of the vernaculars means national suicide.
('15', 299, 7, 17, 595009) One hears many protagonists of the English language being continued as the medium of instruction pointing to the fact that English educated Indians are the sole custodians of public and patriotic work.
('15', 299, 7, 18, 595211) It would be monstrous if it were not so.
('15', 299, 7, 19, 595252) For, the only education given in this country is through the English language.
('15', 299, 7, 20, 595331) The fact, however, is that the results are not at all proportionate to the time we give to our education.
('15', 299, 7, 21, 595437) We have not reacted on the masses.
('15', 299, 7, 22, 595472) But I must not anticipate Dr. Mehta.
('15', 299, 7, 23, 595509) He is in earnest.
('15', 299, 7, 24, 595527) He writes feelingly.
('15', 299, 7, 25, 595548) He has examined the pros and cons and collected a mass of evidence in support of his arguments.
('15', 299, 7, 26, 595644) The latest pronouncement on the subject is that of the Viceroy.
('15', 299, 7, 27, 595708) Whilst His Excellency is unable to offer a solution, he is keenly alive to the necessity of imparting instruction in our
('15', 299, 8, 28, 595829) 1 In Bombay on 9 2 1917 2 The printed Gujarati Introduction (S.N. 6341) bears this date.
('15', 300, 0, 1, 595918) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 301
('15', 300, 1, 2, 595960) schools through the vernaculars.
('15', 300, 1, 3, 595993) The Jews of Middle and Eastern Europe, who are scattered in all parts of the world, finding it necessary to have a common tongue for mutual intercourse, have raised Yiddish to the status of a language and have succeeded in translating into Yiddish the best books to be found in the world’s literature.
('15', 300, 1, 4, 596295) Even they could not satisfy the soul’s yearning through the many foreign tongues of which they are masters; nor did the learned few among them wish to tax the masses of the Jewish population with having to learn a foreign language before they could realise their dignity.
('15', 300, 1, 5, 596567) So they have enriched what was at one time looked upon as a mere jargon—but what the Jewish children learnt from their mothers—by taking special pains to translate into it the best thought of the world.
('15', 300, 1, 6, 596770) This is a truly marvellous work.
('15', 300, 1, 7, 596803) It has been done during the present generation, and Webster’s Dictionary defines it as a polyglot jargon used for inter communication by Jews from different nations.
('15', 300, 1, 8, 596969) But a Jew of Middle and Eastern Europe would feel insulted if his mother tongue were now so described.
('15', 300, 1, 9, 597072) If these Jewish scholars have succeeded, within a generation, in giving their masses a language, of which they may feel proud, surely it should be an easy task for us to supply the needs of our own vernaculars which are cultured languages.
('15', 300, 1, 10, 597312) South Africa teaches us the same lesson.
('15', 300, 1, 11, 597353) There was a duel there between Taal, a corrupt form of Dutch, and English.
('15', 300, 1, 12, 597428) The Boer mothers and the Boer fathers were determined that they would not let their children, with whom they in their infancy talked in Taal, be weighed down with having to receive instruction through English.
('15', 300, 1, 13, 597638) The case of English here was a strong one.
('15', 300, 1, 14, 597681) It had able pleaders for it.
('15', 300, 1, 15, 597710) But English had to yield before Boer patriotism.
('15', 300, 1, 16, 597759) It may be observed that they rejected even the High Dutch.
('15', 300, 1, 17, 597818) The school masters, therefore, who are accustomed to speak the polished Dutch of Europe, are compelled to teach the easier Taal.
('15', 300, 1, 18, 597947) And literature of an excellent character is at the present moment growing up in South Africa in the Taal, which was only a few years ago the common medium of speech between simple but brave rustics.
('15', 300, 1, 19, 598146) If we have lost faith in our vernaculars, it is a sign of want of faith in ourselves; it is the surest sign of decay.
('15', 300, 1, 20, 598264) And no scheme of Self Government, however benevolently or generously it may be bestowed upon us, will ever make us a self governing nation, if we have no respect for the languages our mothers speak.
('15', 300, 2, 21, 598463) The Leader, 25 5 1917, quoting The Rangoon Mail

('15', 301, 2, 3, 598571) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, AHMEDABAD, Maha Sud 10, Samvat 1973, [February 1, 1917]
('15', 301, 3, 4, 598646) I wish Bhai Karsandas 2 success in his endeavour.
('15', 301, 3, 5, 598696) Eating or drinking, awake or asleep, sitting or standing, Bhai Karsandas Chitalia always has the Bhagini Samaj uppermost in his mind.
('15', 301, 3, 6, 598830) He believes that the service of women is the service of the country and that the service of women is possible through the Bhagini Samaj.
('15', 301, 3, 7, 598967) That is why Bhai Karsandas has become the moving spirit of the Bhagini Samaj.
('15', 301, 3, 8, 599045) In doing so, he is fully keeping the pledge he has taken for the Servants of India Society.
('15', 301, 3, 9, 599137) This is his belief.
('15', 301, 3, 10, 599157) Once Bhai Deodhar remarked in jest that some way would have to be found to cure Bhai Karsandas of the obsession.
('15', 301, 3, 11, 599270) This remark was by way of a homage and the homage was genuine.
('15', 301, 3, 12, 599333) India badly needs persons who can be so totally dedicated to their work.
('15', 301, 3, 13, 599406) I know Karsandas to be such a person, so I could not decline his request to write the foreword.
('15', 301, 3, 14, 599502) Since I had to write the foreword, I was forced to read the book by Bhogindrarao Divetia.
('15', 301, 3, 15, 599592) Many problems concerning women have been discussed in this work in a beautiful, easy and concise language.
('15', 301, 3, 16, 599699) Instead of asserting his views, Devatia has merely expressed them by way of suggestions.
('15', 301, 3, 17, 599788) It has struck me as a distinctive trait of Divetia’s writing.
('15', 301, 3, 18, 599850) In a book about women, for that matter even about men, meant for the general reader, assertions become a hindrance.
('15', 301, 3, 19, 599966) I hope that the reader will not infer that because I am writing this introduction I approve of all the reforms the author advocates.
('15', 301, 3, 20, 600099) Bhai Divetia has placed his views before the reader in an interesting manner.
('15', 301, 3, 21, 600177) it may be hoped that his writing will be widely read.
('15', 301, 3, 22, 600231) In his dialogues the writer has depicted the husband as a teacher to his wife.
('15', 301, 3, 23, 600310) This seems pretty realistic.
('15', 301, 3, 24, 600339) We desire girls’ education.
('15', 301, 3, 25, 600367) But we have yet to discover what type of education it should be.
('15', 301, 3, 26, 600432) For the present, we are only experimenting.
('15', 301, 3, 27, 600476) But we are not going to bring about women’s education merely through girls’ schools.
('15', 301, 3, 28, 600561) Thousands

('15', 302, 1, 3, 600892) They become housewives!
('15', 302, 1, 4, 600916) So long as this sinful custom does not disappear from amongst us, men will have to learn to be the teachers of women.
('15', 302, 1, 5, 601034) [The fulfilment of] many of our hopes lies in their education in this respect.
('15', 302, 1, 6, 601113) So long as our women do not cease to be objects of our lust and our cooks and do not become our better halves, sharing our happiness and misery, all our efforts will be futile.
('15', 302, 1, 7, 601290) Some people regard their wives as animals.
('15', 302, 1, 8, 601333) Some of the things in our old Sanskrit texts, as also a famous couplet of Tulsidas, are to blame for this.
('15', 302, 1, 9, 601440) Tulsidas has written in one place: “drums, boors, shudras, animals and women, all are fit to be beaten.” I am a devotee of Tulsidas.
('15', 302, 1, 10, 601573) But my devotion is not blind.
('15', 302, 1, 11, 601603) Either the above couplet is an interpolation, or if it is really by Tulsidas, he must have written it without thought, only expressing the prevalent attitude.
('15', 302, 1, 12, 601762) As for the utterances in the Sanskrit texts, the idea seems to have become fixed that every verse coined in Sanskrit is the word of the scriptures.
('15', 302, 1, 13, 601910) We must get rid of this false notion and do away with this age old attitude that regards women as inferior creatures.
('15', 302, 1, 14, 602028) On the other hand, some of us, blinded by passion, worship women as a goddess or treat her as a doll and decorate her with ornaments as we decorate the idols every day.
('15', 302, 1, 15, 602197) It is necessary for us to free ourselves of this wrong worship also.
('15', 302, 1, 16, 602266) Shiva had Uma, Rama had Sita, Nala had Damayanti.
('15', 302, 1, 17, 602316) When our women, too, participate in our discussions, argue with us, understand and support our utterances, with their extraordinary intuition, understand and share our external troubles and bring to us the balm of peace, then, and not till then, will our salvation become possible.
('15', 302, 1, 18, 602598) There is very little chance of bringing about such a situation merely through girls’ schools.
('15', 302, 1, 19, 602692) So long as we carry round our necks the millstone of child marriage, husbands will have to act as teachers to their wives.
('15', 302, 1, 20, 602815) And such education must not be confined to a knowledge of letters.
('15', 302, 1, 21, 602882) Gradually they can be introduced to subjects like polities and social reform.
('15', 302, 1, 22, 602960) Literacy should not be a precondition to this.
('15', 302, 1, 23, 603007) Husbands will have to change their attitude towards their wives.
('15', 302, 1, 24, 603072) Is it not possible for a woman to remain a student till she attains maturity and for the husband to observe brahmacharya till such time?
('15', 302, 1, 25, 603209) Unless we were crushed with insensibility and inertia, we would certainly not subject a girl of twelve or fifteen to the great strain of child bearing.
('15', 302, 1, 26, 603361) The very thought should make us shudder.
('15', 302, 1, 27, 603402) There are classes for married women and lectures are arranged for them.
('15', 302, 1, 28, 603474) All this is fine.
('15', 302, 1, 29, 603492) Those who are engaged in such activities are

('15', 303, 1, 4, 603760) With a little thought, everyone will find this self evident.
('15', 303, 1, 5, 603821) Hence, it may be expected that if the Bhagini Samaj can spread among husbands the desire to educate their wives, its objectives can be attained faster.

('15', 303, 3, 8, 604038) 231. SPEECH AT ANTI INDENTURE MEETING, AHMEDABAD 1
('15', 303, 4, 9, 604089) February 4, 1917
('15', 303, 5, 10, 604106) Today we, men, have assembled here to register our protest against this system and tomorrow there is to be a meeting of women in the Mahadev 2 temple of Sathodara Nagars 3. These women’s meetings started with the one at Kanpur.
('15', 303, 5, 11, 604334) As Mr. Polak and Mr. Andrews report, women labourers suffer very much in the Colonies and hence women too should join in the protest.
('15', 303, 5, 12, 604468) I have seen in Natal the conditions of indentured women and know what they suffer.
('15', 303, 5, 13, 604551) Girmit [agreement] is an English term and means binding oneself under a contract to work as a labourer.
('15', 303, 5, 14, 604655) But the Indian labourers in the Colonies understand by the term girmitio a slave, because they feel their condition to be no better than that of slaves.
('15', 303, 5, 15, 604808) When the British people had succeeded in putting an end to legalized traffic in slaves, they required another race to work as slaves for them.
('15', 303, 5, 16, 604951) They have been recruiting these from among Negroes and our people.
('15', 303, 5, 17, 605018) As Mr. Curtis says 4, we are only a little better than Negroes.
('15', 303, 5, 18, 605082) The law permitting recruitment of indentured labour came into being 50 years ago.
('15', 303, 5, 19, 605164) It had the result of placing Indians in the same condition as slaves.
('15', 303, 5, 20, 605234) The late Sir William Hunter himself described it as slavery.
('15', 303, 5, 21, 605295) It was in 1896 that a protest was first made against this enslaving law.
('15', 303, 5, 22, 605368) It had no effect then and things remained as they were up to 1911. In that year, the practice was prohibited only in respect of Natal.
('15', 303, 5, 23, 605503) In Fiji, however, the condition of
('15', 303, 6, 24, 605538) 1 As Chairman at the meeting, which was also addressed by Andrews and Polak 2 God Shiva 3 A Brahmin community of Gujarat 4 Vide “Statement on Lionel Curtis’ Letter”, before 14 1 1917.
('15', 304, 0, 1, 605722) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 305
('15', 304, 1, 2, 605764) Indian labourers has been worse than it was in Natal.
('15', 304, 1, 3, 605818) There was a strong public opinion in Natal, but there is none in Fiji.
('15', 304, 1, 4, 605889) Lord Hardinge declared last year 1 that the law would be repealed very soon.
('15', 304, 1, 5, 605966) We had hoped then that it would go after a year or 50. But we hear now, one and a half years after the declaration, that the law will remain for five more years and that afterwards they would see what could be done.
('15', 304, 1, 6, 606182) This report has revived our concern for the sufferings of our fellow countrymen and it has become our duty now to raise a strong protest to ensure the immediate repeal of the law.
('15', 304, 1, 7, 606362) The agitation was launched at Allahabad and, meetings having already been held at Madras, Poona and other places, we also have met here to register our protest.
('15', 304, 1, 8, 606523) Mr. Andrews has dedicated his life to this struggle.
('15', 304, 1, 9, 606576) Mr. Gokhale had the fullest confidence in him and, at his instance, Mr. Andrews and Mr. Pearson went to Fiji to see things for themselves.
('15', 304, 1, 10, 606715) He [Mr. Andrews] had £300 with him—this was all he had —and this he made over to the Satyagraha Fund at Lahore.
('15', 304, 1, 11, 606827) He no longer wants to be styled Reverend, but thinks it an honour to be known as Tagore’s disciple.
('15', 304, 1, 12, 606927) Mr. Polak is known to you.
('15', 304, 1, 13, 606954) He is young, and if the young people here were to do even a tenth of what he has done, we should have swaraj this moment.

('15', 304, 4, 16, 607115) 232. STATEMENT ON ABOLITION OF INDENTURED LABOUR
('15', 304, 5, 17, 607164) [After February 7, 1917]
('15', 304, 6, 18, 607189) There is no doubt that we are engaged in a severe struggle for the preservation of our honour and that, if we do not take care, the promise made by Lord Hardinge that indentured labour should soon be a thing of the past may be reduced to a nullity.
('15', 304, 6, 19, 607438) The Viceregal pronouncement just made 2 seems to set at rest one fear that the system may be prolonged for a further period of five years which, as Sir Ramakrishna Bhandarkar showed at Poona, would in reality mean ten years.
('15', 304, 6, 20, 607663) We are thankful to Lord Chelmsford for his assurance.
('15', 304, 6, 21, 607717) And we are thankful, too, to that good Englishman Mr. C.F. Andrews, for the lead that he gave us in the matter.
('15', 304, 6, 22, 607829) So soon as he gained the
('15', 304, 7, 23, 607854) 1 Vide the following item.
('15', 304, 7, 24, 607881) 2 During the address to the Imperial Legislative Council on 7 2 1917
('15', 305, 0, 1, 607950) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 305, 1, 2, 607992) information from Fiji that five years’ extension was taken by the planters of those lands as a settled fact, he forsook his sick bed and his rest at Shantiniketan and sounded for us the call of duty.
('15', 305, 2, 3, 608192) But if one cloud that threatened to destroy our hopes seems to have disappeared, another equally dangerous looms on the horizon.
('15', 305, 2, 4, 608321) The conditions of abolition as stated by Lord Hardinge last March 1
('15', 305, 3, 5, 608389) are these:
('15', 305, 4, 6, 608400) On behalf of His Majesty’s Government, he the Secretary of State has asked us, however, to make it clear that the existing system of recruiting must be maintained until new conditions under which labour should not be permitted to proceed to the Colonies should have been worked out in conjunction with the Colonial Office and the Crown Colonies concerned; until proper safeguards in the Colonies should have been provided and until they should have had reasonable time to adjust themselves to the change, a period which must necessarily depend on circumstances and conditions imperfectly known at present.
('15', 305, 5, 7, 609006) Those of us who know anything of the system knew that it was well nigh impossible to find new conditions which would be economically sound for the planters and morally sound for us.
('15', 305, 5, 8, 609188) We felt that the Government would soon find this out for themselves and that, in view of Lord Hardinge’s whole hearted disapproval of the system, his view of the nearness of the end would coincide with our 2 own.
('15', 305, 5, 9, 609401) But now a different situation faces us.
('15', 305, 5, 10, 609441) Nearly a year has gone by and we discover that the planters of Fiji have been led to believe that they will have five years more of the system and at the end of it new conditions may after all be a change in name but not in substance.
('15', 305, 5, 11, 609676) Let Mr. Bonar Law’s 3 despatch speak for itself.
('15', 305, 5, 12, 609725) Writing under date March 4, 1916, to the Acting Governor of Fiji, he says:
('15', 305, 6, 13, 609800) The Secretary of State for India is satisfied that it would not be possible for the Government of India to continue to defeat by a bare official majority resolutions in their Legislative Council, urging the abolition of indenture; that in his opinion the strong and universal feeling in India on this

('15', 306, 1, 3, 610724) He then proceeds:
('15', 306, 2, 4, 610742) Though, from the point of view of the Colonies concerned, the decision which the Indian Government and the Secretary of State for India have taken is to be regretted, I recognize that the final decision upon this question must rest with the Indian Government.
('15', 306, 2, 5, 611002) Thus, the humanities of the question are tacitly supposed to be no concern of the Colonies.
('15', 306, 2, 6, 611094) Now mark this significant paragraph culled from the same illuminating despatch:
('15', 306, 3, 7, 611174) I have, therefore, agreed to the appointment of an inter departmental committee to consider what system should be substituted for the system of indenture, should be allowed for a further period of five years and should cease at the end of that period.
('15', 306, 3, 8, 611426) .The Secretary of State for India is anxious that the change of system should be brought about with as little disturbance as possible to the economic interests of the Colonies and that he has made it clear that the existing system must be maintained until a properly safeguarded system has been devised.
('15', 306, 3, 9, 611730) Mr. Andrews has been twitted for having referred to the five years’ extension.
('15', 306, 3, 10, 611809) Let his critics explain away Mr. Bonar Law’s emphatic pronouncement published in the Fiji newspapers.
('15', 306, 3, 11, 611911) What with the official statement and the Secretary of State for India’s solicitude for the economic interests of the planters, our cause may easily be lost if we are found unwatchful.
('15', 306, 3, 12, 612095) In the light of the Viceregal speech and Mr. Bonar Law’s despatch, our duty seems to be clear.
('15', 306, 3, 13, 612190) We must strengthen the Government’s hands where necessary and even stimulate their activity so that this inter departmental committee is not allowed to frustrate our hopes.
('15', 306, 3, 14, 612363) It is a body wherein the influence of the Crown Colonies and the Colonial Office will be preponderant.
('15', 306, 3, 15, 612466) It is a body which has to find a substitute which would be acceptable to us.
('15', 306, 3, 16, 612543) As I hold, it will be a vain search if the mere well being of the labourer is to be the primary consideration.
('15', 306, 3, 17, 612654) But if the planters can have their own way, we know that they will urge an impossible substitute and, in the event of its rejection by us, they will, in accordance with Mr. Bonar Law’s despatch, claim continuance of recruiting under indenture.
('15', 306, 3, 18, 612898) It must therefore be clearly understood that the onus of producing an acceptable substitute rests with them and not with us.
('15', 306, 3, 19, 613023) They have had
('15', 307, 0, 1, 613037) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 307, 1, 2, 613079) more than a year already.
('15', 307, 1, 3, 613105) Lord Hardinge’s despatch urging total abolition is dated the 15th October 1915. The committee is to sit in May next.
('15', 307, 1, 4, 613222) This period for finding a substitute is long enough in all conscience.
('15', 307, 1, 5, 613293) Either Mr. Andrews’ harrowing picture of the conditions of life in Fiji is true or it is untrue.
('15', 307, 1, 6, 613390) We believe it to be true and it has never been seriously attacked.
('15', 307, 1, 7, 613457) And in waiting for over a year, we shall have waited almost beyond the point of endurance.
('15', 307, 1, 8, 613548) Substitute or no substitute, we are entitled for the sake of our own honour and reputation and indeed that of the Empire to the unconditional abolition of this last remnant of slavery.
('15', 307, 1, 9, 613733) Natal stopped 1 the system without the provision of a substitute.
('15', 307, 1, 10, 613799) Mauritius has done likewise.
('15', 307, 1, 11, 613828) The Johannesburg mines survived not only the shock of an abrupt termination of Chinese labour but the withdrawal of every Chinese labourer from the country as fast as transport could be got ready.
('15', 307, 1, 12, 614025) Capital is both bold and timid.
('15', 307, 1, 13, 614057) If only we shall do our duty, if only the Government of India will steel their hearts against the blandishments of the Fijian and West Indian planters, there is no doubt that these people will know how to save millions without India’s having to go to their rescue.

('15', 307, 3, 15, 614377) 233. SPEECH AT ANTI INDENTURE MEETING, BOMBAY
('15', 307, 4, 16, 614423) February 9, 1917
('15', 307, 5, 17, 614440) At a public meeting held at the Excelsior Theatre, Bombay, on February 9, 1917, under the presidentship of Sir Jamsetji Jeejibhoy, a resolution, moved by Sir N.G. Chandavarkar, demanding the immediate abolition of indentured labour, was unanimously passed.
('15', 307, 5, 18, 614697) Mr. H. A. Wadia then proposed that the chairman of the meeting be authorised to communicate the resolution to His Majesty’s Secretary of State for India and H. E. the Viceroy and Governor General of India by telegram.
('15', 307, 6, 19, 614915) Mr. M. K. Gandhi supporting the resolution said that, yielding to the command of his friends on the platform, he had undertaken to speak to them in English on that occasion.
('15', 307, 6, 20, 615089) The resolution which he supported asked that the preceding resolution be sent to the Secretary of State for India and H. E. the Viceroy by telegram.
('15', 307, 6, 21, 615238) What was the meaning of this?
('15', 307, 6, 22, 615268) They had fixed with great deliberation the
('15', 307, 7, 23, 615311) 1 The indenture system was brought to an end in Natal by the Indian Government’s refusal in 1911 to allow recruitment.
('15', 308, 0, 1, 615430) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 309
('15', 308, 1, 2, 615472) 31st of May of this year as the last date on which this remnant of slavery should come to an end.
('15', 308, 1, 3, 615570) (Applause.) It meant that they had slept for nearly 50 years and allowed this system to continue, but that immediately they were awakened to their sense of responsibility and duty, they did not like to sleep for a day longer and it was, therefore, that they wished that the resolution should be wired without a moment’s delay.
('15', 308, 1, 4, 615897) In passing that resolution, they were strengthening the hands of the Government and were awakening the Colonies to a sense of their duty to consider India as an integral part of the Empire.
('15', 308, 1, 5, 616087) It would also strengthen the Viceroy’s hands, and H. E. the Viceroy could say that he would no longer govern India if they were not ready to remove the blot of indentured labour before the 31st of May.
('15', 308, 1, 6, 616289) (Applause.) The honour of the people of India was at stake and they were bound to think of it, waking or sleeping.
('15', 308, 1, 7, 616404) He asked them to remember the 31st of May.
('15', 308, 1, 8, 616447) Till then let them not sleep.
('15', 308, 1, 9, 616477) (Applause).

('15', 308, 3, 11, 616521) 234. SPEECH AT ANTI INDENTURE MEETING, BOMBAY 1
('15', 308, 4, 12, 616569) February 11, 1917
('15', 308, 5, 13, 616587) Announcing that the proceedings of the meeting would be in an Indian language, Gandhiji, who was in the chair, said: The system of indenture under which helpless, illiterate sisters and brothers from our country are reduced to utter misery must end forthwith.
('15', 308, 5, 14, 616847) We shall fix May 31 as the date by which it should be stopped.
('15', 308, 5, 15, 616910) Clapping our hands will not avail us much.
('15', 308, 5, 16, 616953) We shall succeed in our aim only if we approach the intending recruits themselves in their homes and dissuade them from joining up; and this task is yours.
('15', 308, 6, 17, 617109) [From Gujarati]

('15', 309, 1, 2, 617245) 235. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS ON GOKHALE ANNIVERSARY
('15', 309, 2, 3, 617296) DELHI, February 17, 1917
('15', 309, 3, 4, 617321) SIR, Upon the advice of the Hon.
('15', 309, 3, 5, 617354) Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya and other friends, I venture to draw public attention to a suggestion I have made to my Ahmedabad friends regarding the celebration of the Gokhale anniversary on the 19th instant.
('15', 309, 3, 6, 617562) It is to the effect that we should at these meetings take a definite practical step from year to year to promote some public object in keeping with the teachings of the deceased patriot.
('15', 309, 3, 7, 617749) Ahmedabad will probably raise subscriptions for translating and publishing in Gujarati Mr. Gokhale’s speeches to be ready for circulation at the latest on the next anniversary.
('15', 309, 3, 8, 617926) Other centres may translate other works or may raise subscriptions to found scholarships for some special training.
('15', 309, 3, 9, 618042) If some such definite and not very ambitious steps are taken at the hundreds of meetings that will be held yearly, the educational advance we shall have in a few years will, it is held, be not inconsiderable.
('15', 309, 4, 10, 618251) The Leader, 19 2 1917

('15', 310, 5, 20, 619729) 238. SPEECH ON GOKHALE ANNIVERSARY AT GODHRA
('15', 310, 6, 21, 619774) February 19, 1917
('15', 310, 7, 22, 619792) Gandhiji presided at a crowded meeting held at Godhra on February 19, 1917 in connection with the Gokhale anniversary, when a resolution was moved appointing a committee to take steps to keep green the memory of Gokhale by furthering the cause of education in the district which was so dear to his heart.
('15', 310, 8, 23, 620097) 1 The first two pages of the letter are not available.
('15', 310, 8, 24, 620152) 2 Gandhiji arrived in Godhra on February 19 and presided over the Gokhale death anniversary meeting.
('15', 310, 8, 25, 620253) 3 Vide “National Gujarati School”, after 18 1 1917.
('15', 311, 0, 1, 620305) 312 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 311, 1, 2, 620347) After the resolution was supported and adopted, Mr. Gandhi rose to deliver his presidential address.
('15', 311, 1, 3, 620448) The first point he touched was the religious catholicity of Mr. Gokhale, who, on one occasion, rebuked a seeming sadhu who drew a sharp line of difference between Hindus and Mahomedans.
('15', 311, 1, 4, 620634) Religious convictions were fast dwindling in this country everywhere, but then another religion was developing and that was love of country.
('15', 311, 1, 5, 620775) Mr. Gokhale cultivated this religion to the highest level to the point where he laid down his life in the service of the Motherland.
('15', 311, 2, 6, 620908) Mr. Gandhi dwelt in his own inimitable and impressive manner on two great qualities of Mr. Gokhale which should always go with patriotism: love of truth and fearlessness.
('15', 311, 2, 7, 621079) Whilst most people expressed opinions which would be palatable to the hearers, Mr. Gokhale always gave to the officials and the public the result of his mature studies and deliberation.
('15', 311, 3, 8, 621265) Mr. Gandhi advised all officials, high or low, to take a leaf from the career of Mr. Gokhale who, though highly placed in life as a member of the Imperial Legislative Council, was always kind and gentle towards all his fellow countrymen.
('15', 311, 3, 9, 621503) Mr. Gandhi remarked that the feeling of patriotism which pervaded thousands of men, young and old, was running to waste like the river Ganges, which flowed from the Himalayas into the Bay of Bengal, for want of the sterling qualities of truthfulness and fearlessness.
('15', 311, 4, 10, 621771) Finally, Mr. Gandhi urged the people of the city to support energetically the Committee which had been appointed to further the cause of education in the district and thanked all who had given him such a magnificent and hearty welcome to the city.
('15', 311, 4, 11, 622019) The Bombay Chronicle, 23 2 1917
('15', 311, 5, 12, 622051) 239. SPEECH AT AHMEDABAD ON SAROJINI NAIDU 1
('15', 311, 6, 13, 622096) February 23, 1917
('15', 311, 7, 14, 622114) Seeing sister Sarojini 2 today, I was reminded of Lord Colin Campbell who came out to India as Commander in Chief at the time of the Mutiny in 1857. In those days, military officers used camels very freely for transporting luxury articles and they were not available in sufficient number for carrying provisions, etc.
('15', 311, 7, 15, 622432) Lord Colin Campbell, therefore, kept only one camel for himself and thus tacitly

('15', 312, 1, 2, 622768) reminded the other officers of their duty.
('15', 312, 1, 3, 622811) This had the effect of reducing in some measure the discontent among the troops.
('15', 312, 1, 4, 622892) Though Sarojini travels first class, the luggage she carries is contained in just two boxes.
('15', 312, 1, 5, 622985) I have observed her life at home and come to respect her for that.
('15', 312, 1, 6, 623052) She has had four children, the youngest being now 13. At present, therefore, she lives very nearly like one in the vanaprastha 1
('15', 312, 2, 7, 623181) stage of life.
('15', 312, 2, 8, 623196) Though a millionaire’s daughter and a millionaire’s wife, she runs her house with great skill.

('15', 312, 5, 17, 623703) 240. SPEECH AT SURAT ON INDENTURE 2
('15', 312, 6, 18, 623739) February 26, 1917
('15', 312, 7, 19, 623757) SISTERS AND BROTHERS, It is obvious that I, a resident of Ahmedabad, can have no knowledge of civic affairs in Surat.
('15', 312, 7, 20, 623875) When I arrived here, it was suggested to me that I should take the chair.
('15', 312, 7, 21, 623949) I was rather surprised.
('15', 312, 7, 22, 623973) I felt that I was not the proper person to do so.
('15', 312, 7, 23, 624023) As I knew little about the civic affairs here, I respected the suggestion of local friends and told them that they could put forward my name if my taking the chair would help matters.
('15', 312, 7, 24, 624207) I am quite conscious of my responsibility.
('15', 312, 7, 25, 624250) I cannot claim, moreover, that I have come here prepared for the matters to be debated and the resolutions to be passed.
('15', 312, 7, 26, 624371) This is why I feel I am not the proper person.
('15', 312, 7, 27, 624418) I shall request you all, sisters and brothers, to overlook any deficiency that you may observe in me.
('15', 312, 7, 28, 624520) Before I start the proceedings, I shall deliver Mrs. Sarojini Naidu’s message.
('15', 312, 7, 29, 624599) When she was in Ahmedabad, I told her it would be good if she could go to Surat.
('15', 312, 7, 30, 624680) But she said she had an important engagement on Sunday.
('15', 312, 7, 31, 624736) Later, there was a telegram from Dr. Hora and I told her

('15', 313, 1, 2, 624989) again that Surat should not feel disappointed and asked her to come along.
('15', 313, 1, 3, 625064) I also found out from her the nature of her engagement to see if I could urge her to come.
('15', 313, 1, 4, 625155) The lady has been in bad health for several years past.
('15', 313, 1, 5, 625211) She has such strength of mind, however, and such is her love for the motherland, that, when occasion demands, she makes it possible to meet it.
('15', 313, 1, 6, 625355) God alone knows from where she gets the strength, but she who looked worn out just a moment earlier betrays no signs of suffering on her face when she is at work.
('15', 313, 1, 7, 625518) So wonderful is her strength.
('15', 313, 1, 8, 625548) There is to be a big meeting in Bombay on the 27th and she must conserve her health to be able to make a complete success of it.
('15', 313, 1, 9, 625677) As her coming to Surat would have made this impossible, she did not know how to manage it.
('15', 313, 1, 10, 625768) Even so, we should make every sacrifice and agitate on this issue; if for no other reason, out of consideration for this lady who, an ornament to India, goes up and down all over the country taking no thought of her health.
('15', 313, 1, 11, 625992) There is no religion among us which does not forbid our undertaking a second task before we have completed the first.
('15', 313, 1, 12, 626110) You have come forward at this meeting to take upon yourself a great responsibility.
('15', 313, 1, 13, 626194) But one has no right to assume an additional burden before one has fully discharged a duty already undertaken.

('15', 313, 1, 15, 626418) I have heard nothing further about it.
('15', 313, 1, 16, 626457) Mr. Adwani put down Rs. 50/ and the matter never went beyond that.
('15', 313, 1, 17, 626524) I met him in Godhra but did not have the courage to mention the subject to him.
('15', 313, 1, 18, 626604) It is not yet too late for you to raise something for the fund, though, of course, collections for the Fund in the charge of Mr. Jehangir Petit are over.
('15', 313, 1, 19, 626758) I think even the Trust Deed in respect of that Fund is ready.

('15', 313, 1, 23, 627082) But I would say that, if you subscribe Rs. 100/ this time, you will be able to pay Rs. 1,000/ next time.
('15', 313, 1, 24, 627187) The matter is important for this reason: Mrs. Naidu has been sacrificing herself for the cause.
('15', 313, 1, 25, 627283) Besides, Mahatma Gokhale was drawn into it in 1896 and in 1912 he made the cause his own.
('15', 313, 1, 26, 627373) I know also that his speeches at the time affected his health.
('15', 313, 1, 27, 627436) You should, therefore remind yourselves of your promise to raise a fund in memory of this man who had even sacrificed his life for this cause, and give to it to the best

('15', 314, 1, 2, 627685) of your means.
('15', 314, 1, 3, 627700) The gentleman who proposed me [to the chair] said that, of the two questions, that concerning volunteers [for the Army] was the more important one.
('15', 314, 1, 4, 627848) I shall say, though, that the question of in denture is more important.
('15', 314, 1, 5, 627920) It is of course right that we express satisfaction over the right of offering ourselves as volunteers, but the satisfaction will avail us nothing unless we follow up the expression of it with necessary action.
('15', 314, 1, 6, 628130) In regard to the issue of indenture, on the other hand, it is our unceasing duty to see that no town or village, known or unknown, goes without a protest against this system.
('15', 314, 1, 7, 628305) You know that I have come from Delhi.
('15', 314, 1, 8, 628343) I have had meetings with His Excellency the Viceroy and other leaders of the nation.
('15', 314, 1, 9, 628428) Like Mrs. Sarojini Naidu and the late Mr. Gokhale, Mr. Andrews too has made sacrifices.
('15', 314, 1, 10, 628516) As he pondered over this problem, he was so upset in mind that he took ill.
('15', 314, 1, 11, 628592) Even his speech, which has been translated into every language, had to be read out by Mr. Polak.
('15', 314, 1, 12, 628689) We should now hold public meetings for the purpose.
('15', 314, 1, 13, 628741) We do not at all embarrass the Government by doing so; on the contrary, we strengthen its hands.
('15', 314, 1, 14, 628838) The Government itself has admitted that the system is immoral and brings no benefit whatever.
('15', 314, 1, 15, 628932) Possibly there is some economic gain but, in view of the moral degradation it has brought about, it must be ended.
('15', 314, 1, 16, 629047) This is an issue on which there is no difference of opinion.
('15', 314, 1, 17, 629108) The Editor of The Times of India asks who should solve this problem and when.
('15', 314, 1, 18, 629186) Pat will come the reply: that is exclusively India’s right.
('15', 314, 1, 19, 629246) On this matter, we can imagine things far more vividly than the Viceroy.
('15', 314, 1, 20, 629319) I shall give only one illustration of this.
('15', 314, 1, 21, 629363) The worthy Baji Gauri is ill and her younger sister has been attending on her and has suffered in health in consequence.
('15', 314, 1, 22, 629484) I, as a resident of Ahmedabad, will not feel this as much as people here, and none will feel as much as the younger sister.
('15', 314, 1, 23, 629608) If it were otherwise, I would be by her bed side all the time.
('15', 314, 1, 24, 629671) In the same way, the Viceroy cannot imagine as well as we can the condition of our own brothers and sisters.
('15', 314, 1, 25, 629780) We should lay down a time limit and say that we would tolerate the system up to May 31 and that, if it continued even a day longer, thousands will lay down their lives.
('15', 314, 1, 26, 629949) The system has been in existence for fifty years.
('15', 314, 1, 27, 629999) It is a matter of shame for us that, in all these years, it is only recently that we have taken up discussion of a resolution like this.
('15', 314, 1, 28, 630136) I do not, however, wish to go into that matter.
('15', 314, 1, 29, 630184) I have had 20 years, experience of this problem and it is but natural, therefore, that my heart should cry out before you and my imagination grow active; I hope you will forgive me if I set out these things before you at such length.
('15', 314, 1, 30, 630418) The system is but a
('15', 315, 0, 1, 630438) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 315, 1, 2, 630480) form 1 of slavery.
('15', 315, 1, 3, 630499) We have in it, under the British Empire, elements of the very system which England claims proudly to have abolished; this system can be described as slavery for a limited period.
('15', 315, 1, 4, 630678) All the essential elements of the earlier system are present in this, and one more.
('15', 315, 1, 5, 630762) It makes one shudder to know all.
('15', 315, 1, 6, 630796) The system brings India’s womanhood to utter ruin, destroys all sense of modesty.

('15', 315, 1, 32, 632960) Such are my views, but all do not find them acceptable.

('15', 318, 1, 2, 636460) 243. SPEECH AT HOME RULE LEAGUE HEADQUARTERS, KARACHI
('15', 318, 2, 3, 636514) March 2, 1917
('15', 318, 3, 4, 636528) In the course of the day (2nd instant), Gandhi visited the Home Rule League Headquarters twice.
('15', 318, 3, 5, 636624) On both occasions he spoke to the members, associates and college students on passive resistance and austerity.
('15', 318, 3, 6, 636736) The love of dress, which Gandhi has noticed among Sindhis, has impressed him unfavourably.
('15', 318, 3, 7, 636827) One of the members asked him why he went about bare footed.
('15', 318, 3, 8, 636887) He replied that unless he maintained austerity, he could not expect the masses to believe in his sincerity.
('15', 318, 3, 9, 636995) He said that India was too poor and that those who could afford to spend money on dress should refrain from spending it in that way and give it to the poor.
('15', 318, 3, 10, 637152) Jethmal 1, of the Hindvasi, questioned him about passive resistance and Gandhi explained its value by examples from his South African experiences.
('15', 318, 4, 11, 637299) He also visited the Hardevi Bai Girls’ Schools and said a few words to the children on education.
('15', 318, 5, 12, 637397) He met the Cutchhi and Gujarati community at the Parsi Theatre in the afternoon and told them about indentured labour.
('15', 318, 6, 13, 637516) Bombay Secret Abstracts, 1917, p.
('15', 318, 7, 14, 637550) 244. SPEECH AT PARSI THEATRE, KARACHI
('15', 318, 8, 15, 637588) March 2, 1917
('15', 318, 9, 16, 637602) On his visit, Mr. Gandhi made a definite pronouncement with regard to the duty of Indians to join the Defence of India Force in the Parsi Theatre public meeting, Karachi.
('15', 318, 9, 17, 637773) He said that lndians had been pressing for admission in the army, time and again, and now as the permission had been granted, they should join in overwhelming numbers, and thus fulfil their duty to the Motherland.
('15', 318, 9, 18, 637987) Mr. Gandhi said that, in speaking as he had done, he had spoken not as a Passive Resister, but as one claiming to know the Indian mind and understanding India’s present conditions.
('15', 318, 9, 19, 638168) He held very strong views about the use of weapons even in self defence but he knew that his views were not shared by those of his countrymen who had for years past been agitating for the reform that had now come.
('15', 318, 9, 20, 638382) It is an opportunity of a life time that no lover of his country should miss.
('15', 318, 9, 21, 638460) Sir Satyendra Sinha 2, in his Presidential address,

('15', 319, 3, 11, 639836) 245. SPEECH AT ANTI INDENTURE MEETING AT KARACHI
('15', 319, 4, 12, 639885) March 2, 1917
('15', 319, 5, 13, 639899) Under the auspices of the Citizens’ Association, Karachi, a public meeting was held in the Khalikdina Hall on the 2nd instant to protest against the continuance of the system of indentured labour.
('15', 319, 5, 14, 640096) The Hon’ble Mr. Harchandrai, President of the Association, was in the chair....
('15', 319, 6, 15, 640176) M. K. Gandhi arrived after the time fixed and informed the audience that he could not attend throughout as he had to catch the mail train to Calcutta, having been invited by the Maharaja of Cassimbazar to be present in that city on the 6th instant.
('15', 319, 7, 16, 640425) After speaking in Hindi for half an hour, he left the Hall.
('15', 319, 8, 17, 640485) He began by requesting the assembly to send a telegram of condolence to A. M. Kachalia, who had just lost his nephew 2, and explained how much Mr. Kachalia had done for Indians in South Africa.
('15', 319, 8, 18, 640679) Gandhi then spoke on indentured labour.
('15', 319, 8, 19, 640719) After mentioning the various evils of the system, he told the audience that Indians must insist on its abolition by the 31st of May this year.
('15', 319, 8, 20, 640862) If their request were not acceded to, all practical steps should be taken to prevent Indians from leaving the country for labour in Fiji.
('15', 319, 8, 21, 641000) Every effort should be made to teach the people to hate the system and to clamour for its suppression.
