('15', 320, 1, 2, 641241) 246. SPEECH AT ANTI INDENTURE MEETING, CALCUTTA
('15', 320, 2, 3, 641289) March 6, 1917
('15', 320, 3, 4, 641303) At a public meeting held at the Town Hall, Calcutta, on March 6, 1917, under the presidentship of Maharaja Manindra Chandra Nandi, Gandhiji made a statement on indentured emigration to South Africa.
('15', 320, 4, 5, 641502) Mr. M. K. Gandhi, in seconding the resolution moved by the chair, said they all expressed their sympathy to Mahomed Kachalia who had recently lost his son.
('15', 320, 4, 6, 641658) Mr. Kachalia was the president of the Transvaal British Indian Association.
('15', 320, 4, 7, 641734) He was one of the passive resisters and went to jail again and again.
('15', 320, 4, 8, 641804) Mr. Gandhi said that the Government did not allow Mr. Malaviya to introduce his Bill because the Government wanted to introduce a measure which would satisfy the people.
('15', 320, 4, 9, 641974) They all knew that the Viceroy was in sympathy with them, but the Secretary of State for India was opposed to them.
('15', 320, 4, 10, 642090) He was to weigh the interests of Colonial planters at [the cost?] of the Indians in a scale of gold.
('15', 320, 4, 11, 642191) Sitting at a long distance, the Secretary of State could not understand the feeling of the Indians.
('15', 320, 4, 12, 642291) India believed that Mr. Andrews’ report 1 was true.
('15', 320, 4, 13, 642343) The planters had engaged their best men to go to England and they were pressing for time.
('15', 320, 4, 14, 642433) If India did not rise to the occasion, the planters would gain the day.
('15', 320, 4, 15, 642505) It was not the Secretary of State for India but the people who could say when this system should be abolished and they fixed the 31st May for its abolition.
('15', 320, 4, 16, 642662) They could not contemplate with calmness the shifting of dates from season to season.
('15', 320, 4, 17, 642748) It was their duty to say that India could not tolerate this wrong a minute longer than the 31st May.
('15', 320, 4, 18, 642849) No substitute to be brought forward by the London Conference was acceptable to India.
('15', 320, 4, 19, 642935) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 7 3 1917

('15', 323, 7, 15, 647485) 251. OUR SYSTEM OF EDUCAT1ON
('15', 323, 8, 16, 647514) March, 24, 1917
('15', 323, 9, 17, 647530) It has become customary with us to judge whatever we do by Western standards.
('15', 323, 9, 18, 647608) We claim that oriental civilization is superior to the occidental, but our behaviour is contrary to what we say.
('15', 323, 9, 19, 647721) That is why the education of Indian children has become hybrid.
('15', 323, 9, 20, 647785) Our educational institutions do not produce heirs to the traditions of our saints and seers.
('15', 323, 9, 21, 647878) It is very sad.
('15', 323, 9, 22, 647894) I have been thinking on the matter for a long time and I put before the readers the conclusions to which I have come.
('15', 323, 9, 23, 648012) No one will quarrel with the principle that pupils should be imparted a general knowledge of the basic occupations of the country.
('15', 323, 9, 24, 648143) According to this principle, all our boys should be taught farming and weaving, for nearly 95 per cent of the country’s population is engaged in agriculture, while 90 per cent of these used to be engaged in weaving.
('15', 323, 9, 25, 648359) So long as the educated among us do not pay attention to these two important matters, we cannot have any idea of the misery of our
('15', 324, 0, 1, 648490) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 325
('15', 324, 1, 2, 648532) tens of millions of agriculturists and hundreds of thousands of weavers, nor can there be any improvement in these two pursuits.
('15', 324, 1, 3, 648661) We shall not be able to do any work if our body is not healthy.
('15', 324, 1, 4, 648725) So it is necessary to educate boys in the principles of health and hygiene right from childhood.
('15', 324, 1, 5, 648822) Dharma is the basis of everything.
('15', 324, 1, 6, 648857) A correct knowledge of the scriptures, however, is not possible without a knowledge of Sanskrit.
('15', 324, 1, 7, 648954) Therefore, every Hindu boy must also learn some Sanskrit.
('15', 324, 1, 8, 649012) But I think it is very difficult to establish gurukuls everywhere.
('15', 324, 1, 9, 649079) General education should end with the imparting of general knowledge.
('15', 324, 1, 10, 649149) Special arrangements can be made for boys who are endowed with extraordinary capacities.
('15', 324, 1, 11, 649238) In teaching history and geography, the method followed by the Government should be changed.
('15', 324, 1, 12, 649330) In teaching these subjects, the emphasis should generally be on knowledge concerning India.
('15', 324, 1, 13, 649422) My experience is that many a boy knows where Middlesex is but he has no idea about Kathiawar or Sorath.
('15', 324, 1, 14, 649526) In history they are given a comprehensive knowledge of the United Kingdom, but our Shivaji they consider merely a bandit.
('15', 324, 1, 15, 649648) Our boys can solve intricate mathematical problems but are ignorant of simple arithmetic useful in business.
('15', 324, 1, 16, 649757) They have very little knowledge of the indigenous tables.
('15', 324, 1, 17, 649815) Instruction to pupils in all provinces should be given in their mother tongue.
('15', 324, 1, 18, 649894) Besides this, they should acquire knowledge of two or three other Indian languages.
('15', 324, 1, 19, 649978) English should be taught only to a small number of boys and as a foreign language.
('15', 324, 1, 20, 650061) I am convinced that so long as we are not free of our fondness for English, we cannot achieve real swaraj.
('15', 324, 1, 21, 650168) Some friends tell me that in the ordinary business of life, like travelling by train or reading a telegram, we are at sea if we do not know English.
('15', 324, 1, 22, 650317) But we ourselves are responsible for this state of affairs.
('15', 324, 1, 23, 650377) If through a feeling of inferiority we ignore our religion, our serfdom will only become worse.
('15', 324, 1, 24, 650473) And millions of our brethren who are never likely to learn English will be reduced to slaves and an unbridgeable gulf will form between them and the English educated.
('15', 324, 1, 25, 650640) The education that is in vogue has no impact on our homes either, although as a rule the whole country should be influenced by the lives of students.
('15', 324, 1, 26, 650790) Even a little of perfume will spread its fragrance all round.
('15', 324, 1, 27, 650852) It should be so with the life of a student.
('15', 324, 1, 28, 650896) In my opinion, the
('15', 325, 0, 1, 650915) 326 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 325, 1, 2, 650957) key to swaraj lies not so much in the hands of the Government as in our system of education.
('15', 325, 1, 3, 651050) [From Hindi] Satdharma Pracharak, Gurukul Number, 24 3 1917

('15', 336, 8, 9, 668472) 267. LETTER TO PRIVATE SECRETARY TO VICEROY
('15', 336, 9, 10, 668516) NOT FOR PUBLICATION CARE DISTRICT MAGISTRATE,
('15', 336, 10, 11, 668562) MOTIHARI, April 16, 1917
('15', 336, 11, 12, 668587) DEAR MR. MAFFEY 2, I have come to this district to learn for myself whether there is truth in the allegations of the ryots against the planters.
('15', 336, 11, 13, 668732) I saw the Secretary of the Planters’ Association and then the Commissioner of the Division 3, and sought their co operation.
('15', 336, 11, 14, 668857) Both politely rejected my advances and dissuaded me from my pursuit.
('15', 336, 11, 15, 668926) I could not accept their advice, and have been proceeding with my work.
('15', 336, 11, 16, 668998) The Magistrate has served upon me an order 4 asking me to leave the District.
('15', 336, 11, 17, 669076) The grounds for the order are such as I cannot subscribe to.
('15', 336, 11, 18, 669137) I have therefore been reluctantly obliged to disobey the order and tell the magistrate that I shall suffer the penalty for the breach.
('15', 336, 12, 19, 669272) My motive is national service and that, too, so long as it is consistent with humanitarian dictates.
('15', 336, 12, 20, 669373) I understand, because my South African work was considered to be humanitarian that I was awarded.
('15', 336, 12, 21, 669471) the Kaisar i Hind Gold Medal.
('15', 336, 12, 22, 669501) 6 So long as my humanitarian motive is questioned, so long must I remain undeserving of holding the medal.
('15', 336, 13, 23, 669608) 1 W. B. Heycock 2 Private Secretary to the Viceroy, Lord Chelmsford 3 Vide “Letter to L.F. Morshead”, 12 4 1917. 4 Vide Order under Section 144 Cr.P.C.”, 16 4 1917. 5 Vide the preceding item.
('15', 336, 13, 24, 669800) 6 Vide entries for June 4 and June 26, “Diary for 1915”.
('15', 337, 0, 1, 669857) 338 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 337, 1, 2, 669899) I am therefore asking my people to return the medal to you, 1 and I shall feel honoured to receive it back if it is returned to me when my motive is no longer questioned.
('15', 337, 2, 3, 670070) As to the question itself, so far as I have been able to examine the evidence, given to me, it shows that the planters have successfully used the Civil and Criminal Courts and illegal force to enrich themselves at the expense of the ryots, and that the ryots are living under a reign of terror and that their property, their persons, and their minds are all ‘under the planters’ heels.
('15', 337, 2, 4, 670456) One man graphically said to me: “We belong to the planters, not to the Sircar 2. Thana 3 is nowhere, the planters are everywhere.
('15', 337, 2, 5, 670586) We take what they allow, and we keep what they permit.” I had hoped that a deeper examination would have toned down the impression formed by me.
('15', 337, 2, 6, 670731) Had I been left free, I would have concluded my studies and placed the results at the disposal of the authorities.
('15', 337, 2, 7, 670846) I wish that His Excellency would consider the matter serious enough to have an independent inquiry made.
('15', 337, 2, 8, 670951) The local administration admit that they are sitting upon a mine so dangerous that they cannot tolerate my presence.

('15', 338, 1, 2, 671738) 268. INSTRUCTIONS FOR WORKERS 1
('15', 338, 2, 3, 671770) [April 16, 1917] 2
('15', 338, 3, 4, 671789) The programme of study should be gone through as if I was not imprisoned, that is 1. Villages should be visited systematically and notes of evidence of everyone examined should be taken.
('15', 338, 3, 5, 671976) 2. Where the party consents to sign the notes, his signature or thumb impression should be taken.
('15', 338, 3, 6, 672074) 3. Evidence should be taken even where the parties decline to sign.
('15', 338, 3, 7, 672142) Reason for refusal should be noted.
('15', 338, 3, 8, 672178) 4. Evidence of pleaders who had anything to do with the case of the ryots should be requested and it should be after the pattern suggested for Gorakh Babu 3. For this, evidence as many workers as would come forward should be taken.
('15', 338, 3, 9, 672410) It is to be wished that many workers who would come forward would not be deterred from pursuing their inquiry even though they may receive notice of removal.
('15', 338, 3, 10, 672568) They should quietly go to gaol if they are summoned and tried for disobedience.
('15', 338, 3, 11, 672648) I suggest that no defence be offered.
('15', 338, 3, 12, 672686) The ryots should be instructed definitely not to use violence whether regarding their own grievances or regarding imprisonment of those who may come to assist them.
('15', 338, 3, 13, 672851) But they can be and should be told that where they know they are being unjustly treated, that is, required to plant indigo when they need not, rather than go to law, they should simply refuse to plant indigo and if for so refusing they are imprisoned they should suffer imprisonment.
('15', 338, 3, 14, 673135) This requires very careful explanation.
('15', 338, 3, 15, 673175) Where the workers do not understand the working of this quiet resistance or do not appreciate the force of it, they may drop this point of the programme.
('15', 338, 3, 16, 673329) When the workers of this first class are exhausted or not found at all, second class workers should be enlisted to collect evidence at

('15', 344, 1, 2, 681847) 276. STATEMENT BEFORE THE COURT
('15', 344, 2, 3, 681879) [MOTIHARI,] April 18, 1917
('15', 344, 3, 4, 681906) Mr. Gandhi appeared before the District Magistrate on Wednesday, the 18th instant.
('15', 344, 3, 5, 681989) He read the statement printed below, and being asked to plead and finding that the case was likely to be unnecessarily prolonged, pleaded guilty.
('15', 344, 3, 6, 682135) The Magistrate would not award the penalty but postponed judgement till 3 p.m.
('15', 344, 3, 7, 682214) Meanwhile he was asked to see the Superintendent and then the District Magistrate.
('15', 344, 3, 8, 682297) The result was that he agreed not to go out to the villages, pending instructions from the Government as to their view of his mission.
('15', 344, 3, 9, 682432) The case was then postponed up to Saturday, April 21.With the permission of the Court, I would like to make a brief statement showing why I have taken the very serious step of seemingly disobeying the order made under Section 144 of the Criminal Procedure Code.
('15', 344, 3, 10, 682694) In my humble opinion, it is a question of difference of opinion between the local administration and myself.
('15', 344, 3, 11, 682803) I have entered the country with motives of rendering humanitarian and national service.
('15', 344, 3, 12, 682891) I have done so in response to a pressing invitation’ to come and help the ryots, who urge they are not being fairly treated by the indigo planters.
('15', 344, 3, 13, 683039) I could not render any help without studying the problem.
('15', 344, 3, 14, 683097) I have, therefore, come to study it with the assistance, if possible, of the administration and the planters.
('15', 344, 3, 15, 683207) I have no other motive and I cannot believe that my coming here can in any way disturb the public peace or cause loss of life.
('15', 344, 3, 16, 683334) I claim to have considerable experience in such matters.
('15', 344, 3, 17, 683391) The administration, however, have thought differently.
('15', 344, 3, 18, 683446) I fully appreciate their difficulty, and I admit too, that they can only proceed upon information they receive.
('15', 344, 3, 19, 683558) As a law abiding citizen, my first instinct would be, as it was, to obey the order served upon me.
('15', 344, 3, 20, 683657) I could not do so without doing violence to my sense of duty to those for whom I have come.
('15', 344, 3, 21, 683749) I feel that I could just now serve them only by remaining in their midst.
('15', 344, 3, 22, 683823) I could not, therefore, voluntarily retire.
('15', 344, 3, 23, 683867) Amid this conflict of duty, I could only throw the responsibility of removing me from them on the administration.
('15', 344, 3, 24, 683981) I am fully conscious of the fact that a person, holding in the public life of India a position such as I do, has to be most careful in setting examples.
('15', 344, 3, 25, 684134) It is my firm belief that in the complex constitution
('15', 345, 0, 1, 684188) 346 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 345, 1, 2, 684230) under which we are living, the only safe and honourable course for a self respecting man is, in the circumstances such as face me, to do what I have decided to do, that is, to submit without protest to the penalty of disobedience.
('15', 345, 1, 3, 684461) I have ventured to make this statement not in any way in extenuation of the penalty to be awarded against me, but to show that I have disregarded the order served upon me, not for want of respect for lawful authority, but in obedience of the higher law of our being—the voice of conscience.
('15', 345, 2, 4, 684752) The Leader, 22 4 1917, also Select Documents on Mahatma Gandhi’s Movement in Champaran, No.
('15', 345, 2, 5, 684844) 28, pp.

('15', 348, 9, 10, 689308) BANKIPUR, MOTIHARI, April 21,1917
('15', 348, 10, 11, 689342) The proceedings are withdrawn under instructions from Gov ernment.
('15', 348, 10, 12, 689409) Official assistance during the conduct of my enquiry has been promised and I feel grateful to Government for the withdrawal of the proceedings and promised assistance.
('15', 348, 10, 13, 689577) I am being splendidly helped by local pleaders and others and messages of sympathy and promise of help have been received from many quarters, which encourage my fellow workers and myself.
('15', 348, 10, 14, 689765) During my stay here, I have already visited some villages and seen hundreds of ryots.
('15', 348, 10, 15, 689851) The officials have shown every courtesy throughout.
('15', 348, 10, 16, 689903) While I am carrying on this enquiry, no public agitation is necessary.
('15', 348, 10, 17, 689974) The issues involved are tremendously great.
('15', 348, 10, 18, 690018) I hope to place my final conclusions before Government and the country.

('15', 351, 7, 13, 693231) BETTIAH, April 28, 1917
('15', 351, 8, 14, 693255) DEAR MR. LEWIS 3, I have your note of even date.
('15', 351, 8, 15, 693304) I thank you for having sent me your letter 4 to Mr. Heycock for perusal, I appreciate the frankness that pervades it, and it is, on the whole, a very fair summary of what has happened between us.
('15', 351, 8, 16, 693500) As to the guns, I think you are somewhat unnecessarily offended.
('15', 351, 8, 17, 693565) I mentioned the matter to you on Mr. Heycock’s suggestion, and if you admit the propriety of my having spoken to you about the matter, I could not be blamed for having told the aggrieved parties that there was a probability of their getting back their guns.
('15', 351, 8, 18, 693823) This, if anything, was done to create a good impression about yourself— an impression which, I am happy to say, I carried with me [when] I first met you and which I have had no reason to
('15', 351, 9, 19, 694010) 1 Gandhiji was in Bettiah on this day.
('15', 351, 9, 20, 694049) 2 Swami Shraddhanand 3 Sub divisional Officer of Bettiah 4 Select Document No.

('15', 352, 0, 1, 694152) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 353
('15', 352, 1, 2, 694194) change since.
('15', 352, 1, 3, 694208) There was certainly no interference on my part with your authority.
('15', 352, 2, 4, 694276) I venture to think that your deduction, too, that in the estimation of the raiyats I am superseding local authority is hardly warranted by facts.
('15', 352, 2, 5, 694422) My mission is to invoke the help of local authority in their aid, and to stimulate its interest in them more fully than heretofore.
('15', 352, 3, 6, 694554) I anticipate no trouble, because I always make it a point to seek an interview with the planters wherever I go, to tell the people that relief is to come not from me but from the planters and the Government, and that they are in no case to use violence or stop work but continue it as before as if there was no enquiry being made by me, and also because the enquiry is absolutely open and attended by representatives of the police department, as also the planters.
('15', 352, 4, 7, 695019) You are less than fair to Babu Brajkishore Prasad.
('15', 352, 4, 8, 695070) Together with other friends from Bihar, he is helping me very materially.
('15', 352, 4, 9, 695144) In this enquiry he has no status apart from me: hence he and the other friends have not called on you.
('15', 352, 4, 10, 695247) But I must state that their assistance has been of the greatest value to me.
('15', 352, 5, 11, 695324) Perhaps it is but fair to the planters to say that Mr. Still 1 has of his own motion invited me to visit his dehat 2 and remain there aslong as I like and that Mr. Cox has written to me saying that he is arranging a meeting with some leading planters, and concludes “you may be sure that we wish to assist you in your enquiry”.
('15', 352, 5, 12, 695652) This perhaps is in conflict with your statement, “By the planters he (I) is regarded with great suspicion as their natural enemy.”
('15', 352, 6, 13, 695783) I wish to serve my countrymen and the planters through the Government where their assistance is necessary.
('15', 352, 7, 14, 695890) Yours truly,

('15', 353, 4, 12, 696461) The position is so bad that I dare not leave here even for a day.
('15', 353, 4, 13, 696527) I have cancelled all appointments.
('15', 353, 4, 14, 696562) I cannot be with you in Nasik, much as I should like to be.
('15', 353, 5, 15, 696622) We are taking the statements of men who come to us as fast as we can.
('15', 353, 5, 16, 696692) In a few days, I may have something to report.
('15', 353, 5, 17, 696739) I have kept Mr. Shastriar supplied with all the information to date.
('15', 353, 6, 18, 696808) Although I am not in gaol, I shall still look up to you to finish the programme about the translation of Mr. Gokhale’s speeches.

('15', 354, 1, 4, 697593) I have been writing most regularly to him.
('15', 354, 1, 5, 697636) He gave me, when his departure was imminent, his new address and I wrote several letters to that address.
('15', 354, 1, 6, 697742) Having received no acknowledgement of these letters I resumed writing to his Douglas address.
('15', 354, 1, 7, 697836) But I have practically no acknowledgment of all these letters of mine.
('15', 354, 1, 8, 697907) Pray tell him that we all think of him and miss him so often.
('15', 354, 1, 9, 697969) I miss him most of all.
('15', 354, 1, 10, 697993) Just now I am in the northern part of India.
('15', 354, 1, 11, 698038) It is a country “Where every prospect pleases, man alone is vile.” 2 Here at first my presence was resented by the local authority.
('15', 354, 1, 12, 698170) I received a summons to leave the country.
('15', 354, 1, 13, 698213) I declined.
('15', 354, 1, 14, 698225) I was summoned to answer a charge of contempt.
('15', 354, 1, 15, 698272) I pleaded guilty.
('15', 354, 1, 16, 698290) But the court had not the courage to sentence me.
('15', 354, 1, 17, 698340) Meanwhile came instructions from the superior authority that the proceedings against me should be withdrawn and that I should be allowed to proceed with my work.
('15', 354, 1, 18, 698502) My work is to examine the condition of the peasantry who are working under the indigo planters who are alleged to be treating the peasantry in a most high handed manner.
('15', 354, 1, 19, 698672) I have been carrying on my inquiry and I find the position to be as bad as it was painted.
('15', 354, 1, 20, 698763) I am still going on with the inquiry.
('15', 354, 1, 21, 698801) It is here I miss our friend’s presence.
('15', 354, 1, 22, 698842) I cannot imagine myself doing this class of work without him.
('15', 354, 1, 23, 698904) I know he would have been delighted to be in the thick of it.
('15', 354, 1, 24, 698966) He would have walked with me to the villages and lived with me among the simple folk.
('15', 354, 1, 25, 699052) He would have seen the planters.
('15', 354, 1, 26, 699085) He would have made friends with them and would have played an important part in bringing about a settlement.
('15', 354, 1, 27, 699194) But that was not to be.
('15', 354, 1, 28, 699218) He must pay the penalty that modern civilization exacts from us —man against man to gain man’s so called freedom.
('15', 354, 1, 29, 699332) It is like darkness being used to dispel darkness.
('15', 354, 1, 30, 699383) We are living in an age of materialism.
('15', 354, 1, 31, 699423) We are always hoping for the best to happen though unconsciously doing the opposite to achieve the best.
('15', 354, 1, 32, 699528) I hope with you that the agony will soon end.
('15', 354, 1, 33, 699574) But the hope is against my reason.
('15', 354, 1, 34, 699609) My reason tells me that the peace which we shall have will be mockery; it will be an armed truce to me, it will be the outcome not of one party admitting being in the wrong but both being fairly exhausted and deserving rest.

('15', 365, 0, 1, 715949) 366 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 365, 1, 2, 715991) 301. REPORT ON CONDITION OF RYOTS IN CHAMPARAN 1
('15', 365, 2, 3, 716040) BETTIAH, May 13, 1917
('15', 365, 3, 4, 716062) In accordance with the suggestions made by Hon’ble Mr. Maude 2, I beg to submit herewith the preliminary conclusions which I have arrived at as a result of the inquiry being made by me into the agrarian condition of the raiyats of Champaran.
('15', 365, 3, 5, 716304) At the outset I would like to state that it was not possible for me to give the assurance which Mr. Maude would have liked me to have given, viz., that the vakil friends who have been assisting me would be withdrawn.
('15', 365, 3, 6, 716521) I must confess that this request has hurt me deeply.
('15', 365, 3, 7, 716574) It has been made ever since my arrival here.
('15', 365, 3, 8, 716619) I have been told, that is, after the withdrawal of the order of removal from the District, that my presence was harmless enough and that my bona fides were unquestioned, but that the presence of the vakil friends was likely to create ‘a dangerous situation’.
('15', 365, 3, 9, 716878) I venture to submit that if I may be trusted to conduct myself decorously, I may be equally trusted to choose helpers of the same type as myself.
('15', 365, 3, 10, 717024) I consider it a privilege to have the association, in the difficult tasks before me, of these able, earnest and honourable men.
('15', 365, 3, 11, 717152) It seems to me that for me to abandon them is to abandon my work.
('15', 365, 3, 12, 717218) It must be a point of honour with me not to dispense with their help until anything unworthy is proved against them to my satisfaction.
('15', 365, 3, 13, 717354) I do not share the fear that either my presence or that of my friends can create ‘a dangerous situation’.
('15', 365, 3, 14, 717460) The danger, if any exists, must lie in the causes that have brought about strained relations between the planters and the raiyats.
('15', 365, 3, 15, 717591) And if the causes were removed, there never need be any fear of a dangerous situation arising in Champaran so far as the raiyats are concerned.
('15', 365, 3, 16, 717735) Coming to the immediate purpose of this representation, I beg to state that nearly four thousand raiyats have been examined and their statements taken after careful cross examination.
('15', 365, 3, 17, 717919) Several villages have been visited and many judgments of courts studied.
('15', 365, 3, 18, 717992) And the inquiry is, in my opinion, capable of sustaining the following
('15', 365, 4, 19, 718063) 1 This was sent to the Chief Secretary, Bihar & Orissa.
('15', 365, 4, 20, 718119) 2 Member of the Executive Council, Bihar & Orissa, in his talk with Gandhiji on 10th May; vide “Note By Hon’ble W. Maude on Interview with Gandhiji”, 10 5 1917.
('15', 366, 0, 1, 718280) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 367
('15', 366, 1, 2, 718322) conclusions:
('15', 366, 2, 3, 718335) Factories or concerns in the district of Champaran may be divided into two classes—(1) those that have never had indigo plantations, and (2) those that have:—
('15', 366, 3, 4, 718494) (1) The concerns which have never grown indigo have exacted abwabs known by various local names equal in amount at least to the rent paid by the raiyats.
('15', 366, 3, 5, 718648) This exaction, although it has been held to be illegal, has not altogether stopped.
('15', 366, 4, 6, 718732) (2) The indigo growing factories have grown indigo either under the tinkathia system or khuski.
('15', 366, 4, 7, 718828) The former has been most prevalent and has caused the greatest hardship.
('15', 366, 4, 8, 718901) The type has varied with the progress of time.
('15', 366, 4, 9, 718948) Starting with indigo, it has taken in its sweep all kinds of crops.
('15', 366, 4, 10, 719016) It may now be defined as an obligation presumed to attach to the raiyat’s holding whereby the raiyat has to grow a crop on 3/20 of the holding at the will of the landlord for a stated consideration.
('15', 366, 4, 11, 719215) There appears to be no legal warrant for it.
('15', 366, 4, 12, 719260) The raiyats have always fought against it and have only yielded to force.
('15', 366, 4, 13, 719334) They have not received adequate consideration for the services.
('15', 366, 4, 14, 719398) When, however, owing to the introduction of synthetic indigo the price of the local product fell, the planters desired to cancel the indigo sattas 1. They, therefore, devised a means of saddling the losses upon the raiyats.
('15', 366, 4, 15, 719622) In lease hold lands they made the raiyats pay tawan, i.e., damages to the extent of Rs. 100/ per bigha in consideration of their waiving their right toindigo cultivation.
('15', 366, 4, 16, 719793) This, the raiyats claim, was done under coercion.
('15', 366, 4, 17, 719843) Where the raiyats could not find cash, hand notes and mortgage bonds were made for payment in instalments bearing interest at 12 per cent per annum.
('15', 366, 4, 18, 719992) In these the balance due has not been described as tawan, i.e., damages, but it has been fictitiously treated as an advance to the raiyat for some purpose of his own.
('15', 366, 5, 19, 720159) In mukarrari 2 lands, the damage has taken the shape of sharahbeshi sattas, meaning enhancement of rent in lieu of indigo cultivation.
('15', 366, 5, 20, 720294) The enhancement according to the survey report has in
('15', 366, 6, 21, 720348) 1 Agreements 2 A permanent tenure.
('15', 367, 0, 1, 720383) 368 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 367, 1, 2, 720425) the case of 5,955 tenancies amounted to Rs. 31,062, the pre enhancement figure being Rs. 53,865. The total number of tenancies affected is much larger.
('15', 367, 1, 3, 720577) The raiyats claim that these sattas were taken from them under coercion.
('15', 367, 1, 4, 720650) It is inconceivable that the raiyats would agree to an enormous perpetual increase in their rents against freedom from liability to grow indigo for a temporary period which freedom they were strenuously fighting to secure and hourly expecting.
('15', 367, 1, 5, 720894) Where tawan has not been exacted, the factories have forced the raiyats to grow oats, sugarcane, or such other crops under the tinkathia system.
('15', 367, 1, 6, 721039) Under the tinkathia system, the raiyat has been obliged to give his best land for the landlord’s crops; in some cases the land in front of his house has been so used; he has been obliged to give his best time and energy also to it, so that very little time has been left to him for growing his own crops—his means of livelihood.
('15', 367, 1, 7, 721368) Cart hire sattas have been forcibly taken from the raiyats for supplying carts to the factories on hire insufficient even to cover the actual outlay.
('15', 367, 1, 8, 721518) Inadequate wages have been paid to the raiyats whose labour has been impressed, and even boys of tender age have been made to work against their will.
('15', 367, 1, 9, 721669) Ploughs of the raiyats have been impressed and detained by the factories for days together for ploughing factory lands for a trifling consideration and at a time when they required them for cultivating their own lands.
('15', 367, 1, 10, 721888) Dasturi 1 has been taken by the notoriously ill paid factory amlas 2 out of the wages received by the labourers, often amounting to a fifth of their daily wage, and also out of the hire paid for carts and ploughs.
('15', 367, 1, 11, 722102) In some villages, the chamars 3 have been forced to give up to the factories the hides of dead cattle belonging to the raiyats.
('15', 367, 1, 12, 722230) Against the carcases the chamars used to supply the raiyats with shoes and leather straps for ploughs and their women used to render services to the latter’s families at child birth.
('15', 367, 1, 13, 722413) Now they have ceased to render
('15', 367, 2, 14, 722444) 1 A customary but illegal commission.
('15', 367, 2, 15, 722482) 2 Staff.
('15', 367, 2, 16, 722491) 3 Member of the caste dealing in hides and skins
('15', 368, 0, 1, 722540) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 369
('15', 368, 1, 2, 722582) these valuable services.
('15', 368, 1, 3, 722607) Some factories have for the collection of such hides opened hides godowns.
('15', 368, 1, 4, 722682) Illegal fines—often of heavy amounts—have been imposed by factories upon raiyats who have proved unbending.
('15', 368, 1, 5, 722790) Among the other (according to the evidence before me) methods adopted to bend the raiyats to their will, the planters have impounded the raiyats’ cattle, posted peons on their houses, withdrawn from them barbers’, dhobis’, carpenters’, and smiths’ services; have prevented the use of village wells and pasture lands by ploughing up the pathway and lands just in front of or behind their homesteads, have brought or promoted civil suits, or criminal complaints against them, and resorted to actual physical force and wrongful confinements.
('15', 368, 1, 6, 723329) The planters have successfully used the institutions of the country to enforce their will against the raiyats and have not hesitated to supplement them by taking the law in their own hands.
('15', 368, 1, 7, 723519) The result has been that the raiyats have shown an abject helplessness such as I have not witnessed in any part of India where I have travelled.
('15', 368, 2, 8, 723664) They are members of District Boards and assessors under the Chaukidari Act and keepers of pounds.
('15', 368, 2, 9, 723762) Their position as such has been felt by the raiyats.
('15', 368, 2, 10, 723815) The roads which the latter pay for at the rate of half an anna per rupee of rent paid by them are hardly available to them.
('15', 368, 2, 11, 723939) Their carts and bullocks which perhaps most need the roads are rarely allowed to make use of them.
('15', 368, 2, 12, 724038) That this is not peculiar to Champaran does not in any way mitigate the grievance.
('15', 368, 3, 13, 724121) I am aware that there are concerns which form exceptions to the rule laid down, but as a general charge the statements made above are capable of proof.
('15', 368, 4, 14, 724273) I am aware, too, that there are some Indian zamindars who are open to the charges made above.
('15', 368, 4, 15, 724367) Relief is sought for in their cases as in those of the planters.
('15', 368, 4, 16, 724432) Whilst there can be no doubt the latter have inherited a vicious system, they with their trained minds and superior position have reduced it to an exact science, so that the raiyats would not only have been unable to raise their heads above water but would have sunk deeper still had not the Government granted some protection.
('15', 368, 4, 17, 724760) But that protection has been meagre and provokingly slow and has often come too late to be appreciated by the raiyats.
('15', 369, 0, 1, 724879) 370 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 369, 1, 2, 724921) It is true that the Government await the Settlement Officer’s report on some of the matters covered by this representation.
('15', 369, 1, 3, 725045) It is submitted that when the raiyats are groaning under the weight of oppression, such as I have described above, an inquiry by the Settlement Officer is a cumbersome method.
('15', 369, 1, 4, 725221) With him the grievances mentioned herein are but an item in an extensive settlement operation.
('15', 369, 1, 5, 725316) Nor does his inquiry cover all the points raised above.
('15', 369, 1, 6, 725372) Moreover, grievances have been set forth herein which are not likely to be disputed.
('15', 369, 1, 7, 725457) And they are so serious as to require immediate relief.
('15', 369, 1, 8, 725513) That tawan and sharahbeshi sattas and abwabs have been exacted cannot be questioned.
('15', 369, 1, 9, 725598) I hope it will not be argued that the raiyats can be fully protected as to these by recourse to law.
('15', 369, 1, 10, 725699) It is submitted that where there is wholesale exaction, courts are not a sufficient protection for the raiyats and the administrative protection of the Sarkar 1 as the supreme landlord is an absolute necessity.
('15', 369, 2, 11, 725910) The wrongs are twofold.
('15', 369, 2, 12, 725934) There are wrongs which are accomplished facts and wrongs which continue.
('15', 369, 2, 13, 726007) The continuing wrongs need to be stopped at once and a small inquiry may be made as to past wrongs, such as damages and abwabs already taken and sharahbeshi payments already made.
('15', 369, 2, 14, 726187) The raiyats should be told by proclamation and notices distributed broadcast among them that they are not only not bound to pay abwabs, tawan and sharahbeshi charges but that they ought not to pay them, that the Sarkar will protect them if any attempt is made to enforce payment thereof.
('15', 369, 2, 15, 726475) They should further be informed that they are not bound to render any personal service to their landlords and that they are free to sell their services wherever they choose and that they are not bound to grow indigo, sugar cane or any other crop unless they wish to do so and unless it is profitable for them.
('15', 369, 2, 16, 726785) The Bettiah Raj leases given to the factories should not be renewed until the wrongs are remedied and should, when renewed, properly safeguard the raiyats’ rights.
('15', 369, 3, 17, 726949) As to dasturi, it is clear that better paid and educated men should substitute the present holders of responsible offices and that no countenance should be given to the diminution in raiyats’ wages by illegal exaction of dasturi.
('15', 369, 3, 18, 727179) I feel sure that the planters are quite capable of dealing with the evil, although it is in their language ‘as old as the Himalayas’.
('15', 369, 4, 19, 727313) 1 Government
('15', 370, 0, 1, 727326) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 371
('15', 370, 1, 2, 727368) The raiyats being secured in their freedom, it would be no longer necessary to investigate the question of the inadequacy or otherwise of the consideration in the indigo sattas and cart hire sattas, and the wages.
('15', 370, 1, 3, 727582) The raiyats by common agreement should be advised to finish indigo or other crops for the current year.
('15', 370, 1, 4, 727686) But thenceforth, whether it is indigo or any other crop, it should be only under a system of absolute free will.
('15', 370, 2, 5, 727799) It will be observed that I have burdened this statement with as little argument as possible.
('15', 370, 2, 6, 727892) But if it is the desire of the Government that I should prove any of my conclusions, I shall be pleased to tender the proofs on which they are based.
('15', 370, 3, 7, 728042) In conclusion, I would like to state that I have no desire to hurt the planters’ feelings.
('15', 370, 3, 8, 728133) I have received every courtesy from them.
('15', 370, 3, 9, 728175) Believing as I do that the raiyats are labouring under a grievous wrong from which they ought to be freed immediately, I have dealt, as calmly as is possible for me to do so, with the system which the planters are working.
('15', 370, 3, 10, 728398) I have entered upon my mission in the hope that they as Englishmen born to enjoy the fullest personal liberty and freedom will not fail to rise to their status and will not begrudge the raiyats the same measure of liberty and freedom.
('15', 370, 4, 11, 728633) I am sending copies to the Commissioner of the Tirhut Division, the Collector of Champaran, the Subdivisional Officer of Bettiah, the Manager of the Bettiah Raj, the Secretaries, respectively, of the Bihar Planters’ Association and the District Planters’ Association.
('15', 370, 4, 12, 728901) I am circulating them also among those leaders of public opinion in the country who have kept themselves in touch with the work being done by my colleagues and myself.
('15', 370, 4, 13, 729069) The copies are being marked not for publication, as there is no desire to invite a public discussion of the question unless it becomes absolutely necessary.
('15', 370, 5, 14, 729226) I need hardly give the assurance that I am at the disposal of the Government whenever my presence may be required.

('15', 371, 1, 2, 729455) 302. NOTES ON THE POSITION IN CHAMPARAN TO DATE 1
('15', 371, 2, 3, 729505) BETTIAH, May 14, 1917
('15', 371, 3, 4, 729527) CONFIDENTIAL Since the withdrawal of the order of the Magistrate served on Mr. Gandhi, the work of recording statements has continued without interruption.
('15', 371, 3, 5, 729683) Nearly 4000 statements have been taken.
('15', 371, 3, 6, 729723) Rayats have flocked to the two stations, Motihari and Bettiah.
('15', 371, 3, 7, 729786) The rush has been so great that the volunteers have not been able to cope with the work from day to day.
('15', 371, 3, 8, 729891) The volunteers are all local pleaders who have performed their work with great zeal and devotion.
('15', 371, 3, 9, 729989) Babu Brajakishore Prasad has superintended this part of the work.
('15', 371, 3, 10, 730055) The names of the other volunteers are: Babu Rajendra Prasad 2, Babu Dharanidhar 3, Babu Gorakh Prasad, Babu Ramnawami Prasad 4, Babu Sambhusaran 5 and Babu Anugrah Narain Sinha 6. Chance comers have also assisted occasionally.
('15', 371, 3, 11, 730282) Several villages have been visited and hundreds of rayats have been seen in their homes.
('15', 371, 3, 12, 730371) Planters have been always invited to attend the meetings with the rayats.
('15', 371, 3, 13, 730445) They have, however, not attended.
('15', 371, 3, 14, 730479) Their jamadars 7 have.
('15', 371, 3, 15, 730502) Planters have been individually seen by Mr. Gandhi and there was a conference between representative planters and him.
('15', 371, 3, 16, 730621) The planters were quite courteous but uncompromising.
('15', 371, 3, 17, 730675) They overstated their case,
('15', 371, 4, 18, 730703) 1 These appear to have been prepared by Gandhiji from time to time to brief his co workers and also (vide Note III) editors of the sympathetic papers to enable them to write with understanding of the real situation in Champaran.
('15', 371, 4, 19, 730932) Numbers III, V and VI in this series are signed by Gandhiji; No.
('15', 371, 4, 20, 730997) IV has not become available and it is not clear if this is No.

('15', 372, 1, 2, 731682) inasmuch as they claimed that they had always acted as benefactors of their rayats and that they had protected them from the rapacity of moneylenders.
('15', 372, 1, 3, 731833) Frequent interviews have taken place between the local officials and Mr. Gandhi.
('15', 372, 1, 4, 731914) The former have been more open than the planters and have certainly shown a desire for amicable settlement.
('15', 372, 1, 5, 732022) The officials have never concealed their opinion that they did not approve of the mission.
('15', 372, 1, 6, 732113) Some of them only reluctantly carried out the Government instructions to give Mr. Gandhi every facility.
('15', 372, 1, 7, 732218) The result has been that it has not been always an easy matter to obtain information from them.
('15', 372, 1, 8, 732314) They have expressed stronger disapproval of the presence of the helpers mentioned above.
('15', 372, 1, 9, 732403) The Sub divisional Officer at Bettiah often said 1 that he was afraid of a conflagration taking place any day by reason of the inquiry.
('15', 372, 1, 10, 732539) He said that the rayats had grown bolder and had formed a highly exaggerated notion of the results of the mission.
('15', 372, 1, 11, 732654) He even reported to the Government that unless the inquiry could be stopped, he could not be responsible for the peace of the district under his charge.
('15', 372, 1, 12, 732807) Some planters, too, went to Ranchi to complain to the Government that they were afraid of their own safety if the inquiry was continued.
('15', 372, 1, 13, 732944) It was on account of this that Mr. Gandhi was invited to meet Hon’ble Mr. Maude at Bankipur on the 10th instant.
('15', 372, 2, 14, 733057) An outwork has been burnt down.
('15', 372, 2, 15, 733089) 2 The planters grew nervous and even suggested that it might be due to our inquiry.
('15', 372, 2, 16, 733173) There seems to be no connection between the fire and the inquiry.
('15', 372, 3, 17, 733239) Mr. Maude suggested 3 that the inquiry might now usefully be closed entirely and that Mr. Gandhi might submit his report to the Government.
('15', 372, 3, 18, 733379) and that if the inquiry could not be stopped, Mr. Gandhi should withdraw the ‘pleader friends’ from the district.
('15', 372, 3, 19, 733493) Mr. Gandhi stated that the inquiry could not be entirely stopped but that he had advanced far enough to enable him to frame preliminary conclusions, that he could not as a point of honour think of dispensing with the help of the pleader friends whom he considered to be as sober and honourable as himself and who were of the greatest assistance to him in his work.
('15', 372, 3, 20, 733858) Mr. Maude was quite conciliatory in his conversation.
('15', 372, 4, 21, 733912) 1 Vide “Letter to W. H. Lewis”, 28 4 1917.

('15', 373, 1, 2, 734122) The enclosed representation 1 is the result of the interview.
('15', 373, 1, 3, 734184) The inquiry continues except to the extent that, instead of statements being recorded as heretofore by the volunteers, Mr. Gandhi will himself, as soon as he is free to be able to do so, sit for a few hours daily among the rayats and after hearing their statements 2 record his impressions.
('15', 373, 1, 4, 734475) The representation is deliberately an understatement.
('15', 373, 1, 5, 734529) The condition of the rayat is far worse than is pictured there.
('15', 373, 1, 6, 734593) It is not capable of being understood by a layman.
('15', 373, 1, 7, 734644) The planters’ rule has practically supplanted the rule of the local Government.
('15', 373, 1, 8, 734724) Nobody has the courage to speak up for the rayats.
('15', 373, 1, 9, 734775) The latter do not readily get the assistance of the local mukhtars 3. Many have privately come to Mr. Gandhi and told him much worse stories of oppression than have been recorded in the statements.
('15', 373, 1, 10, 734973) In Fiji and Natal, the evil was represented by a single law.
('15', 373, 1, 11, 735034) The evil was dealt with, if the law could be removed.
('15', 373, 1, 12, 735088) In Champaran, the evil is like a weed growing everywhere and anyhow and in growing has smothered all law and order.
('15', 373, 1, 13, 735204) The very laws for the protection of the rayats have been used by the planters to reduce them to serfdom.
('15', 373, 1, 14, 735309) As the planters have placed themselves above law, even decrees of courts have had no binding effect on them in many cases.
('15', 373, 1, 15, 735432) The evil, therefore, will require a tremendous effort before it is checked.
('15', 373, 1, 16, 735508) No stone is being left unturned to induce the planters to do justice without the necessity of a great and very serious public agitation.
('15', 373, 1, 17, 735645) The desire is, by inviting the Government to deal with the planters firmly, to avoid the publication of a report which is bound to stagger India.
('15', 373, 1, 18, 735791) Public men and women of India will never be able to sit still if the report has ever to be published until the wrongs it will narrate are remedied.
('15', 373, 1, 19, 735939) The mere narration is calculated to rouse passions and therefore every effort is being made to bring about a settlement without any public agitation.
('15', 373, 1, 20, 736089) If the settlement comes or even if it does not, it is necessary to post volunteers in villages to act as links between the planters and rayats, to steel the latter’s hearts and by their very presence to protect them from the tyranny of the amlas, etc.
('15', 373, 1, 21, 736341) The volunteers will be expected to remain in the villages for at least six months.
('15', 373, 1, 22, 736424) Their work will be smooth, if the Government approve of their
('15', 373, 2, 23, 736486) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('15', 373, 3, 24, 736513) 2 Vide “Statement of Peasants taken by Gandhiji”, 19 5 1917.

('15', 374, 1, 2, 736628) pre sence; it will be risky if they do not.
('15', 374, 1, 3, 736672) It is to be done in any event.
('15', 374, 1, 4, 736703) Whilst they are in the villages, they will teach the village boys and girls and will give the rayats lessons in elementary sanitation.
('15', 374, 1, 5, 736838) It may be stated that the rayat are the most backward and ignorant of almost any in India.
('15', 374, 1, 6, 736929) Education is admittedly in the lowest stage in this dis trict.
('15', 374, 1, 7, 736992) Sanitation is of the worst type.
('15', 374, 1, 8, 737025) Children are ill looking because they are ill fed.
('15', 374, 1, 9, 737076) The adult population suffers from some disease or other.
('15', 374, 1, 10, 737133) Many suffer from an ugly growth on the throat called goitre.
('15', 374, 1, 11, 737194) They have no physical or moral stamina.

('15', 374, 1, 18, 737708) At least a hundred such volunteers are required.
('15', 374, 1, 19, 737757) Those who need support for their families will have it given them, so far as it is on a moderate scale.

('15', 378, 7, 10, 743281) 310. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL GANDHI
('15', 378, 8, 11, 743314) BETTIAH, Vaishakh Vad 11, May 17,1917
('15', 378, 9, 12, 743352) CHHAGANLAL, There is no harm in sending the report of the Benares speech as revised by me.
('15', 378, 10, 13, 743443) You need not henceforth send Jamnadas’s letters here for he has resumed writing to me.
('15', 378, 10, 14, 743530) The one you sent this time, I am forwarding to Narandas.
('15', 378, 10, 15, 743587) He doesn’t seem to have seen it.
('15', 378, 10, 16, 743620) You may inform me if there is anything particular in his letter.
('15', 378, 10, 17, 743685) You need not send a puggree for me here.
('15', 378, 10, 18, 743726) I am carrying on with what I have.

('15', 382, 6, 10, 750829) DEAR MR. HOLTTUM 2, I thank you for having come to Sariswa 3 and having sent your carriage.
('15', 382, 6, 11, 750921) After you and Mr. Lewis had withdrawn, I sat with the people who must have numbered over 500 and talked to them.
('15', 382, 6, 12, 751034) I told them that you wanted to do justice, that you were ready to take back the zirat 4 lands and that you considered that it was more profitable to you to get it back.
('15', 382, 6, 13, 751203) I told them too that in your opinion the people had taken the zirat lands from your predecessor not only willingly but most eagerly, that it was given to the raiyats not in lieu of indigo cultivation but it was given in order to relieve the raiyats from liability to supply labour to the landlord.
('15', 382, 6, 14, 751501) I further told them that you had shown me Mr. Barclay’s 5 letter to Mr. Gourlay 6 confirming the view and finally told them, whilst on this point, that if they returned the

('15', 383, 1, 2, 752198) zirat lands, you expected them to grow indigo again as before up to the termination of the period of their contracts and I assured them that I would plead with you that it would be quite unfair to ask for raiyats to revert to indigo growing (for reasons to be presently stated).
('15', 383, 1, 3, 752477) I then invited those who wanted to abandon the zirat at once, although they had paid for the full agricultural year.
('15', 383, 1, 4, 752594) As a result, over 175 gave in their names there and then and men have been streaming in during the two days.

('15', 383, 1, 6, 752763) In going through the khatians 1, the receipts and the amounts charged against the zirat land, I find in 70 tenancies that on an average the raiyats are paying you Rs. 24.5.3 per bigha 2 of zirat land.
('15', 383, 1, 7, 752964) The largest amount charged is Rs. 91.7.3 per bigha and the smallest is Rs. 7.8.0 per bigha.
('15', 383, 1, 8, 753056) Incidentally, I observe that whilst 27 bighas of kasht 3 land pay Rs. 59.13.6, 27 bighas of zirat land pay you Rs. 659.7.0. It seems that in the vast majority of cases, the raiyats hold less than one bigha of zirat land.
('15', 383, 1, 9, 753277) The rate fixed varies with the extent of their kasht holding and not with the quality of the zirat.

('15', 383, 1, 12, 753626) The average worked out for fifty villagers comes to 1_ kathas per bigha.
('15', 383, 1, 13, 753699) This, in my opinion, hardly bears out Mr. Barclay’s contention.
('15', 383, 1, 14, 753763) It rather bears out the raiyats’ contention that the settlement of zirat is another form of the tinkathia and was designed to cover the losses suffered by the concern when the price of indigo fell.
('15', 383, 1, 15, 753961) The raiyats insist that pressure was effectively put upon them to take zirat land.
('15', 383, 1, 16, 754044) Their contention seems to be borne out by the readiness with which they have come forward to surrender it.
('15', 383, 1, 17, 754151) For the last ten years, the raiyats have been paying what according to the above view amounts to tawan for not growing indigo.
('15', 383, 1, 18, 754278) And the concern has on that account an average of more than Rs. 100 per bigha of tinkathia.
('15', 383, 1, 19, 754370) In the circumstances and regard being had to the fact that you believe it to be advantageous for you to receive back the zirat land, I hope you will not press for reversion to indigo growing.

('15', 384, 1, 2, 754753) I notice that in some cases damages have been settled on kathas taken out of the kasht land of the raiyats.
('15', 384, 1, 3, 754861) I venture to think that, if you would see your way to accept my suggestion, take back the zirat and forgo the future damage whether tacked on to the zirat or to the kasht land, one of the sorest points of dispute between the concern and the raiyats would be amicably settled and you will have set an example which would be advantageously followed by the other planters.
('15', 384, 1, 4, 755231) In describing the process adopted by the concern for recovering losses on indigo from the raiyats, I have hitherto confined myself to your mukarrari land.

('15', 384, 1, 8, 755618) The raiyats for the sake of peace and compromise should say nothing as to refund either on the hunda above referred to or the tawan already collected and of which the handnotes represent the balance.
('15', 384, 1, 9, 755818) As to the fines, I must confess that there is overwhelming evidence to show that they have been imposed on recalcitrant raiyats.
('15', 384, 1, 10, 755947) This complaint is almost universal.
('15', 384, 1, 11, 755983) I told the raiyats that you said that only nominal fines were imposed when the raiyats came to you for adjustment of their mutual quarrels and that you refunded these to the winners.
('15', 384, 1, 12, 756166) The raiyats resolutely protested and said that the fines even as much as Rs. 25 at a time and more were imposed for the so called offences against the concern.
('15', 384, 1, 13, 756326) The raiyats are equally firm in their complaint against your jamadar, Gokul Missir, and I would be pleased to place the evidence before you if you will care to go further into the matter.
('15', 384, 1, 14, 756514) With reference to the method (I understand only recently adopted) of the charging for permission to build new buildings or to rebuild, you justified the charge on the ground that the earth on the raiyats’ tenement belonged to the landlord and if the raiyats used it for building purposes, they must pay for it.
('15', 384, 1, 15, 756825) I find, on looking up the Bengal Tenancy Act, that the law allows the raiyats to build without any interference from the landlord so long as they build for the benefit of their holdings.
('15', 384, 1, 16, 757012) It seems to me that the charge is not warranted by law and I hope that you will waive it in future.
('15', 384, 1, 17, 757112) There remains then the question of cutting trees.
('15', 384, 1, 18, 757162) The section of the Bengal Tenancy Act dealing with the subject clearly allows the
('15', 385, 0, 1, 757244) 386 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 385, 1, 2, 757286) raiyat to cut without previous notice to or permission of the landlord.
('15', 385, 1, 3, 757358) But I understand that of late years the landlords have all over been receiving half of the timber cut.
('15', 385, 1, 4, 757461) I do not know whether the custom has been proved; this is a large question which can await settlement.
('15', 385, 1, 5, 757564) I await papers promised by you regarding Kodai Pan.
('15', 385, 1, 6, 757616) As to Sitaram Tewari 1, I think Rs. 36 on 11 kathas is a clerical error and I venture to suggest that it would be graceful on your part to recognize the error and take the rent at the usual assessment rate.
('15', 385, 1, 7, 757823) I would beg of you to carefully consider the points mentioned herein and, if you can grant relief to your raiyats in accordance with the suggestions made above, I do not doubt that it will lead to a lasting peace between your concern and its raiyats and, what is more, it will be a simple act of justice.

('15', 386, 4, 5, 759121) 315. LETTER TO W. B. HEYCOCK
('15', 386, 5, 6, 759150) BETTIAH, May 20, 1917
('15', 386, 6, 7, 759172) DEAR MR. HEYCOCK, I have hitherto refrained from bringing to your notice statements, which have continued to stream in, to the effect that the raiyats are being prevented from coming in to me and that those who have come in have been subjected to all kinds of pinpricks by the kothi amlas and in some cases by the managers themselves.
('15', 386, 6, 8, 759507) I have discounted some of the statements.
('15', 386, 6, 9, 759549) I have taken down a few.
('15', 386, 6, 10, 759574) But if what I have heard about the doings of the Belwa and the Dhokraha concerns is true, it is calculated to end on one side at least, the friendly spirit in which the inquiry has hitherto been carried on.
('15', 386, 6, 11, 759781) I am most anxious to continue and to increase the friendly spirit.
('15', 386, 6, 12, 759848) I am straining every [nerve], so far as in me lies, to so conduct my mission that nothing but good will should be left behind, when its labours are finished.
('15', 386, 6, 13, 760006) I send you the statements 1 taken regarding the Belwa and the Dhokraha concerns.
('15', 386, 6, 14, 760087) If the statements are true, they do not reflect any credit upon the concerns in question.
('15', 386, 6, 15, 760177) I enclose, too, my letter 2 to Mr. Holttum which was written before I heard of the fire and which was despatched before I took the statements of the Dhokraha men last evening after 6.30 P.M. I can understand and even appreciate the feelings which are bound to fill those who are called upon to contemplate the prospect of having to forego huge incomes which they have hitherto been in the habit for a long time of receiving from their raiyats.
('15', 386, 6, 16, 760621) One cannot, therefore, mind any legitimate effort on their part to hold on to what they have considered as their rights.
('15', 386, 6, 17, 760742) But what is reported to have happened at the Belwa and Dhokraha dehats does not in my opinion fall under such a category.
('15', 386, 7, 18, 760864) 1 Vide Appendix “Statements of peasants taken by Gandhiji”, 19 5 1917.
('15', 386, 8, 19, 760935) 2 Vide “Letter to A. K. Holttum”, 19 5 1917.
('15', 387, 0, 1, 760980) 388 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 387, 1, 2, 761022) It is a known fact that the desire of the planters generally is, that my friends and I should not carry on our work.
('15', 387, 1, 3, 761139) I can only say that nothing but physical force from the Government or an absolute guarantee that the admitted or provable wrongs of the raiyats are to stop for ever, can possibly remove us from the District.
('15', 387, 1, 4, 761347) What I have seen of the conditions of the raiyats is sufficient to convince me that if we withdrew at this stage, we would stand condemned before man and God and, what is most important of all, we would never be able to forgive ourselves.
('15', 387, 1, 5, 761586) But the mission is totally of peace.
('15', 387, 1, 6, 761623) I cannot too often give the assurance that I bear no ill will against the planters.
('15', 387, 1, 7, 761707) I have been told that this is true of myself but that my friends are fired with an anti English feeling and that for them this is an anti English movement.
('15', 387, 1, 8, 761863) I can only say that I do not know a body of men who have less of that feeling than my friends.
('15', 387, 1, 9, 761958) I was not prepared for this pleasant revelation.
('15', 387, 1, 10, 762007) I was prepared for some degree of ill will.
('15', 387, 1, 11, 762051) I would have held it excusable.
('15', 387, 1, 12, 762083) I do not know that I have not been guilty of it myself under circumstances which have appeared to me most provoking.
('15', 387, 1, 13, 762200) But if I found that any of my associates were, in the conduct of this mission, actuated by any ill will at all, I should disassociate myself entirely from them and insist upon their leaving the mission.
('15', 387, 1, 14, 762403) At the same time, the determination to secure a freedom for the raiyats from the yoke that is wearing them down is inflexible.
('15', 387, 1, 15, 762530) Cannot the Government secure that freedom?
('15', 387, 1, 16, 762573) This is a natural exclamation.
('15', 387, 1, 17, 762604) My answer is that they cannot, in cases like this, without such assistance as is afforded to them by my mission.
('15', 387, 1, 18, 762717) The Government machinery is designedly slow.
('15', 387, 1, 19, 762762) It moves, must move, along the line of least resistance.
('15', 387, 1, 20, 762819) Reformers like myself, who have no other axe to grind but that of reform they are handling for the time being, specialize and create a force which the Government must reckon with.
('15', 387, 1, 21, 762999) Reformers may go wrong by being overzealous, indiscreet or indolent and ignorant.
('15', 387, 1, 22, 763081) The Government may go wrong by being impatient of them or over confident of their ability to do without them.
('15', 387, 1, 23, 763191) I hope, in this case, neither catastrophe will take place and the grievances, which I have already submitted and which are mostly admitted, will be effectively redressed.
('15', 387, 1, 24, 763362) Then the planters will have no cause to fear or suspect the mission of which I have the honour to be in charge and they will gladly accept the assistance of volunteers who will carry on the work of education and sanitation among the villagers and act as links between them and the raiyats.
('15', 388, 0, 1, 763652) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 389
('15', 388, 1, 2, 763694) Pray, excuse the length of this letter as also its argumentative character.
('15', 388, 1, 3, 763770) I could not avoid it, if I was to place my true position before you.
('15', 388, 1, 4, 763839) In bringing the two matters which have necessitated this communication, I have no desire to seek legal relief.
('15', 388, 1, 5, 763950) But I ask you to use such administrative influence as you can to preserve the friendly spirit which has hitherto prevailed between the kothis and my friends and myself.
('15', 388, 2, 6, 764119) I do not wish to suggest that the kothis in question are responsible for the fire.
('15', 388, 2, 7, 764202) That is the suspicion of some of the raiyats.
('15', 388, 2, 8, 764248) I have talked to hundreds of them about the two fires.
('15', 388, 2, 9, 764303) They say that the raiyats are not responsible for them, that they have no connection with the mission.
('15', 388, 2, 10, 764406) I readily accept this repudiation because we are incessantly telling the raiyats that this is not a mission of violence or reprisals and that any such thing on their part can only delay relief.
('15', 388, 2, 11, 764600) But if the kothis may not be held responsible for them, they may not seek to establish a connection between them and the mission.
('15', 388, 2, 12, 764730) Fires have taken place before now, and, mission or no mission, they will take place for ever.
('15', 388, 2, 13, 764824) Neither party may blame the other without the clearest possible proofs.
('15', 388, 3, 14, 764896) There is talk, too, about the lives of the planters being in danger.
('15', 388, 3, 15, 764965) Surely this cannot be serious talk.
('15', 388, 3, 16, 765001) Anyway, the mission cannot render them less safe than they are.
('15', 388, 3, 17, 765065) The character of the mission is wholly against any such activity.
('15', 388, 3, 18, 765131) It is designed to seek relief by self suffering, never by doing violence to the supposed or real wrongdoer.
('15', 388, 3, 19, 765239) And this lesson has been inculcated among the raiyats in season and out of season.Lastly, there is, I fear, ample proof of intimidation such as is described in the statements thereto attached.
('15', 388, 3, 20, 765432) Intimidation can only mean more trouble all round without meaning the slightest relief to the planters in the shape of retention of the present system.
('15', 388, 3, 21, 765584) I seek such help as you can vouchsafe in the circumstances I have ventured to place before you.
('15', 388, 3, 22, 765680) I am sending a copy to Mr. Lewis.
('15', 388, 4, 23, 765714) Yours truly,
('15', 388, 5, 24, 765727) M. K. GANDHI

('15', 390, 0, 1, 767510) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 391
('15', 390, 1, 2, 767552) 317. NOTES ON THE SITUATION IN CHAMPARAN III
('15', 390, 2, 3, 767597) (Dated Bettiah, the 20th May 1917)
('15', 390, 3, 4, 767632) BETTIAH, May 21 1, 1917
('15', 390, 4, 5, 767656) CONFIDENTIAL This is the 3rd note on the situation in Champaran.
('15', 390, 4, 6, 767721) The planters are, it is evident, trying to quash the mission or to discredit it.
('15', 390, 4, 7, 767802) The first remedy to secure their end was to tell the Government that their lives were in danger, owing to the presence of the mission in Champaran, and to suggest that there should be a commission appointed to investigate the relations between the planters and rayats.
('15', 390, 4, 8, 768071) Their lives are no more in danger now than they were before.
('15', 390, 4, 9, 768132) The rayats are too docile, and too much cowed down to attempt any such thing even if they wished it; moreover, the creed of the mission is absence of violence under every conceivable circumstance.
('15', 390, 5, 10, 768329) Mr. Gandhi himself, in his letter 2 to the Viceroy, written just after his arrival, suggested a commission, when he was about to be imprisoned.
('15', 390, 5, 11, 768473) But in the light of the discoveries since made, any commission can only delay relief.
('15', 390, 5, 12, 768559) And the leaders, after knowing the situation as it is partly disclosed in the representation to the Government already sent to them, cannot contemplate the possibility of the grievances continuing for an indefinite time.
('15', 390, 5, 13, 768780) Most of the serious grievances are admitted.
('15', 390, 5, 14, 768825) They have not disappeared because the Government have been supine.
('15', 390, 5, 15, 768892) They have been afraid to apply the remedies with firmness.
('15', 390, 5, 16, 768951) They have placed too much reliance upon the good faith of the planters.
('15', 390, 5, 17, 769023) And the planters have disregarded both the laws and the Government instructions.
('15', 390, 5, 18, 769104) No commission can deal with such a situation.
('15', 390, 5, 19, 769150) The Government alone can do it, if they wish or are forced.
('15', 390, 5, 20, 769210) It is clear that the planters want a commission, which would supplant and extinguish the activities of the mission.
('15', 390, 5, 21, 769326) The workers in the cause cannot, without doing the greatest violence to their conscience, retire in favour of a commission.
('15', 390, 5, 22, 769450) The appointment of the
('15', 390, 6, 23, 769473) 1 Gandhiji appears to have begun this note on the 20th and to have concluded it on the 21st.
('15', 390, 6, 24, 769566) 2Vide “Letter to Private Secretary to Viceroy”, 16 4 1917.
('15', 391, 0, 1, 769625) 392 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 391, 1, 2, 769667) commission can, therefore, be accepted only if the continuing wrongs are remedied now, and if the members appointed on the commission are such as to inspire confidence, and this on the understanding that the mission is to continue its work.
('15', 391, 1, 3, 769908) The scope of it will be changed if a commission is appointed, i.e., the mission instead of conducting the enquiry will be collecting evidence to be placed before the commission, and taking the villagers’ statements.
('15', 391, 1, 4, 770124) The wrongs that must be redressed before a commission is accepted are (i) the abolition, not in name but in reality, of abwabs or illegal cesses exacted by the planters, (ii) the abolition of the damages in lieu of the indigo cultivations whether in a lump sum or by way of sharahbeshi, (iii) the abolition of tinkanthia in every shape or form, (iv) the abolition of the custom of imposing fines on raiyats, (v) the abolition of force in exacting labour or other obedience to the planters’ will.
('15', 391, 2, 5, 770620) What, therefore, the commission will enquire into will be: (l) the condition of the tenure of planters; (2) the propriety and possibility of securing for the rayats a refund of the illegal cesses already taken by the planters; (3) the condition under which labour has been received by the landlords; (4) the sufficiency or otherwise of the wages received by the labourers; (5) the causes of the deep poverty of the masses and their utter helplessness.
('15', 391, 3, 6, 771072) The above points have merely to be mentioned to know that the planters contemplate a commission totally different from the one we should accept.
('15', 391, 4, 7, 771217) The safest plan, therefore, for the Press and the public, in so far as it may be necessary to give an opinion, is to insist on the redress of the admitted wrongs first, and then accept appointment of a commission, if found necessary, it being always understood that the workers continue their work, in any event.
('15', 391, 5, 8, 771530) The second method adopted by the planters is to seize or create incidents in order to make the Government nervous about the mission and to intimidate the mission and its helpers.
('15', 391, 6, 9, 771709) One fire 1 has already been so used.
('15', 391, 6, 10, 771746) The popular belief is that the damage done is slight and that it is the work of the planters themselves.
('15', 391, 6, 11, 771851) But that idea may be dismissed.
('15', 391, 6, 12, 771883) The fire may be accepted as an accident or the act of an incendiary, not in any way connected
('15', 391, 7, 13, 771977) 1 At the Olaha factory
('15', 392, 0, 1, 772000) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 393
('15', 392, 1, 2, 772042) with the mission.
('15', 392, 1, 3, 772060) Mr. Heycock’s letter 1, in answer to Mr. Gandhi’s question 2, shows that (1) the damage done is at the mostRs. 20,000; he himself emphasises the fact that it is a rough estimate, i.e., given by the planters; (2) he has no evidence that there is the slightest connection between the enquiry and the fire.
('15', 392, 2, 4, 772364) To this may be added the fact that no member of the mission has gone to these parts, and that the outwork was not in use, when the fire broke out.
('15', 392, 2, 5, 772511) Another fire 3 broke out on the 19th instant.
('15', 392, 2, 6, 772557) A katcheri 4
('15', 392, 3, 7, 772570) has been burnt down.
('15', 392, 3, 8, 772591) It is not known whether it has been utilised by the planters for the end suggested above.
('15', 392, 3, 9, 772681) That fire did take place in a place just newly visited by the mission.
('15', 392, 3, 10, 772752) Mr. Gandhi went there on Wednesday and the fire broke out, on Friday last.
('15', 392, 3, 11, 772827) Immediately on the outbreak of the fire, information was brought to Mr. Gandhi that it was probably the work of the kothi people.
('15', 392, 3, 12, 772957) A statement 5 has been recorded to the effect that a factory man was seen the very evening removing a bundle of papers—the inference being that the papers were removed prior to setting the katcheri on fire.
('15', 392, 3, 13, 773164) Support is lent to the story from the fact that the manager and the Sub Divisional Officer were present at the enquiry for a short time on Wednesday, that the rayats mentioned—firmly that they were forcibly made to take zirat land, which was made to bear the losses which the concern suffered owing to the fall in the price of indigo, that the manager in bravado said that he would gladly take the zirat back, that Mr. Gandhi promptly invited the names of those who wanted to surrender the zirat land.
('15', 392, 3, 14, 773666) This mishap (to the concern) must have (so the theory runs) enraged the manager, and in order to discredit the enquiry, he must have instigated the fire.
('15', 392, 3, 15, 773820) On Thursday, the day previous to the fire, the manager went to a neighbouring village, and spoke roughly to the people, inasmuch as they had surrendered their zirat, and threatened them by saying he would insist on their re growing indigo.
('15', 392, 3, 16, 774060) The rayats remained unmoved.
('15', 392, 3, 17, 774089) This would be an additional reason for starting the fire.
('15', 392, 3, 18, 774147) This, however, is purely an impression which may have no foundation in facts.
('15', 392, 3, 19, 774225) One thing is certain that the mission has
('15', 392, 4, 20, 774267) 1 Vide footnote 2 to “Letter to Associated Press of India”, on or after 14 5 1917. 2Vide “Letter to W. B. Heycock”, 14 5 1917.
('15', 392, 5, 21, 774394) 3 At Dhokraha 4 An office building 5 Vide Appendix “Statements of Peasants taken by Gandhiji”, 19 5 1917.

('15', 393, 1, 2, 774542) absolutely nothing to do with the fires.
('15', 393, 1, 3, 774583) The value of the katcheri is unknown.
('15', 393, 1, 4, 774621) It is not likely to be more than Rs. 200. 1
('15', 393, 2, 5, 774665) The third method adopted is continuous pinpricks administered to the villagers.
('15', 393, 2, 6, 774745) The latest instance of organised intimidation is where factory amlas went to a village, and molested the labourers of a small zamindar, who is a co sharer in a small zamindari with the factory, and who declines to surrender his share to it, and who is alleged to have circulated among the rayats the news of the mission.
('15', 393, 2, 7, 775066) Statements have been received abundantly proving the alleged intimidation.
('15', 393, 2, 8, 775141) Reports are continuously being received from individual rayats to the effect that they are threatened with all kinds of penalties for going to Mr. Gandhi and they come at considerable risk to themselves.
('15', 393, 3, 9, 775345) Needless to say that nothing will deter the workers from continuing their work.
('15', 393, 3, 10, 775425) To abandon it would mean a terrible wrong done to the rayats.
('15', 393, 3, 11, 775487) The presence of a body of workers, always listening to the simple but pathetic tale of their woes, and the knowledge that they are striving to help them and that the latter would go to them in the hour of need have buoyed them up and have given them hope and courage.
('15', 393, 3, 12, 775755) The workers will be unworthy of their cause and country, if through fear or anything else, they for a moment thought of withdrawing until the rayats are able to breathe free.
('15', 393, 4, 13, 775930) Mr. Gandhi has addressed to the District Magistrate of Champaran a letter 2 on the incidents above set forth.
('15', 393, 4, 14, 776040) Copies of this letter and other documents will be sent herewith or will shortly follow.
('15', 393, 4, 15, 776128) The precautions thus taken may restrain the planters in their plan of intimidation.
('15', 393, 4, 16, 776212) But the situation may develop at any moment and lawlessness may break out in intense form.
('15', 393, 4, 17, 776303) It will now be understood that if this happens, the fault will in no way be that of the members of the mission, and that the public will understand that the mission will continue its work.
('15', 393, 4, 18, 776492) The foregoing emphasises the need for getting volunteers ready, so that they may start at a moment’s notice.
('15', 393, 4, 19, 776601) The volunteers must be grown up, responsible, sober and educated men.
('15', 393, 4, 20, 776671) They should be inured to hardships or ready to bear hardships; they should come prepared to see the struggle through, they must have workable knowledge of Hindi (Tamils alone are, therefore, ineligible, unless
('15', 393, 5, 21, 776881) 1 Vide enclosure to “Letter to W. B. Heycock”, 22 5 1917.

('15', 394, 0, 1, 776965) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 395
('15', 394, 1, 2, 777007) they have picked up a little Hindi), they must be prepared to go to the villages and live in the midst of the rayats.
('15', 394, 1, 3, 777125) It is estimated that they will have to work for at least 6 months.
('15', 394, 2, 4, 777192) M. K. GANDHI

('15', 396, 8, 9, 779530) This morning at about 10 a.m.
('15', 396, 8, 10, 779560) some men came from Dhokraha and informed Mr. Gandhi that some officers had been there.
('15', 396, 8, 11, 779647) He was questioning them on the occurrence, when one of them said that he had heard that the doors of the kachahri had
('15', 396, 9, 12, 779765) been removed by the factory men before the fire.
('15', 396, 9, 13, 779814) I suggested that a local inspection might give us useful information.
('15', 396, 9, 14, 779884) Mr. Gandhi accepted the suggestion and asked me to go to Dhokraha personally.
('15', 396, 9, 15, 779962) Accordingly, I proceeded to the scene at once.I reached Dhokraha at about 11.30 a.m.

('15', 396, 10, 18, 780187) I asked him to fetch the chaukidar.
('15', 396, 10, 19, 780223) Meanwhile I proceeded to inspect the kachahri.
('15', 396, 11, 20, 780270) This kachahri is situated inside the compound of the residential bungalow of the manager of the concern.
('15', 396, 11, 21, 780375) It consists of a single room about 21 feet by 15 feet roughly.
('15', 396, 12, 22, 780438) The entire roof work has come down.
('15', 396, 12, 23, 780474) The walls are made of bricks, plastered with mud.
('15', 396, 12, 24, 780524) The whitewash on the walls, both inside and outside, is unaffected.
('15', 396, 12, 25, 780592) Black was noticeable at the top at four or five places only.
('15', 396, 12, 26, 780653) The appearance of the upper portion of the wall gives one the impression that the rafter of the roof must have been pulled away to prevent the spreading of the fire.
('15', 396, 12, 27, 780819) The roof was thatched with straw over which was placed a covering of country tiles.
('15', 396, 12, 28, 780903) .At places in the heap of rubbish were noticeable charred rafters, both outside and inside the room.
('15', 396, 12, 29, 781004) There was found a heap of partly burnt papers.
('15', 396, 12, 30, 781051) I examined them.
('15', 396, 12, 31, 781068) They were all siahas 2 and sattas.
('15', 396, 12, 32, 781103) The siahas were for the
('15', 396, 13, 33, 781127) 1 Watchman 2 Account books

('15', 397, 1, 2, 781196) year 1313 Fasli and the year 1315 Fasli 1. None of these were completely destroyed.

('15', 397, 11, 30, 782932) Whatever your parents may say, deep down they do wish that their devoted son and their daughter in law should be with them.
('15', 397, 11, 31, 783056) One of you two brothers should certainly stay with them.
('15', 397, 11, 32, 783113) If they are unwilling to come to Ahmedabad you should
('15', 397, 12, 33, 783167) 1 A harvest era introduced by Akbar.
