('15', 398, 1, 3, 783365) If the times were not awry why would families break up?
('15', 398, 1, 4, 783421) Hence, I am convinced that if Khushalbhai does not come to Ahmedabad, one of you brothers must stay at Rajkot.
('15', 398, 1, 5, 783532) We assume that there is nothing wrong in our women going to their in laws or their parents for delivery.
('15', 398, 1, 6, 783637) This too I think is not right.
('15', 398, 1, 7, 783668) Why should Narandas send Jamna to Rajkot?
('15', 398, 1, 8, 783710) Why can’t you see that if the delivery cannot take place in Bombay, it is not a fit place to live in?
('15', 398, 1, 9, 783812) Who will see Jamna through her delivery?
('15', 398, 1, 10, 783853) Had Dev Bhabhi 1 not been an invalid it would have been simple.
('15', 398, 1, 11, 783917) Now she cannot be expected to attend to such jobs.
('15', 398, 1, 12, 783968) It is our duty to make our parents feel in their old age that it is not only we who are their children but that they are the progenitors of the world at large.
('15', 398, 1, 13, 784128) This can happen only when we do not make them slave for us.
('15', 398, 1, 14, 784188) It is the duty of a husband to be with his wife during child birth.
('15', 398, 1, 15, 784256) (This last is a separate idea but I am mentioning it here.) Why is Santok at Morvi?
('15', 398, 1, 16, 784340) I am troubled by the information.
('15', 398, 1, 17, 784374) Her duty solely was to serve the sick at Rajkot.
('15', 398, 1, 18, 784423) She should not have left the house at Rajkot even for a single moment.
('15', 398, 1, 19, 784494) That is my view.
('15', 398, 1, 20, 784511) I realize that if Santok does not feel so she cannot be forced to do it.
('15', 398, 1, 21, 784584) I am writing this for consideration of the matter to the extent that Maganlal has sympathy with it.
('15', 398, 1, 22, 784684) Maganlal too is one of us.
('15', 398, 1, 23, 784711) All that he can say is: ‘this is worth doing and this is not.’ He cannot go beyond that.
('15', 398, 1, 24, 784800) It occurs to me that I should put before you two the question whether our education has in some way harmed the purity of filial devotion.
('15', 398, 1, 25, 784938) If you think it proper let Narandas read this letter.
('15', 398, 1, 26, 784992) My mind is otherwise occupied and right now I have some other work to attend to.
('15', 398, 1, 27, 785073) Hence, I have not found the peace of mind that is requisite for writing this letter.
('15', 398, 1, 28, 785158) Usually I have peace at this time.
('15', 398, 1, 29, 785193) It is just six o’clock in the morning.
('15', 398, 1, 30, 785232) I am hesitating for fear that Narandas may not realize the import of my writing.
('15', 398, 1, 31, 785313) You two know me quite well and so I do not hesitate to put my jumbled ideas before you.
('15', 398, 1, 32, 785401) Jamnadas may read this letter.
('15', 398, 2, 33, 785432) Blessings from

('15', 401, 8, 12, 789240) 327. LETTER TO CHIEF SECRETARY, BIHAR AND ORISSA
('15', 401, 9, 13, 789289) BETTIAH, May 25, 1917
('15', 401, 10, 14, 789311) TO THE CHIEF SECRETARY THE GOVERNMENT OF BIHAR AND ORISSA RANCHI
('15', 401, 11, 15, 789376) SIR, I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letters of the 19th and the 21st instant.
('15', 401, 11, 16, 789476) I am grateful for the letters and the assurances contained therein.
('15', 401, 12, 17, 789544) 1 A leading planter; manager of the Motihari Indigo concern, the oldest in Champaran 2 Jurisdiction
('15', 402, 0, 1, 789644) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 403
('15', 402, 1, 2, 789686) I am suggesting that [as] the matters complained of by me required immediate treatment, it was not contemplated that the Government could pass orders without receiving reports from the local officers and without hearing the landlords.
('15', 402, 1, 3, 789921) Had I intended otherwise, the sending of copies of my note 1 to the local officers and the Planters’ Associations would have been purposeless.
('15', 402, 1, 4, 790064) If I may be permitted to say so, the instructions to the local officers and the invitation to the Planters’ Associations to send in their reports or observations, as the case may be, before the 30th June next largely meets the situation in point of time.
('15', 402, 1, 5, 790319) With reference to the legal aspect and the decisions of courts, they have not escaped attention.
('15', 402, 1, 6, 790416) But I venture to submit that legal decisions or legal technicalities cannot for a moment be allowed to perpetuate wrongs suffered by vast masses of people.
('15', 402, 1, 7, 790572) With much respect, but every confidence, I submit that the situation presented by me raises grave moral issues which in order that justice may be done might necessitate disregard of legal technicalities and legal decisions where they are in conflict with real justice.
('15', 402, 1, 8, 790841) The vast inequality between landlords and rayats renders it well nigh impossible for courts of law or even Settlement Officers to arrive at the truth in cases brought before them.
('15', 402, 1, 9, 791021) I see illustrations of the proposition just submitted multiplying before me every day.
('15', 402, 1, 10, 791108) Instances are not wanting of wrongs having been rectified in spite of their having been countenanced by courts of justice.
('15', 402, 1, 11, 791231) Regarding abwabs, I may be permitted to point out that the inclusion of a penalty clause in the forthcoming Bettiah Raj leases will grant only partial and tardy relief.
('15', 402, 1, 12, 791400) For the leases will not cover the whole of the tenancies affected, and with respect to a wrong which has been unanimously admitted, the postponement of relief till the termination of and the renewal of the leases means unnecessary delay.
('15', 402, 1, 13, 791638) I take it that the leases will not be renewed until the agrarian condition is placed on a sound basis.
('15', 402, 1, 14, 791741) It may be added that a penalty clause in his lease is no remedy against a landlord who places himself above law.
('15', 402, 1, 15, 791854) In my humble opinion, therefore, the issue of a notice warning landlords against exacting abwabs, salami 2, fines, etc., or impressing labour, carts, or ploughs and informing raiyats that they ought not to pay them and that they are not bound to give their landlords their labour
('15', 402, 2, 16, 792134) 1 Vide “Report on Condition of Ryots in Champaran”, 13 5 1917.
('15', 402, 3, 17, 792197) 2 Presents
('15', 403, 0, 1, 792208) 404 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 403, 1, 2, 792250) or carts or ploughs will be most appropriate at the present moment, will ease the raiyats’ minds and will be an earnest of the Government’s desire to grant them speedy relief where relief is deemed necessary.
('15', 403, 2, 3, 792459) I have the honour to be,
('15', 403, 4, 4, 792484) Your most obedient servant,

('15', 406, 1, 2, 796951) 332. SPREADING HINDI 1
('15', 406, 2, 3, 796974) Hindi alone can become the common language of the educated people of India.
('15', 406, 2, 4, 797050) All that has to be considered is how this can be brought about.
('15', 406, 2, 5, 797114) The place that English is trying to usurp today, and which it is impossible for it to take, must be given to Hindi; for it alone has the right to it.
('15', 406, 2, 6, 797264) This place cannot go to English, for it is a foreign language and very difficult for us to learn.
('15', 406, 2, 7, 797362) Learning Hindi is child’s play in comparison.
('15', 406, 2, 8, 797408) The number of those speaking Hindi is almost 65 million.
('15', 406, 2, 9, 797465) The Bengali, Bihari, Oriya, Marathi, Gujarati, Rajasthani, Punjabi and Sindhi languages are sisters of Hindi.
('15', 406, 2, 10, 797575) People speaking these languages can understand and speak a little of Hindi.
('15', 406, 2, 11, 797651) If we include these, the number is almost 220 million.
('15', 406, 2, 12, 797706) How then can English, which even a hundred thousand Indians cannot speak correctly, compete successfully with a language which is so widely used?
('15', 406, 2, 13, 797852) That to this day we have not even begun conducting our national business in Hindi is because of our cowardice, lack of faith and ignorance of the greatness of the Hindi language.
('15', 406, 2, 14, 798031) If we give up our cowardice, cultivate faith and realize the greatness of the Hindi language, Hindi will begin to be used for the work of our national and Provincial councils and Government or ganizations.
('15', 406, 2, 15, 798237) The beginning should be made in the Provinces.
('15', 406, 2, 16, 798284) If there is some difficulty in this, it is for people speaking the Dravidian languages like Tamil, etc., but we have the remedy for this too.
('15', 406, 2, 17, 798426) Hindi knowing men who are zealous, brave, full of self respect and energetic should be sent to Madras and other provinces to teach Hindi without receiving payment.
('15', 406, 2, 18, 798590) With the help of such heroic missionaries, the educated people of Madras, etc.
('15', 406, 2, 19, 798669) can learn Hindi in a very short time.
('15', 406, 2, 20, 798707) If we have the right spirit, the solution is as simple as the rule of three.
('15', 406, 2, 21, 798784) The more instructors are sent, the faster will be the spread of Hindi.
('15', 406, 2, 22, 798855) Besides the sending of teachers, self instruction books should also be prepared.
('15', 406, 2, 23, 798936) These books should be distributed free.
('15', 406, 2, 24, 798976) Famous speakers should also be sent to bring home to the people the importance of learning Hindi.
('15', 406, 2, 25, 799074) What it is necessary to do in Tamil Nad for the spread of Hindi, it is desirable to do in Bombay and other provinces.
('15', 406, 2, 26, 799192) Hindi books should be prepared for people speaking Marathi, Gujarati, etc., and
('15', 406, 3, 27, 799272) 1 This article in Hindi was sent for publication to various papers in May 1917.
('15', 407, 0, 1, 799352) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 407, 1, 2, 799394) workers should be sent to those areas.
('15', 407, 1, 3, 799433) This work requires money.
('15', 407, 1, 4, 799459) The well to do among us should not take it as a burden.
('15', 407, 1, 5, 799515) It is their duty to assist in this gigantic enterprise.
('15', 407, 1, 6, 799571) It is necessary to set up a small committee to organize this.
('15', 407, 1, 7, 799633) It will be proper to see that only active workers are put on it.
('15', 407, 1, 8, 799698) One important matter is implied in this submission and that is that no distinction is made between Hindi and Urdu.
('15', 407, 1, 9, 799813) Indeed, why should we quarrel with our Muslim brethren?
('15', 407, 1, 10, 799869) They may use the Persian script.
('15', 407, 1, 11, 799902) A few among us know the Persian script and more will learn it.
('15', 407, 1, 12, 799965) So long as our Muslim brethren have not learnt the Devnagari, both the scripts will continue to be used for national work.
('15', 407, 1, 13, 800088) However, this is a matter we can decide in a fraternal spirit with our Muslim brethren.
('15', 407, 1, 14, 800176) Right now the chief task is to spread the national language throughout India in the Devnagari script.

('15', 407, 3, 16, 800309) 333. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL GANDHI
('15', 407, 4, 17, 800342) BETTIAH, Tuesday [May 29, 1917] 1
('15', 407, 5, 18, 800376) CHHAGANLAL, I am sending you a letter from Prabhudas.
('15', 407, 5, 19, 800430) He is not with me at present.
('15', 407, 5, 20, 800460) I am going to tell him that he has written the letter half heartedly.
('15', 407, 5, 21, 800530) He should write on a good paper without smudging it and in detail.
('15', 407, 5, 22, 800597) I will tell him that.
('15', 407, 5, 23, 800619) You too may write to him something to that effect.
('15', 407, 5, 24, 800670) I do not want to hurt him, still I want him to make progress.
('15', 407, 5, 25, 800732) He is very happy here goes for walks.
('15', 407, 5, 26, 800770) He complains of headaches in the afternoon.
('15', 407, 5, 27, 800814) It seems there is some problem with his eyes.
('15', 407, 5, 28, 800860) He may require glasses after his eyes are examined.
('15', 407, 5, 29, 800912) His health is improving here.
('15', 407, 5, 30, 800942) He is able to eat well.

('15', 408, 7, 9, 801897) 334. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS ON CHAMPARAN COMMITTEE
('15', 408, 8, 10, 801948) BANKIPORE, May 29, 1917
('15', 408, 9, 11, 801972) With reference to The Pioneer’s statement announcing the Bihar Governments
('15', 408, 10, 12, 802047) intention to appoint a committee of enquiry into the relations between zamindars and
('15', 408, 11, 13, 802132) tenants in general and European planters and their ryots in particular, Mr. Gandhi has
('15', 408, 12, 14, 802219) issued the following statement to the Press.
('15', 408, 13, 15, 802264) If the continuing known wrongs are immediately redressed, any inquiry covering definite issues with a time limit as to its findings is likely to meet the existing situation.
('15', 408, 13, 16, 802438) The work of my colleagues and myself will then for the time being mostly consist in marshalling leading evidence before the enquiry committee.

('15', 409, 7, 10, 803047) 336. LETTER TO W. S. IRWIN
('15', 409, 8, 11, 803074) BETTIAH, May 30, 1917
('15', 409, 9, 12, 803096) DEAR SIR, Owing to certain statements made by your raiyats of Tola Gujpura Ramsingh, Chhatauni, I paid on Friday last a surprise visit to the Tola at about 8 p.m.
('15', 409, 9, 13, 803259) I met over fifty villagers and they pointed out to me a piece of land said to be 51 bighas in extent which (they said) had been recently converted by you into zirat.
('15', 409, 9, 14, 803425) They said that in most cases they were given an equivalent in extent but not in quality.
('15', 409, 9, 15, 803514) They pointed out the village pasturage bordering on the converted zirat which (they said) had now become practically inaccessible owing to the fear of their cattle being impounded.
('15', 409, 9, 16, 803695) They showed me also the only way (according to their statement) leading to the cattle pound, and said that they could not for the same fear use it as it passed by the zirat.
('15', 409, 9, 17, 803869) The men bitterly complained that the dispossession which they hold was forcible had caused them a great loss.
('15', 409, 9, 18, 803979) They stated that at the time of conversion they were made to put their thumb impressions to certain documents the contents of which they did not know and the
('15', 409, 10, 19, 804137) 1 Lieutenant Governor
('15', 410, 0, 1, 804159) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 411
('15', 410, 1, 2, 804201) copies of which they were not given.
('15', 410, 2, 3, 804238) Hiraman Lohar, who was one of the party, told me that he was assaulted on Sunday, the 20th instant, by your employees for having remonstrated with them on their trying to take his bhusa 1, and that he was only released on the importunity of the villagers who intervened on his behalf.
('15', 410, 2, 4, 804523) Nepali and Japal, nephew and son, respectively, of Hiraman, told me that as a result of the occurrence they were on their way to me.
('15', 410, 2, 5, 804656) The cry was raised that they were going to the thana.
('15', 410, 2, 6, 804710) Your men thereupon ran after them, seized them (so it is stated) and took them to you.
('15', 410, 2, 7, 804797) They added that you whipped them.
('15', 410, 2, 8, 804831) One of them showed strong marks on his calves and on his back.
('15', 410, 2, 9, 804894) They were sent by you to the murghikhana 2 and were fined Rs. 10 each.
('15', 410, 2, 10, 804965) They were released at midnight on their promising to secure the fines in the morning.
('15', 410, 2, 11, 805051) For these fines a guarantee was given by Mahajan Liladhar Sah to your representative the next morning.
('15', 410, 3, 12, 805154) Jadu Rai, of village Katha, son of Man Singh Rai, came to me at Motihari on the 26th instant and said that he held six bighas of land, that he had paid Rs. 75 as tawan in lieu of indigo cultivation, that for failure to supply a plough to the factory and to pay a fine of Rs. 10 in default he was dispossessed of his land and made to sign a document.

('15', 411, 1, 2, 805940) 337. LETTER TO CHIEF SECRETARY, BIHAR
('15', 411, 2, 3, 805978) BETTIAH, May 30, 1917
('15', 411, 3, 4, 806000) I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th instant on the agrarian situation in Champaran.
('15', 411, 3, 5, 806120) I shall be pleased to wait on His Honour at Ranchi on Monday next, the 4th June, at midday.
('15', 411, 3, 6, 806212) Your letter raises issues which it is impossible for me to ignore if I am faithfully to serve the cause that keeps me in Champaran.
('15', 411, 3, 7, 806344) It is part of the raiyats’ case that the planters will stop short of nothing to gain their end.
('15', 411, 3, 8, 806440) I have noticed ever since my arrival the very great and undue influence that the planters enjoy over everybody and in everything.
('15', 411, 3, 9, 806570) They have striven their best to have me removed from Champaran.
('15', 411, 3, 10, 806634) They have not hesitated to impute motives to the honourable men who at considerable personal sacrifice have been giving me valuable assistance.
('15', 411, 3, 11, 806778) They have without doubt used at least “moral suasion” in keeping the raiyats from coming to me.
('15', 411, 3, 12, 806874) At Dhokraha I witnessed the sorrowful spectacle of two or three men declaiming, in the presence of the Manager and the Subdivisional Officer, on the virtues of the kothi in front of a crowd of nearly 500 men who complained bitterly against the kothi about zirat land forced on them and fines exacted from them for disobedience.
('15', 411, 3, 13, 807202) These witnesses were brought by the Manager from Loheria to say that Loheria had no complaint and that the Dhokraha complaints were due to the machinations of one or two agitators.
('15', 411, 3, 14, 807383) Since then many Loheria raiyats have come and complained precisely in the same manner as Dhokraha men.
('15', 411, 3, 15, 807486) It should be noted that if full justice is done to the raiyats, planters stand to lose huge yearly incomes and many privileges they have hitherto enjoyed.
('15', 411, 3, 16, 807641) In the circumstances, I do not entirely discount the statement the raiyats make to me that the fires have been instigated by the kothis in question to discredit my mission and to remove me from their midst.
('15', 411, 3, 17, 807848) The raiyats add that they might be given some credit for selfishness and that their self interest should deter them from incendiarism or such other acts.
('15', 411, 3, 18, 808002) I have submitted to the District Magistrate the results of my inquiry 1 into the Dhokraha fire.
('15', 411, 3, 19, 808098) I beg to enclose copy of my letter to Mr. Heycock 2. I
('15', 411, 4, 20, 808153) 1 Vide “Letter to W.B. Heycock”, 22 5 1917.
('15', 412, 0, 1, 808197) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 413
('15', 412, 1, 2, 808239) am, however, willing to disbelieve the raiyats’ theory and put down the fire to natural accidents.
('15', 412, 1, 3, 808338) I may add, however, that in the Dhokraha fire, it was the roofing alone that was burnt.
('15', 412, 1, 4, 808426) But I venture to suggest that even if it is the wilful act of a maniacal raiyat done in the excitement caused by my presence; it would be no justification for my removal, unless the Government are satisfied that I have been directly or indirectly instrumental in causing the fires.
('15', 412, 1, 5, 808708) Finally, there have been fires in the kothis before my arrival and that the excitement in Champaran as admitted by the Commissioner was in existence long before I entered Bihar.
('15', 412, 1, 6, 808886) I wish respectfully to warn the Government that they will have utterly misunderstood the position if they remove me from the raiyats.
('15', 412, 1, 7, 809020) I have no desire to do aught except promote peace between the planters and the raiyats so as to secure to the raiyats the freedom and dignity that should belong to all mankind.
('15', 412, 2, 8, 809197) I ask the Government to dismiss from their minds the theory suggested by the planters that the present excitement is caused by mischievous persons for private reasons.
('15', 412, 2, 9, 809365) Planters are too powerful to be touched by any person, no matter how mischievous he may be.
('15', 412, 2, 10, 809457) The raiyats say that they never deserved the police guards that were placed in their villages and that they were part of the policy of repression pursued by the planters.
('15', 412, 2, 11, 809628) It is admitted that in Sathi the Manager was more to blame than the raiyats, and yet the raiyats had to pay with their blood and money.
('15', 412, 2, 12, 809764) It is all peace there now, because the Manager knows his work.
('15', 412, 2, 13, 809827) I have before me statements from over 7,000 raiyats from all parts of Champaran.
('15', 412, 2, 14, 809908) I have seen all of them though I have found it impossible personally to take down their statements.
('15', 412, 2, 15, 810008) It is difficult for me to believe that they all tell lies at the instigation of a few mischievous men.
('15', 412, 3, 16, 810111) I enclose copies of my letters 1 addressed to the Manager of the Motihari concern.
('15', 412, 3, 17, 810194) I have not had any reply to my first communication.
('15', 412, 3, 18, 810246) Probably there is the other side to the story, but the incidents described show at what risk the raiyats come to me.
('15', 412, 3, 19, 810363) I quote what Mr. Johnston 2, one time Subdivisional Officer in Bettiah Subdivision, had to say in 1914 regarding the methods adopted by planters to bend the raiyats to their will:
('15', 412, 4, 20, 810543) There are four methods prevalent in this subdivision compelling recalcitrant tenants to pay up.
('15', 412, 4, 21, 810639) The commonest way is by putting peons on, the petitions do not
('15', 412, 5, 22, 810702) 1 Vide letters to Irwin, 24 5 1917 & 30 5 1917.
('15', 412, 6, 23, 810750) 2 Edward Hamilton Johnston, I.C.S., Subdivisional Officer, Bettiah, in 1913 4
('15', 413, 0, 1, 810828) 414 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 413, 1, 2, 810870) allege that this has been done.
('15', 413, 1, 3, 810902) The next way is to attach crops standing on khalihan 1,
('15', 413, 2, 4, 810958) but this also is not alleged.
('15', 413, 2, 5, 810988) Then sometimes the barbers and washermen are stopped from rendering their services; the petitioners only fear this, it has not been done yet.
('15', 413, 2, 6, 811130) Finally, a very effective means is to impound the raiyats’ cattle either in a private
('15', 413, 3, 7, 811216) pound or if the D. B. pound is leased out to the landlord then in it.
('15', 413, 4, 8, 811286) The report itself is otherwise hostile to the raiyats.
('15', 413, 4, 9, 811341) I am of opinion that it did not do justice to the raiyats.
('15', 413, 4, 10, 811400) I give this opinion in all humility and after having thoroughly gone into the situation.
('15', 413, 4, 11, 811489) It is often forgotten that it is not necessary for the planters to resort to force actually in every case.
('15', 413, 4, 12, 811596) The fact that it is there to be used on the slightest attempt at the show of independence is enough to prevent recalcitrancy.
('15', 413, 4, 13, 811722) I respectfully submit that planters have had it their own way long enough [so] that the raiyats are in a condition of paralysis.
('15', 413, 4, 14, 811851) They are worthy of patient care and attention from the Government.
('15', 413, 4, 15, 811918) But the latter will not render that help, unless they are prepared to believe the raiyats’ story (exaggerated no doubt it will be) in preference to the planters’.
('15', 413, 5, 16, 812081) I tender my apology for the length of this communication.
('15', 413, 5, 17, 812139) If I have been over frank, the cause I espouse must be my excuse.
('15', 413, 5, 18, 812205) It is too great to admit of tinkering.
('15', 413, 5, 19, 812244) I hope that at a crisis like the one that faces the Government and the people of India, the Government do not wish me to conceal my feelings.
('15', 413, 6, 20, 812386) I am deeply grateful to His Honour that he has decided to have a personal conversation with me.
('15', 413, 6, 21, 812482) I shall hope for the sake of the raiyats that nothing I may say or do will adversely affect their cause, and that I shall find the right word in His Honour’s presence so that he can appreciate the awfulness of the raiyats’ position even as I do.

('15', 414, 2, 3, 812899) BETTIAH,
('15', 414, 3, 4, 812908) May 30, 1917
('15', 414, 4, 5, 812921) CONFIDENTIAL
('15', 414, 5, 6, 812934) The matters seem to be reaching a crisis as will appear from the enclosed letter 1 from the Government and reply 2 thereto.
('15', 414, 5, 7, 813058) If Mr. Gandhi and his colleagues are removed, it is expected that the leaders will one after another step into the breach.
('15', 414, 5, 8, 813181) In order to do this, it is necessary to realize the inner situation here.
('15', 414, 5, 9, 813255) It is this: raiyats are so paralysed and have suffered so long that they had begun to believe that deliverance was never coming.
('15', 414, 5, 10, 813384) They now feel the warmth of the proximity of their own countrymen who are at least willing to listen to them if they can render no effective help.
('15', 414, 5, 11, 813531) This has been enough to rouse their drooping spirits.
('15', 414, 5, 12, 813585) It will be cruel to leave them unguarded until the question is settled and their independence guaranteed to them.
('15', 414, 5, 13, 813699) Forcible removal of the mission is likely to lead to terrorism and under it to recantation of the statements hitherto made.
('15', 414, 5, 14, 813823) A further note with the papers referred to in the reply to the Chief Secretary will follow.
('15', 414, 6, 15, 813915) M. K. GANDHI
('15', 414, 7, 16, 813928) From the typewritten office copy signed by Gandhiji.

('15', 415, 1, 2, 814158) 339. LETTER TO SANKALCHAND SHAH
('15', 415, 2, 3, 814190) BETTIAH, Jeth Sud I [May 30, 1917] 1
('15', 415, 3, 4, 814227) BHAISHRI SANKALCHAND, I happen to be free at the moment.
('15', 415, 3, 5, 814284) I read your letter again, and also the time table 2. A time table always gives me a headache.
('15', 415, 3, 6, 814378) I have made no attempt to remember this one.
('15', 415, 4, 7, 814423) I think history and geography, which have been mentioned as separate subjects, should be included under Gujarati.
('15', 415, 4, 8, 814537) We want to develop the intellect through the Gujarati language.
('15', 415, 4, 9, 814601) For that purpose, we may use a language book one day and a text on history the next.
('15', 415, 4, 10, 814686) We should orally go over the matter to be taught and then make [the students] read something on it.
('15', 415, 4, 11, 814786) This will reduce the quantum of literature by a little, but that should not matter.
('15', 415, 4, 12, 814870) If the history and the geography being taught are of the same country, the latter will be easy to learn and prove interesting.
('15', 415, 4, 13, 814997) As for history, to the extent that we treat it as literature, we may give [the students] some well phrased pithy sentences.
('15', 415, 4, 14, 815121) For instance, “We look upon Ramachandra as an avatar, as God Himself.
('15', 415, 4, 15, 815191) The term avatar is of Sanskrit origin.
('15', 415, 4, 16, 815230) Avatru means to descend.
('15', 415, 4, 17, 815255) God’s descent (to this earth) is his avatar.
('15', 415, 4, 18, 815300) But at the moment we are not thinking of Rama as an avatar.
('15', 415, 4, 19, 815360) We shall only consider the Rama of history.” Whether these sentences have any life in them, you teachers know best.
('15', 415, 4, 20, 815476) But they are good enough to illustrate my point.
('15', 415, 4, 21, 815525) This will cover literature all right.
('15', 415, 4, 22, 815563) We may compose many such sentences as we narrate the history of Ramachandra.
('15', 415, 4, 23, 815640) We may first dictate them or write them out on the blackboard and then tell the story.
('15', 415, 4, 24, 815727) We may deliberately use some difficult words, as we do so.
('15', 415, 4, 25, 815786) The pupils will want to know their meanings and so the discussion will proceed.
('15', 415, 4, 26, 815866) Since he was born in Ayodhya, it will be necessary to explain its geography.
('15', 415, 4, 27, 815943) There will of course be a map.
('15', 415, 4, 28, 815974) How far it is from Ahmedabad, how one may arrive there, what it is like today, whether it answers to the poet’s description of it—all this is literature, history, and geography combined.
('15', 415, 4, 29, 816161) You must
('15', 415, 5, 30, 816170) 1 Gandhiji was in Bettiah on this day.

('15', 416, 1, 3, 816513) Sanskrit should be simplified and, if it is grouped with Marathi and the two taught on alternate days, there will be some saving of time.

('15', 416, 3, 15, 817495) The man who teaches us should be one who has himself been a successful farmer.
('15', 416, 3, 16, 817574) If a gardener is available, he should remain on the farm and teach us various techniques, which we, teachers and pupils, may learn for a year or two.
('15', 416, 3, 17, 817724) We may then go into the science of agriculture.
('15', 416, 3, 18, 817772) It will not be possible to provide for some hours of agricultural work to all the boys every day.
('15', 416, 3, 19, 817870) But they can learn the work only if every week different classes are given two or three days by turns.
('15', 416, 3, 20, 817973) Forty minutes are not enough for the purpose.
('15', 416, 3, 21, 818019) They may suffice for learning the science of agriculture theoretically.
('15', 416, 3, 22, 818091) The same is true of weaving.
('15', 416, 3, 23, 818120) Both will require constant practice.
('15', 416, 3, 24, 818157) It will be necessary, therefore, to set apart days on which pupils can give at least two hours at a stretch.
('15', 416, 3, 25, 818266) If Shri Pandya knows both the theory and the practice of agriculture and if he agrees to join, no doubt he will be very useful.
('15', 416, 3, 26, 818394) As a rule, a man coming from a Government agricultural school cannot, I believe, be of much help to us.
('15', 416, 3, 27, 818498) Ask Maganlal to tell the story of Nagin Babu of Santiniketan.
('15', 416, 3, 28, 818560) It was not his fault.
('15', 416, 3, 29, 818582) How could he help it?
('15', 416, 4, 30, 818604) It is not necessary to teach carpentry till a boy is twelve.
('15', 416, 4, 31, 818665) A child is not able even to lift or use a hammer.

('15', 426, 1, 2, 835334) 347. LETTER TO MAHARAJA BAHADUR SIR RAMESHWAR SINGH
('15', 426, 2, 3, 835386) RANCHI, June 4, 1917
('15', 426, 3, 4, 835407) DEAR MAHARAJA SAHEB BAHADUR 1, In accordance with your suggestion, I reduce to writing my views about the proposed inquiry.
('15', 426, 3, 5, 835531) In my opinion, simultaneously with the appointment of a Committee of Enquiry (or arbitration, as suggested herein below), there should be declaration regarding the various points referred to in my letter to the Government dated the 13th May last.
('15', 426, 3, 6, 835778) 2 Tinkathia in every shape and form, hand notes being balances of tawan and hundas as in the Dhokraha kothi, should be declared as abolished or cancelled.
('15', 426, 3, 7, 835933) I have no desire, if I can help it, to lead evidence as to the coercive methods adopted by the planters to bend the raiyats to their will except in so far as it may be necessary regarding sharahbeshi and tawan.
('15', 426, 3, 8, 836144) I am anxious to see cordial relations established between the planters and the raiyats.
('15', 426, 3, 9, 836232) And in any inquiry that is the result of a mutual understanding, an investigation into methods of coercion can find no place.
('15', 426, 3, 10, 836358) There would then remain only the question of sharahbeshi, sattas and individual hardships, in the shape of raiyats having been dispossessed of their lands, etc., and the refund of tawan and sharahbeshi already taken.
('15', 426, 3, 11, 836575) These the Committee will investigate.
('15', 426, 3, 12, 836613) Sharahbeshi payments should meanwhile be suspended.
('15', 426, 3, 13, 836665) The Committee will confine its attention to sharahbeshi sattas not covered by the forthcoming judgment of the High Court, the latter to be accepted as final by both the parties.
('15', 426, 3, 14, 836843) Inquiry into sharahbeshi sattas will then naturally be postponed till after the judgment of the High Court.
('15', 426, 3, 15, 836951) Upon the Committee being appointed, the scope of our work will be altered.
('15', 426, 3, 16, 837026) It will then consist in collecting, collating and leading evidence and in simultaneously carrying out the educative and
('15', 426, 4, 17, 837146) 1 Of Darbhanga, Member; Executive Council, Bihar and Orissa 2 Vide “Report on Condition of Ryots in Champaran”, 13 5 1917.
('15', 427, 0, 1, 837269) 428 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 427, 1, 2, 837311) protective programme sketched before you.
('15', 427, 1, 3, 837353) Such a Committee, then, may be in the nature of an arbitration of which the planters’ and the raiyats’ nominees (one of each) will be members with the right to them to appoint an umpire.
('15', 427, 1, 4, 837540) The decision of the arbitration should be treated as final and binding on both the parties.
('15', 427, 1, 5, 837632) Behind it, in the place of judicial authority, will be that of the Government, if either party failed to carry out the award of the arbitration.
('15', 427, 1, 6, 837777) This is a domestic quarrel and if it is settled in the manner indicated by me, it will create a healthy precedent.
('15', 427, 1, 7, 837892) If, however, it may not be in the nature of an arbitration, it will then be a Committee appointed by the Government, two members being the same as under the arbitration scheme and the president being a High Court Judge.
('15', 427, 1, 8, 838112) If there is any point herein which requires elucidation and if it is so desired, I shall be prepared to wait on the Council at any time required.
('15', 427, 2, 9, 838258) I remain,
('15', 427, 3, 10, 838268) Yours sincerely,
('15', 427, 4, 11, 838285) M. K. GANDHI
('15', 427, 5, 12, 838298) Select Documents on Mahatma Gandhi’s Movement in Champaran, No.
('15', 427, 7, 13, 838362) 348. INTERVIEW WITH LT. GOVERNOR OF BIHAR 1
('15', 427, 8, 14, 838406) June 5, 1917
('15', 427, 9, 15, 838419) I discussed with Mr. Gandhi this afternoon, Chief Secretary being present, the question of the step to be taken in connection with the Champaran situation.
('15', 427, 9, 16, 838575) I explained to Mr. Gandhi that he had now had ample time to obtain all the information he needed, and that the raiyats were getting in an excited state, and it was ecessary in
('15', 427, 10, 17, 838751) some way to put an end to a situation which was rapidly becoming a d angerous one.
('15', 427, 10, 18, 838834) It is impossible for Mr. Gandhi himself to settle the questions which have been raised, as the planters would not recognise his authority; also for him to attempt to do so would be assuming the functions of Government.
('15', 427, 10, 19, 839053) Government had intended to postpone their consideration of the points at issue until the settlement report had been received, but they recognise that, in present circumstances, this is no longer possible.
('15', 427, 10, 20, 839258) It was decided, therefore, to appoint a Committee consisting of a senior
('15', 427, 11, 21, 839331) 1 This is a note by Lt. Governor, shown to Gandhiji and altered by him.
('15', 428, 0, 1, 839403) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 429
('15', 428, 1, 2, 839445) revenue officer from another province (Mr. Sly) as President, and the following members:—Mr. Rainy, Deputy Secretary, Financial Department, Government of India; Mr. Adami, Legal Remembrancer; Mr. D. Reid, representative of the planters on the Legislative Council; Raja Harihar Prasad Narayan Singh of Amawan, as the representative of the zamindars; and Mr. Gandhi himself as the representative of the raiyats.
('15', 428, 1, 3, 839855) The appointment of the last three gentleman, of course, could only be made
('15', 428, 2, 4, 839930) with their consent, and I asked Mr. Gandhi if he would agree to serve.
('15', 428, 2, 5, 840001) He said at first that he would prefer to remain outside the Committee, so that he might lead the evidence.
('15', 428, 2, 6, 840108) But, after some discussion, he admitted that there were advantages in his being on the Committee, provided that it was recognised by Government that he had his own pronounced views which he might not readily change, and also that he would wish to place his own evidence before the Committee in the form of a written statement, on which the other members of the Committee would of course examine him.
('15', 428, 2, 7, 840508) He also wished that he might be given freedom to produce witnesses for examination.
('15', 428, 2, 8, 840592) I said that even if he were on the Committee, he would have as much freedom in these respects as if he had remained outside it.
('15', 428, 2, 9, 840720) Mr. Gandhi then asked for time to consult Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya, and promised to let me know his decision as soon as he had seen that gentleman at Bankipore.
('15', 428, 3, 10, 840884) Mr. Gandhi agreed that the following terms of reference to the Committee were suitable, namely:
('15', 428, 4, 11, 840980) “To enquire into the relations between landlord and tenant in the Champaran district as also into all disputes arising out of the manufacture and cultivation of indigo.
('15', 428, 4, 12, 841149) The Committee to examine the material already available, supplementing it by such further enquiry, local and otherwise, as they consider desirable.
('15', 428, 4, 13, 841297) They should report their conclusions to Government, if possible by the 15th October, and state the measures they recommend in order to remove any abuse or grievance which they might find to exist.”
('15', 428, 5, 14, 841495) Mr. Gandhi asked if it might be taken as certain that the above terms of reference covered all the points I mentioned in his note of 13th May 1, including the question of sharahbeshi sattas, although a case relating to them is pending in the
('15', 428, 6, 15, 841737) High Court.
('15', 428, 6, 16, 841749) I replied in the affirmative.
('15', 428, 7, 17, 841779) Mr. Gandhi presumed that the term “material already available” would include any evidence which he might wish to tender.
('15', 428, 7, 18, 841900) I again replied in the affirmative.
('15', 428, 8, 19, 841936) Mr. Gandhi said that in his opinion the proceedings of the Committee should be of an informal and summary nature.
('15', 428, 8, 20, 842050) I said I was inclined to agree but thought this might be left to the discretion of the Commissioners.
('15', 428, 9, 21, 842152) Mr. Gandhi, on his part, undertakes at once to put a stop to his
('15', 428, 10, 22, 842217) 1 Vide “Report on Condition of Ryots in Champaran”, 13 5 1917.
('15', 429, 0, 1, 842280) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 429, 1, 2, 842322) enquiry and to abstain henceforth from taking a single statement, and also from visiting any dehat or allowing any of his assistants to do so.
('15', 429, 1, 3, 842465) Mr. Gandhi does not want the raiyats to feel that
('15', 429, 2, 4, 842515) ‘A’ he has deserted them, and is unwilling on that account to leave the district altogether, pending the assembly of the Committee.
('15', 429, 2, 5, 842647) But he undertakes not to go beyond Bettiah and Motihari; after short visits to these places, he will go on a visit to Ahmedabad.
('15', 429, 3, 6, 842776) Mr. Gandhi asked that orders should issue at once putting a stop to illegal acts, such as the levy of abwabs and the impressment of labour.
('15', 429, 3, 7, 842916) I said we could not do this
('15', 429, 4, 8, 842944) unless at the same time we issued a notice which the planters asked us to issue, stating
('15', 429, 5, 9, 843033) that Mr. Gandhi had no official recognition.
('15', 429, 5, 10, 843078) Mr. Gandhi said he would be quite

('15', 429, 7, 12, 843196) notice precise instructions should be issued to the local officers to take vigorous
('15', 429, 8, 13, 843280) action to prevent all abuses that may come to light.
('15', 429, 8, 14, 843333) For instance, the taking of abwabs must, as far as possible, be finally stopped, use being made where necessary
('15', 429, 9, 15, 843445) of the power of refusing to renew leases.
('15', 429, 9, 16, 843487) Similarly, the illegal impressment of labour,
('15', 429, 10, 17, 843533) carts and ploughs must by all means be prevented wherever it comes to notice.
('15', 429, 11, 18, 843611) Mr. Gandhi asked that warnings should be sent to planters not to impress carts or coolies or collect abwabs, etc., during the interval which will elapse before the
('15', 429, 12, 19, 843775) report of the Committee is received.
('15', 429, 12, 20, 843812) I replied that the planters would take offence, if Government were to issue such a warning, as it would imply a prejudging of their case, but said that when the planter member of the Committee is appointed, I would point out to him the harm that would be done if such practices occurred, and ask him to consider the desirability of making such a communication to his brother planters.
('15', 429, 13, 21, 844197) The following action should now be taken:—

('15', 429, 15, 23, 844422) (2) Mr. Reid and the Raja of Amawan should be asked if they will serve on the Committee.
('15', 429, 16, 24, 844511) (3) A letter should be sent to the Commissioner informing him of the fact that it has been decided to refer the whole question of the agrarian conditions in Champaran to a Committee, the constitution of which will be communicated to him as soon as possible and that, meanwhile, Mr. Gandhi has agreed (as at ‘A’ above).
('15', 429, 16, 25, 844830) The Planters’ Association should also be informed of the decision arrived at.
('15', 429, 17, 26, 844908) (4) A short resolution to be drafted appointing the Committee, so that it

('15', 432, 1, 2, 848175) 352. LETTER TO ESTHER FAERING
('15', 432, 2, 3, 848205) BETTIAH, June 9, 1917
('15', 432, 3, 4, 848227) MY DEAR ESTHER, As you will have seen from the papers sent to you, I have been to Ranchi, from which place I returned only yesterday to find your letters.
('15', 432, 3, 5, 848382) Yours is a difficult question to answer.
('15', 432, 3, 6, 848423) The total effect of Euro pean activity has not been for the good of India.
('15', 432, 3, 7, 848498) The general body of Europeans who have come to India have succumbed to the vices of the East instead of imposing their own virtues on the East.
('15', 432, 3, 8, 848642) It could not well be otherwise.
('15', 432, 3, 9, 848674) Religion has not made a lasting impression on them, as we see demonstrated even by the present war.
('15', 432, 3, 10, 848774) My theory is that modern civilization is decidedly anti Christian.
('15', 432, 3, 11, 848841) And what Europeans have brought to India is that civilization, not the life of Jesus.
('15', 432, 3, 12, 848927) You and a handful of others are striving to represent that life.
('15', 432, 3, 13, 848992) It is bound to leave its mark upon the soil.
('15', 432, 3, 14, 849037) But it must take time.
('15', 432, 3, 15, 849060) “The mills of God grind slowly.” You and people like you are not affected by the evil that stares you in the face.
('15', 432, 3, 16, 849175) You get behind it, discover the good lying underneath and add it to your own stock, thus producing a perfect blend.
('15', 432, 3, 17, 849291) What I want is a reciprocity of that method.
('15', 432, 3, 18, 849336) And so I welcomed your visit to the Ashram, as I welcome that of many European friends who are true to their best traditions and are broadminded enough to take in the best that this land has to give.
('15', 432, 3, 19, 849536) Have I made myself clear?
('15', 432, 3, 20, 849562) Please discuss this further and freely with me.
('15', 432, 3, 21, 849610) I am likely to serve on the Committee the Government are about to appoint.
('15', 432, 3, 22, 849685) I am presently framing a general note 1 which will give you the details of the visit to Ranchi.
('15', 432, 3, 23, 849781) It was a good thing I went.
('15', 432, 3, 24, 849809) Mrs. Gandhi and Devdas are here now and so is Polak.
('15', 432, 3, 25, 849862) Had I been arrested, Mrs. Gandhi and Devdas would have worked among the poor raiyats and heartened them for the struggle.
('15', 432, 3, 26, 849984) I am most anxious for you to meet Mrs. Gandhi at the earliest moment.
('15', 432, 3, 27, 850054) Please don’t think that I am killing myself with work.
('15', 432, 3, 28, 850109) With love from us all,
('15', 432, 4, 29, 850132) Yours, BAPU
('15', 432, 5, 30, 850144) My Dear Child, pp.
('15', 432, 6, 31, 850163) 1 Vide “Note on the Situation in Champaran—VI”, 17 6 1917.

('15', 436, 1, 2, 854523) 357. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL GANDHI
('15', 436, 2, 3, 854556) MOTIHARI , Jeth Vad 6 [June 11, 1917] 1
('15', 436, 3, 4, 854596) CHHAGANLAL, I have come to Motihari for a day.
('15', 436, 3, 5, 854643) I have noticed that by mistake, Devdas has put the letter in my bag.
('15', 436, 3, 6, 854712) I am returning it.
('15', 436, 3, 7, 854731) I saw here the Nitishatak which was sent for Prabhudas.
('15', 436, 3, 8, 854787) It carries a shloka, the meaning of which is given thus: ‘Just as a good woman wants her breasts pinched with nails as sharp as sword, similarly a brave man wants his chest—the symbol of victory, attacked by swords as sharp as nails’.
('15', 436, 3, 9, 855022) I felt very unhappy on reading it.
('15', 436, 3, 10, 855057) There is hardly any book which does not carry something that needs to be omitted before we put it into the hands of the children.
('15', 436, 3, 11, 855187) How could Bhartrihari write such shlokas in his Nitishatak.
('15', 436, 3, 12, 855247) Only in an age of extreme debauchery can one think of such thoughts.
('15', 436, 3, 13, 855316) I find it simply impossible that any woman, leading a disciplined life, would want her breasts pinched or any good man would enjoy making such assaults.
('15', 436, 3, 14, 855469) That suggests a highly debauched state.
('15', 436, 3, 15, 855509) A good woman can never be in such a state.
('15', 436, 3, 16, 855552) Such comparison cannot even be thought of while writing shlokas for the Nitishatak.
('15', 436, 3, 17, 855636) That such shlokas and ideas are found even in good collections, brings to mind two things.

('15', 438, 5, 9, 858958) 359. LETTER TO H. McPHERSON
('15', 438, 6, 10, 858986) BETTIAH, June 13, 1917
('15', 438, 7, 11, 859009) DEAR MR. MCPHERSON, I went over to Motihari yesterday and formally stopped the taking of statements.
('15', 438, 7, 12, 859110) I have told the raiyats that the Government are about to appoint a committee of inquiry which is likely to commence its work about the middle of July next and which will listen to their tale in so far as it may be necessary.
('15', 438, 7, 13, 859335) And I have told them that in view of the above mentioned decision of the Government, it is no longer necessary for me to take their statements.
('15', 438, 7, 14, 859479) I am shifting the headquarters to Motihari where my work and that of my colleagues will consist in studying and analysing the evidence we have already collected and in putting it in a presentable form.
('15', 438, 7, 15, 859681) The raiyats will still continue to come to us for information and guidance.
('15', 438, 7, 16, 859757) I do notice that to allow them to talk to us in any manner they choose is a great relief to them and they readily accept the advice that is given to them.
('15', 438, 7, 17, 859912) They are being told not to disturb the existing situation pending the inquiry except where it is manifestly illegal and in no case to take the law in their own hands.
('15', 438, 7, 18, 860079) I am not leaving for Ahmedabad till the resolution 1 appointing the committee is published and the hot controversy going on in the Press has subsided a little.
('15', 438, 7, 19, 860239) If you could please drop me a wire as to when the resolution is likely to be gazetted, I shall be obliged.

('15', 439, 7, 8, 860745) 360. NOTE ON THE SITUATION IN CHAMPARAN VI
('15', 439, 8, 9, 860788) CONFIDENTIAL AND NOT FOR PUBLICATION MOTIHARI, June 17, 1917
('15', 439, 9, 10, 860849) As it will be remembered, prior to the publication of the Government Resolution 1 appointing the Committee of Inquiry, Mr. Gandhi was summoned to Ranchi, the Government intention then being to remove him and his co workers from Champaran.
('15', 439, 9, 11, 861088) There was an exhaustive discussion 2 of the whole situation between the Lieutenant Governor and Mr. Gandhi.
('15', 439, 9, 12, 861196) The latter saw also the other members of the Executive Council 3 and after two days’ discussion the Government desired to appoint a Committee and suggested that, in that event, Mr. Gandhi should stop taking statements.
('15', 439, 9, 13, 861415) He readily accepted the suggestion.
('15', 439, 9, 14, 861451) The Lieutenant Governor inquired if he would then withdraw his co workers and himself from Champaran.
('15', 439, 9, 15, 861553) Mr. Gandhi said he could not do so, and his colleagues and he would be occupied in marshalling the evidence and preparing for the Committee.
('15', 439, 9, 16, 861694) They could not do this well, out of Champaran.
('15', 439, 9, 17, 861741) Moreover, he could not let the raiyats think that he had, in any way, deserted them.
('15', 439, 9, 18, 861826) The Lieutenant Governor then did not press the point but hoped that, pending the meeting of the Committee, neither Mr. Gandhi nor his companions would go to the villages.
('15', 439, 9, 19, 861997) This, too, was agreed to.
('15', 439, 9, 20, 862023) The taking of statements and visits to the villages have now been entirely stopped.
('15', 439, 9, 21, 862107) The headquarters have been removed to
('15', 439, 10, 22, 862145) 1Vide Appendix “Report of Champaran Agrarian Enquiry Committee”, 3 10 1917. 2 Vide “Interview with Lt. Governor of Bihar”, 5 6 1917.

('15', 440, 1, 2, 862387) Motihari and one of the workers remains at Bettiah to attend to the raiyats who may desire information or assistance.
('15', 440, 1, 3, 862505) In all cases, they are being advised, pending the result of the inquiry, not to disturb the existing situation and it is Mr. Gandhi’s firm opinion that whilst the mission has undoubtedly strengthened the raiyats in their resolve to combat coercion and heartened them for a struggle to gain their freedom, its presence serves to restrain any excess on the part of the raiyats who without guidance might easily be betrayed into action which might harm them in the end.
('15', 440, 1, 4, 862972) The Committee meets about the 15th of July.
('15', 440, 1, 5, 863016) 1 During the interval, Mr. Gandhi is paying a flying visit to Ahmedabad, returning to Motihari at the latest on the 28th instant.
('15', 440, 1, 6, 863146) As to the constitution of the Committee, Mr. Gandhi has accepted his own appointment on the clear understanding that he should be free to give his own evidence and prepare and give the evidence of the raiyats and be as to this in the same position in which he would be if he was not a member of the Committee.
('15', 440, 1, 7, 863456) He has done so with the approval of the Hon’ble Pandit Malaviyaji and Bihar friends, whom he met at Bankipore on his return from Ranchi.
('15', 440, 1, 8, 863593) The other nominations seem to have been made by the Government with much care and with a view to secure an equitable finding by the Committee.
('15', 440, 1, 9, 863736) There was throughout the discussion at Ranchi a deep desire on the part of the Lieutenant Governor to arrive at a fair settlement.
('15', 440, 1, 10, 863867) An unauthorised statement has been circulated by the Associated Press to the effect that Mr. Gandhi has advised private inquiry.
('15', 440, 1, 11, 863996) In substance the report is true.
('15', 440, 1, 12, 864029) Evidence collected is of an inflammatory nature and a heated newspaper discussion of the evidence is bound to create an atmosphere which will interfere with the conducting of a dispassionate inquiry.
('15', 440, 1, 13, 864229) The mission has no wish to unnecessarily injure the planters’ interest and so in their interest and to demonstrate that the mission desired nothing but justice for the raiyats, a private inquiry was suggested.
('15', 440, 1, 14, 864439) The raiyats could not be hurt by this procedure.
('15', 440, 1, 15, 864488) It is not to be inferred that the report was to be withheld from the public.
('15', 440, 1, 16, 864565) On the appearance, however, of the Asso ciated Press statement, Mr. Gandhi wired 2 to the Government saying that, as the suggestion was wholly in the planters interest, he withdrew
('15', 440, 2, 17, 864746) 1 Vide Appendix “Government notice inviting evidencee before champaran agrarian enquiry committee”, July 1917. 2 Vide “Telegram to Chief Secretary, Bihar”, 8 6 1917.

('15', 441, 1, 2, 864954) it and would welcome a public inquiry if the planters so desired.
('15', 441, 1, 3, 865020) It should be understood that whilst no more volunteers are required at present, no matter what the final result of the Government inquiry is, they will be required soon after the publication of the Government’s decision on the Committees report.
('15', 441, 1, 4, 865266) Their work will be the most important and lasting and therefore it will be the final and essential stage of the mission.

('15', 442, 1, 2, 866483) 362. TALK WITH TEACHERS OF THE NATIONAL SCHOOL
('15', 442, 2, 3, 866530) [AHMEDABAD, June 23, 1917] 1
('15', 442, 3, 4, 866559) I take it that all of you have dedicated your lives to the school and I should like, therefore, to acquaint you with the present state of our finances.
('15', 442, 3, 5, 866711) We have Rs. 10,000 in cash in the Ashram Fund.
('15', 442, 3, 6, 866758) Besides this, I have jewellery and other gifts worth Rs. 20,000 given to me when I left for India.
('15', 442, 3, 7, 866857) A friend, again, has promised to buy and donate land and this should mean Rs. 10,000. We have thus a total of Rs. 40,000 or thereabouts.
('15', 442, 3, 8, 866994) It is my wish that the gifts l have received should not be put to sale in my life time, though of course they will be used in the service of the nation and we may dispose of them if we find that necessary.
('15', 442, 3, 9, 867200) This means that, even if we get no help just now and the position continues as at present, we have enough money to meet our needs for four years.
('15', 442, 3, 10, 867346) I am confident, though, that we shall get all the money we need.
('15', 442, 3, 11, 867411) It may happen, however, that we displease everyone as a result of our principles and that we get no money.
('15', 442, 3, 12, 867518) At such a time, the teachers will have two courses open to them.
('15', 442, 3, 13, 867583) One that they leave the school and take up some other work.
('15', 442, 3, 14, 867643) As for this, none of you is so entirely good for nothing that he cannot make a living somehow.
('15', 442, 3, 15, 867738) The other course is to continue to run the school, no matter what happens, maintaining yourselves, if need be, on no more than the plainest bread.
('15', 442, 3, 16, 867885) If it becomes necessary for you even to go begging for money, you should.
('15', 442, 3, 17, 867959) In other words, you should be ready to turn yourselves into beggars for the sake of the school.
('15', 442, 4, 18, 868055) OBJECTS OF SCHOOL l.
('15', 442, 4, 19, 868076) To adopt a new method of education.
('15', 442, 4, 20, 868112) 2. To pay special attention to character building, the aim being that ten per cent of the pupils at any rate get trained for national service.
('15', 442, 4, 21, 868255) 3. To raise the status of the Gujarati language.
('15', 442, 4, 22, 868304) 4. To work for the spread of the national language, Hindi.
('15', 442, 4, 23, 868363) 5. To open schools of the new pattern in every place, and make this school a model for them, and for Government as well, to
('15', 442, 5, 24, 868487) 1 Gandhiji was in Ahmedabad on this date, having left Motihari on the 18th.
('15', 442, 5, 25, 868563) He was in Bombay on the 24th and returned to Motihari on the 28th.

('15', 443, 1, 2, 868672) The aim is to have teachers trained in this school who will then go to villages and run schools there.

('15', 446, 1, 2, 873729) 366. REPLY REGARDING DRESS TO “THE PIONEER”
('15', 446, 2, 3, 873773) MOTIHARI, June 30, 1917
('15', 446, 3, 4, 873797) SIR, I have hitherto successfully resisted the temptation of either answering your or Mr. Irwin’s criticism of the humble work I am doing in Champaran.
('15', 446, 3, 5, 873949) Nor am I going to succumb now except with regard to a matter which Mr. Irwin has thought fit to dwell upon and about which he has not even taken the trouble of being correctly informed.
('15', 446, 3, 6, 874135) I refer to his remarks on my manner of dressing.
('15', 446, 3, 7, 874184) My “familiarity with the minor amenities of western civilization” has taught me to respect my national costume, and it may interest Mr. Irwin to know that the dress I wear in Champaran is the dress I have always worn in India except that for a very short period in India I fell an easy prey in common with the rest of my countrymen to the wearing of semi European dress in the courts and elsewhere outside Kathiawar.
('15', 446, 3, 8, 874601) I appeared before the Kathiawar Courts now 21 years ago in precisely the dress I wear in Champaran.
('15', 446, 3, 9, 874701) One change I have made and it is that having taken to the occupation of weaving and agriculture and having taken the vow of swadeshi, my clothing is now entirely hand woven and hand sewn and made by me or my fellow workers.
('15', 446, 3, 10, 874925) Mr. Irwin’s letter suggests that I appear before the ryots in a dress I have temporarily and specially adopted in Champaran to produce an effect.
('15', 446, 3, 11, 875071) The fact is that I wear the national dress because it is the most natural and the most becoming for an Indian.
('15', 446, 3, 12, 875182) I believe that our copying of the European dress is a sign of our degradation, humiliation and our weakness; and that we are committing a national sin in discarding a dress which is best suited to the Indian climate and which, for its simplicity, art and cheapness, is not to be beaten on the face of the earth and which answers hygienic requirements.
('15', 446, 3, 13, 875534) Had it not been for a false pride and equally false notions of prestige, Englishmen here would long ago have adopted the Indian constume.
('15', 446, 3, 14, 875672) I may mention incidentally that I do not go about Champaran bare headed.
('15', 446, 3, 15, 875745) I do avoid shoes for sacred reasons, but I find too that it is more natural and healthier to avoid them whenever possible.
('15', 447, 0, 1, 875868) 448 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 447, 1, 2, 875910) I am sorry to inform Mr. Irwin and your readers that my esteemed friend Babu Brijkishore Prasad, the “Ex hon.
('15', 447, 1, 3, 876020) member of council,” still remains unregenerate and retains the provincial cap and never walks barefoot and “kicks up” a terrible noise even in the house we are living in by wearing wooden sandals.
('15', 447, 1, 4, 876217) He has still not the courage, in spite of most admirable contact with me, to discard his semi anglicised dress and whenever he goes to see officials puts his legs into the bifurcated garment and on his own admission tortures himself by cramping his feet in inelastic shoes.
('15', 447, 1, 5, 876491) I cannot induce him to believe that his clients won’t desert him and the courts won’t punish him if he wore his more becoming and less expensive “dhoti”.
('15', 447, 1, 6, 876645) I invite you and Mr. Irwin not to believe the “stories” that the latter hears about me and my friends, but to join me in the crusade against educated Indians abandoning their manners, habits and customs which are not proved to be bad or harmful.
('15', 447, 1, 7, 876891) Finally, I venture to warn you and Mr. Irwin that you and he will ill serve the cause both of you consider is in danger by reason of my presence in Champaran if you continue, as you have done, to base your strictures on unproved facts.
('15', 447, 1, 8, 877127) I ask you to accept my assurance that I should deem myself unworthy of the friendship and confidence of hundreds of my English friends and associates—not all of them fellow cranks—if in similar circumstances I acted towards them differently from my own countrymen.
('15', 447, 2, 9, 877392) M. K. GANDHI

('15', 447, 4, 11, 877427) 367. LETTER TO ESTHER FAERING
('15', 447, 5, 12, 877457) MOTIHARI, June 30, 1917
('15', 447, 6, 13, 877481) MY DEAR ESTHER, I have your two letters before me.
('15', 447, 6, 14, 877532) I returned from Ahmedabad on the 28th.
('15', 447, 6, 15, 877571) I had a nice time there.
('15', 447, 6, 16, 877596) The city life I have always found, to be chilling; the village life, free, invigorating and godly.
('15', 447, 6, 17, 877695) ‘Why has God given us so many gifts, powers, skill to invent if we are not to use them?’ You have asked a question which I have asked myself and thousands are always asking.
('15', 447, 6, 18, 877869) My humble opinion is
('15', 448, 0, 1, 877890) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 449
('15', 448, 1, 2, 877932) that God has placed temptations in our way the strength of which is the same as that of the possibilities of rise in moral grandeur.
('15', 448, 1, 3, 878065) We may use our inventive faculty either for inward growth or for outward indulgence.
('15', 448, 1, 4, 878150) I may devote my talents for utilizing the falls from the Himalayas; I only increase mankind’s facilities for indulgence.
('15', 448, 1, 5, 878271) I may use my talents for discovering laws which govern the falls from the Himalayas within me; I serve myself and mankind by adding to the permanent happiness.
('15', 448, 1, 6, 878431) You will make up for yourself countless illustrations showing that all our talents are to be utilized only for inward growth which can come from self restraint alone.
('15', 448, 1, 7, 878598) Do please remember me to Mr. Bittmann 1 and thank him on my behalf for permitting you to come to the Ashram whenever you are free.
('15', 448, 1, 8, 878729) Your experience of the young man is nothing extraordinary.
('15', 448, 1, 9, 878788) Pray do not be impatient to reform men and women whom you meet.
('15', 448, 1, 10, 878852) The first and the last thing we have to attend to is to reform ourselves.
('15', 448, 1, 11, 878926) In trying to reform, we seem to be judging.
('15', 448, 1, 12, 878970) These young men often become worse for our handling.
('15', 448, 1, 13, 879023) The safest course is to let such men leave us when they are found wanting.
('15', 448, 1, 14, 879098) I have not sufficiently expressed myself.
('15', 448, 1, 15, 879140) But you will understand.
('15', 448, 1, 16, 879165) If not, please ask.
('15', 448, 1, 17, 879185) Yours, BAPU

PETIT, After much careful consideration, I am unable to suggest any other act of universal application with a view to inviting imprisonment, save a vigorous propaganda among the masses, going to the villages, speaking to them, distributing among them leaflets, etc.
('15', 449, 12, 25, 881191) The descent at
('15', 449, 13, 26, 881206) 1 Eleventh day of each dark and bright fortnight, observed with a fast 2 Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru (1875 1949), lawyer and statesman 3 Vide the following item.

('15', 450, 1, 4, 881669) There are various other methods which I am unwilling to advise until passive resistance in its present form has soaked into us a bit.

('15', 451, 1, 2, 883269) 372. CIRCULAR LETTER FOR FUNDS FOR ASHRAM
('15', 451, 2, 3, 883311) FOR PRIVATE CIRCULATION ONLY MOTIHARI, CHAMPARAN, Ashadh Sud 11, Samvat 1973 [July 1, 1917] 1
('15', 451, 3, 4, 883405) DEAR FRIEND, All these days the expenses on the Satyagraha Ashram and its various activities could be met entirely from help voluntarily given by some friends; but these activities have now expanded so much that it does not seem possible to meet the expenses without asking for help.
('15', 451, 3, 5, 883689) The activities of the Ashram can be divided under the following heads: (1) Boarding and lodging expenses of the Ashram inmates: The present strength of the Ashram, including adults and children, may be put down at 30. The expenses on their account, including rent, amount to Rs. 400/ a month.
('15', 451, 3, 6, 883982) This figure includes expenditure on guests.
('15', 451, 3, 7, 884026) (2) Hand weaving: No one in the Ashram knew this two years ago.
('15', 451, 3, 8, 884090) Today practically everyone knows something of it.
('15', 451, 3, 9, 884140) Some of them may actually be regarded as experts.
('15', 451, 3, 10, 884190) There are seven looms working in the Ashram and five more under its supervision.
('15', 451, 3, 11, 884271) This activity has taken up a capital of Rs. 3,000/ .
('15', 451, 3, 12, 884324) Cloth gets sold as soon as it is produced.
('15', 451, 3, 13, 884367) Cloth worth Rs. 500/ has been sold up to this time.
('15', 451, 3, 14, 884419) This work has enabled four families which had given up weaving to resume it and in all 17 persons make their living by it.
('15', 451, 3, 15, 884542) One family has learnt weaving recently and taken to it for a living.
('15', 451, 3, 16, 884611) It cannot be said yet that it makes enough for a livelihood.
('15', 451, 3, 17, 884672) The expectation is that in ten years thousands of weavers who have given up weaving as a profession will have resumed it.
('15', 451, 3, 18, 884794) It is admitted on all hands that, even if the textile mills stay, there is sufficient scope in the country for hand weaving.
('15', 451, 3, 19, 884919) This activity involves some loss at present but ultimately there should benone.
('15', 451, 3, 20, 884999) The current expenditure may be put down at Rs. 100/ a month.
('15', 451, 4, 21, 885060) 1 Vide “Letter to Fulchand Shah”, 3 7 1917, which says: “I sent one copy to Ambalalbhai yesterday.” The printed copy, however, bears the date Ashadh Vad 9, Samvat 1973, corresponding to July 13, 1917.
('15', 452, 0, 1, 885261) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 453
('15', 452, 1, 2, 885303) [(3)] The third activity is the National School.
('15', 452, 1, 3, 885352) We in the Ashram believe that the great harm that is being done to the country will continue so long as education is not given along national lines.
('15', 452, 1, 4, 885501) Accordingly, a National School has been started as an experiment.
('15', 452, 1, 5, 885567) The aim is to give higher education through the mother tongue and in a manner that will impose no strain.
('15', 452, 1, 6, 885673) If the experiment succeeds, the intention is to ask the Government itself to provide such education, and to carry on ceaseless agitation for the purpose.
('15', 452, 1, 7, 885827) Likewise, if the success of the experiment can be demonstrated, it is likely that private enterprise may start other experiments of a similar nature.
('15', 452, 1, 8, 885977) In this experiment, both mental and physical education is provided.
('15', 452, 1, 9, 886045) A curriculum extending over 13 years is visualized.
('15', 452, 1, 10, 886097) This will include, besides training corresponding to a graduate’s, instruction in the Hindi language, in agriculture and weaving.
('15', 452, 1, 11, 886227) The responsibility for conducting this experiment has been undertaken by Professor Sankalchand Shah, formerly Professor of Science at Gujarat College.
('15', 452, 1, 12, 886378) He has worked for ten years with Professor Gajjar 1. His assistants are Shri Narahari Parikh, LL.B., Shri Dattatreya Kalelkar, B.A., Shri Fulchand Shah, B.A., Shri Kishorelal Mashruwala 2, B.A.,LL.B., and my nephew, Chhaganlal Gandhi.
('15', 452, 1, 13, 886613) We are looking for one or two more teachers, who should be men of character.
('15', 452, 1, 14, 886690) In the study of Sanskrit, Shastri Girijashankar of Ahmedabad has been giving help.
('15', 452, 1, 15, 886773) Professor Anandshankar Dhruva supervises the experiment and makes suggestions.
('15', 452, 1, 16, 886852) Help is also sought from other men of learning.
('15', 452, 1, 17, 886900) The teachers draw maintenance allowance according to their needs.
('15', 452, 1, 18, 886966) The experiment costs at present Rs 500/ a month.
('15', 452, 1, 19, 887015) This does not include rent since it has been included in the expenditure for the Ashram.
('15', 452, 1, 20, 887104) The number of students at present is 12. The experiment has reached such a stage that it is proposed to admit day students now.
('15', 452, 1, 21, 887232) So far, the students were either boys from the Ashram or sons of the teachers.
('15', 452, 1, 22, 887311) [(4)] The fourth activity is propagation of the Hindi language.
('15', 452, 1, 23, 887375) There is no room for any difference of opinion about Hindi being
('15', 452, 2, 24, 887440) 1 Tribhuvandas Kalyandas Gajjar (1863 1920), Professor of Chemistry, Baroda College, Baroda; pioneer of chemical industry in Western India 2 Constructive worker and associate of Gandhiji; Editor of Gandhiji’s weekly, Harijan; author of Gandhi and Marx
('15', 453, 0, 1, 887692) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 453, 1, 2, 887734) entitled to the place which is at present usurped by English, but, to our misfortune, such a difference does exist.
('15', 453, 1, 3, 887850) The educated class must have a common language and that can only be Hindi.
('15', 453, 1, 4, 887925) It will be easy to work among the masses through it.
('15', 453, 1, 5, 887978) And therefore the delay in Hindi gaining its rightful place means so much of harm to the nation.
('15', 453, 1, 6, 888075) Efforts are being made in the country to stop this harm.
('15', 453, 1, 7, 888132) The work by the Ashram will add one more to these efforts.
('15', 453, 1, 8, 888191) The first step in this work consists mainly in securing Hindi teachers and training them.
('15', 453, 1, 9, 888281) I estimate the monthly expenditure on this work at not less than Rs. 200/ .
('15', 453, 1, 10, 888357) [(5)] The fifth category consists of my political activities, on such matters only in which I can see my way.
('15', 453, 1, 11, 888467) The only expenditure in this is on railway fare for me and my co workers.
('15', 453, 1, 12, 888541) It hardly comes to Rs. l00/ a month.
('15', 453, 1, 13, 888578) So far, I have had to make no effort to find it.
('15', 453, 1, 14, 888627) All the same, I include it here.
('15', 453, 1, 15, 888660) Thus, the total monthly expenditure comes to: Rs. For running Ashram 400 Weaving 100 School 500 Propagation of Hindi 200 My railway fare 100 1,300 approximately.
('15', 453, 1, 16, 888822) The expenditure on the National School will increase by and by, so that it will not be an over estimate to put the total expenditure at Rs. 1,500/ .
('15', 453, 1, 17, 888971) A large plot of land is required for all these activities.
('15', 453, 1, 18, 889030) Such a plot, admeasuring about 55 bighas, has already been purchased on the banks of the Sabarmati near the Sabarmati jail.
('15', 453, 1, 19, 889154) Efforts are proceeding to buy some more.
('15', 453, 1, 20, 889195) A workshop for weaving, living rooms, kitchens for the Ashram and a building for the National School are to be constructed on this land.
('15', 453, 1, 21, 889332) This is likely to cost Rs. 100,000. The responsibility for supervising the building construction has been taken over by Shri Amritlal Thakkar of the Hind Sevak Samaj 1.
('15', 453, 2, 22, 889501) My needs, therefore, adding a year’s expenses to the cost of the buildings, come to Rs. 118,000. For the land, I have drawn upon
('15', 453, 3, 23, 889630) 1 Servants of India Society
('15', 454, 0, 1, 889658) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 455
('15', 454, 1, 2, 889700) the funds with me.
('15', 454, 1, 3, 889719) There will be a trust for this land and the buildings.
('15', 454, 2, 4, 889774) If these ventures meet with your approval, I have no option but to hold out my hand to you and you have none but to give, to the best of your means, and induce others to give to the best of theirs.
('15', 454, 2, 5, 889972) If you desire to help only in regard to a particular item in the programme, your contribution will be spent accordingly.
('15', 454, 2, 6, 890093) Even if, however, you see nothing but eccentricity in all my activities, it is my request that all those who know me should help me that I may satisfy my own self.

('15', 456, 9, 23, 894257) MOTIHARI, BIHAR, Ashadh Sud 13, July 3, 1917
