('15', 457, 6, 37, 896320) 376. CIRCULAR LETTER FOR FUNDS FOR ASHRAM
('15', 457, 7, 38, 896362) MOTIHARI,
('15', 457, 8, 39, 896372) CHAMPARAN, [On or after July 3, 1917] 1
('15', 457, 9, 40, 896412) DEAR MR. SHASTRIAR, I have been conducting the Satyagraha Ashram at Ahmedabad now for the last two years.
('15', 457, 9, 41, 896518) The object of the Ashram is to bring together men, women and children whose aim or whose parents’ aim for their children is national service for life.
('15', 457, 9, 42, 896669) The Ashram at present contains after much weeding out 30 inmates including men, women and children.
('15', 457, 9, 43, 896769) So long as its activity was confined to self training, its
('15', 457, 10, 44, 896828) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('15', 458, 0, 1, 896855) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 459
('15', 458, 1, 2, 896897) expenses were met from support given by friends without the necessity of a formal appeal being made to them.
('15', 458, 1, 3, 897006) The expenses including those of a considerable number of temporary visitors have amounted to Rs. 400/ per month on an average.
('15', 458, 1, 4, 897133) But its activity has gradually widened and includes (i) weaving by means of handlooms, (ii) an experiment in evolving a national type of education, (iii) spread of Hindi as a common medium for educated India.
('15', 458, 1, 5, 897342) These activities mean much greater expenditure of money than has come to me as above stated.
('15', 458, 1, 6, 897435) For developing them a permanent habitation on a fairly large plot of land is a necessity.
('15', 458, 1, 7, 897525) Out of funds already in my possession over fifty bighas of land has been purchased on the banks of the Sabarmati on a healthy site some distance from the central gaol.
('15', 458, 1, 8, 897693) It affords an easy access to the College students who have in ever increasing numbers been making use of the Ashram Library which contains a fair volume of selected literature and newspapers and magazines, the latter being kindly supplied free of charge by the respective publishers.
('15', 458, 1, 9, 897977) According to a rough estimate made by Mr. Amritlal Thakkar of the Servants of India Society, who is drawing up the plans, the cost of the buildings will be Rs. 100,000. The educational experiment is costing Rs. 500/ per month.
('15', 458, 1, 10, 898204) The handloom industry Rs. 100/ per month.
('15', 458, 1, 11, 898246) The Hindi propaganda for the ensuing year will cost Rs. 200/ per month.
('15', 458, 1, 12, 898318) The educational and Hindi expenditure are a progressive charge.
('15', 458, 1, 13, 898382) To these may be added my own travelling expenses Rs. 100/ per month in connection with one public activity or other.
('15', 458, 1, 14, 898499) These last are easily met.
('15', 458, 1, 15, 898526) Thus the whole figure comes to capital expenditure of Rs. 100,000 and Rs. 1,300, say Rs. 1500, allowing extra Rs. 200/ per month for progressive expenditure, making rupees 18,000/ for the next twelve months.
('15', 458, 1, 16, 898734) I shall attempt only the briefest description of the activities mentioned above.
('15', 458, 1, 17, 898815) The handloom weaving is in a dying condition.
('15', 458, 1, 18, 898861) Everyone admits that whatever may be the future of the mill industry, the handlooms ought not to be allowed to perish.
('15', 458, 1, 19, 898980) Dr. Mann 1 in his recent pamphlet says that probably one of the causes of the growing poverty observed by him in particular villages was the destruction of handlooms which complemented agricultural occupation.
('15', 458, 1, 20, 899190) The object of the Ashram, therefore, is for every inmate to learn hand weaving
('15', 458, 2, 21, 899269) 1 Of Poona Agricultural College; author of Land and Labour in a Deccan Village
('15', 459, 0, 1, 899348) 460 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 459, 1, 2, 899390) and thus study at first hand the secrets and defects of the art and then find out the means of saving the industry.
('15', 459, 1, 3, 899506) Every inmate, though none belongs to the weaving class, now knows something of the art.
('15', 459, 1, 4, 899594) And a few have attained considerable skill in the art.
('15', 459, 1, 5, 899649) The Ashram is already supporting weaving families numbering 17 souls and one family having learnt the art at the Ashram has set up inde pendently and is trying to support itself from the business.
('15', 459, 1, 6, 899846) Seven looms are working at the Ashram.
('15', 459, 1, 7, 899885) It has involved a capital expenditure of Rs. 3,000/ .
('15', 459, 1, 8, 899939) It ought soon to be self supporting.
('15', 459, 1, 9, 899976) Ne arly Rs. 500 worth of stuff has already been sold by the Ashram and many who have hitherto used the shoddy mill made stuff, whether foreign or home made, are using the durable Ashram made cloth.
('15', 459, 1, 10, 900174) This enterprise is expected in 10 years’ time to resuscitate hundreds of weavers who have for the moment abandoned their trade in hopeless despair.
('15', 459, 1, 11, 900322) The system of education at present in vogue is, it is held, wholly unsuited to India’s needs, is a bad copy of the western model and it has by reason of the medium of in struction being a foreign language sapped the energy of the youths who have passed through our schools and colleges and has prduced an army of clerks and office seekers.
('15', 459, 1, 12, 900662) It has dried up all originality, impoverished the vernaculars and has deprived the masses of the benefit of higher knowledge which would otherwise have percolated to them through the intercourse of the educated classes with them.
('15', 459, 1, 13, 900892) The system has resulted in creating a gulf between educated India and the masses.
('15', 459, 1, 14, 900974) It has stimulated the brain but starved the spirit for want of a religious basis for education and emaciated the body for want of training of handicrafts.
('15', 459, 1, 15, 901129) It has criminally neglected the greatest need of India in that there is no agricultural training worth the name provided in the course.
('15', 459, 1, 16, 901265) The experiment now being carried on at the Ashram seeks to avoid all t he defects above noted.
('15', 459, 1, 17, 901360) The medium of instruction is the provincial vernacular.
('15', 459, 1, 18, 901416) Hindi is taught as a common medium and handloom weaving and agriculture are taught from he very commencement.
('15', 459, 1, 19, 901526) Pupils are taught to look up to these as a means of livelihood and the knowledge of letters as a training for the head and the heart and as a means of national service.
('15', 459, 1, 20, 901695) The curriculum has been mapped so as to cover all the essentials of the graduate course in the existing institutions within a period of 13 years.
('15', 459, 1, 21, 901841) The experiment is in the hands of Professor Shah, late of the Gujarat College.
('15', 459, 1, 22, 901920) Mr. Shah was associated with Professor Gajjar for 10 years.
('15', 459, 1, 23, 901980) He is assisted by Mr. Narhari, B.A., LL.B., Mr. Fulchand Shah, B.A., Mr. Dattatreya Kalelkar, B.A., Mr. Chhaganlal Gandhi and Mr. Kishorelal Mashruwala, B.A., LL.B. All but the last named have pledged themselves exclusively to he work for life on a pittance enough to support them and their families.
('15', 459, 1, 24, 902281) Mr. Kishorelal has given
('15', 460, 0, 1, 902306) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 461
('15', 460, 1, 2, 902348) his services free for one year, having means of his own, and will if he finds the work congenial at the end of the year cast in his lot with the rest.
('15', 460, 1, 3, 902499) The experiment is confined to about 12 lads including two girls belonging to the Ashram or being children of the teachers.
('15', 460, 1, 4, 902622) It is being supervised by Professor Anandshankar Dhruva, Vice Principal of the Gujarat College.
('15', 460, 1, 5, 902718) I build the highest hopes upon it.
('15', 460, 1, 6, 902753) My faith in it is unquenchable.
('15', 460, 1, 7, 902785) It may fail but if it does, the fault must not be in the system but with us the workers.
('15', 460, 1, 8, 902874) If it succeeds, voluntary institutions after its model can be multiplied and the Government called upon to adopt it.
('15', 460, 1, 9, 902991) That Hindi ought at the earliest moment to displace English seems to be a self demonstrated proposition.
('15', 460, 1, 10, 903096) Hindi can not only become the common medium between the educated classes but it opens the door to the hearts of the masses in a way which no other vernacular does and English certainly never can.
('15', 460, 1, 11, 903292) Madras alone presents a difficulty but I have sufficient faith in the spirituality and the imaginative faculty of the southerners to know that they will not be long before they take up Hindi as the common medium.
('15', 460, 1, 12, 903505) No presidency in India has the same aptitude for learning languages that Madras has.
('15', 460, 1, 13, 903590) That is my South African experience.
('15', 460, 1, 14, 903627) Although the preponderating element there is Dravidian, the Tamils and the Telugus picked up Hindi instead of the Hindustani speaking races picking up Tamil or Telugu.
('15', 460, 1, 15, 903795) It is then for these experiments that I ask for your pecuniary support.
('15', 460, 1, 16, 903867) I hope you will send me what you can, if you at all agree with any of the activities.
('15', 460, 1, 17, 903953) You may earmark your donation if you wish.
('15', 460, 1, 18, 903996) A trust will be created of the land and buildings.
('15', 460, 1, 19, 904047) Accurate account of the expenditure in the various branches is being kept and an abstract will be rendered to the donors.
('15', 460, 1, 20, 904169) I do not want if I can help it as yet to make an appeal through the Press.
('15', 460, 1, 21, 904244) The activities have not advanced far enough to warrant such an appeal.
('15', 460, 1, 22, 904315) But I do not hesitate to approach with confidence those who know me personally either to assist me themselves or advise their friends to do so.
('15', 460, 2, 23, 904459) Yours sincerely,
('15', 460, 3, 24, 904476) M. K. GANDHI

('15', 461, 1, 2, 904656) 377. LETTER TO PRIVATE SECRETARY TO VICEROY
('15', 461, 2, 3, 904700) BANKIPORE, July 7, 1917
('15', 461, 3, 4, 904724) DEAR MR. MAFFEY, I am on my way to Ranchi in connection with the work of the Champaran committee.
('15', 461, 3, 5, 904822) I write this regarding the Annie Besant agitation.
('15', 461, 3, 6, 904873) As I am taking part in it by keeping myself in touch with the leaders and pressing on their attention my views regarding it, 1 I feel that I could not do so without His Excellency knowing the fact and knowing also my position in the agitation.
('15', 461, 3, 7, 905117) In my humble opinion, the internments are a big blunder.
('15', 461, 3, 8, 905174) Madras was absolutely calm before then.
('15', 461, 3, 9, 905214) Now it is badly disturbed.
('15', 461, 3, 10, 905241) India as a whole had not made common cause with Mrs. Besant but now she is on a fair way towards commanding India’s identity with her methods.
('15', 461, 3, 11, 905384) Having had breathing time, I had gone down to Ahmedabad for some work connected with the institution I am conducting there, I passed through Bombay and Allahabad on my return and I was able to gauge the situation.
('15', 461, 3, 12, 905598) I myself do not like much in Mrs. Besant’s method.
('15', 461, 3, 13, 905649) I have not liked the idea of the political propaganda being carried on during the War.
('15', 461, 3, 14, 905736) In my opinion, our restraint will have been the best propaganda.
('15', 461, 3, 15, 905801) But the whole country was against me.
('15', 461, 3, 16, 905839) And no one could deny Mrs. Besant’s great sacrifice and love for India or her desire to be strictly constitutional, nor could the country’s right to carry on the propaganda be denied if it chose to do so.
('15', 461, 3, 17, 906044) Many of us have respectfully differed from Mrs. Besant but all have recognised her powers and devotion.
('15', 461, 3, 18, 906148) The Congress was trying to ‘capture’ Mrs. Besant.
('15', 461, 3, 19, 906198) The latter was trying to ‘capture’ the former.
('15', 461, 3, 20, 906245) Now they have almost become one.
('15', 461, 3, 21, 906278) I plead with all the earnestness I can command for the boldest policy, i.e., to acknowledge the blunder in the frankest manner and to withdraw the orders of internment and to declare that the country has the right to carry on any propaganda that is not subversive of the British Constitution and is totally free from violence.
('15', 461, 3, 22, 906605) Such an act will be a demonstration of strength, not of weakness.
('15', 461, 3, 23, 906671) Only a government having the desire always to do the right and the power to crush the wrong can do it.
('15', 461, 4, 24, 906774) 1 Vide “Letter to J. B. Petit”, 30 6 1917.
('15', 462, 0, 1, 906817) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 463
('15', 462, 1, 2, 906859) If unfortunately timid counsels prevail, there will be no rest in the country and the cult of violence will surely spread.
('15', 462, 1, 3, 906982) Open violence one could understand and deal with.
('15', 462, 1, 4, 907032) That may not be practised, but secret violence would be attempted.
('15', 462, 1, 5, 907099) No one would be or feel responsible for it.
('15', 462, 1, 6, 907143) Young minds without any lead from anybody in particular are, I regretfully observe, drifting in that direction.
('15', 462, 1, 7, 907255) My life is dedicated to the preventing of the spread of the disease and its uprooting in so far as it has gained a foothold.
('15', 462, 1, 8, 907380) I have presented to the youths and to Indians in general in my humble way a better and more effective method and that is the method of soul force or truth force or love force which for want of a better term I have described as passive resistance.
('15', 462, 1, 9, 907627) And I am asking the leaders to adopt this method fully and boldly at this critical juncture.
('15', 462, 1, 10, 907720) It involves self suffering and that alone throughout.
('15', 462, 1, 11, 907774) No government in the world can afford continually to imprison or molest innocent men; the British Government cannot afford it.
('15', 462, 1, 12, 907901) It is its great secret and character that even when it does wrong, it seeks to justify it before the world on moral grounds.I think I have sufficiently explained myself.
('15', 462, 1, 13, 908071) I hope, I shall not be misunderstood.
('15', 462, 1, 14, 908109) I ask for forgiveness for the presumption in writing this letter and earnestly pray for the acceptance of my proposal.
('15', 462, 2, 15, 908228) Please place this before His Excellency.
('15', 462, 2, 16, 908269) If my presence is required at Simla, I am at H.E.’s disposal.
('15', 462, 3, 17, 908331) Yours sincerely,
('15', 462, 4, 18, 908348) M. K. GANDHI
('15', 462, 6, 19, 908361) I shall be in Ranchi care of Hon’ble Mr. Sahay up to the 11th instant, and then at Motihari, Champaran.
('15', 462, 7, 20, 908465) M. K. G.

('15', 466, 1, 2, 913930) 381. A FEW WORDS TO ORPHANAGES 1
('15', 466, 2, 3, 913963) [Before July 11, 1917]
('15', 466, 3, 4, 913986) In the course of my travels in India, I have examined a number of orphanages, some of them closely and others cursorily, and have expressed my views on some of them before the managers.
('15', 466, 3, 5, 914172) Like anyone else, I also think well of my ideas and I feel that it will not be amiss to place them before the public.
('15', 466, 3, 6, 914290) An anathashrama may be correctly defined as a place which gives shelter to those who are anatha 2 and makes them sanatha 3. In respect of such institutions, the term anatha is especially applied to children who have no living parents or guardians.
('15', 466, 3, 7, 914538) Their claim is, or ought to be, to make good the want of a guardian.
('15', 466, 3, 8, 914607) Anathashram is a translation of the English term ‘orphanage’.
('15', 466, 3, 9, 914669) Though this is the meaning of the term anatha, besides children, young men who can earn their livelihood are also accommodated in orphanages.
('15', 466, 3, 10, 914811) In addition, the disabled, the lame, the crippled and the blind are also admitted and now even foundling boxes have been introduced in orphanages.
('15', 466, 3, 11, 914958) It is my opinion that this way one of the purposes is served fully.
('15', 466, 3, 12, 915026) Though, superficially considered, it might suggest a more philanthropic attitude, on deeper reflection it will be seen that this state of affairs comes of a commercial mentality.
('15', 466, 3, 13, 915205) I have no doubt that the future of the orphanages is the same as that of misers who would earn the highest interest on their moneys and so ultimately ruin themselves.
('15', 466, 3, 14, 915372) I have used the word ‘future’ only to be on the safe side.
('15', 466, 3, 15, 915431) Personally, I see their degradation in the present.
('15', 466, 3, 16, 915483) An arrangement like this is a sign of our fear, of our lack of faith.
('15', 466, 3, 17, 915553) We assume that, for all our institutions, we get help from the rich only with the utmost efforts.
('15', 466, 3, 18, 915651) “We cannot but protect the disabled and we are bound to take care of babies born in secret; so let us manage that from whatever we have received.” This is an abject attitude.
('15', 466, 3, 19, 915826) I am convinced that for a good cause money will be available even in this poor country of India.
('15', 466, 3, 20, 915923) It is for those in charge to prove that the cause is good.
('15', 466, 3, 21, 915982) Institutions have
('15', 466, 4, 22, 916000) 1 The article originally appeared in Chitramaya Jagat, a Marathi journal, under the title “A Few Words to Orphanages”.
('15', 466, 4, 23, 916119) Its publication was noticed in Kheda Vartaman of 11 7 1917.
('15', 466, 5, 24, 916179) 2 Unprotected 3 Protected
('15', 467, 0, 1, 916205) 468 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 467, 1, 2, 916247) declined not for lack of funds but for lack of organizers with steadfastness, faith and integrity.
('15', 467, 1, 3, 916346) Whether or no this view is right, one thing is certain, that, in trying to ride three horses at once the orphanages succeed in managing none.
('15', 467, 1, 4, 916488) In these conditions, how can the ‘orphans’ cease to be ‘orphans’?
('15', 467, 1, 5, 916554) They are constantly reminded of the fact of their being such.
('15', 467, 1, 6, 916616) We would never want to leave our children in charge of these institutions.
('15', 467, 1, 7, 916691) Here is the real test of an orphanage.
('15', 467, 1, 8, 916730) We would not welcome the companionship of the disabled, the blind, or the crippled for our children.
('15', 467, 1, 9, 916831) If these institutions were [really] the guardians of those without any guardians, we would find the manager’s children among the inmates.
('15', 467, 1, 10, 916969) They would have no hesitation in placing their children in the midst of the orphans, if for no other reason, at least in order to test themselves.
('15', 467, 1, 11, 917116) I submit, on the strength of my extensive experience, that this is not too excessive an expectation.
('15', 467, 1, 12, 917217) That the orphans are placed with the disabled is not all; the other arrangements also are mostly such that the children are constantly reminded of their destitute condition.
('15', 467, 1, 13, 917391) If orphanages were reserved for orphans alone, they could be self supporting in a very short time.
('15', 467, 1, 14, 917490) We have much to learn from the Salvation Army 1 in this respect.
('15', 467, 1, 15, 917555) The orphanages which they run have a soul in them.
('15', 467, 1, 16, 917606) Ours are by comparison soulless.
('15', 467, 1, 17, 917639) They have given refuge to thousands of children, have made men of them, have found employment for them.
('15', 467, 1, 18, 917743) The children in our orphanages have not been given this sense of security.
('15', 467, 1, 19, 917818) Some have been found petty jobs.
('15', 467, 1, 20, 917851) These may be left out of account.
('15', 467, 1, 21, 917885) The general practice in our orphanages is to send away the children when they come of age.
('15', 467, 1, 22, 917976) Not so with the Salvation Army.
('15', 467, 1, 23, 918008) In its institutions the orphans, when they come of age, start working in its factories, in the same way that a son in the family who has grown up is regarded as an additional shield and support for the family.
('15', 467, 1, 24, 918218) It is necessary that such a family feeling be injected in our institutions too.
('15', 467, 1, 25, 918298) We can educate them in the institutions and find work for them in the factories of the institutions even as we provide them with lodging, boarding and clothing.
('15', 467, 1, 26, 918459) We can launch great national experiments in the institutions, can impart education on national lines, teach them crafts, teach them agriculture, and save the professions which are dying out.
('15', 467, 1, 27, 918650) If affairs are managed in this manner, the
('15', 467, 2, 28, 918693) 1 Organisation for religious philanthropic work founded by William Booth in 1880 .
('15', 468, 0, 1, 918776) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 469
('15', 468, 1, 2, 918818) orphans of today can become teachers, artisans, and leaders in their own orphanages.
('15', 468, 1, 3, 918903) We can also raise an Indian Defence Force suited to our conditions from among the inmates of such orphanages.
('15', 468, 1, 4, 919013) If I am right in these calculations, a common standard can be set up for all the institutions by bringing together the heads of all the institutions, or at least of those in the Bombay Province, and consulting their views.
('15', 468, 1, 5, 919236) If there is a central executive body for all, it can supervise them and make such changes as are called for by experience.
('15', 468, 1, 6, 919359) If we are not ready for such an integrated scheme, a policy like the one indicated above can surely be introduced in those institutions which have more of life in them.
('15', 468, 2, 7, 919528) In some institutions, I noted a tendency to coax children into staying on there.
('15', 468, 2, 8, 919609) To me this seems to be an ill considered thing to do.
('15', 468, 2, 9, 919663) The boys who do not want to continue in the orphanages are not orphans but free persons [who can look after themselves].
('15', 468, 2, 10, 919784) The worth of an orphanage should not be judged by the number of inmates, but rather by the number of citizens it turns out.
('15', 468, 3, 11, 919908) There are enough institutions to meet the needs of the disabled.
('15', 468, 3, 12, 919973) That, wherever necessary, such institutions should be set up separately, requires no elaborate proof.
('15', 468, 3, 13, 920075) The problem of admitting foundlings is a serious one.
('15', 468, 3, 14, 920129) I am not yet convinced that providing for such admissions is ethically sound.
('15', 468, 3, 15, 920207) I have a kind of feeling that such facilities lead to increase in indulgence.
('15', 468, 3, 16, 920285) It can in no way be proved that keeping alive every creature that is born, no matter how, is a part of humanitarianism.
('15', 468, 3, 17, 920405) It is indeed futile to make such an effort.
('15', 468, 3, 18, 920449) One detects a hidden pride behind it.
('15', 468, 3, 19, 920487) I, for one, realize every moment from experience that the term ‘humanitarianism’ is not easy to understand.
('15', 468, 3, 20, 920595) I have in some measure made that subject my own and hence I have ventured to be so emphatic.
('15', 468, 3, 21, 920688) Humanitarianism does not mean saving a definite number of lives.
('15', 468, 3, 22, 920753) It is the very property of the soul.
('15', 468, 3, 23, 920790) Because of this fact, living creatures in the presence of a compassionate soul have an immediate and direct experience of its compassion.
('15', 468, 3, 24, 920928) There is no room for arithmetic in humanitarianism.
('15', 468, 3, 25, 920980) Unclean flour is infested with numberless lives.
('15', 468, 3, 26, 921029) To preserve such flour is no humanitarianism.
('15', 468, 3, 27, 921075) It lies rather in covering up the flour with earth or destroying it, though either way the vermin in the flour perish.
('15', 468, 3, 28, 921194) Numberless vermin perish even in the process of keeping our bodies clean.
('15', 468, 3, 29, 921268) Pure humanitarianism will seek ways to prevent the infesting of the flour
('15', 469, 0, 1, 921342) 470 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 469, 1, 2, 921384) and keeping the body from becoming unclean.
('15', 469, 1, 3, 921428) So also, pure humanitarianism will look for the cause of surreptitious admissions and take measures to promote moral purity.
('15', 469, 1, 4, 921553) It will not encourage and shield laxity by accepting the burden of such admissions.
('15', 469, 1, 5, 921637) I need hardly say that my criticism is only meant to be helpful and is not prompted by a desire to cast aspersions.
('15', 469, 1, 6, 921753) It is also not true that all the comments apply to every institution.
('15', 469, 1, 7, 921823) The sole purpose of this article is to see that all the institutions attain the highest possible level.
('15', 469, 1, 8, 921927) In almost all our institutions, we notice more of the attitude of the vanik 1 than anything else.
('15', 469, 1, 9, 922025) It is imperative to keep this in the background and give prominence to the (venturesome) spirit of the Kshatriya, to the (far sighted) vision of the Brahmin, above all, to the Sudra’s spirit (of service).
('15', 469, 2, 10, 922230) [From Gujarati]
('15', 469, 3, 11, 922246) Mahatma Gandhini Vicharsrishti
('15', 469, 4, 12, 922277) 382. LETTER TO ESTHER FAERING
('15', 469, 5, 13, 922307) MOTIHARI, July 14, 1917
('15', 469, 6, 14, 922331) MY DEAR ESTHER,
('15', 469, 7, 15, 922347) I have just returned from Ranchi to find your letter awaiting me.
('15', 469, 7, 16, 922413) You never told me you had taken to vegetarianism.
('15', 469, 7, 17, 922463) I am sure it is the proper thing for this climate, apart from its religious value.
('15', 469, 7, 18, 922546) A convert to vegetarianism is often told to eat of pulses, butter, cheese and milk more than during the meat eating period.
('15', 469, 7, 19, 922670) This is a mistake.
('15', 469, 7, 20, 922689) Pulses may be eaten only sparingly.
('15', 469, 7, 21, 922725) If one takes a fair quantity of milk, very little butter is required.
('15', 469, 7, 22, 922795) In my opinion, it is wrong to possess unnecessary things; they presuppose defence of things possessed against those who may covet them.
('15', 469, 7, 23, 922931) They require care and attention which might well be devoted to more important matters and loss of them always leaves a pang, no matter how detached you may feel about them.
('15', 469, 7, 24, 923104) The sittings of the Committee commence on Monday.

('15', 471, 1, 2, 924711) 384. SPEECH AT CHAMPARAN ENQUIRY COMMITTEE MEETING
('15', 471, 2, 3, 924762) BETTIAH, July 19, 1917
('15', 471, 3, 4, 924785) The Champaran Agrarian Enquiry Committee resumed their sitting today.
('15', 471, 3, 5, 924855) At the outset the Chairman 1 said some of the written statements put before them contained events relating to specific acts of coercion alleged to have occurred many years ago.
('15', 471, 3, 6, 925032) Some were about twenty or twenty five years old.
('15', 471, 3, 7, 925081) It was quite impossible for them for their inquiry to extend back to such remote periods.
('15', 471, 3, 8, 925171) Their inquiry related to the present agrarian conditions of Champaran District and their concern with the past history would be inasmuch as it would elucidate present conditions.
('15', 471, 3, 9, 925350) He did not think any advantage would accrue by inquiring into individual cases that occurred a long number of years ago and he ruled the Committee should confine itself to more recent events for the reason that there was a special inquiry made by Mr. Gourlay in 1909 which dealt with all agrarian conditions prior to that date and he proposed the Committee should undertake only an inquiry of conditions after Mr. Gourlay’s inquiry.
('15', 471, 3, 10, 925783) That seemed to him to be the reasonable time to adopt.
('15', 471, 3, 11, 925838) The second point he wished to put forward was that certain incidents referred to matters which had been the subject of decisions of judicial courts of the country.
('15', 471, 3, 12, 926002) Again, it would be useless for them to attempt to review those cases.
('15', 471, 3, 13, 926072) Already those cases had been heard and decided by judicial courts and it was not in the province of the Committee to revise the decisions of the judicial courts of the country.
('15', 471, 3, 14, 926249) Therefore, so far as those cases were concerned, all that they could consider was the judicial record and not any extra facts connected with it.
('15', 471, 4, 15, 926394) Mr. Gandhi said he wished to say just a few words on the subject as he was responsible for putting in those statements.
('15', 471, 4, 16, 926514) He bowed to the Chairman’s ruling but he thought it was necessary to put those matters in statement as otherwise he would not have done justice to those men unless he allowed them to give their story in its historical sequence.
('15', 471, 4, 17, 926742) He did not wish the Committee to go behind judicial decisions, but he thought the Committee should have an opportunity of having the full story of the ryots.
('15', 471, 5, 18, 926900) The Chairman said they could not enquire into allegations that judgements of courts were based on false facts.
('15', 471, 6, 19, 927011) Mr. Gandhi said he agreed, but he thought it was proper not to withhold anything from the Committee.
('15', 471, 6, 20, 927112) The Hindu, 20 7 1917
('15', 471, 7, 21, 927133) 1 Sir Frank George Sly
('15', 472, 0, 1, 927156) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 473
('15', 472, 1, 2, 927198) 385. QUESTIONS DURING EVIDENCE BEFORE CHAMPARAN ENQUIRY COMMITTEE
('15', 472, 2, 3, 927264) July 23, 1917
('15', 472, 3, 4, 927278) Mr. Gandhi, who questioned witness [Mr. A. Ammon 1], said the case about Sant Raut was not that his house was looted, but that when he returned in January he found his field granaries, grain, utensils, sal tree logs, etc.
('15', 472, 3, 5, 927500) looted.
('15', 472, 4, 6, 927508) Witness replied that it was not true, so far as he knew.
('15', 472, 4, 7, 927565) He did not know that Sant had filed a petition a few days before the alleged occurrence before the magistrate saying he was in fear of these things being looted.
('15', 472, 4, 8, 927727) He heard of the loot for the first time from the newspapers.

('15', 473, 1, 2, 928702) 387. LETTER TO SECRETARY, PASSENGERS’ GRIEVANCES COMMITTEE, RANGOON
('15', 473, 2, 3, 928770) MOTIHARI, July 25, 1917
('15', 473, 3, 4, 928794) TO THE SECRETARY PASSENGERS’ GRIEVANCES COMMITTEE
('15', 473, 4, 5, 928844) RANGOON
('15', 473, 5, 6, 928852) SIR, I have the honour to submit the enclosed note on the matter before your Committee for its consideration.
('15', 473, 7, 7, 928962) Yours faithfully,
('15', 473, 8, 8, 928980) [ENCLOSURE]
('15', 473, 11, 9, 928992) GRIEVANCES
('15', 473, 12, 10, 929003) The undersigned has considerable experience of travelling, having travelled in several parts of the world during the past 25 years.
('15', 473, 13, 11, 929135) The undersigned had occasion during 1901 1 and again in 1915 2
('15', 473, 14, 12, 929198) to travel to Burma.
('15', 473, 14, 13, 929218) The undersigned used to travel, as a rule, first class up to nearly 4 years ago.
('15', 473, 14, 14, 929299) Latterly he has travelled as a deck passenger.
('15', 473, 14, 15, 929346) In the opinion of the undersigned: 1. Deck passengers making use of the British India Steam Navigation Service do not receive adequate attention from the Company’s employees or the police.
('15', 473, 14, 16, 929535) 2. The passengers are hustled about by both, are spoken to roughly, often sworn at and not unoften assaulted.
('15', 473, 14, 17, 929645) 3. The employees do not put themselves out for receiving complaints.
('15', 473, 14, 18, 929714) 4. The crew maltreat the passengers and almost invariably take
('15', 473, 15, 19, 929777) 1 Actually 1902; vide “Letter to G.K. Gokhale”, 2 2 1902.
('15', 473, 16, 20, 929835) 2 Vide “Letter to Agents of B. I. S. N. Company”, 19 3 1915.
('15', 474, 0, 1, 929896) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 475
('15', 474, 1, 2, 929938) bribes.
('15', 474, 1, 3, 929946) 5. Passengers are huddled together anyhow, there being absolutely no supervision as to how and where they seat themselves; the result is that the strongest or the richest secure the best accommodation.
('15', 474, 1, 4, 930148) 6. Female passengers are similarly treated as in clause (5) and have no privacy of any kind reserved for them.
('15', 474, 1, 5, 930259) 7. The deck is often in a filthy condition.
('15', 474, 1, 6, 930303) 8. There is no control over the passengers’ behaviour; the result is that dirty passengers spit and eat anywhere and anyhow, much to the discomfort of the cleanly ones.
('15', 474, 1, 7, 930472) 9. Closets are filthy beyond description; closets allotted for females are often used by men; Mrs. Gandhi had to be specially accompanied each time she wanted to use the closets.
('15', 474, 1, 8, 930651) There are, as a rule, no locks to the doors.
('15', 474, 1, 9, 930696) 10. Bathing accommodation, such as it is, is often taken up by the crew.
('15', 474, 1, 10, 930769) There is hardly any facility for washing clothes.
('15', 474, 1, 11, 930819) 11. Accommodation referred to in (9) and (10) is too little for the number of passengers taken.
('15', 474, 1, 12, 930915) 12. During his voyages, the undersigned felt that the passengers taken were too many for the space reserved for deck passengers.
('15', 474, 1, 13, 931044) 13. There seemed to be no control over the disposition of the luggage of the passengers; the result was that much space was taken up by the passengers’ luggage.
('15', 474, 1, 14, 931205) 14. The undersigned found that through ignorance, fear, laziness and such other causes, passengers seemed to be reluctant to make complaints.
('15', 474, 2, 15, 931347) REMEDIES
('15', 474, 3, 16, 931356) PART II In the opinion of the undersigned: 1. There should be special, trusted representatives of the Company approved by the Government who would go out of their way to understand deck passengers and their grievances.
('15', 474, 3, 17, 931575) 2. For the wharves assistance of trustworthy volunteers should be sought from known organisations conducted in the interest of the passengers.
('15', 474, 3, 18, 931718) 3. Deck, closet and bathing accommodation should be increased.
('15', 475, 0, 1, 931781) 476 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 475, 1, 2, 931823) 4. The representatives mentioned in clause (1) of Part II should inspect every ship and satisfy themselves as to [clause] (3) [of] Part II.
('15', 475, 1, 3, 931963) 5. The representatives aforesaid should meet every steamer and inquire of the passengers as to their experiences.
('15', 475, 1, 4, 932077) 6. Medical Officer on board should be empowered and be expected to look after the physical comforts of the passengers in every way.
('15', 475, 1, 5, 932209) The undersigned was told by a medical officer that the looking after the accomodation of passengers, their cleanliness, the closet arrangement, their condition did not fall within his province.
('15', 475, 1, 6, 932403) 7. An instruction book in several vernaculars should be issued for the passengers and a copy handed to each passenger on his receiving his ticket.
('15', 475, 1, 7, 932550) Should the Committee desire further information from the undersigned, he will gladly endeavour to give it.
('15', 475, 2, 8, 932657) From a photostat of the typewritten draft with corrections in Gandhiji’s hand: S. N. 6382
('15', 475, 3, 9, 932747) 388. LETTER TO W. B. HEYCOCK
('15', 475, 4, 10, 932776) MOTIHARI, July 25, 1917
('15', 475, 5, 11, 932800) DEAR MR. HEYCOCK, I thank you for your confidential note 1 of the 23rd instant just received.
('15', 475, 5, 12, 932894) I had no intention of misconstruing your silence.
('15', 475, 5, 13, 932944) But I appreciate the absolute fairness of your warning.
('15', 475, 5, 14, 933000) The step I wish to take after a settlement of the question is, I know, full of possibilities and I wish to give you the assurance that nothing will be done by me without the fullest details being known by the Government and without due regard to every material circumstance.
('15', 475, 6, 15, 933275) Yours sincerely,

('15', 476, 1, 2, 933786) 389. LETTER TO SHANKERLAL BANKER AND JAMNADAS GANDHI
('15', 476, 2, 3, 933839) BETTIAH, Shravana Sud 6 [July 25, 1917] 1
('15', 476, 3, 4, 933881) DEAR SHANKERLAL AND JAMNADAS,
('15', 476, 4, 5, 933911) I have already replied to the telegrams from both of you.
('15', 476, 4, 6, 933969) Except for going there, I have done everything I could.
('15', 476, 4, 7, 934025) And I would have gone if it had at all been possible.
('15', 476, 4, 8, 934079) The Champaran Committee has been working without interruption.
('15', 476, 4, 9, 934142) Its tenure is for three months.
('15', 476, 4, 10, 934174) The time limit has been set by me.
('15', 476, 4, 11, 934209) How can I ask it to suspend its functioning for a week?
('15', 476, 4, 12, 934265) And how can I remain absent?
('15', 476, 4, 13, 934294) If this task is accomplished you can take it that it will be a great step forward towards swaraj.
('15', 476, 4, 14, 934392) I must not harm it in any way.
('15', 476, 5, 15, 934423) However, I am sure that if all of you remain firm on the path of truth, nothing will go wrong there either.
('15', 476, 5, 16, 934531) I am prepared to fight by your side even in the face of the opposition from the whole country.
('15', 476, 5, 17, 934626) I do not have the strength to handle the work single handed.
('15', 476, 5, 18, 934687) After settling the affairs there, both or either one of you should come over if possible.
('15', 476, 5, 19, 934777) More I shall explain.
('15', 476, 5, 20, 934799) I wish you would come.

('15', 477, 1, 2, 935201) 390. QUESTIONS DURING EVIDENCE BEFORE CHAMPARAN COMMITTEE 1
('15', 477, 2, 3, 935261) MOTIHARI, July 26, 1917
('15', 477, 3, 4, 935285) The only witness examined today by the Champaran Agrarian Enquiry Committee was Mr. W. S. Irwin, Manager of Motihari Limited.
('15', 477, 3, 5, 935411) Examined by the Chairman, witness said his concern consisted of six factories.
('15', 477, 3, 6, 935490) It was an indigo concern before, but it was not now.
('15', 477, 3, 7, 935543) He converted the tinkathia system in 1911 by taking their tawan of sharahbeshi.
('15', 477, 3, 8, 935623) Under the tinkathia obligation every ryot had to work three cottahs 2 of indigo.
('15', 477, 3, 9, 935704) The claim was against every ryot.
('15', 477, 3, 10, 935738) Witness had taken sharahbeshi in mukarrari villages and tawan in thikadari villages.
('15', 477, 4, 11, 935823) Asked whether he claimed that an exclusive right was created because the Raj had allowed it, witness said that the Raj had taken a good deal more than they were allowed to collect under the terms of their leases.
('15', 477, 4, 12, 936036) When he said Government recognised the obligation he meant that they recognised it tacitly, because they said that so long as indigo was grown rents could not be raised.
('15', 477, 5, 13, 936206) Witness then gave similar evidence to the previous witnesses about the imposition of fines and employment of labour.
('15', 477, 6, 14, 936323) To Mr. Gandhi, witness said he had not fined any person Rs. 500/ when told that Mr. Gandhi had a man who alleged witness had fined him a thousand rupees.
('15', 477, 6, 15, 936477) Witness said:
('15', 477, 7, 16, 936491) “If Mr. Gandhi were to remain in this part of the country for the length of time I have (and it is 35 years), he would be convinced what a consummate liar the Champaran ryot is.” There were several good qualities in the Champaran ryot, but certainly truth was not one of them.
('15', 477, 7, 17, 936768) Before his letter to The Pioneer, there was not a
('15', 477, 8, 18, 936818) single complaint made against him.
('15', 477, 9, 19, 936853) Mr. Gandhi said that from Mr. Heycock’s (Collector’s) summary, it appeared during the last four years, 27 petitions had been sent to the Collector from 20 different villages against the factory.
('15', 477, 10, 20, 937048) Witness said he had thirty thousand tenants, and if in four years 27 petitions were sent, it was natural they might not come to his notice.
('15', 477, 11, 21, 937188) Witness was next questioned about specific cases of oppression and in one it was alleged he had destroyed the crop of one Lakhan Rai.
('15', 477, 12, 22, 937322) 1 This report is included in full as a sample of such reports.
('15', 477, 12, 23, 937385) 2 Katha, a measurement of land equal to 1/20th of a bigha
('15', 477, 13, 24, 937443) 3 Vide “Letter to W. S. Irwin”, 24 5 1917.
('15', 478, 0, 1, 937486) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 479
('15', 478, 1, 2, 937528) Witness said that in November 1914 at a court auction sale he had purchased a
('15', 478, 2, 3, 937606) certain plot of one Alam.
('15', 478, 2, 4, 937632) A portion of the holding was in Lakhan Rai’s name as a
('15', 478, 3, 5, 937687) sub ryot, but at the attestation Lakhan Rai told the SettlementOfficer he was no
('15', 478, 4, 6, 937768) longer a sub ryot.
('15', 478, 4, 7, 937787) Witness here produced a certified copy to substantiate his
('15', 478, 5, 8, 937846) statement and aid that at the time there was a crop of oats on the land and he let
('15', 478, 6, 9, 937929) Lakhan Rai have half of it.
('15', 478, 6, 10, 937957) In May last he ordered the whole of this land to be prepared for indigo and it was then discovered that in two cottahs in a corner Lakhan
('15', 478, 7, 11, 938095) Rai had surreptitiously sown china.
('15', 478, 7, 12, 938131) This he had absolutely no right to do, and
('15', 478, 8, 13, 938174) witness’ man ploughed up the whole land.
('15', 478, 8, 14, 938215) The crop was of wry poor quality and the
('15', 478, 9, 15, 938256) damage was very slight.
('15', 478, 10, 16, 938280) With regard to a second incident about which he was asked, witness admitted
('15', 478, 11, 17, 938356) that to a certain extent he was in the wrong.
('15', 478, 11, 18, 938402) The story relating to this incident, he said, was that about the 23rd May last his Gumashta 1 reported to him that three
('15', 478, 12, 19, 938523) factory carts had gone to complainant’s village to bring the factory’s half share of batai bhusa.
('15', 478, 12, 20, 938621) There at the instigation of Bataidar, his cartmen assaulted and the bhusa
('15', 478, 13, 21, 938695) was thrown from the carts.
('15', 478, 13, 22, 938722) When the men went to witness he admitted he gave them a
('15', 478, 14, 23, 938778) few cuts on the leg with a light riding cane, but he was very angry at the time.
('15', 478, 15, 24, 938859) had assaulted his men badly.
('15', 478, 15, 25, 938888) It was true he had threatened to fine them, but he had not
('15', 478, 16, 26, 938947) actually done so.
('15', 478, 16, 27, 938965) As for their being shut up in witness’s hen house, it was absolutely
('15', 478, 17, 28, 939034) The men were nowhere near it.
('15', 478, 18, 29, 939064) MR. GANDHI: Then half of the ryot’s story is true?
('15', 478, 19, 30, 939115) It was true he had converted some of the ryots’ lands into zirat lands, but he
('15', 478, 20, 31, 939194) had given lands in exchange and there was no complaint about it.
('15', 478, 20, 32, 939259) On the exchange
('15', 478, 21, 33, 939275) lands, the ryots had actually sown and reaped their crops.
('15', 478, 21, 34, 939334) Witness had to convert these lands, as it was necessary to have all zirat lands in one place to ensure effective
('15', 478, 22, 35, 939447) supervision.
('15', 478, 22, 36, 939460) It was the practice in all zamindaris to effect this exchange of lands.
('15', 478, 23, 37, 939532) This concluded witness’s evidence and the Committee shortly after left for
('15', 478, 24, 38, 939607) Bettiah to go to villages in the interior where they intend to have local inspection.

('15', 479, 1, 2, 939766) 391. EXTRACTS FROM MINUTES OF CHAMPARAN COMMITTEE MEETING
('15', 479, 2, 3, 939824) GUEST HOUSE, BETTIAH, July 27, 1917
('15', 479, 4, 4, 939860) POUNDS—Mr. Gandhi considered that pounds should be directly managed by the Board and not auctioned.
('15', 479, 5, 5, 939960) (1) Cost of Cultivation:—Mr. Reid said it cost planters Rs. 7 to Rs. 8 per acre for zirat cultivation.
('15', 479, 5, 6, 940063) Raja Kirtyanand Sinha 1 confirmed this from his own experience.
('15', 479, 5, 7, 940127) Mr. Gandhi said that raiyats estimated it not below
('15', 479, 6, 8, 940179) Rs. 20 or Rs. 25 per acre, but he would examine the question further after seeing the factory book.
('15', 479, 7, 9, 940279) Mr. Gandhi urged that voluntary contracts should be limited to one year.
('15', 479, 8, 10, 940352) SHARAHBESHI—As regards enhancement of rent in lieu of tinkathia (sharahbeshi) recognized at the resettlement, Mr. Gandhi thought that it ought to be
('15', 479, 9, 11, 940501) revised and reduced to the ordinary enhancement allowed for rise in prices.
('15', 479, 9, 12, 940577) The President and other members were not prepared to agree and it was pointed out that under the law the enhancement could not be touched in most cases.
('15', 479, 10, 13, 940730) TAWAN—All agreed that tawan was an unjustifiable practice and should be
('15', 479, 11, 14, 940802) stopped for the future.
('15', 479, 11, 15, 940826) The question was then discussed as to what action, if any, should be taken in cases where it had already been taken.
('15', 479, 11, 16, 940943) Mr. Gandhi thought that where sums had already been paid, no action could be taken, but that factories should be required to cancel all outstanding debts on this account.
('15', 479, 11, 17, 941114) He recognized that this could only be applied to factories which were still the property of the persons who had taken the bonds and had not been sold in the meantime.
('15', 479, 11, 18, 941281) This could be enforced by the Court of Wards refusing to renew the leases of thikadars 2 who refused to agree to
('15', 479, 12, 19, 941394) this arrangement.
('15', 479, 12, 20, 941412) Other members felt that there were difficulties in the proposal which required further consideration.
('15', 479, 14, 21, 941514) 1 Of Banaili, a member of the Bihar and Orissa Legislative Council, who was appointed on July 9, 1917 a member of the Champaran Agrarian Enquiry Committee on the resignation of Raja Harihar Prasad Narayan Singh 2 Contractors
('15', 480, 0, 1, 941739) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 481
('15', 480, 1, 2, 941781) Mr. Gandhi’s proposals were:
('15', 480, 2, 3, 941810) 1. That the Court of Wards should not extend the thika system.
('15', 480, 3, 4, 941873) 2. If in the case of existing thikas the estate decided to renew the leases, (they)
('15', 480, 4, 5, 941957) should contain conditions enforcing the recommendations of the Committee,
('15', 480, 5, 6, 942031) including
('15', 480, 6, 7, 942041) (1) no indigo to be grown except in a voluntary system,
('15', 480, 7, 8, 942097) (2) no abwabs to be taken,
('15', 480, 8, 9, 942124) (3) no hurja 1 or tawan to be taken.
('15', 480, 9, 10, 942161) These proposals were accepted.

('15', 481, 1, 2, 943031) 393. CONFIDENTIAL NOTE TO CHAMPARAN COMMITTEE MEMBERS ON SHARAHBESHI
('15', 481, 2, 3, 943100) BETTIAH, July 29, 1917
('15', 481, 3, 4, 943123) In my humble opinion (1) the existence of the committee is due to the evils of the tinkathia system; (2) its chief function is to deal with it in an equitable manner; and (3) it is expected to make such recommendations as would settle the matter once for all, would restore harmony between zamindars or thikadars and the raiyats andwould prevent future disputes whether in the shape of law suits or otherwise.
('15', 481, 3, 5, 943533) If tinkathia is abolished for a consideration, the committee will have neglected its primary duty.
('15', 481, 3, 6, 943632) The committee has been appointed in spite of the tinkathia system being the subject matter of a law suit.
('15', 481, 3, 7, 943738) The committee has overwhelming proof before it to know that tinkathia has bound the raiyat like the coil of a serpent from which whether it be legal or not the raiyats have ever striven to get free and from which the Government have hitherto made unsuccessful attempts to free them.
('15', 481, 3, 8, 944021) Official evidence before us goes to show that it has taxed the officials’ wit to the utmost in their endeavour to get out of it; they attribute everything to tinkathia.
('15', 481, 3, 9, 944190) There is much truth in Mr. Whitty’s remark that though he can produce no direct evidence to show that tinkathia is responsible for the abwabs, etc., he has felt it to be so.
('15', 481, 3, 10, 944364) In the circumstances the committee, I venture to submit, is bound to condemn it in unequivocal terms and advise its abolition without any consideration whatsoever being paid by the raiyats.
('15', 481, 3, 11, 944554) The legality of slavery, when once its sinfulness was recognized, did not require a price from the slave for his freedom.
('15', 481, 3, 12, 944676) It is submitted therefore that the least the committee can do is: (1) to abolish tinkathia unconditionally; (2) to abolish sharahbeshi without interference with the past collections at the sharahbeshi rates; (3) to cancel sharahbeshi whether registered as a matter of contract or compromise subject however to enhancement of the pre sharahbeshi rent as in kham 1 or thika villages.
('15', 481, 4, 13, 945058) 1 An estate under direct management
('15', 482, 0, 1, 945094) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 483
('15', 482, 1, 2, 945136) The result of such a settlement will mean withdrawal of the High Court case and lasting peace so far as tinkathia and sharahbeshi are concerned.
('15', 482, 1, 3, 945281) The result of leaving the matter to be decided as a matter of law pure and simple will be a fruitful source of interminable disputes in which the longest purse alone must win.
('15', 482, 1, 4, 945457) It will promote bitterness between parties and reopening of many cases in the event of the raiyats winning, decided under the Sweeney 1 Settlement and will mean a loss to the landlord of the enhancement offered under the foregoing scheme.
('15', 482, 1, 5, 945696) Neither the Government nor the committee can contemplate with equanimity such a state of things.
('15', 482, 1, 6, 945793) Finally, if tawan is bad, sharahbeshi is worse from the raiyats’ standpoint.
('15', 482, 1, 7, 945870) The former has pinched the present party, the latter leaves a legacy to generations yet unborn.
('15', 482, 1, 8, 945966) We know too that sharahbeshi was proposed and taken when indigo was no longer a profitable proposition for the planter and that the Rajpur concern has shown that khuski indigo has been taken up practically without any extra cost to the planter.
('15', 482, 1, 9, 946211) So with sharahbeshi he has a fair prospect of having obtained the utmost enhancement in his rents and a continuance of profits from indigo under another form.
('15', 482, 1, 10, 946370) M. K. GANDHI
('15', 482, 2, 11, 946383) From the typewritten original signed by Gandhiji in the National Archives of India; also Select Documents on Mahatma Gandhi’s Movement in Champaran.
('15', 482, 3, 12, 946532) 153, pp.

('15', 483, 5, 7, 947331) 395. LETTER TO ESTHER FAERING
('15', 483, 6, 8, 947361) NADIAD, August 3, 1917
('15', 483, 7, 9, 947384) MY DEAR ESTHER, You have raised big questions.
('15', 483, 7, 10, 947431) I think the command of Jesus is unequivocal.
('15', 483, 7, 11, 947476) All killing is bad for one who is filled with love.
('15', 483, 7, 12, 947528) He will not need to kill.
('15', 483, 7, 13, 947554) He will not kill.
('15', 483, 7, 14, 947572) He who is filled with pity for the snake and does not fear him will not kill him and the snake will not hurt him.
('15', 483, 7, 15, 947686) This state of innocence is the one we must reach.
('15', 483, 7, 16, 947736) But only a few can reach it.
('15', 483, 7, 17, 947765) It seems to me to be impossible for nations to reach it.
('15', 483, 7, 18, 947822) Equal progress in all is an inconceivable situation.
('15', 483, 7, 19, 947875) Nations will therefore always fight.
('15', 483, 7, 20, 947912) One of them will be less wrong than the other.
('15', 483, 7, 21, 947959) A nation to be in the right can only fight with soul force.
('15', 483, 7, 22, 948019) Such a nation has still to be born.
('15', 483, 7, 23, 948055) I had hoped that India was that nation.
('15', 483, 7, 24, 948095) I fear I was wrong.
('15', 483, 7, 25, 948115) The utmost I expect of India is that she may become a great restraining force.
('15', 483, 7, 26, 948194) But she must acquire the ability to fight and suffer before she can speak to the world with any degree of effect.The pertinent question for you and me is what is our duty as individuals.
('15', 483, 7, 27, 948381) I have come to this workable decision for myself, ‘I will not kill anyone for any cause whatsoever but be killed by him if resistance or his will render my being killed necessary.’ I would give similar advice to everybody.
('15', 483, 7, 28, 948604) But where I know that there is want of will altogether, I would advise him to exert his will and fight.
('15', 483, 7, 29, 948708) There is no love where there is no will.
('15', 483, 7, 30, 948749) In India there is not only no love but hatred due to emasculation.
('15', 483, 7, 31, 948816) There is the strongest desire to fight and kill side by side with utter helplessness.
('15', 483, 7, 32, 948902) This desire must be satisfied by restoring the capacity for fighting.
('15', 483, 7, 33, 948972) Then comes the choice.
('15', 483, 7, 34, 948995) Yes, the very act of forgiving and loving shows superiority in the doer.
('15', 483, 7, 35, 949068) But that way of putting the proposition begs the question, who can love?
('15', 483, 7, 36, 949141) A mouse as mouse cannot love a cat.
('15', 483, 7, 37, 949177) A mouse cannot
('15', 484, 0, 1, 949192) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 485
('15', 484, 1, 2, 949234) be commonly said to refrain from hurting a cat.
('15', 484, 1, 3, 949282) You do not love him whom you fear.
('15', 484, 1, 4, 949317) Immediately you cease to fear, you are ready for your choice—to strike or to refrain.
('15', 484, 1, 5, 949403) To refrain is proof of awakening of the soul in man; to strike is proof of body force.
('15', 484, 1, 6, 949490) The ability to strike must be present when the power of the soul is demonstrated.
('15', 484, 1, 7, 949572) This does not mean that we must be bodily superior to the adversary.
('15', 484, 1, 8, 949641) This is not a satisfactory letter but I think you will follow my argument.
('15', 484, 1, 9, 949716) But in matters such, as these, prayer is the thing.
('15', 484, 1, 10, 949768) With love,
('15', 484, 2, 11, 949779) My Dear Child, pp.

('15', 484, 9, 21, 950177) 397. EXTRACTS FROM MINUTES OF CHAMPARAN COMMITTEE MEETING
('15', 484, 10, 22, 950235) BETTIAH, August 8, 1917
('15', 484, 12, 23, 950259) Mr. Gandhi suggested that the report should specify the more general kinds of abwab, so that there could be no doubt as to their condemnation.
('15', 484, 12, 24, 950402) This was agreed to.
('15', 484, 14, 25, 950422) FINES—The outstanding point to be settled about fines was the recommendation in respect of cases to which the landlord was a party.
('15', 484, 14, 26, 950554) The President
('15', 484, 15, 27, 950568) 1 Found with Gandhiji’s correspondence of 1917, the letter is placed in that year.
('15', 484, 15, 28, 950651) Again, Gandhiji left Bettiah for Ahmedabad on August 16.
('15', 485, 0, 1, 950708) 486 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 485, 1, 2, 950750) said that, in his opinion, to adopt Mr. Gandhi’s suggestion that in all such cases the matter should go to a court would be injurious to the raiyats and would moreover
('15', 485, 2, 3, 950918) require legislation.
('15', 485, 2, 4, 950939) He thought Mr. Gandhi’s objection might be met if it were clearly laid down and understood—
('15', 485, 3, 5, 951031) (1) that the payment was entirely voluntary,
('15', 485, 4, 6, 951076) (2) that if the raiyat thought he was not liable, or that the payment was
('15', 485, 5, 7, 951150) excessive, it was open for him to refuse to pay.
('15', 485, 6, 8, 951199) Mr. Gandhi said that as the fines were few, so also would be the number of cases in which the landlords would have to report to the court.
('15', 485, 6, 9, 951338) He thought the power of the landlord over the raiyats was so great that it would be difficult to ensure that
('15', 485, 7, 10, 951447) payments were voluntary.
('15', 485, 7, 11, 951472) After some discussion it was agreed, on the suggestion of Mr. Reid, that the assessing of damages should be left to arbitration....

('15', 485, 14, 24, 952157) This condition has come to me with no effort on my part but I feel it is worth while cultivating it.

('15', 485, 15, 31, 952656) 1 Deliverance from both birth and death is the last of the four ends of life, viz., dharma, artha (material prosperity), kama (pleasure), moksha (liberation).

('15', 486, 5, 7, 953020) 399. EXTRACTS FROM MINUTES OF CHAMPARAN COMMITTEE MEETING
('15', 486, 6, 8, 953078) August 10, 1917
('15', 486, 8, 9, 953094) (1) Cost of Cultivation 1: —Mr. Gandhi said that he had not yet got certain
('15', 486, 9, 10, 953170) figures from Mr. Jameson 2 but subject to anything new that these might disclose, it was recorded as the conclusion of the Committee that the maximum cost was Rs. 15 per bigha (8_ hath laggi 3) or Rs. 10 an
('15', 486, 11, 11, 953377) (2) Mr. Gandhi said the cost of seed of country crops was small but the President remarked that for rabi 4 crops, it was a considerable item.
('15', 486, 12, 12, 953519) Khuski Indigo—Mr. Gandhi suggested that a minimum rate should be fixed for khuski indigo.
('15', 486, 12, 13, 953609) Mr. Reid thought that there might be a danger of this suggestion
('15', 486, 13, 14, 953674) extending to other crops, e.g., sugarcane.
('15', 486, 13, 15, 953717) After discussion it was agreed that during the transition stage in view of the past history of indigo, it was desirable that the Association, with the approval of the Commissioner, should fix a minimum rate for khuski indigo, the transition stage being considered to last until Government was satisfied that the raiyats knew that they need not grow indigo unless they liked.
('15', 486, 15, 16, 954092) Compensation for abolition of tinkathia—The next point for discussion was
('15', 486, 16, 17, 954166) whether on abolition of the system, compensation was to be allowed in case where the growing of indigo was recorded as an incident of the tenancy.
('15', 486, 16, 18, 954313) The President, in putting his view before the Committee, said he was anxious to remove anything unjust to the raiyats.
('15', 486, 16, 19, 954432) He thought that perhaps Mr. Gandhi from his experience of a
('15', 486, 17, 20, 954492) 1 The subject under discussion was tinkathia indigo.
('15', 486, 18, 21, 954545) 2 J. V. Jameson, Manager, Jallaha Factory 3 A unit of land measurement used in Champaran 4 Winter crops
('15', 487, 0, 1, 954649) 488 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 487, 1, 2, 954691) raiyatwari tract had not fully appreciated the landlord’s position.
('15', 487, 1, 3, 954759) The proposal he put
('15', 487, 2, 4, 954779) before the meeting was that a special court should be created to deal with these cases.
('15', 487, 2, 5, 954867) This court would decide, subject to appeal to a special judge,
('15', 487, 3, 6, 954930) (a) if the incident of tenancy existed, and if so
('15', 487, 4, 7, 954980) (b) a fair rate for commutation of the incident.
('15', 487, 5, 8, 955029) The commutation should be made by an addition to rent and not by a lump sum.
('15', 487, 5, 9, 955106) In fixing a fair rent as commutation, the court should
('15', 487, 6, 10, 955161) (a) consider the loss incurred by the raiyat under tinkathia
('15', 487, 7, 11, 955222) (b) the actual enhanced rents paid in similar circumstances for commutation, and
('15', 487, 8, 12, 955303) (c) in no circumstances fix a total rent which was not fair and equitable
('15', 487, 9, 13, 955377) The enhancement might be made progressive if it exceeded 25 per cent.
('15', 487, 10, 14, 955447) Mr. Gandhi said he did not wish to enter into legal points but merely to regard the question from the point of view of equity.
('15', 487, 10, 15, 955574) The result of the proposal would be that raiyats in villages under direct management would be placed in a better position than raiyats in indigo villages, although the latter had borne this heavy burden in the past
('15', 487, 11, 16, 955789) which was inequitable.
('15', 487, 11, 17, 955812) He thought that the evil of the system had not been properly recognised by the Committee.
('15', 487, 11, 18, 955902) Government had never agreed that indigo growing was an obligation, and all the papers showed that the system and its accompaniments formed an intolerable burden on the raiyats.
('15', 487, 11, 19, 956079) The proposal did not free the raiyats; on
('15', 487, 12, 20, 956121) the other hand, it was a free gift to the planters, it was the planters who wished to give up indigo because, whatever might be the case now, indigo was not paying when the conversions were made, and it was not fair to the raiyats to make them pay for
('15', 487, 13, 21, 956373) giving up indigo.
('15', 487, 13, 22, 956391) He had considered the matter from the landlords’ point of view, as was shown by his agreement in the matter of tawan.
('15', 487, 13, 23, 956509) In the present question, he could not separate the raiyats of mukarrari villages from those of thika villages.
('15', 487, 14, 24, 956620) were in the same position and should be regarded in the same way.
('15', 487, 14, 25, 956686) He could not therefore agree to anything beyond an enhancement of rent under the ordinary provision of the law, and opposed any special enhancement in lieu of tinkathia.
('15', 487, 15, 26, 956856) foresaw complications in the action proposed.
('15', 487, 15, 27, 956902) A settlement by a special court would take some months, which was undesirable in the present state of unrest.
('15', 487, 15, 28, 957012) An immediate and automatic remedy was required, and this would be the merit of his suggestion of an enhancement at a fixed rate on the ground of the rise in prices, that is, of 3 annas in the rupee all round.
('15', 487, 16, 29, 957221) The President pointed out that in comparing the position of the non indigo raiyats with the indigo raiyats, it had to be considered that in villages where abwab were taken, they were higher than sharahbeshi, and, that where abwab were not taken (e.g., Madhuban Estate), the rent was enhanced to a
('15', 488, 0, 1, 957518) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 489
('15', 488, 1, 2, 957560) higher pitch than elsewhere.
('15', 488, 1, 3, 957589) Admittedly in Bettiah kham villages these
('15', 488, 2, 4, 957631) considerations did not apply but it was impossible to secure absolute equality, and in any case the proposal would improve the position of the raiyat who had been
('15', 488, 3, 5, 957794) growing indigo.
('15', 488, 3, 6, 957810) As to the criticism that the proposal was a free gift to planters, he said that it was only proposed to allow an enhancement where the legal property of the planter existed and even then the full value of this property was not being given.
('15', 488, 3, 7, 958050) He did not think the difficulties of the special court would be great.
('15', 488, 3, 8, 958121) The settlement records would give a good basis and the area to be dealt with was not large.
('15', 488, 4, 9, 958213) Mr. Rainy 1 said the proposal was similar to that adopted in Chhota Nagpur where legislation compelled the computation of predial conditions.
('15', 488, 4, 10, 958355) He denied that Government had never recognised the fact that the obligation might be an incident of tenancy, for section 29 proviso (iii) was clear evidence that they had and so was the Board’s letter No.
('15', 488, 4, 11, 958560) 5032 R(A) dated the 16th October, 1912, regarding Mr. Irwin’s sharahbeshi.
('15', 488, 4, 12, 958635) Mr. Gandhi said that if the legal right was not consistent with equity or
('15', 488, 5, 13, 958709) had been grossly abused as in this case, no compensation should be given.
('15', 488, 6, 14, 958783) Mr. Reid said that most of the raiyats took their holdings under an agreement to grow indigo.
('15', 488, 6, 15, 958877) Mr. Gandhi said the complaint was not against indigo itself but against the manner and method of growing it.
('15', 488, 6, 16, 958986) the complaint was not against the system but against the moral and intellectual damage caused by it to the raiyats by keeping them backward.
('15', 488, 6, 17, 959127) The President pointed out that his proposal gave much to the raiyats, viz., freedom
('15', 488, 7, 18, 959211) (1) from growing indigo if they did not wish,
('15', 488, 8, 19, 959257) (2) from having their best lands selected for indigo,
('15', 488, 9, 20, 959311) (3) from supervision by factory servants,
('15', 488, 10, 21, 959353) (4) from paying compensation for this freedom except in cases where the obligation was the legal property of the landlord and even then full compensation would not be given.
('15', 488, 11, 22, 959527) Mr. Gandhi said that this included nothing that was not offered by the planters themselves but Mr. Rainy pointed out that whereas the planters offered their own terms, the proposal contemplated that they should be compelled to accept terms fixed by a court.
('15', 488, 12, 23, 959785) The President said that Mr. Gandhi’s position practically amounted to the proposition that the raiyats should get off paying an equitable rent on the ground of past oppression, which position did not appear to him to be sound.
('15', 488, 13, 24, 960012) At this stage, the meeting adjourned.

('15', 489, 2, 3, 960283) August 11, 1917
('15', 489, 3, 4, 960299) Resuming the discussion of the previous day, Mr. Gandhi said that the average amount of sharahbeshi taken was about 50 per cent of the rent.
('15', 489, 3, 5, 960440) The note circulated by
('15', 489, 4, 6, 960463) Raja Kirtyanand Sinha suggested a compromise of an enhancement of four annas in the rupee to cover sharahbeshi and ordinary enhancement on the score of rise in
('15', 489, 5, 7, 960623) prices.
('15', 489, 5, 8, 960631) He was anxious to meet the views of his fellow members so far as that was possible, and he was prepared to agree to a small enhancement over and above that admissible for a rise in prices but would not support a penal enhancement.
('15', 489, 5, 9, 960862) The greatest difficulty would be as regards the sharahbeshi already taken.
('15', 489, 5, 10, 960937) He thought that
('15', 489, 6, 11, 960953) anything very much larger than the enhancement allowed for the rise in prices would be near the danger point.
('15', 489, 6, 12, 961063) The President said that he understood the proposal to be that, in cases where the obligation to grow indigo existed as an incident of tenancy or had been commuted by sharahbeshi, a slight enhancement though not a penal one in
('15', 489, 7, 13, 961289) excess of the enhancement generally admissible for a rise in prices should be allowed.
('15', 489, 7, 14, 961376) He pointed out that it was impossible to fix a definite figure for the total enhancement, because it was still uncertain what enhancement would eventually be allowed by the courts on account of the rise in prices.
('15', 489, 7, 15, 961590) The proposal therefore could only refer to the amount of enhancement above this figure.
('15', 489, 7, 16, 961678) He asked Mr. Gandhi to what extra enhancement he was prepared to agree.
('15', 489, 7, 17, 961750) Mr. Gandhi said he thought not more than one anna in the rupee.
('15', 489, 8, 18, 961814) The President said that the facts were that by a settlement between the planters and raiyats, there had been a sharahbeshi enhancement of 50 per cent, which
('15', 489, 9, 19, 961971) Mr. Gandhi thought excessive because the legal property in exchange for which this enhancement was taken was inequitable and therefore the enhancement should be reduced.
('15', 489, 9, 20, 962141) Mr. Gandhi added that there was also the fact that the tenants were not paying rents and in one case their resistance had been successful.
('15', 489, 9, 21, 962280) By adopting his suggestion, the Committee would put a stop at once to the present trouble and it was not open to the Committee to shift responsibility by suggesting another tribunal.
('15', 489, 9, 22, 962463) Mr. Adami held the view that one anna was not sufficient and, considering the difficulties which had been pointed out by Mr. Rainy, he would be inclined to adopt the suggestion of a general settlement of rents in mukarrari villages by a special
('15', 489, 10, 23, 962708) tribunal in all cases where the obligation still existed or where it had been converted.
('15', 489, 10, 24, 962797) Raja Kirtyanand Sinha supported the proposal in his note for an enhancement of four annas in the rupee.
('15', 489, 10, 25, 962901) Mr. Gandhi remarked that if Mr. Adami’s proposal was accepted, the Committee would only have half done its work, but his main objection to it was
('15', 490, 0, 1, 963047) 491 VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917
('15', 490, 1, 2, 963089) that it would add to a ferment which already existed.
('15', 490, 1, 3, 963143) The Committee had the right to confer with the planters and he thought it would be far better if they could come to some agreement with the planters without the necessity of appointing any tribunal which would delay a final agreement.
('15', 490, 1, 4, 963378) Mr. Reid pointed out that the three concerns mainly affected were Motihari, Pipra and Turkaulia and he was prepared to put the proposal before these three concerns.
('15', 490, 1, 5, 963543) The President remarked that it should first be decided whether the proposal was to be put before the planters as a final one which they could adopt or not or merely as a basis for discussion.
('15', 490, 1, 6, 963735) He inclined to the latter.
('15', 490, 1, 7, 963762) There was a tremendous advantage in getting the question settled without reference to any court and, as he himself doubted whether one anna was adequate, he thought the suggestion should be used as a basis for discussion.
('15', 490, 1, 8, 963984) Mr. Gandhi said that he would not go so far as to say that he could not agree to anything above one anna, but at the same time he could not say that he would go beyond this point.
('15', 490, 1, 9, 964164) The one anna was pure concession on his part, because he did not think the raiyats should be called upon to
('15', 490, 2, 10, 964272) pay any enhancement beyond that allowed by the rise in prices.
('15', 490, 2, 11, 964335) Mr. Reid doubted if the planters would agree to anything under eight annas enhancement and pointed out that even in Pipra which had taken the biggest enhancement, the rents were only Rs. 2 an acre.
('15', 490, 3, 12, 964533) Mr. Reid then suggested that it would be a fairer proposal if the amount of sharahbeshi was reduced by a fixed percentage, say, by 25 per cent.
('15', 490, 3, 13, 964677) Mr. Gandhi said
('15', 490, 4, 14, 964693) he would be very willing to consider that as a basis for a settlement and would be prepared to go a long way to get good will established.
('15', 490, 4, 15, 964832) It was generally agreed that this was a fairer basis for discussion than the original proposal, and that Messrs Irwin 1, Hill 2, and Norman 3 should be asked to come on the following day in order that the proposal might be put to them.
('15', 490, 5, 16, 965068) Tawan—The proposal left over for decision from the first meeting was that no action should be taken in cases where tawan had been already paid but that outstanding bonds on account of tawan should be cancelled.
('15', 490, 5, 17, 965279) The President said
('15', 490, 6, 18, 965298) one difficulty about this proposal was that some bonds were mixed and included amounts taken on accounts other than tawan, and some sort of enquiry would therefore
('15', 490, 7, 19, 965462) be necessary before the question of these bonds could be finally disposed of.
('15', 490, 7, 20, 965540) The other difficulty was that the proposal worked unequally both on raiyats
('15', 490, 8, 21, 965616) and planters.
('15', 490, 8, 22, 965630) Mr. Gandhi pointed out that the first difficulty could be got over by examining the factory books, and he would leave it to the Bettiah Raj to satisfy itself that outstanding amounts on account of tawan had been foregone.
('15', 490, 8, 23, 965852) Mr. Reid
('15', 490, 9, 24, 965861) said that he thought the only factory where such mixed bonds were taken was
('15', 490, 10, 25, 965937) 1 W. S. Irwin of Motihari Factory 2 J. L. Hill, Manager, Turkaulia Concern 3 J. B. Norman, Manager, Pipra Indigo Concern
('15', 491, 0, 1, 966058) 492 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 491, 1, 2, 966100) Bairia where in some cases the debts of raiyats had been taken over and added to the tawan.
('15', 491, 1, 3, 966192) He would be inclined to apply the same suggestion to tawan that he made in the case of sharahbeshi, namely, to deduct a percentage from outstandings and to refund a percentage on the tawan already paid.
('15', 491, 1, 4, 966395) This would only apply to thika
('15', 491, 2, 5, 966426) villages.
('15', 491, 3, 6, 966436) The next point considered was whether the Raj could claim an enhancement of rent in cases where tawan had been taken.
('15', 491, 3, 7, 966554) Mr. Rainy said he was inclined to agree
('15', 491, 4, 8, 966594) to the proposal that no enhancement should be applied for in such cases, but the President felt that the interests of the Bettiah Raj also needed consideration.
('15', 491, 4, 9, 966755) He would propose that the Raj should not be debarred from claiming an enhancement of rent in cases where tawan had been taken but that for a period of years, say five, the enhanced

('15', 491, 7, 16, 967354) for the position.
('15', 491, 7, 17, 967372) After discussion, it was decided to recommend that in cases where tawan had been taken, the Raj was not to be debarred from claiming enhancement but
('15', 491, 8, 18, 967521) it would forego realisation of the enhancement for a period of seven years.
('15', 491, 9, 19, 967597) Mr. Gandhi made the following proposals:
('15', 491, 10, 20, 967638) (1) That the Committee should make a general recommendation that the orders passed by Government on the Committee’s report should be communicated in the vernacular to the raiyats.
('15', 491, 10, 21, 967818) This was accepted.
('15', 491, 11, 22, 967837) (2) That the kerosene oil monopoly should be stopped.
('15', 491, 11, 23, 967891) This was agreed to.
('15', 491, 12, 24, 967911) (3) He proposed that raiyats should be informed that dasturi was illegal.
('15', 491, 12, 25, 967985) It was agreed to say in the report that it had been brought to notice that amla took commissions on payments which were entirely illegal and that every effort should be made to stop them and to recommend that a proclamation should be issued to the raiyats, informing them that this dasturi was not legally payable.
('15', 491, 13, 26, 968300) (4) He suggested that some officer should be deputed to enquire periodically if the orders of Government on the Committee’s recommendations were being carried out.
('15', 491, 13, 27, 968464) It was agreed that a paragraph should be included to emphasise that an important part of the duties of the district staff would be to see that Government orders on the recommendation were carried out which would apply especially to the staff of the Bettiah Raj until Government was satisfied that the full effect of these orders had been secured.
