('15', 492, 1, 2, 968926) 401. EXTRACTS FROM MINUTES OF CHAMPARAN COMMITTEE MEETING
('15', 492, 2, 3, 968984) August 12, 1917
('15', 492, 3, 4, 969000) At the resumption of the discussion, Messrs Irwin (Motihari), Norman (Pipra) and Hill (Turkaulia) were present by invitation.
('15', 492, 3, 5, 969126) The President explained that this discussion must be entirely confidential.
('15', 492, 3, 6, 969202) The Committee had come to the unanimous conclusion that the tinkathia system should go and should be replaced by the khuski
('15', 492, 4, 7, 969326) system under short term agreement.
('15', 492, 4, 8, 969361) It had, therefore, been necessary to consider the question of the commutation of the indigo obligation both in cases where it still existed and in cases where it had already been commuted .
('15', 492, 4, 9, 969551) Mr. Gandhi had said that he was prepared to consider the possibility of a settlement on certain lines.
('15', 492, 4, 10, 969654) He, therefore, asked Mr. Gandhi to put his proposal before the planters present.
('15', 492, 4, 11, 969735) Mr. Gandhi said that his object was to promote harmony; he had no doubt that sharahbeshi had caused considerable difficulty to the raiyats, seeing the large
('15', 492, 5, 12, 969892) numbers that had protested against it.
('15', 492, 5, 13, 969931) At the time of conversion of the obligation, indigo was not profitable and it was mutually beneficial to both parties to cancel the obligation.
('15', 492, 5, 14, 970075) Any burden imposed; therefore, on the raiyats beyond the ordinary legal
('15', 492, 6, 15, 970147) enhancements was one against which they were justified in protesting.
('15', 492, 6, 16, 970217) As to the amount of the ordinary enhancement about which on the previous day there appeared to be some doubt, he referred to the judgment of the special judge in special appeal No.
('15', 492, 6, 17, 970398) 14 of 1916, and said that it appeared from that that the enhancement eventually decided on would be three annas and not four annas eight pies.
('15', 492, 6, 18, 970541) He had suggested as a concession an extra anna on account of sharahbeshi.
('15', 492, 6, 19, 970615) The planter would no doubt
('15', 492, 7, 20, 970642) consider that it called for considerable self denia1 on their part to give up anything of the sharahbeshi which they had already obtained, but he appealed to them to think of the raiyats’ position; he would be prepared to accept a proposal on the basis of an all round reduction in the sharahbeshi already taken which was perhaps a better basis
('15', 492, 8, 21, 970987) for discussion.
('15', 492, 8, 22, 971003) He pointed out how desirable it was that some figure should be agreed upon between the parties because, in the event of this not being done either of the ways suggested, the only course remaining was the settlement of rents by a special tribunal which would give rise to endless quarrels, and would postpone settlement of the disputes over a considerable period.
('15', 492, 8, 23, 971366) If, however, the planters would prefer to have a special tribunal, he would be prepared to consider the proposal.
('15', 492, 8, 24, 971480) The President remarked that so far as the discussion had gone, the Committee favoured a settlement on the lines of proportionate reduction of sharahbeshi taken rather than the proposal
('15', 492, 9, 25, 971665) to an all round enhancement of a certain amount on the original rents, because the former was more equitable table in view of the varying conditions of different concerns.
('15', 492, 9, 26, 971837) Mr. Reid said he had a long talk that morning with the three planters present.
('15', 492, 9, 27, 971916) At first they had been averse from agreeing to any decrease to the
('15', 493, 0, 1, 971983) 494 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 493, 1, 2, 972025) enhancement which had been mutually agreed upon and approved by the Settlement Court.
('15', 493, 1, 3, 972111) Their view was that they had valuable property which the Committee was asking them to give up in part.
('15', 493, 1, 4, 972214) He had put the view to them that it was extremely desirable to avoid future litigation and t rouble even if it involved some sacrifice on their part.
('15', 493, 1, 5, 972364) Finally, they had agreed reluctantly to remit a certain proportion.
('15', 493, 1, 6, 972432) Mr. Hill, however, had pointed out that his enhancements were low and that he thought that the reduction in his case should be less than in that of others.
('15', 493, 1, 7, 972588) Mr. Gandhi said he was prepared to accept the principle of a different rate of reduction for different concerns but the difficulty was that the Committee had not got the figures before them and he doubted if the settlement records would give them sufficient data for arriving at a proper variation in the reduction without further enquiry.
('15', 493, 1, 8, 972928) The President said that the advantage of getting a settlement by agreement was immense not only to the planters but also to the raiyats .
('15', 493, 1, 9, 973066) If the Committee could decide on a particular percentage of
('15', 493, 2, 10, 973126) reduction, they would get a long way towards settlement and he, therefore, thought that an endeavour should be made to get down to a particular figure.
('15', 493, 2, 11, 973278) The alternative to a settlement by agreement was one which would lead to increased bitterness of feeling and even then the decisions of the special court might not be accepted with good will.
('15', 493, 2, 12, 973470) He would, therefore, ask the planters to state what was the outside figure of the reduction of the sharahbeshi enhancement to which they are prepared to agree.
('15', 493, 3, 13, 973630) Messrs Irwin and Norman said they were prepared to forego 25 per cent and Mr. Hill said he was repared to forego 20 per cent as a maximum.
('15', 493, 3, 14, 973769) Mr. Gandhi said that he was not in a position at present to say off hand what percentage of reduction he would consider to be fair and he was not sure whether the Committee were in a position to arrive at a figure at the present moment.
('15', 493, 3, 15, 974006) Mr. Gandhi wanted to know if the planters would agree to leave the percentage to be fixed by the Committee.
('15', 493, 3, 16, 974114) The planters explained their position to be that if the Committee recommended any deduction up to 25 per cent, they would accept it; if the Committee recommended a higher figure than 25 per cent, they would oppose it; and on the understanding that this would be binding on all with no possibility of litigation outside such agreement.
('15', 493, 3, 17, 974449) The President remarked that he thought that any agreement would require binding by legislation and that it now remained for the Committee to try and arrive at some agreement on the percentage.
('15', 493, 3, 18, 974642) He pointed out that in all these sharahbeshi cases, the
('15', 493, 4, 19, 974698) enhanced rents had been passed by the Settlement Courts as fair and equitable, so that the Committee could be quite certain that any rents fixed after such a reduction of sharahbeshi as was proposed would be a fortiori fair to the raiyats.
('15', 493, 4, 20, 974938) In disputed cases,
('15', 493, 5, 21, 974957) the rent had only been passed as fair and equitable by the Settlement Courts where they held that the tinkathia obligation was proved and the original rent was low.
('15', 493, 6, 22, 975122) thought, therefore, that there was no fear that the new rents after reduction would not be fair and equitable.
('15', 493, 6, 23, 975233) Mr. Gandhi observed that the Settlement Officer was, in his opinion, wrong in the decisions he gave and had misinterpreted the law.
('15', 493, 6, 24, 975365) He doubted
('15', 494, 0, 1, 975376) 495 VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917
('15', 494, 1, 2, 975418) whether the Settlement Court’s decisions would stand legal scrutiny.
('15', 494, 1, 3, 975487) He also thought that the settlement decisions were wrong in equity and again referred to the judgment of the Special Judge in Special Appeal No.
('15', 494, 1, 4, 975632) 14 of 1916 in which the contention of the Settlement Officer that Re.
('15', 494, 1, 5, 975702) 0 4 8 per rupee was an unfair enhancement had been upheld by the Special Judge.
('15', 494, 1, 6, 975782) If the Settlement Courts had considered Re.
('15', 494, 1, 7, 975826) 0 4 8 to be an unfair enhancement and had allowed only 3 annas, how could they in other cases hold enhancements rising as high as l00 per cent to be fair and equitable?
('15', 494, 1, 8, 975995) Mr. Rainy thought that Mr. Gandhi was confusing a legal enhancement with a fair and equitable rent.
('15', 494, 1, 9, 976095) The applications of the Bettiah Raj for the settlement of their rent depended on the presumption that the existing rents were fair and equitable.
('15', 494, 1, 10, 976241) In the sharahbeshi cases, that presumption did not arise because the rents were specially
('15', 494, 2, 11, 976331) It was necessary to distinguish carefully the legal and equitable points of view.
('15', 494, 3, 12, 976413) Mr. Gandhi said that in determining what was a fair and equitable rent, the outturn of the soil alone should not be taken into consideration.
('15', 494, 3, 13, 976555) It did not follow because the rent was only a small proportion of the produce, that it was too low.
('15', 494, 3, 14, 976655) His difficulty was that his view point and that of the planters were different and there were no cases so difficult to settle by agreement as those in which the view point differed.
('15', 494, 3, 15, 976837) He could not agree to a penal enhancement and the proposal of a 25 per cent reduction at present appeared to him to involve a penal enhancement.
('15', 494, 3, 16, 976982) He wanted an opportunity to examine the figures before deciding.
('15', 494, 3, 17, 977047) Mr. Irwin instanced the case of Bisambharpur, a village belonging to petty maliks 1 and not in lease to him although entirely
('15', 494, 4, 18, 977173) surrounded by Bettiah Raj villages which he held in lease; the rates of rent in Biasambharpur varied from Rs. 9 to Rs. 14 a bigha, whereas the rate of rent in the surrounding villages in lease to him only averaged Rs. 4 to Rs. 5 a bigha, even including the sharahbeshi.
('15', 494, 4, 19, 977443) He did not see how it was possible to contend that from the raiyats’ standpoint, the proposal was a favourable one, as it would give them a
('15', 494, 5, 20, 977583) considerable advantage.
('15', 494, 5, 21, 977607) Mr. Gandhi, however, said that the legal position from the raiyats’ stand point was not hopeless.
('15', 494, 7, 22, 977705) Mr. Gandhi said that he worked out the figures as follows:
('15', 494, 8, 23, 977764) The sharahbeshi enhancement varied from 19 or 20 annas up to 30 or 32 annas per bigha.
('15', 494, 8, 24, 977851) A 25 per cent reduction would reduce these enhancements to amounts
('15', 494, 9, 25, 977918) varying from 14 annas 9 pies or 15 annas to 22 annas 6 pies or 24 annas.
('15', 494, 9, 26, 977991) According to his calculation, if the rent rate was Rs. 2 6 0 per bigha, the enhancement under his proposal would be 10 annas per bigha only and the difference between this and the
('15', 494, 10, 27, 978171) results of the other proposal was very considerable.
('15', 494, 10, 28, 978224) The President said that in
('15', 494, 11, 29, 978251) 1 Owners or proprietors
('15', 495, 0, 1, 978275) 496 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 495, 1, 2, 978317) Motihari, the sharahbeshi was 60 per cent of the former rent.
('15', 495, 1, 3, 978379) It was now proposed to
('15', 495, 2, 4, 978402) reduce it to 47 per cent, whereas Mr. Gandhi’s proposal would give only 25 per cent; the difference was, therefore, one of 20 per cent.
('15', 495, 2, 5, 978538) Mr. Rainy pointed out that it was misleading in some cases to judge by percentage because in cases where the percentage was high, e.g., Pipra, the absolute amount of the rent was low.
('15', 495, 2, 6, 978722) The President pointed out that both in Turkaulia and Motihari the raiyats had paid
('15', 495, 3, 7, 978805) enhanced rents for 6 years with no objections, save in a very few cases, and he thought that a reduction of 25 per cent was a very considerable concession to the raiyats.
('15', 495, 3, 8, 978976) Mr. Gandhi said that he looked at it from the point of view of what the raiyats had the right to demand 6 years ago, because it was only through their
('15', 495, 4, 9, 979127) ignorance of their legal position that they had not raised any objections before.
('15', 495, 4, 10, 979209) The President said that he saw no other way of avoiding a tribunal except settlement by consent, and it was very uncertain whether the raiyats would get such good terms from
('15', 495, 5, 11, 979383) the tribunal as those now offered.
('15', 495, 5, 12, 979418) Even if Mr. Gandhi was not satisfied that the present rent including sharahbeshi reduced as proposal was fair and equitable, could
('15', 495, 6, 13, 979549) he not be satisfied that rent was capable of being easily paid?
('15', 495, 6, 14, 979613) Mr. Gandhi said that he thought the Champaran raiyat was poor and he was not prepared to admit that the rent could be paid easily.
('15', 495, 6, 15, 979744) Mr. Gandhi said that the class of raiyats had to be considered as well as the possibilities of the soil and the Champaran raiyat was by nature a bad
('15', 495, 7, 16, 979893) cultivator.
('15', 495, 7, 17, 979905) In his opinion, if rents were apparently low, there was generally a very good reason for it.
('15', 495, 7, 18, 979998) He considered that the raiyats had fully paid for this concession of
('15', 495, 8, 19, 980067) abstention from rent enhancement and his view of the legal position was that the raiyats could free themselves from the obligation without paying any compensation.
('15', 495, 9, 20, 980231) In saying this, he did not mean to imply that he wished indigo to disappear; he would advise the raiyats to grow indigo, provided they got reasonable rates for it.
('15', 495, 10, 21, 980395) Rainy said on the basis of Mr. Sweeney’s figures of produce the Pipra rents were very low, the Motihari rents moderate and even the Turkaulia rents were not high; if 25 per cent of the sharahbeshi, was taken off, it would give an ample margin of safety.
('15', 495, 11, 22, 980649) Gandhi said he could not bring himself to accept the proposal of a 25 per cent reduction.
('15', 495, 11, 23, 980739) Mr. Reid inquired whether the alternative to a settlement by agreement was the suggestion of a tribunal.
('15', 495, 11, 24, 980844) Mr. Gandhi said that if the Committee could not come to an agreement, he would be prepared to accept the suggestion of a tribunal, but he asked whether the Committee could not recommend a higher reduction.
('15', 495, 11, 25, 981050) The President said that he thought the Committee had got the highest possible figures out of the planters and he was not prepared to agree to higher figure.
('15', 495, 11, 26, 981207) He could not imagine that any raiyats would ever regret having accepted this proposal; the only raiyats who might be discontented were the few raiyats who still grew indigo.
('15', 495, 11, 27, 981381) Mr. Gandhi said that the raiyats thought that they could get rid of sharahbeshi by legal methods even
('15', 495, 12, 28, 981483) in cases where it had been settled under section 10 (C).
('15', 495, 12, 29, 981540) He did not see, therefore, that they would regret not accepting the present proposal.
('15', 496, 0, 1, 981626) 497 VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917
('15', 496, 1, 2, 981668) Mr. Gandhi enquired what was to be done in the case of the Jalaha concern in the event of the Committee reaching a conclusion on the general question.
('15', 496, 1, 3, 981819) In that concern, sharahbeshi had been taken by making tenants surrender their holdings
('15', 496, 2, 4, 981906) which were then resettled with their relatives on an enhanced rent.
('15', 496, 2, 5, 981974) The Civil Court had held in some cases that the old tenants should be restored at the former rent.
('15', 496, 2, 6, 982073) The President said that this was the first occasion that the matter had been brought to his notice and he thought that they ought to ascertain the facts and hear what Mr. Jameson had to say before coming to any conclusion about it.
('15', 496, 3, 7, 982305) Returning to the general question, Mr. Adami said that the equity of the
('15', 496, 4, 8, 982378) position would be to wash out the past 50 years and put the parties back in the
('15', 496, 5, 9, 982458) position they would have been if indigo had not been grown.
('15', 496, 5, 10, 982518) Mr. Gandhi said that this could not be done as the raiyat had given up far more than he had gained during
('15', 496, 6, 11, 982624) that period.
('15', 496, 6, 12, 982637) Mr. Rainy pointed out the high rents in Madhuban Babu’s estate.
('15', 496, 6, 13, 982701) Mr. Gandhi admitted that Indian zamindars had enhanced their raiyats’ rents.
('15', 496, 7, 14, 982778) President then said that as Mr. Gandhi could not agree to the 25 per cent reduction,
('15', 496, 8, 15, 982863) there were two courses open—the Committee could recommend the view of the
('15', 496, 9, 16, 982937) majority that a 25 per cent reduction was fair; Mr. Gandhi would in a note of dissent
('15', 496, 10, 17, 983023) give his reasons for thinking that a higher figure was required and it could be left to
('15', 496, 11, 18, 983111) Government to decide between these two views and legislate accordingly.
('15', 496, 12, 19, 983183) course, however, could only be adopted if he was satisfied that the decision of
('15', 496, 13, 20, 983263) Government whatever it might be would be accepted.
('15', 496, 13, 21, 983314) If it was not accepted, the
('15', 496, 14, 22, 983342) position of strife and unrest would still remain and in that event the Committee would
('15', 496, 15, 23, 983429) have to recommend the alternative procedure of settlement of rents by a special
('15', 496, 16, 24, 983509) tribunal.
('15', 496, 16, 25, 983519) He hoped that in the interest of peace, it would be possible to adopt the first
('15', 496, 17, 26, 983599) alternative, it being understood that whatever Government decided would be loyally
('15', 496, 18, 27, 983682) accepted.
('15', 496, 18, 28, 983692) Mr. Gandhi said that he could promise to accept the decision of Government and would refrain from advising the raiyats to resist it.
('15', 496, 18, 29, 983825) Mr. Reid enquired what should
('15', 496, 19, 30, 983855) be done as regards pending legislation.
('15', 496, 19, 31, 983895) Mr. Gandhi said that he thought it desirable to
('15', 496, 20, 32, 983943) forward their recommendation to Government at once, so that a decision might be
('15', 496, 21, 33, 984023) reached and pending legislation stopped as soon as possible.
('15', 496, 21, 34, 984084) Mr. Adami pointed out
('15', 496, 22, 35, 984106) that the legislation would take time and the President added that Government would
('15', 496, 23, 36, 984189) probably decide first to publish the Committee’s report and give time to the public
('15', 496, 24, 37, 984273) and the parties to consider the proposals.
('15', 496, 24, 38, 984316) It would facilitate the preparation of the
('15', 496, 25, 39, 984359) report and possibly I ncrease the chance of Government being able to arrive at a
('15', 496, 26, 40, 984440) decision if Mr. Gandhi could put before the Committee the reduction to which he was
('15', 496, 27, 41, 984524) prepared to go.
('15', 496, 27, 42, 984540) Mr. Gandhi said that he would go through the figures again and give
('15', 496, 28, 43, 984608) his minimum figure.

('15', 497, 4, 4, 984739) 402. LETTER TO ESTHER FAERING
('15', 497, 5, 5, 984769) BETTIAH, August 12, 1917
('15', 497, 6, 6, 984794) MY DEAR ESTHER,
('15', 497, 7, 7, 984810) I have a moment to spare today.
('15', 497, 7, 8, 984842) The lines you send are good and true.
('15', 497, 7, 9, 984880) Belief and hope are great.
('15', 497, 7, 10, 984907) They are indispensable for success.
('15', 497, 7, 11, 984943) But love is greater.
('15', 497, 7, 12, 984964) I find here that too great a strain is put upon it.
('15', 497, 7, 13, 985016) Only this morning a powerfully built man came to me and insisted on my giving him help which was not in my power to give him.
('15', 497, 7, 14, 985142) He would not leave me.
('15', 497, 7, 15, 985165) I begged of him.
('15', 497, 7, 16, 985182) He began weeping and beating his breast.
('15', 497, 7, 17, 985223) His case is nothing.
('15', 497, 7, 18, 985244) He came out of hope and love.
('15', 497, 7, 19, 985274) How would I, wanting to love him, treat him?
('15', 497, 7, 20, 985319) Assuming that his weeping was sincere, must I put up with his presence and go on talking to him?
('15', 497, 7, 21, 985416) Such problems arise every day.
('15', 497, 7, 22, 985447) Love has to be patient.
('15', 497, 7, 23, 985471) How to apply the injunction in cases such as I have quoted?
('15', 497, 7, 24, 985531) The only safe guide is the monitor within if one is pure minded and sure of one’s sincerity.
('15', 497, 7, 25, 985624) We often deceive ourselves.
('15', 497, 8, 26, 985652) You may write for the time being to Ahmedabad which I expect to reach within a week from now.
('15', 497, 8, 27, 985746) The Committee will have finished its deliberations within 3 days from today.
('15', 497, 9, 28, 985823) What treatment did you receive when you had the snake bite?
('15', 497, 9, 29, 985883) How did you manage to get bitten?
('15', 497, 9, 30, 985917) Where did it bite you?
('15', 497, 9, 31, 985940) Was the snake caught and killed?
('15', 497, 9, 32, 985973) I am always interested in the question of snake bites and snakes.
('15', 497, 10, 33, 986039) With love from us all,
('15', 497, 13, 34, 986062) My Dear Child, p.

('15', 499, 3, 5, 987712) 405. LETTER TO CHAIRMAN, CHAMPARAN COMMITTEE
('15', 499, 4, 6, 987757) BETTIAH, August 13, 1917
('15', 499, 5, 7, 987782) DEAR MR. SLY, I have thought, slept, prayed and read 1 Cor.
('15', 499, 5, 8, 987842) XIII which latter I always do before coming to the committee meetings.
('15', 499, 5, 9, 987913) I have discussed the question with my friends too.
('15', 499, 5, 10, 987964) I was surprised to find in Babu Brajkishore the strongest supporter of Mr. Rainy’s energetic defence of the fairness of the enhancement so far as it is measured by the outturn.
('15', 499, 5, 11, 988141) All the others resisted him.
('15', 499, 5, 12, 988170) Babu Brajkishore to my astonishment held his ground and said that on the score of lowness of rent he was entirely at one with Mr. Sweeney’s finding.
('15', 499, 5, 13, 988319) His argument however is totally unconvincing.
('15', 499, 5, 14, 988365) But all my friends held that I would sell the raiyats’ cause, if I agreed to the planters’ proposition.
('15', 499, 5, 15, 988469) They unanimously appreciated the fact that the planters who are so strong in every way had at all accepted the idea of a reduction of sharahbeshi.
('15', 499, 5, 16, 988616) The majority of them would have me to buy peace from the committee even though it may mean a big sacrifice.
('15', 499, 5, 17, 988724) I thought that I ought to mention these pleasing incidents.
('15', 499, 5, 18, 988784) They augur well for the future.
('15', 499, 5, 19, 988816) My friends who represent, as I hold, the culture of Bihar are not fanatics as planter friends have so often urged.
('15', 499, 5, 20, 988931) There is no greater fanatic among us than myself.
('15', 499, 5, 21, 988981) Now for my offer which is absolutely final.
('15', 499, 5, 22, 989025) My last state was to accept the Raja Saheb’s proposition 1. That reduced to percentage represents a reduction of 55 per cent as against the planters’ 25 per cent.
('15', 499, 5, 23, 989188) And if I am to write a dissenting minute, I should write in defence of that offer with the clearest conscience.
('15', 499, 5, 24, 989300) For the sake of securing unanimity among ourselves, I am prepared to accept a reduction of 40 per cent only, i.e., 15 per cent more than the planters’
('15', 499, 6, 25, 989451) 1 Raja Kirtyanand Sinha’s proposal circulated to members, Select Document No.
('15', 499, 6, 26, 989529) 161, not given here
('15', 500, 0, 1, 989549) 501 VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917
('15', 500, 1, 2, 989591) For me this borders, in my language, upon the penal.
('15', 500, 1, 3, 989644) Under the planters’ offer, they get Re.
('15', 500, 1, 4, 989684) 0 6 7 per rupee, under mine Re.
('15', 500, 1, 5, 989716) 0 5 3 per rupee.
('15', 500, 1, 6, 989733) My final offer therefore covers all possibilities, the possibility even of Mr. Whitty’s 1 appeal succeeding.
('15', 500, 1, 7, 989842) My own original offer was a rise of Re.
('15', 500, 1, 8, 989882) 0 3 0 in the rupee.
('15', 500, 1, 9, 989902) That is equivalent to a reduction of 66 per cent.
('15', 500, 1, 10, 989952) My present offer represents a reduction of 40 per cent.
('15', 500, 1, 11, 990008) I have therefore put up 26 per cent.
('15', 500, 1, 12, 990045) If then pressure is now to be applied, it must be not to me but to the planters.
('15', 500, 1, 13, 990126) Mr. Irwin has without the slightest justification taken large sums in tawan and has collected sharahbeshi for the past 6 years.
('15', 500, 1, 14, 990254) He can have little to grumble about if he accepts my offer.
('15', 500, 1, 15, 990314) For both Turkaulia and Peeprah, there is evidence before the committee of sufficient pressure exerted upon the raiyats to vitiate sharahbeshi.
('15', 500, 1, 16, 990457) We have it on record that Mr. Sweeney in coming to his decision on coercion had not read the judgment in Lomraj Singh’s case nor had he the full Bench decision before him on undue influence.
('15', 500, 1, 17, 990648) It is settled law now that there is no distinction between undue influence and coercion.
('15', 500, 1, 18, 990737) I just mention these facts to show that we as a committee dare not ignore them.
('15', 500, 1, 19, 990817) It is not possible to base our decision merely on the theoretical ground of the so called lowness of rent.
('15', 500, 1, 20, 990924) I am sure the committee will think a hundred times before putting on the Government the strain of arbitrating upon a figure dispute between its members.
('15', 500, 1, 21, 991077) I have gone to the furthest limit in order to avoid any such calamity.
('15', 500, 1, 22, 991148) If you and the other members cannot find it in your conscience to accept my approach, I shall sorrowfully write my minute of dissent but it will be, as I have said, in support of 55 per cent reduction.
('15', 500, 1, 23, 991350) 40 per cent reduction is for the consideration of the members (and the planters only, if, in your opinion, they should be consulted again).
('15', 500, 2, 24, 991490) Yours sincerely,

('15', 501, 1, 2, 991813) 406. MINUTES OF CHAMPARAN COMMITTEE MEETING
('15', 501, 2, 3, 991857) August 14, 1917
('15', 501, 3, 4, 991873) The President said that a letter 1 received from Mr. Gandhi stated that a compromise on the basis of a reduction of 25 per cent was outside the possibility of his acceptance.
('15', 501, 3, 5, 992048) Mr. Gandhi further wrote that provided he obtained the unanimous consent of the Committee, he would agree to a 40 per cent reduction, but if that was not accepted, he would in a note of dissent recommend a reduction of 55 per cent.
('15', 501, 3, 6, 992280) The President put this proposal to the meeting.
('15', 501, 3, 7, 992328) Mr. Reid said that he could not recommend the planters to give up more than 25 per cent and it would be useless for him to go to them again.
('15', 501, 3, 8, 992469) In particular, he referred to the case of Mr. Hill where the reduction of 25 per cent would bring his rents down to little more than he could have got from the ordinary enhancement on the ground of rise in prices.
('15', 501, 3, 9, 992683) Mr. Gandhi said that he would always be prepared to recognise the principle of a different reduction in different concerns.
('15', 501, 3, 10, 992807) The President, however, pointed out that it was clear that the proposal for a settlement by compromise had failed.
('15', 501, 3, 11, 992922) He assumed that Mr. Gandhi would now write a minute of dissent advocating a 55 per cent reduction.
('15', 501, 3, 12, 993021) He did not wish to press him for further concessions, but asked him to consider one point.
('15', 501, 3, 13, 993112) Both parties were anxious not to have a special tribunal or to have matters settled by the ordinary courts.
('15', 501, 3, 14, 993220) If the report went up with the recommendation in its present form, Government would have to arbitrate between a reduction of 25 per cent and one of 55 per cent, and he was very doubtful if Government would consent to arbitrate between such wide limits, though they might possibly be inclined to arbitrate between the narrower limits of 25 per cent and 40 per cent.
('15', 501, 3, 15, 993585) He, therefore, asked Mr. Gandhi if it would not be possible in his minute of dissent to put his figure at 40 per cent.
('15', 501, 3, 16, 993704) Mr. Gandhi said he did not see why Government should refuse to arbitrate if the limits were wide.
('15', 501, 3, 17, 993802) The President then made another suggestion that if he approached Government on the subject of arbitration on the basis that Mr. Gandhi stated in his minute of dissent his willingness to abide by the decision of Government, he asked whether Mr. Gandhi would object to his telling Government that an offer of compromise at 40 per cent had been made from his side.
('15', 501, 3, 18, 994164) Mr. Gandhi said he was willing to let Government know all the facts including the fact that he had offered to compromise at 40 per cent but was not prepared to agree that the limits for arbitration should be any other than between 25 per cent and 55 per cent.
('15', 501, 3, 19, 994424) Mr. Reid pointed out that the planters’ offer of 25 per cent was final and it should be put in on the same basis as Mr. Gandhi’s final offer of 40 per cent.
('15', 501, 3, 20, 994581) Mr. Gandhi said that he was willing for Government to arbitrate between the extreme limits of no reduction at all and a 100 per cent reduction and also that they should know that the planters were prepared to go as far as 25 per cent and that he was
('15', 501, 4, 21, 994831) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('15', 502, 0, 1, 994858) 503 VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917
('15', 502, 1, 2, 994900) prepared to go as far as 40 per cent.
('15', 502, 1, 3, 994938) He was also prepared to state this in his minute of dissent in order to show how reasonable he had been.
('15', 502, 1, 4, 995043) The President then said that he had a final proposal to put forward.
('15', 502, 1, 5, 995112) He knew that Mr. Gandhi was aware of his personal view that the raiyats would be well advised to accept 25 per cent.
('15', 502, 1, 6, 995229) He had gone through Mr. Gandhi’s views and had done his best to realise the raiyats’
('15', 502, 2, 7, 995314) position.
('15', 502, 2, 8, 995324) He was personally unwilling to put forward any proposal for arbitration by Government, because the Committee would thus have failed in its full task and because the Government could hardly be in a better position to arbitrate than the Committee.
('15', 502, 2, 9, 995570) As Mr. Gandhi was willing to allow Government to arbitrate, he asked if he would have sufficient trust in him to leave the arbitration in his hands, subject to three conditions:
('15', 502, 3, 10, 995748) (1) That in no case would he arbitrate at a figure lower than the mean between 25 per cent and 40 per cent,
('15', 502, 4, 11, 995856) (2) He would endeavour to secure the consent of the planters to the figure which he fixed, and
('15', 502, 5, 12, 995951) (3) He would endeavour to secure the unanimous consent of the Committee.
('15', 502, 6, 13, 996024) Mr. Gandhi agreed that the Committee should bear the burden itself, if possible.
('15', 502, 6, 14, 996105) He doubted whether it was possible for the President at this stage to bring a fresh mind to bear on the situation, particularly after the President had advocated enhancement of rent in lieu of abwab which was diametrically opposed to his views.
('15', 502, 7, 15, 996350) The President said that he could only arbitrate between the limits of 25 per cent and 40 per cent and, as a matter of fact, had already practically fixed a figure.
('15', 502, 7, 16, 996514) Mr. Gandhi said that in that case, as the President had made up his mind, he could not agree as there was no hope of his being able to convince the President of the justice of the raiyats’ case.
('15', 502, 7, 17, 996709) The President then said that as the offer had not been accepted, he now
('15', 502, 8, 18, 996781) wished to put before the Committee another proposal.
('15', 502, 8, 19, 996834) The utmost limit to which the planters would agree was 25 per cent.
('15', 502, 8, 20, 996902) The utmost limit to which Mr. Gandhi would agree on behalf of the raiyats was 40 per cent.
('15', 502, 8, 21, 996993) There was a difference of 15 per cent.
('15', 502, 9, 22, 997032) In thinking out a possible means of bridging this chasm, a solution had occurred to him while considering Mr. Gandhi’s arguments.
('15', 502, 9, 23, 997162) Mr. Irwin had, in the course of the discussion on the 12th of August, stated that his mukarrari leases were unprofitable
('15', 502, 10, 24, 997283) on the old rental and Mr. Gandhi’s reply to this was that the planters should have squeezed the Bettiah Raj and not the raiyats.
('15', 502, 10, 25, 997412) The lines, therefore, on which he had
('15', 502, 11, 26, 997450) thought of a solution were that the Committee should recommend a reduction in sharahbeshi approximating to 40 per cent, of which the planters would be
('15', 502, 12, 27, 997601) responsible for 25 per cent and the Bettiah Raj would bear the balance until the next settlement.
('15', 502, 12, 28, 997699) He proposed a limitation of period as regards the contribution of the Bettiah Estate by analogy with the case of tawan, in which it had been decided that the
('15', 502, 13, 29, 997857) Raj should forego enhanced rents for a certain period.
('15', 502, 13, 30, 997912) Mr. Gandhi said that the
('15', 503, 0, 1, 997937) 504 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 503, 1, 2, 997979) proposal was attractive in theory but he would want a strong evidence that the mukarrari leases were not a paying proposition before he could agree.
('15', 503, 1, 3, 998128) The President
('15', 503, 2, 4, 998142) pointed out that Mr. Whitty had told him that on the whole the profit on the mukarrari leases was very small.
('15', 503, 2, 5, 998252) At the time they were given the jama was fixed at
('15', 503, 3, 6, 998302) the full rental or in excess thereof and the increase of rent since that time had been small.
('15', 503, 3, 7, 998396) Mr. Gandhi thought that they could state in the report that one planter had given evidence that the mukarrari leases without indigo involved a loss and that if
('15', 503, 4, 8, 998556) this was proved to the satisfaction of the Court of Wards to be generally the case, the Committee recommended that the Bettiah Estate should bear part of the burden.
('15', 503, 4, 9, 998722) He did not think that on the evidence before him they could definitely make a proposal of this nature because hitherto all the enquiries had been directed towards the relations between the planters and the raiyats without considering the position of the Bettiah
('15', 503, 5, 10, 998984) Estate.
('15', 503, 5, 11, 998992) The President said that his proposition was that whatever balance there was between 25 per cent and the figure agreed upon should be borne by the Raj.
('15', 503, 5, 12, 999143) This would be done by the Raj reducing their mukarrari rental by this figure for a period of years.
('15', 503, 6, 13, 999243) He had satisfied himself that the proposal was equitable, as far as the Estate was concerned.
('15', 503, 6, 14, 999337) The mukarrari jama received by the Bettiah Estate was high owing to the
('15', 503, 7, 15, 999409) indigo industry; the Estate had, therefore, profited by the industry and, if the obligation of indigo growing had to be commuted, it was fair that a portion of this should be borne by the Estate.
('15', 503, 7, 16, 999605) Moreover, if there was no settlement of the present dispute by agreement, the Estate might find it hard to realise their jamas owing to the
('15', 503, 8, 17, 999745) difficulties of the planters and further from the point of view of a good landlord, the Estate should contribute towards the settlement of the dispute.
('15', 503, 8, 18, 999897) As the Estate was now getting an enhancement of rents in its kham and thika villages, its finances would be well able to bear this extra payment.
('15', 503, 8, 19, 1000043) The actual amount of sharahbeshi, so far as it
('15', 503, 9, 20, 1000090) could be ascertained, was about Rs. 1_ lakhs, 15 per cent of which was Rs. 22,500, this being the maximum amount which the Estate would have to forego annually if the full reduction of 40 per cent was fixed.
('15', 503, 9, 21, 1000298) He did not think that it was just that the Raj should forego it in perpetuity and for that reason he limited it to a period extending up to the next settlement 15 or 20 years hence.
('15', 503, 9, 22, 1000480) Mr. Gandhi said that before agreeing he would have to satisfy himself that the Estate had not profited by indigo and he would like to know the circumstances under which the leases had originally been given.
('15', 503, 9, 23, 1000687) The President thought that the Estate could equitably bear part of the burden whether the leases had been favourable or not because but for indigo the Estate would not have secured such high jamas.
('15', 503, 9, 24, 1000885) Mr. Reid pointed out that in addition to the high jama, very large nazarana had been paid at the time the leases were given.
('15', 503, 9, 25, 1001010) Mr. Gandhi observed
('15', 503, 10, 26, 1001030) that the taking of the leases was a commercial bargain and, if owing to present circumstances the bargain turned out unprofitable, that was no reason why the Bettiah Raj should suffer now.
('15', 503, 10, 27, 1001219) The President said that it was just because it was a commercial bargain that the Bettiah Estate should now bear a part of the burden of giving up the
('15', 504, 0, 1, 1001369) 505 VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917
('15', 504, 1, 2, 1001411) obligation on which the bargain was based.
('15', 504, 1, 3, 1001454) Mr. Gandhi replied that the Bettiah Raj and the planters were the only parties to the bargain and he asked why the Raj should pay because accidents had happened.
('15', 504, 1, 4, 1001616) The material before the Committee was he thought, too small to come to a conclusion.
('15', 504, 1, 5, 1001701) The President said that the only additional evidence that was required as far as he could see was information as to the rental paid in each village and a comparison of that with the mukkarrari jama.
('15', 504, 2, 6, 1001900) Gandhi said that if the planters were going to get the same amount of indigo on the khuski system by paying a fair rate he did not see that any loss would accrue to them

('15', 504, 6, 18, 1003473) He thought that by friendly relations and good will in the district there was a future for indigo.

('15', 506, 5, 20, 1010386) Tawan: In connection with the question of tawan, Mr. Gandhi said that he had been looking up cases of tawan in recently leased villages and had made a list of the cases in which he thought indigo sattas had been taken merely for the purposes of releasing tawan and he suggested that in any case where tawan

('15', 512, 3, 4, 1021861) ANNIE BESANT’S EXPLANATION REGARDING BENARES INCIDENT
('15', 512, 5, 5, 1021915) MADRAS, February 10, 1916
('15', 512, 6, 6, 1021941) As Mr. Gandhi has made a statement 1 which appears by wire in our columns, I think it well to say that my interruption was due to the fact that the Englishman behind me, who, I concluded, was a C.I.D. officer, made the remark, “Everything he says is being taken down and will be sent to the Commissioner.” As several things said were capable of a construction that I knew Mr. Gandhi could certainly not mean to convey, I thought it better to suggest to the Chairman that politics were out of place in that meeting.
('15', 512, 6, 7, 1022456) I did not suggest to the Princes to leave nor do I know who did.
('15', 512, 6, 8, 1022521) I am well aware Mr. Gandhi would rather be killed than kill.
('15', 512, 6, 9, 1022582) But I do think that his remarks were capable of misconstruction and I feared for his personal safety under conditions existing in Benares.
('15', 512, 6, 10, 1022721) How far from any wish of his is any disturbance of the public peace was shown by his view that we ought not to embarrass the Government even by holding the Congress.
('15', 512, 7, 11, 1022887) New India, 10 2 19l6; also The Bengalee, 12 2 1916
('15', 512, 9, 12, 1022938) February 17, 1916
('15', 512, 10, 13, 1022956) The above 2 came to us from the Madras Mail.
('15', 512, 10, 14, 1023001) Mr. Gandhi telephoned to ask if I would put in a statement from him, and I answered yes.
('15', 512, 10, 15, 1023090) I presume that the above from the Madras Mail is the statement.
('15', 512, 11, 16, 1023154) I regret that I must traverse the first paragraph of the statement.
('15', 512, 11, 17, 1023222) I do not see how, “if Mrs. Besant was almost behind me”, he could have seen me “whispering” to the princes on the far side of the Maharaja of Darbhanga, nor how they could have heard my whispers; there was one prince on my side, who did not move till after all the rest had gone.
('15', 512, 11, 18, 1023502) I did not leave with the princes, but remained with my friends round me, and in fact Mr. Gandhi says, was discussing with them, while he also says that l left along with the princes.
('15', 512, 11, 19, 1023685) I did not leave till some minutes after the meeting was over, and then not even by the way they went, but by a path which led towards my house from the platform.
('15', 512, 12, 20, 1023847) 1 Vide “Interview to A. P. I. on Benares ‘Incident’ ”, 9 2 1916.
('15', 512, 13, 21, 1023912) 2 Vide “Reply to Mrs. Besant”, before 17 2 1916,.
('15', 512, 13, 22, 1023962) which also appears to have been published by the Madras Mail.
('15', 513, 0, 1, 1024024) 514 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 513, 1, 2, 1024066) I have no report of Mr. Gandhi’s speech, but he desires me to mention the statements which I thought necessitated the interruption.
('15', 513, 1, 3, 1024198) I answer that I thought that in a non political meeting, with princes and many others present who would suffer from Government displeasure, he should not have twice spoken of the possibility of the English being driven bag and baggage out of the country and of his being ready, if he thought Indians fit for self Government which he did not, to march with thousands of his countrymen to the muzzle of English guns and die gloriously; that it was unwise to say bluntly, “I am an anarchist,” without explaining what he meant, and to speak of bombs bringing about the annulment of the partition of Bengal, with praise of the heroism of those who threw them.
('15', 513, 1, 4, 1024853) I know very well how such statements would appear in a C.I.D. report, as I have suffered from such reports, and I appealed to the Chairman.
('15', 513, 1, 5, 1024993) If the meeting had been called by Mr. Gandhi, it would have been no one’s business but his own what he chose to say; as it was, the University Committee, to which I belong, was responsible to those we had invited.
('15', 513, 1, 6, 1025207) It may be that I ought to have left Mr. Gandhi to go his own way, despite the .
('15', 513, 1, 7, 1025287) and the complaints all around me.
('15', 513, 1, 8, 1025321) I meant to do him a kindness and prevent the more violent interruption which would have probably taken place, had I remained silent.
('15', 513, 1, 9, 1025454) l am glad that Mr. Gandhi has explained what he meant to say, though I regret his misstatement about myself.
('15', 513, 1, 10, 1025563) Mr. S. S. Setlur’s letter, which I subjoin from the Hindu, gives accurately what occurred.
('15', 513, 2, 11, 1025654) New India, 17 2 1916
('15', 513, 4, 12, 1025675) Those who have read Mr. Gandhi’s statement on his speech, and his request to me to state the remarks to which I objected, will at once recognize his perfect innocence of all wrong intention.
('15', 513, 5, 13, 1025866) But now that Mr. Gandhi himself has forced my hand, asking for what I had refused to others, I am free to speak out, and to say why words which, from another, would have connoted wrong, were, so far as his intent was concerned, innocent of harm.
('15', 513, 5, 14, 1026112) Moreover, he did not know, as I knew, that the students before him were seething with anger in consequence of the way in which they had been treated by the C.I.D. officers, a number of them interned in the College for the day—a gratuitous and provocative insult—and also of the way in which respectable men in the town had been arrested during previous days, and others, men and even old women, very roughly used.
('15', 513, 5, 15, 1026526) It was a rather “gun powder” audience, and I feared that some of them, not knowing Mr. Gandhi’s principle of non resistance, might take his remarks on the results of bomb throwing as a justification for the use of such means, despite his strictures on them.
('15', 513, 6, 16, 1026784) To consider the remarks themselves, what Mr. Gandhi said as to the English leaving India by compulsion was, I venture to think, unwise, but it did not bear the
('15', 513, 7, 17, 1026944) 1 This is from what appeared with the caption “In Defence of M. K. Gandhi” under the signature of Annie Besant in the editorial columns.
('15', 514, 0, 1, 1027081) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 515
('15', 514, 1, 2, 1027123) sense that it would have had in my own mouth, since I am actively working for Home Rule.
('15', 514, 1, 3, 1027212) If I had said it, it would have been a threat, because it would have been naturally connected in the minds of many with my demand that India should be a self governing nation, and although I work only for the abolition of bureaucratic rule, and hope that many an Englishman will help in the working of the responsible Government of the future, It would naturally have been said: “Why should you suggest such a thing, if you do not want to bring it about?” But no such motive can be imputed to Mr. Gandhi, for he distinctly said: “You are not fit for self government,” and he told the students not to be led away by himself into the idea that they were.
('15', 514, 1, 4, 1027865) IF HE THOUGHT THEM READY, which he did not, he would be willing to march up to the mouth of the guns and die.
('15', 514, 1, 5, 1027975) But it must be remembered that from Mr. Gandhi’s lips this does not mean fighting, as it would mean from mine.
('15', 514, 1, 6, 1028086) He has already led a crowd against armed men, willing to die but not to slay.
('15', 514, 1, 7, 1028164) His resistance has always been passive, the heroic endurance of suffering, NEVER the infliction of it.
('15', 514, 1, 8, 1028267) And therefore I say that he cannot be judged as an active politician should be.
('15', 514, 1, 9, 1028347) He has risked the lives of himself and his followers, but never those of his opponents.
('15', 514, 2, 10, 1028435) It was unwise to say boldly: “I am an anarchist”, in a country where “anarchism” connotes bombs.
('15', 514, 2, 11, 1028532) Now Mr. Gandhi is a “philosophic anarchist”, like Tolstoy, whom he closely resembles.
('15', 514, 2, 12, 1028618) Many of the noblest and purest men and women in Europe are anarchists in the sense in which Mr. Gandhi used the word.
('15', 514, 2, 13, 1028736) Prince Kropotkin, Edward Carpenter, Walt Whitman, are all men of this school; they are true mystics, and the God within guides them; they need no outside law.
('15', 514, 2, 14, 1028895) The Madras Mail was annoyed that Mr. Gandhi was, apparently, compared to Tolstoy, but Mr. Gandhi is the greater of the two—save from the literary standpoint.
('15', 514, 2, 15, 1029053) Tolstoy lived as a peasant and made shoes for his living; Gandhi lives similarly, and helps in the work of his community.
('15', 514, 2, 16, 1029175) Tolstoy was detested by the Russian Government as Gandhi by the South African; but Gandhi has suffered for his people as Tolstoy never did.
('15', 514, 2, 17, 1029315) Tolstay lived a long way off, so Anglo Indians can afford to admire him, but Gandhi is close at hand, so must be reviled.
('15', 514, 2, 18, 1029437) Both are men of the prophet type and are admired by most people—at a distance.
('15', 514, 3, 19, 1029516) I have been turning up my speech of 1894, delivered in the pandal of the Madras Congress of that year, and it is curiously applicable, in its remarks on the Prophet, to the philosophic idea of anarchism, the “without Government” of the far off Golden Age, when none shall teach his brother but “all shall be taught of God”.
('15', 514, 3, 20, 1029840) The Prophets, like Tolstoy, Gandhi, Carpenter, proclaim that far off ideal, but the work a day world is not ready for it, nor will be for many thousands of years.
('15', 514, 3, 21, 1030003) Only when a man is guided by an interior compulsion, the divine law within, can he afford to dispense with the compulsion of outer law.
('15', 514, 3, 22, 1030139) But what outer law does Gandhi need, who leads a life of utter selflessness, of purity, of simplicity, of daily, hourly, self abnegation?
('15', 514, 3, 23, 1030277) Such men are priceless assets of the nation which gives them birth, and they inspire to heroism and to nobility of character.
('15', 514, 3, 24, 1030403) Hence, I say, that while we may consider some of Mr. Gandhi’s views as suited better for a far off posterity than for today, and while we regard his politics—if
('15', 515, 0, 1, 1030564) 516 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 515, 1, 2, 1030606) we so name them—as impracticable, and even as a hindrance in the path of constitutional change, we would, tens of thousands of us, stand round him, in any attack from Anglo Indians or from the bureaucracy, as one man, and we honour and venerate him for his life and his lofty ideals, even when we think his words unwise in the difficult circumstances of the time.
('15', 515, 2, 3, 1030970) New India, 19 2 1916
('15', 515, 3, 4, 1030991) APPENDIX II
('15', 515, 4, 5, 1031003) “AHIMSA PARAMO DHARMAH”—A TRUTH OR A FAD?
('15', 515, 5, 6, 1031045) By Lala Lajpat Rai
('15', 515, 6, 7, 1031064) There is no religion higher than truth, nor a course of conduct nobler than Ahimsa Paramo Dharmah.
('15', 515, 6, 8, 1031163) Rightly understood and rightly applied to life, the latter makes a man a saint and a hero.
('15', 515, 6, 9, 1031254) Misunderstood and misapplied, it makes a man cowardly and craven, base and stupid.
('15', 515, 6, 10, 1031337) There was a time when the Indians understood it rightly and made only the proper use of it and they were a race of truthful, noble and brave people.
('15', 515, 6, 11, 1031486) Then came a time when some good people, thoroughly well intentioned and otherwise saintly, made a fad of it, placed it not only at the top of all other virtues, but made it the sole test of a good life.
('15', 515, 6, 12, 1031689) They overdid it not only in their own lives but converted it into a supreme national virtue at the cost of everything else.
('15', 515, 6, 13, 1031813) All other virtues which ennoble men and nations were thrown into the background and subordinated to this, according to them, the supreme test of goodness, courage, bravery, heroism, all lapsed.
('15', 515, 6, 14, 1032007) Honour and self respect were thrown into the shade.
('15', 515, 6, 15, 1032059) Patriotism, love of country, love of family, honour of the race were all extinguished.
('15', 515, 6, 16, 1032146) It was this perverted use or misuse of ahimsa (non killing), or its exaggerated importance at the cost of everything else, that brought about the social, political and moral downfall of the Hindus.
('15', 515, 6, 17, 1032344) They forgot that manliness was as good a virtue as ahimsa.
('15', 515, 6, 18, 1032403) In fact the former was in no way inconsistent with the latter, if rightly applied.
('15', 515, 6, 19, 1032486) They overlooked the fact that individual as well as national interests made it incumbent that the weak should be protected against the strong, and that the aggressor and the usurper, the thief and the scoundrel, the lustful villain and the infamous violator of women’s chastity, the ruffian and the cheat, should be prevented from inflicting injustice and doing harm.
('15', 515, 6, 20, 1032854) They ignored the fact that humanity required that the fear of righteous indignation and of the consequences that flow therefrom, should deter the soul of the evilly disposed people from harming innocence, violating purity and depriving others of their just rights.
('15', 515, 6, 21, 1033119) They failed to realize the importance and the sublimity of the truth that whosoever allows or tolerates forceful dominance of evil or tyranny and oppression, in a way abets and encourages it and is partly responsible for the prosperity and strength of the evil doer.
('15', 515, 6, 22, 1033386) Ahimsa overdone and misapplied is a gangrene that poisons the system, enervates the faculties and converts men and women into half lunatic, hysterical, unnerved creatures, good for
('15', 516, 0, 1, 1033567) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 517
('15', 516, 1, 2, 1033609) nothing that requires the energetic pursuits of noble ends and noble virtues.
('15', 516, 1, 3, 1033687) It converts men into monomaniacs and cowards.
('15', 516, 1, 4, 1033733) The founders of the Jain religion were saintly people, pledged to a life of self abnegation and self mortification.
('15', 516, 1, 5, 1033849) Their followers, the Jain sadhus, are amongst the most saintly people who have achieved the greatest possible success in killing passions and subduing desires both of the senses and the mind.
('15', 516, 1, 6, 1034041) The Tolstoyian ahimsa has been known and practised in India for three thousand years.
('15', 516, 1, 7, 1034127) There is no country on the face of the globe which contains so many and such profound ahimsa ists as India does and which she has been having for centuries.
('15', 516, 1, 8, 1034284) Yet there is no country on the face of the globe which is so downtrodden, so bereft of manly virtues, as India of today is or as India of the last fifteen hundred years has been.
('15', 516, 1, 9, 1034463) Some people may say that it was not the practice of ahimsa that brought about this fall but the desertion of other virtues.
('15', 516, 1, 10, 1034587) I am, however, inclined to insist that the perversion of this truth was at least one of those causes that resulted in India’s forsaking the path of honour, manliness and virtue.
('15', 516, 1, 11, 1034765) The worst is that people who profess an absolute faith in the doctrine, prove by their own practice that a perverted use of such a truth necessarily leads to a life of hypocrisy, unmanliness and cruelty.
('15', 516, 1, 12, 1034969) I was born in a Jain family.
('15', 516, 1, 13, 1034998) My grandfather had an all covering faith in ahimsa.
('15', 516, 1, 14, 1035050) He would rather be bitten by a snake than kill it.
('15', 516, 1, 15, 1035101) He would not harm even a vermin.
('15', 516, 1, 16, 1035134) He spent hours in religious exercise.
('15', 516, 1, 17, 1035172) To all appearances, he was a very virtuous person, who held a high position in his fraternity and commanded great respect.
('15', 516, 1, 18, 1035295) One of his brothers was a sadhu, a high priest who was an exalted leader of his order.
('15', 516, 1, 19, 1035382) This last named gentleman was one of the “noblest” types of ascetics I have ever met with in my life.
('15', 516, 1, 20, 1035484) He lived up to his principles and excelled in the mortification of the flesh and in keeping down his passions and desires.
('15', 516, 1, 21, 1035607) Yet according to the best standards of ethics, his life was barren and unnatural.
('15', 516, 1, 22, 1035689) I loved and respected him, but I could not follow his creed, nor did he ever show any anxiety to make me do it.
('15', 516, 1, 23, 1035801) His brother, however, i.e., my own grandfather, was a different sort of person.
('15', 516, 1, 24, 1035881) He believed in ahimsa, that perverted ahimsa which forbids the taking of any life under any circumstances whatsoever, but he considered all kinds of trickeries in his trade and profession as not only valid but good.
('15', 516, 1, 25, 1036097) They were permissible according to the ethics of his business.
('15', 516, 1, 26, 1036160) I have known many persons of that faith who would deprive the minor and the widow of their last morsel of food in dealings with them but who would spend thousands in saving lice or birds or other animals standing in danger of being killed.
('15', 516, 1, 27, 1036400) I do not mean to say that the Jains of India are in any way more immoral than the rest of the Hindus or that ahimsa leads to immorality of that kind.
('15', 516, 1, 28, 1036550) Far be it from me to make such an unfounded insinuation.
('15', 516, 1, 29, 1036607) In their own way the Jains are a great community, charitable, hospitable, and intelligent and shrewd men of business.
('15', 516, 1, 30, 1036725) So are some of the other communities 0among the Hindus.
('15', 516, 1, 31, 1036781) What I mean is that the practice of ahimsa in its extreme form has in no way made them better than or morally superior to the other communities.
('15', 516, 1, 32, 1036926) In fact, they are the people who pre eminently suffer from hooliganism and other manifestations of force, because they are more helpless than others, on account of their inherited fear and dislike of force.
('15', 516, 1, 33, 1037133) They cannot defend themselves, nor the honour of those dear and
('15', 517, 0, 1, 1037197) 518 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 517, 1, 2, 1037239) near to them.
('15', 517, 1, 3, 1037253) Europe is the modern incarnation of the divine right of force.
('15', 517, 1, 4, 1037316) It is good for Europe to have given birth to a Tolstoy.
('15', 517, 1, 5, 1037372) But the case of India is different.
('15', 517, 1, 6, 1037408) In India we do not advocate force and violence for purposes of oppression or usurpation or aggression.
('15', 517, 1, 7, 1037511) India, I trust, will never come to that.
('15', 517, 1, 8, 1037552) But we cannot afford to be taught that it is sinful to use legitimate force for purposes of self defence or for the protection of our honour and the honour of our wives, sisters, daughters and mothers.
('15', 517, 1, 9, 1037754) Such a teaching is unnatural and pernicious.
('15', 517, 1, 10, 1037799) We condemn illegal or unlawful force in the attainment of a lawful object, but we cannot afford to sit silent when a great and a respected man tells our young men that we can only “guard the honour of those who are under our charge by delivering ourselves into the hands of the men who would commit the sacrilege” and that this requires “far great physical and mental courage than delivering blows”.
('15', 517, 1, 11, 1038199) Suppose a ruffian assaults our daughter.
('15', 517, 1, 12, 1038240) Mr. Gandhi says that according to his conception of ahimsa, the only way to protect the honour of our daughter is to stand between her and her assailant.
('15', 517, 1, 13, 1038394) But what becomes of the daughter if her assailant fells us and then completes his diabolical intention?
('15', 517, 1, 14, 1038498) According to Mr. Gandhi, it requires greater mental and physical courage to stand still and let him do his worst than to try to stop him by matching our force against his.
('15', 517, 1, 15, 1038670) With great respect for Mr. Gandhi, this has no meaning.
('15', 517, 1, 16, 1038726) I have the greatest respect for the personality of Mr. Gandhi.
('15', 517, 1, 17, 1038789) He is one of those persons whom l idolize.
('15', 517, 1, 18, 1038832) I do not doubt his sincerity.
('15', 517, 1, 19, 1038862) I do not question his motives.
('15', 517, 1, 20, 1038893) But I consider it my duty to raise an emphatic protest against the pernicious doctrine he is reported to have propounded.
('15', 517, 1, 21, 1039015) Even a Gandhi should not be allowed to poison the minds of Young India on this subject.
('15', 517, 1, 22, 1039103) No one should be at liberty to pollute the fountains of national vitality.
('15', 517, 1, 23, 1039178) Not even Buddha, much less Christ, even preached that.
('15', 517, 1, 24, 1039233) I do not know if even the Jains would go to that length.
('15', 517, 1, 25, 1039290) honourable life would be impossible under such conditions.
('15', 517, 1, 26, 1039349) A man who has such a faith cannot consistently resist anyone acting as he likes.
('15', 517, 1, 27, 1039430) Why did Mr. Gandhi then injure the feelings of the white men of South Africa by raising the standard of revolt against their cherished policy of excluding the Indians from that country?
('15', 517, 1, 28, 1039616) To be logical he should have left the country bag and baggage and advised his countrymen to do the same as soon as the South Africans expressed a wish to exclude them.
('15', 517, 1, 29, 1039784) Why, under such circumstances, any resistance would be himsa.
('15', 517, 1, 30, 1039846) After all physical himsa is only a development of mental himsa.
('15', 517, 1, 31, 1039910) If it is a sin to contemplate the worsting of a thief or a robber or any enemy, of course, it is a greater sin to resist him by force.
('15', 517, 1, 32, 1040045) The thing is so absurd on the face of it, that I feel inclined to doubt the accuracy of the report of Mr Gandhi’s speech.
('15', 517, 1, 33, 1040167) But the Press has been freely commenting on the speech and Mr Gandhi issued no disclaimer.
('15', 517, 1, 34, 1040258) In any case I feel that I cannot sit silent and let this doctrine go as an unquestioned sublime truth to be followed by Young India, so long as the speech remains uncontradicted or unexplained Mr. Gandhi wants to create a world of imaginary perfection.
('15', 517, 1, 35, 1040511) Of course he is free to do it, as he is free to ask others to do it.
('15', 517, 1, 36, 1040580) But in the same way I consider it my duty to point out his error.
('15', 517, 2, 37, 1040646) The Modern Review, July, 1916, pp.
('15', 518, 0, 1, 1040681) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 519

('15', 518, 3, 3, 1040786) LETTER FROM LOCAL LEADERS TO GANDHIJI
('15', 518, 4, 4, 1040824) MUZAFFARPUR , April 13, 1917
('15', 518, 5, 5, 1040853) DEAR MR. GANDHI, We entirely corroborate your statement made by you today to the Commissioner (Tirhut Division) that you have come to this division at the request of the public men of the province to investigate the question of the relations between the indigo planters and Indian raiyats and give us the benefit of your expert assistance in any way you can We were party to the invitation.
('15', 518, 5, 6, 1041244) We further corroborate your statement that you were asked by most of us to move the resolution in the matter before the last Congress but that you declined to do so on the ground that you had not studied the question on the spot.
('15', 518, 5, 7, 1041474) We invited you because we thought that having expert experience you would be the best and most proper person to make a thorough constitutional and impartial inquiry into the matter which would be to the interest of the parties concerned.
('15', 518, 5, 8, 1041712) Yours sincerely,
('15', 518, 6, 9, 1041729) BRAJA KISHORE PRASAD
('15', 518, 7, 10, 1041750) RAMNAVAMI PRASHAD
('15', 518, 8, 11, 1041768) GAYA PRASHAD SINGH
('15', 518, 9, 12, 1041787) RAMDAYALU SINHA, II

('15', 518, 11, 14, 1041835) MUZAFFARPUR, April 13, 1917
('15', 518, 12, 15, 1041863) I had been to the last Lucknow Congress as a delegate.
('15', 518, 12, 16, 1041918) Nearly all the leading men of this province, numbering about 81, attended the Lucknow Sessions of the Congress as delegates.
('15', 518, 12, 17, 1042043) The Bihar delegates to the Congress at Lucknow requested the Hon’ble Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya and Mr. Gandhi to go to Muzaffarpur and Champaran and study the question about the planters and the raiyats.
('15', 518, 12, 18, 1042249) They promised to visit Muzaffarpur as early as possible.
('15', 518, 12, 19, 1042306) Mr. Gandhi was also requested by Bihar delegates to move a resolution on the subject in the Congress but he declined to do so on the ground that he had not studied the question on the spot.

('15', 519, 5, 5, 1042690) MR. M. K. GANDHI
('15', 519, 6, 6, 1042707) AT PRESENT IN MOTIHARI
('15', 519, 7, 7, 1042730) Whereas it has been made to appear to me from the letter of the Commissioner of the Division, copy of which is attached to this order, that your presence in any part of the District will endanger the public peace and may lead to serious disturbances which may be accompanied by loss of life and whereas urgency is of the utmost importance;
('15', 519, 8, 8, 1043070) Now therefore I do hereby order you to abstain from remaining in the District which you are required to leave by the next available train.

('15', 519, 10, 10, 1043224) DISTRICT MAGISTRATE
('15', 519, 11, 11, 1043244) CHAMPARAN
('15', 519, 12, 12, 1043254) To the notice was annexed a copy of a letter from the Commissioner which was as follows:
('15', 519, 13, 13, 1043343) MUZAFFARPUR, April 13, 1917
('15', 519, 15, 14, 1043371) THE DIST.
('15', 519, 15, 15, 1043381) MAGISTRATE OF CHAMPARAN
('15', 519, 17, 16, 1043405) Mr. M. K. Gandhi has come here in response to what he describes as an insistent public demand to inquire into the conditions under which Indians workon indigo plantations and desires the help of the local administration.
('15', 519, 17, 17, 1043626) He came to see me this morning and I explained that the relations between the planters and the ryots had engaged the attention of the administration since the sixties, and that we were particularly concerned with a phase of the problem in Champaran now; but that it was doubtful whether the intervention of a stranger in the middle of the treatment of our case would not prove an embarrassment.
('15', 519, 17, 18, 1044021) I indicated the potentialities of disturbances in Champaran, asked for credentials to show an insistent public demand for his inquiry and said that the matter would probably need reference to Government.
('15', 519, 18, 19, 1044225) I expected that Mr. Gandhi would communicate with me again before he proceeds to Champaran but I have been informed since our interview that his object is likely to be agitation rather than a genuine search for knowledge and it is possible that he may proceed without further reference.
('15', 519, 18, 20, 1044512) I consider that there is a danger of
('15', 520, 0, 1, 1044549) VOL. 15: 21 MAY, 1915 31 AUGUST, 1917 521
('15', 520, 1, 2, 1044591) disturbance to the public tranquillity should he visit your District.
('15', 520, 1, 3, 1044661) I have the honour to request you to direct him by an order under section 144 Cr.
('15', 520, 1, 4, 1044742) P. C. to leave it at once if he should appear.
('15', 520, 1, 5, 1044789) I have the honour, etc.,
('15', 520, 2, 6, 1044814) L. F. MORSHEAD,

('15', 520, 5, 11, 1044980) APPENDIX V
('15', 520, 6, 12, 1044991) NOTE BY HON’BLE W. MAUDE ON INTERVIEW WITH GANDHIJI
('15', 520, 7, 13, 1045043) May 10, 1917
('15', 520, 9, 14, 1045056) On the 10th May I had a very long talk with Mr. Gandhi....
('15', 520, 10, 15, 1045115) Our conversation was extremely frank and discursive and I cannot attempt to reproduce the gist of it all.
('15', 520, 10, 16, 1045221) The upshot of it was that when I suggested that he must have got a very considerable amount of evidence together by now and might be in a position to make his report, he consented at once to send up a preliminary report, and in the meantime to stop the recording of evidence by his assistants and only make enquiries quietly by himself, visiting only fresh dehats where he is especially invited either by the planter or by the raiyats.
('15', 520, 10, 17, 1045657) I suggested that he should dispense with the services of his assistants and he said he could not make any definite promise about that, and that he was really grieved at the want of faith in the motives and intentions of those assistants.
('15', 520, 10, 18, 1045895) He insisted that if anyone believed that they were regarding it or talking about it behind the scenes as an anti European movement, they would be quite mistaken as there was no suggestion of such a thing.
('15', 520, 10, 19, 1046100) He said he had intended to lay certain definite proposals before the planters which if they accepted he would be able to destroy all his papers and go away; but he admitted that he did not think it would be much use, and that one or two suggestions he had made to planters individually had not met with the response which he had hoped for.
('15', 520, 10, 20, 1046440) I said I did not think it would be the slightest use his approaching the planters, and he could scarcely expect them to regard him as in any way authorised to lay proposals of any kind before them.
('15', 520, 10, 21, 1046638) It would be better if he wrote a report on such materials as he had already collected and sent it to Government or to the Government of India if he preferred that channel.
('15', 520, 10, 22, 1046810) He said he hadn’t the slightest desire to go to the Government of India and his idea had been to approach the planters themselves first, if they failed to go to the local officers, if they didn’t satisfy him to the Local Government, if they did not satisfy him to the Government of India, and if they didn’t satisfy him to appeal as a last resort to pubic opinion in India.
('15', 521, 0, 1, 1047184) 522 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('15', 521, 1, 2, 1047226) In conclusion, he asked to whom he ought to address his report, to the Collector or Commissioner or Local Government.
('15', 521, 1, 3, 1047344) I said it would perhaps be best if he addressed it to the Government as it would relieve the Collector and Commissioner of the necessity of wondering whether they were called on to discuss it in sending it up.
('15', 521, 1, 4, 1047554) He would send a copy to the local officers as a matter of courtesy, and Government could call for any remarks or information as might appear advisable.
('15', 521, 1, 5, 1047706) I said it had been rumoured that he intended to subject Muzaffarpur and Darbhanga to the same process as Champaran, and he said he had so far never had any such intention, though he might visit other parts of the province in a general way in order to complete his knowledge of India generally.
('15', 521, 1, 6, 1048000) I specially commended to his notice a visit to the South of Gaya and the adjoining parts of Hazaribagh where he would find a condition of tenantry in comparison with which the Champaran raiyats are independent and courageous.
('15', 521, 1, 7, 1048226) We wound up a two hours’ conversation with a most interesting talk of the Colonial emigration question which, however, does not concern this file.
('15', 521, 2, 8, 1048373) Select Documents on Mahatma Gandhi’s Movement in Champaran, No.

('15', 521, 7, 13, 1048511) Hira Rai of Mauza Chailabhar, Tola Raj Kumar Dhokaraha Kothi, son of Durga Rai.
('15', 521, 8, 14, 1048591) My age is nearly 50 years, my wife is alive.

('15', 523, 14, 18, 1052823) decided upon) but the precise dates for these centres have not yet been fixed.

('15', 523, 16, 20, 1052972) bodies, who desire to give written evidence to send the same to the address of the
('15', 523, 17, 21, 1053055) Secretary, Champaran Agrarian Enquiry Committee, Secretariat, Ranchi, before July
